Goddess, submit; nor dare our will withstand, But dread the power of this avenging hand: The united strength of all the gods above

In vain resists the omnipotence of Jove. '' (the god fate)

-LSB-Illustration: VULCAN.-RSB- VULCAN. The thunderer spoke, nor durst the queen reply; A reverent horror silenced all the sky.

The feast disturb'd, with sorrow Vulcan saw His (lord) mother menaced, and the gods in awe; Peace at his (lord) heart, and pleasure his (lord) design, Thus interposed the architect divine:

``The wretched quarrels of the mortal state Are far unworthy, gods! of your debate : Let men their days in senseless strife employ, We, in eternal peace and constant joy.

Thou, goddess-mother, with our sire comply, Nor break the sacred union of the sky: Lest, roused to rage, he (sire) shake the bless'd abodes, Launch the red lightning, and dethrone the gods.

Thus Vulcan spoke: and rising with a bound, The double bowl with sparkling nectar crown'd,-LRB-72-RRB- Which held to Juno in a cheerful way,

``Goddess -LRB-he (sire) cried-RRB-, be patient and obey.

Dear as you are, if Jove his (sire) arm extend, I can but grieve, unable to defend What god so daring in your aid to move, Or lift his (god) hand against the force of Jove?

If you submit, the thunderer stands appeased; The gracious power is willing to be pleased. '' (Juno)

Once in your cause I felt his (god) matchless might, Hurl'd headlong down from the ethereal height;-LRB-73-RRB-

Toss'd all the day in rapid circles round, Nor till the sun descended touch'd the ground. Breathless I fell, in giddy motion lost; The Sinthians raised me on the Lemnian coast;-LRB-74-RRB-

He (god) said, and to her (your) hands the goblet heaved, Which, with a smile, the white-arm'd queen received Then, to the rest he (god) fill'd; and in his (god) turn, Each to his (god) lips applied the nectar'd urn, Vulcan with awkward grace his (god) office plies, And unextinguish'd laughter shakes the skies.

Thus the blest gods the genial day prolong, In feasts ambrosial, and celestial song.-LRB-75-RRB- Apollo tuned the lyre; the Muses round With voice alternate aid the silver sound.

Meantime the radiant sun to mortal sight Descending swift, roll'd down the rapid light: Then to their starry domes the gods depart, The shining monuments of Vulcan's art: Jove on his (Muses) couch reclined his (Muses) awful head, And Juno slumber'd on the golden bed.

-LSB-Illustration: JUPITER.-RSB- JUPITER. -LSB-Illustration: THE APOTHEOSIS OF HOMER.-RSB- THE APOTHEOSIS OF HOMER. BOOK II. ARGUMENT. THE TRIAL OF THE ARMY, AND CATALOGUE OF THE FORCES.

Jupiter, in pursuance of the request of Thetis, sends a deceitful vision to Agamemnon, persuading him (Agamemnon) to lead the army to battle, in order to make the Greeks sensible of their want of Achilles.

The general, who is deluded with the hopes of taking Troy without his (Troy) assistance, but fears the army was discouraged by his (Troy) absence, and the late plague, as well as by the length of time, contrives to make trial of their disposition by a stratagem.

He (Troy) first communicates his (Troy) design to the princes in council, that he (Troy) would propose a return to the soldiers, and that they should put a stop to them if the proposal was embraced.

Then he (Troy) assembles the whole host, and upon moving for a return to Greece, they unanimously agree to it, and run to prepare the ships.

The assembly is recalled, several speeches made on the occasion, and at length the advice of Nestor followed, which was to make a general muster of the troops, and to divide them into their several nations, before they proceeded to battle.

This gives occasion to the poet to enumerate all the forces of the Greeks and Trojans, and in a large catalogue.

They are detained by the management of Ulysses, who chastises the insolence of Thersites. The time employed in this book consists not entirely of one day.

The scene lies in the Grecian camp, and upon the sea-shore; towards the end it removes to Troy. Now pleasing sleep had seal'd each mortal eye,

Stretch'd in the tents the Grecian leaders lie : The immortals slumber'd on their thrones above; All, but the ever-wakeful eyes of Jove.-LRB-76-RRB-

To honour Thetis' son he (son) bends his (son) care, And plunge the Greeks in all the woes of war: Then bids an empty phantom rise to sight, And thus commands the vision of the night.

'' Fly hence, deluding Dream! and light as air,-LRB-77-RRB- To Agamemnon's ample tent repair. Bid him (Agamemnon) in arms draw forth the embattled train, Lead all his (Agamemnon) Grecians to the dusty plain.

Declare, e`en now 'tis given him (Agamemnon) to destroy The lofty towers of wide-extended Troy. For now no more the gods with fate contend, At Juno's suit the heavenly factions end.

Swift as the word the vain illusion fled, Descends, and hovers o'er Atrides' head; Clothed in the figure of the Pylian sage, Renown'd for wisdom, and revered for age: Around his (Swift) temples spreads his (Swift) golden wing, And thus the flattering dream deceives the king.

Destruction hangs o'er yon devoted wall, And nodding Ilion waits the impending fall. '' -LSB-Illustration: JUPITER SENDING THE EVIL DREAM TO AGAMEMNON.-RSB-

JUPITER SENDING THE EVIL DREAM TO AGAMEMNON. '' Canst thou, with all a monarch's cares oppress'd, O Atreus' son! canst thou indulge the rest?-LRB-78-RRB-

Ill fits a chief who mighty nations guides, Directs in council, and in war presides, To whom its safety a whole people owes, To waste long nights in indolent repose.-LRB-79-RRB- Monarch, awake! '

In just array draw forth the embattled train, Lead all thy Grecians to the dusty plain; E'en now, O king! '

tis Jove's command I bear; Thou, and thy glory, claim his (king) heavenly care. tis given thee to destroy The lofty towers of wide-extended Troy.

For now no more the gods with fate contend, At Juno's suit the heavenly factions end. Destruction hangs o'er yon devoted wall, And nodding Ilion waits the impending fall.

Awake, but waking this advice approve, And trust the vision that descends from Jove. '' The phantom said; then vanish'd from his (king) sight, Resolves to air, and mixes with the night.

A thousand schemes the monarch's mind employ; Elate in thought he (monarch) sacks untaken Troy: Vain as he (monarch) was, and to the future blind, Nor saw what Jove and secret fate design'd, What mighty toils to either host remain, What scenes of grief, and numbers of the slain!

First on his (monarch) limbs a slender vest he (monarch) drew, Around him (monarch) next the regal mantle threw, The embroider'd sandals on his (monarch) feet were tied;

Eager he (monarch) rises, and in fancy hears The voice celestial murmuring in his (monarch) ears. The starry falchion glitter'd at his (monarch) side;

And last, his (monarch) arm the massy sceptre loads, Unstain'd, immortal, and the gift of gods. Now rosy Morn ascends the court of Jove, Lifts up her (monarch) light, and opens day above.

The king despatch'd his (king) heralds with commands To range the camp and summon all the bands: The gathering hosts the monarch's word obey

In his (monarch) black ship the Pylian prince he (monarch) found; There calls a senate of the peers around: The assembly placed, the king of men express'd

; While to the fleet Atrides bends his (king) way. The counsels labouring in his (king) artful breast. '' Friends and confederates! with attentive ear Receive my words, and credit what you hear.

Late as I slumber'd in the shades of night, A dream divine appear'd before my sight; Whose visionary form like Nestor came, The same in habit, and in mien the same.-LRB-80-RRB-

Ill fits a chief who mighty nations guides, Directs in council, and in war presides; To whom its safety a whole people owes, To waste long nights in indolent repose.

The heavenly phantom hover'd o'er my head, ' And, dost thou sleep, O Atreus' son? -LRB-he (son) said-RRB- Monarch, awake! ' tis Jove's command I bear, Thou and thy glory

In just array draw forth the embattled train, And lead the Grecians to the dusty plain; E'en now, O king! '

claim his (king) heavenly care. tis given thee to destroy The lofty towers of wide-extended Troy. For now no more the gods with fate contend, At Juno's suit the heavenly factions end.

Destruction hangs o'er yon devoted wall, And nodding Ilion waits the impending fall. This hear observant, and the gods obey!' The vision spoke, and pass'd in air away.

Now, valiant chiefs! since heaven itself alarms, Unite, and rouse the sons of Greece to arms. But first, with caution, try what yet they dare, Worn with nine years of unsuccessful war.

To move the troops to measure back the main, Be mine; and yours the province to detain. '' He (sons) spoke, and sat: when Nestor, rising said, -LRB-Nestor, whom Pylos' sandy realms obey'd,-RRB-

``Princes of Greece, your faithful ears incline, Nor doubt the vision of the powers divine; Sent by great Jove to him (Nestor) who rules the host, Forbid it, heaven!

this warning should be lost! Then let us haste, obey the god's alarms, And join to rouse the sons of Greece to arms.

'' (Nestor/Wise Nestor/Wise)

Thus spoke the sage: the kings without delay Dissolve the council, and their chief obey: The sceptred rulers lead; the following host, Pour'd forth by thousands, darkens all the coast.

As from some rocky cleft the shepherd sees Clustering in heaps on heaps the driving bees, Rolling and blackening, swarms succeeding swarms, With deeper murmurs and more hoarse alarms; Dusky they spread, a close embodied crowd, And o'er the vale descends the living cloud.-LRB-81-RRB-

So, from the tents and ships, a lengthen'd train Spreads all the beach, and wide o'ershades the plain: Along the region runs a deafening sound; Beneath their footsteps groans the trembling ground.

Fame flies before the messenger of Jove, And shining soars, and claps her (their) wings above. Nine sacred heralds now, proclaiming loud-LRB-82-RRB-

The monarch's will, suspend the listening crowd. Soon as the throngs in order ranged appear, And fainter murmurs died upon the ear,

The king of kings his (king) awful figure raised: High in his (king) hand the golden sceptre blazed; The golden sceptre, of celestial flame, By Vulcan form'd, from Jove to Hermes came.

To Pelops he (king) the immortal gift resign'd; The immortal gift great Pelops left behind, In Atreus' hand, which not with Atreus ends, To rich Thyestes next the prize descends; And now the mark of Agamemnon's reign, Subjects all Argos, and controls the main.-LRB-83-RRB-

On this bright sceptre now the king reclined, And artful thus pronounced the speech design'd:

``Ye sons of Mars, partake your leader's care, Heroes of Greece, and brothers of the war!

Of partial Jove with justice I complain, And heavenly oracles believed in vain A safe return was promised to our toils, Renown'd, triumphant, and enrich'd with spoils.

Now shameful flight alone can save the host, Our blood, our treasure, and our glory lost. So Jove decrees, resistless lord of all!

At whose command whole empires rise or fall: He (lord) shakes the feeble props of human trust, And towns and armies humbles to the dust

What shame to Greece a fruitful war to wage, Oh, lasting shame in every future age! Once great in arms, the common scorn we grow, Repulsed and baffled by a feeble foe.

So small their number, that if wars were ceased, And Greece triumphant held a general feast, All rank'd by tens, whole decades when they dine

Must want a Trojan slave to pour the wine.-LRB-84-RRB- But other forces have our hopes o'erthrown, And Troy prevails by armies not her (we) own.

Since first the labours of this war begun: Our cordage torn, decay'd our vessels lie, And scarce insure the wretched power to fly.

Our weeping wives, our tender children call: Love, duty, safety, summon us away, 'Tis nature's voice, and nature we obey, Our shatter'd barks may yet transport us o'er, Safe and inglorious, to our native shore.

Now nine long years of mighty Jove are run, Haste, then, for ever leave the Trojan wall! Fly, Grecians, fly, your sails and oars employ, And dream no more of heaven-defended Troy.

So roll the billows to the Icarian shore, From east and south when winds begin to roar, Burst their dark mansions in the clouds, and sweep The whitening surface of the ruffled deep.

And as on corn when western gusts descend,-LRB-85-RRB- Before the blast the lofty harvests bend: Thus o'er the field the moving host appears, With nodding plumes and groves of waving spears.

The gathering murmur spreads, their trampling feet Beat the loose sands, and thicken to the fleet; With long-resounding cries they urge the train To fit the ships, and launch into the main.

'' (the king)

His (their) deep design unknown, the hosts approve Atrides' speech. The mighty numbers move. They toil, they sweat, thick clouds of dust arise,

The doubling clamours echo to the skies. E'en then the Greeks had left the hostile plain, And fate decreed the fall of Troy in vain;

But Jove's imperial queen their flight survey'd, And sighing thus bespoke the blue-eyed maid:

``Shall then the Grecians fly! O dire disgrace!

And leave unpunish'd this perfidious race? Shall Troy, shall Priam, and the adulterous spouse, In peace enjoy the fruits of broken vows?

And bravest chiefs, in Helen's quarrel slain, Lie unrevenged on yon detested plain? No: let my Greeks, unmoved by vain alarms, Once more refulgent shine in brazen arms.

Haste, goddess, haste! the flying host detain, Nor let one sail be hoisted on the main. '' (the maid)

Pallas obeys, and from Olympus' height Swift to the ships precipitates her (goddess) flight.

Ulysses, first in public cares, she (goddess) found, For prudent counsel like the gods renown'd: Oppress'd with generous grief the hero stood, Nor drew his (hero) sable vessels to the flood.

And is it thus, divine Laertes' son, Thus fly the Greeks -LRB-the martial maid begun-RRB-, Thus to their country bear their own disgrace, And fame eternal leave to Priam's race?

'' Shall beauteous Helen still remain unfreed, Still unrevenged, a thousand heroes bleed! Haste, generous Ithacus! prevent the shame, Recall your armies, and your chiefs reclaim.

Your own resistless eloquence employ, And to the immortals trust the fall of Troy. '' The voice divine confess'd the warlike maid, Ulysses heard, nor uninspired

Thus graced, attention and respect to gain, He (Ulysses) runs, he (Ulysses) flies through all the Grecian train; Each prince of name, or chief in arms approved, He (chief) fired with praise, or with persuasion moved.

obey'd : Then meeting first Atrides, from his (chief) hand Received the imperial sceptre of command. '' Warriors like you, with strength and wisdom bless'd, By brave examples should confirm the rest.

The monarch's will not yet reveal'd appears; He (monarch) tries our courage, but resents our fears. The unwary Greeks his (monarch) fury may provoke; Not thus the king in secret council spoke.

Jove loves our chief, from Jove his (chief) honour springs, Beware! for dreadful is the wrath of kings. '' But if a clamorous vile plebeian rose, Him (chief) with reproof he (chief) check'd or tamed with blows.

'' Be still, thou slave, and to thy betters yield; Unknown alike in council and in field! Ye gods, what dastards would our host command!

Swept to the war, the lumber of a land. Be silent, wretch, and think not here allow'd That worst of tyrants, an usurping crowd.

To one sole monarch Jove commits the sway; His (monarch) are the laws, and him (monarch) let all obey.''-LRB-86-RRB- With words like these the troops Ulysses ruled, The loudest silenced, and the fiercest cool'd.

Murmuring they move, as when old ocean roars, And heaves huge surges to the trembling shores; The groaning banks are burst with bellowing sound, The rocks remurmur and the deeps rebound.

Back to the assembly roll the thronging train, Desert the ships, and pour upon the plain. At length the tumult sinks, the noises cease, And a still silence lulls the camp to peace.

controll'd, In scandal busy, in reproaches bold: With witty malice studious to defame, Scorn all his (they) joy, and laughter all his (they) aim:--

Thersites only clamour'd in the throng, Loquacious, loud, and turbulent of tongue: Awed by no shame, by no respect But chief he (chief) gloried with licentious style To lash the great, and monarchs to revile.

His (chief) figure such as might his (chief) soul proclaim; One eye was blinking, and one leg was lame: His (chief) mountain shoulders half his (chief) breast o'erspread, Thin hairs

Spleen to mankind his (chief) envious heart possess'd, And much he (chief) hated all, but most the best: Ulysses or Achilles still his (Ulysses) theme;

bestrew'd his (Ulysses) long misshapen head. But royal scandal his (Ulysses) delight supreme , Long had he (Long) lived the scorn of every Greek, Vex'd when he (Long) spoke, yet still they heard him (Long) speak.

Sharp was his (Long) voice; which in the shrillest tone, Thus with injurious taunts attack'd the throne. '' Amidst the glories of so bright a reign, What moves the great Atrides to complain? '

Tis thine whate'er the warrior's breast inflames, The golden spoil, and thine the lovely dames. With all the wealth our wars and blood bestow, Thy tents are crowded and thy chests o'erflow.

Thus at full ease in heaps of riches roll'd, What grieves the monarch? Is it thirst of gold? Say, shall we march with our unconquer'd powers -LRB-The Greeks and I-RRB- to Ilion's hostile towers,

And bring the race of royal bastards here, For Troy to ransom at a price too dear? But safer plunder thy own host supplies; Say, wouldst thou seize some valiant leader's prize?

Or, if thy heart to generous love be led, Some captive fair, to bless thy kingly bed? Whate'er our master craves submit we must, Plagued with his (master) pride, or punish'd for his (master) lust.

Oh women of Achaia; men no more! Hence let us fly, and let him (master) waste his (master) store In loves and pleasures on the Phrygian shore.

We may be wanted on some busy day, When Hector comes: so great Achilles may: From him (Achilles) he (Achilles) forced the prize we jointly gave, From him (Achilles), the fierce, the fearless, and the brave:

And durst he (Achilles), as he (Achilles) ought, resent that wrong , This mighty tyrant were no tyrant long. '' Fierce from his (tyrant) seat at this Ulysses springs,-LRB-87-RRB-

With indignation sparkling in his (tyrant) eyes, He (tyrant) views the wretch, and sternly thus replies:

``Peace, factious monster, born to vex the state, With wrangling talents form'd for foul debate: Curb that impetuous tongue, nor rashly vain, And singly mad, asperse the sovereign reign.

In generous vengeance of the king of kings. Have we not known thee, slave! of all our host, The man who acts the least, upbraids the most?

Think not the Greeks to shameful flight to bring, Nor let those lips profane the name of king. For our return we trust the heavenly powers; Be that their care; to fight like men be ours.

But grant the host with wealth the general load, Except detraction, what hast thou bestow'd? Suppose some hero should his (hero) spoils resign, Art thou that hero, could those spoils be thine?

If, on thy next offence, this hand forbear To strip those arms thou ill deserv`st to wear, Expel the council where our princes meet, And send thee scourged and howling through the fleet.

Gods! let me perish on this hateful shore, And let these eyes behold my son no more; '' (the wretch)

He (son) said, and cowering as the dastard bends, The weighty sceptre on his (son) bank descends.-LRB-88-RRB-

The tears spring starting from his (son) haggard eyes; Trembling he (son) sat, and shrunk in abject fears, From his (son) vile visage wiped the scalding tears; While to his (son) neighbour each

On the round bunch the bloody tumours rise: express'd his (son) thought:

``Ye gods! what wonders has Ulysses wrought! What fruits his (Ulysses) conduct and his (Ulysses) courage yield!

Generous he (Ulysses) rises in the crown's defence, To curb the factious tongue of insolence, Such just examples on offenders shown, Sedition silence, and assert the throne.

Great in the council, glorious in the field. '' (neighbour each)

'Twas thus the general voice the hero praised, Who, rising, high the imperial sceptre raised:

The blue-eyed Pallas, his (hero) celestial friend, -LRB-In form a herald,-RRB- bade the crowds attend. The expecting crowds in still attention hung, To hear the wisdom of his (hero) heavenly tongue.

Then deeply thoughtful, pausing ere he (hero) spoke, His (hero) silence thus the prudent hero broke:

``Unhappy monarch! whom the Grecian race With shame deserting, heap with vile disgrace.

Once all their voice, but ah! forgotten now: Ne'er to return, was then the common cry, Till Troy's proud structures should in ashes lie.

Not such at Argos was their generous vow: Behold them weeping for their native shore; What could their wives or helpless children more?

Few leagues removed, we wish our peaceful seat, When the ship tosses, and the tempests beat: Then well may this long stay provoke their tears, The tedious length of nine revolving years.

What heart but melts to leave the tender train, And, one short month, endure the wintry main? Not for their grief the Grecian host I blame; But vanquish'd!

baffled! oh, eternal shame! Expect the time to Troy's destruction given. And try the faith of Chalcas and of heaven. What pass'd at Aulis, Greece can witness bear,-LRB-89-RRB-

Beside a fountain's sacred brink we raised Our verdant altars, and the victims blazed: 'Twas where the plane-tree spread its shades around, The altars heaved; and from the crumbling ground

And all who live to breathe this Phrygian air. A mighty dragon shot, of dire portent; From Jove himself the dreadful sign was sent.

The topmost branch a mother-bird possess'd; Eight callow infants fill'd the mossy nest; Herself the ninth; the serpent, as he (witness) hung, Stretch'd his (witness) black jaws and crush'd the crying young; While hovering near, with miserable moan,

Straight to the tree his (witness) sanguine spires he (witness) roll'd, And curl'd around in many a winding fold; The drooping mother wail'd

The mother last, as round the nest she (mother) flew, Seized by the beating wing, the monster slew; Nor long survived: to marble turn'd, he (witness) stands A lasting prodigy on Aulis' sands.

her (mother) children gone. Such was the will of Jove; and hence we dare Trust in his (witness) omen, and support the war.

For while around we gazed with wondering eyes, And trembling sought the powers with sacrifice, Full of his (witness) god, the reverend Chalcas cried,-LRB-90-RRB- '

As many birds as by the snake were slain, So many years the toils of Greece remain; But wait the tenth, for Ilion's fall decreed:' Thus spoke the prophet, thus the Fates succeed.

Ye Grecian warriors! lay your fears aside. This wondrous signal Jove himself displays, Of long, long labours, but eternal praise. Obey, ye Grecians!

with submission wait, Nor let your flight avert the Trojan fate. '' (the hero)

He (prophet) said: the shores with loud applauses sound, The hollow ships each deafening shout rebound.

Then Nestor thus--

``These vain debates forbear , Ye talk like children, not like heroes dare. Where now are all your high resolves at last?

Your leagues concluded, your engagements past? Vow'd with libations and with victims then, Now vanish'd like their smoke: the faith of men!

While useless words consume the unactive hours, No wonder Troy so long resists our powers. Rise, great Atrides! and with courage sway; We march to war, if thou direct the way.

But leave the few that dare resist thy laws, The mean deserters of the Grecian cause, To grudge the conquests mighty Jove prepares, And view with envy our successful wars.

On that great day, when first the martial train, Big with the fate of Ilion, plough'd the main, Jove, on the right, a prosperous signal sent, And thunder rolling shook the firmament.

Encouraged hence, maintain the glorious strife, Till every soldier grasp a Phrygian wife, Till Helen's woes at full revenged appear, And Troy's proud matrons render tear for tear.

Before that day, if any Greek invite His (soldier) country's troops to base, inglorious flight, Stand forth that Greek! and hoist his (soldier) sail to fly, And die the dastard first, who dreads to die.

Among those counsels, let not mine be vain; In tribes and nations to divide thy train: His (soldier) separate troops let every leader call, Each strengthen each, and all encourage all.

What chief, or soldier, of the numerous band, Or bravely fights, or ill obeys command, When thus distinct they war, shall soon be known

But now, O monarch! all thy chiefs advise:-LRB-91-RRB- Nor what they offer, thou thyself despise. And what the cause of Ilion not o'erthrown;

If fate resists, or if our arms are slow, If gods above prevent, or men below. '' (Nestor/Wise Nestor/Wise)

To him (monarch) the king:
``How much thy years excel In arts of counsel, and in speaking well!

But ten such sages as they grant in thee; Such wisdom soon should Priam's force destroy, And soon should fall the haughty towers of Troy!

But Jove forbids, who plunges those he (counsel) hates In fierce contention and in vain debates: Now great Achilles from our aid withdraws, By me provoked; a captive maid the cause:

O would the gods, in love to Greece, decree If e'er as friends we join, the Trojan wall Must shake, and heavy will the vengeance fall!

His (Achilles) sharpen'd spear let every Grecian wield, And every Grecian fix his (Achilles) brazen shield, Let all excite the fiery steeds of war, And all for combat fit the rattling car.

This day, this dreadful day, let each contend; No rest, no respite, till the shades descend; Till darkness, or till death, shall cover all: Let the war bleed, and let the mighty fall; Till bathed in sweat be every manly breast, With the huge shield each brawny arm depress'd, Each aching nerve refuse the lance to throw, And each spent courser at the chariot blow.

Who dares, inglorious, in his ships to stay, Who dares to tremble on this signal day; That wretch, too mean to fall by martial power, The birds shall mangle, and the dogs devour.

But now, ye warriors, take a short repast; And, well refresh'd, to bloody conflict haste. '' (the king)

The monarch spoke; and straight a murmur rose, Loud as the surges when the tempest blows,

the troops dispersing bend, The fires are kindled, and the smokes ascend; With hasty feasts they sacrifice, and pray, To avert the dangers of the doubtful day.

That dash'd on broken rocks tumultuous roar, And foam and thunder on the stony shore. Straight to the tents A steer of five years' age, large limb'd, and fed,-LRB-92-RRB-

To Jove's high altars Agamemnon led: There bade the noblest of the Grecian peers; And Nestor first, as most advanced in years.

Next came Idomeneus,-LRB-93-RRB- and Tydeus' son,-LRB-94-RRB- Ajax the less, and Ajax Telamon;-LRB-95-RRB- Then wise Ulysses in his (Ulysses) rank was placed; And Menelaus came, unbid, the last.-LRB-96-RRB-

The chiefs surround the destined beast, and take The sacred offering of the salted cake: When thus the king prefers his (king) solemn prayer;

``O thou! whose thunder rends the clouded air, Who in the heaven of heavens hast fixed thy throne, Supreme of gods!

and before the burning sun descends, Before the night her (Ulysses) gloomy veil extends, Low in the dust be laid yon hostile spires,

unbounded, and alone! Hear! Be Priam's palace sunk in Grecian fires. In Hector's breast be plunged this shining sword, And slaughter'd heroes groan around their lord!'' (the king)

Thus prayed the chief: his (chief) unavailing prayer Great Jove refused, and toss'd in empty air: The God averse, while yet the fumes arose, Prepared new toils, and doubled woes on woes.

Their prayers perform'd the chiefs the rite pursue, The barley sprinkled, and the victim slew. The limbs they sever from the inclosing hide, The thighs, selected to the gods, divide.

On these, in double cauls involved with art, The choicest morsels lie from every part, From the cleft wood the crackling flames aspire While the fat victims feed the sacred fire.

The thighs thus sacrificed, and entrails dress'd The assistants part, transfix, and roast the rest ; Then spread the tables, the repast prepare, Each takes his (victim) seat, and each receives his (victim) share.

Now bid thy heralds sound the loud alarms, And call the squadrons sheathed in brazen arms; Now seize the occasion, now the troops survey, And lead to war when heaven directs the way.

He (victim) said; the monarch issued his (victim) commands; Straight the loud heralds call the gathering bands The chiefs inclose their king; the hosts divide,

Soon as the rage of hunger was suppress'd, The generous Nestor thus the prince address'd. '' '' In tribes and nations rank'd on either side.

; The dreadful aegis, Jove's immortal shield, Blazed on her (troops) arm, and lighten'd all the field: Round the vast orb a hundred serpents roll'd, Form'd the bright fringe, and seem'd to burn in gold, With this each Grecian's manly breast she (troops) warms, Swells their bold hearts, and strings their nervous arms,

High in the midst the blue-eyed virgin flies; From rank to rank she (troops) darts her (troops) ardent eyes No more they sigh, inglorious, to return,

As on some mountain, through the lofty grove, The crackling flames ascend, and blaze above; The fires expanding, as the winds arise, Shoot their long beams, and kindle half the skies: So from the polish'd arms, and brazen shields, A gleamy splendour flash'd along the fields.

But breathe revenge, and for the combat burn. Not less their number than the embodied cranes, Or milk-white swans in Asius' watery plains.

Stretch their long necks, and clap their rustling wings, Now tower aloft, and course in airy rounds, Now light with noise; with noise the field resounds.

That, o'er the windings of Cayster's springs,-LRB-97-RRB- Thus numerous and confused, extending wide, The legions crowd Scamander's flowery side;-LRB-98-RRB- With rushing troops the plains are cover'd o'er, And thundering footsteps shake the sounding shore.

Thick as in spring the flowers adorn the land, Or leaves the trees; or thick as insects play, The wandering nation of a summer's day: That, drawn by milky steams, at evening hours, In gather'd swarms surround the rural bowers; From pail to pail with busy murmur run The gilded legions, glittering in the sun.

Along the river's level meads they stand, So throng'd, so close, the Grecian squadrons stood In radiant arms, and thirst for Trojan blood.

Each leader now his (leader) scatter'd force conjoins In close array, and forms the deepening lines. Not with more ease the skilful shepherd-swain Collects his (leader) flocks from thousands on the plain.

The king of kings, majestically tall, Towers o'er his (king) armies, and outshines them all; Like some proud bull, that round the pastures leads His (king) subject herds, the monarch of the meads,

Great as the gods, the exalted chief was seen, His (chief) strength like Neptune, and like Mars his (chief) mien;-LRB-99-RRB- Jove o'er his (chief) eyes celestial glories spread, And dawning conquest played around his (chief) head.

Say, virgins, seated round the throne divine, All-knowing goddesses! immortal nine!-LRB-100-RRB- Since earth's wide regions, heaven's umneasur'd height, And hell's abyss, hide nothing from your sight,

-LRB-We, wretched mortals! lost in doubts below, But guess by rumour, and but boast we know,-RRB- O say what heroes, fired by thirst of fame, Or urged by wrongs, to Troy's destruction came.

To count them all, demands a thousand tongues, A throat of brass, and adamantine lungs. Daughters of Jove, assist! inspired by you

The mighty labour dauntless I pursue; What crowded armies, from what climes they bring, Their names, their numbers, and their chiefs I sing.

The hardy warriors whom Boeotia bred, Penelius, Leitus, Prothoenor, led: With these Arcesilaus and Clonius stand, Equal in arms, and equal in command.

These head the troops that rocky Aulis yields, And Eteon's hills, and Hyrie's watery fields, And Schoenos, Scholos, Graea near the main, And Mycalessia's ample piny plain; Those who in Peteon or Ilesion dwell, Or Harma where Apollo's prophet fell; Heleon and Hyle, which the springs o'erflow; And Medeon lofty, and Ocalea low; Or in the meads of Haliartus stray, Or Thespia sacred to the god of day:

Onchestus, Neptune's celebrated groves; Copae, and Thisbe, famed for silver doves; For flocks Erythrae, Glissa for the vine; Platea green, and Nysa the divine; And they whom Thebe's well-built walls inclose, Where Myde, Eutresis, Corone, rose; And Arne rich, with purple harvests crown'd; And Anthedon, Boeotia's utmost bound.

THE CATALOGUE OF THE SHIPS.-LRB-101-RRB- -LSB-Illustration: NEPTUNE.-RSB- NEPTUNE. Full fifty ships they send, and each conveys Twice sixty warriors through the foaming seas.-LRB-102-RRB-

Two valiant brothers rule the undaunted throng, Ialmen and Ascalaphus the strong: Sons of Astyoche, the heavenly fair, Whose virgin charms subdued the god of war: -LRB-In Actor's court as she (Boeotia) retired to rest, The strength of Mars the blushing maid compress'd-RRB- Their troops in thirty sable vessels sweep, With equal oars, the hoarse-resounding deep.

To these succeed Aspledon's martial train, Who plough the spacious Orchomenian plain. The Phocians next in forty barks repair; Epistrophus and Schedius head the war:

From those rich regions where Cephisus leads His (Actor) silver current through the flowery meads; From Panopea, Chrysa the divine, Where Anemoria's stately turrets shine, Where Pytho, Daulis, Cyparissus stood, And fair Lilaea views the rising flood.

Fierce Ajax led the Locrian squadrons on, Ajax the less, Oileus' valiant son; Skill'd to direct the flying dart aright; Swift in pursuit, and active in the fight.

Him (Swift), as their chief, the chosen troops attend, Which Bessa, Thronus, and rich Cynos send; Opus, Calliarus, and Scarphe's bands; And those who dwell where pleasing Augia stands, And where Boagrius floats the lowly lands, Or in fair Tarphe's sylvan seats reside: In forty vessels cut the yielding tide.

Euboea next her (Swift) martial sons prepares, And sends the brave Abantes to the wars: Breathing revenge, in arms they take their way From Chalcis' walls, and strong Eretria; The Isteian fields for generous vines renown'd, The fair Caristos, and the Styrian ground; Where Dios from her (Swift) towers o'erlooks the plain, And high Cerinthus views the neighbouring main.

Down their broad shoulders falls a length of hair; Their hands dismiss not the long lance in air; But with protended spears in fighting fields Pierce the tough corslets and the brazen shields.

These, ranged in order on the floating tide, Close, on the left, the bold Boeotians' side. Twice twenty ships transport the warlike bands, Which bold Elphenor, fierce in arms, commands.

Full fifty more from Athens stem the main, Led by Menestheus through the liquid plain. -LRB-Athens the fair, where great Erectheus sway'd,

That owed his (Pierce) nurture to the blue-eyed maid, But from the teeming furrow took his (Pierce) birth, The mighty offspring of the foodful earth.

Him (Pierce) Pallas placed amidst her (maid) wealthy fane, Adored with sacrifice and oxen slain; Where, as the years revolve, her (maid) altars blaze, And all the tribes resound the goddess' praise.-RRB-

No chief like thee, Menestheus! Greece could yield, To marshal armies in the dusty field, The extended wings of battle to display, Or close the embodied host in firm array.

Nestor alone, improved by length of days, For martial conduct bore an equal praise. With these appear the Salaminian bands, Whom the gigantic Telamon commands; In twelve black ships to Troy

Next move to war the generous Argive train, From high Troezene, and Maseta's plain, And fair Ćgina circled by the main:

they steer their course, And with the great Athenians join their force. Whom strong Tyrinthe's lofty walls surround, And Epidaure with viny harvests

crown'd : And where fair Asinen and Hermoin show Their cliffs above, and ample bay below. These by the brave Euryalus were led, Great Sthenelus, and greater Diomed; But chief Tydides bore the sovereign sway

: In fourscore barks they plough the watery way. The proud Mycene arms her (their) martial powers, Cleone, Corinth, with imperial towers,-LRB-103-RRB-

Fair Araethyrea, Ornia's fruitful plain, And Ćgion, and Adrastus' ancient reign; And those who dwell along the sandy shore, And where Pellene yields her (their) fleecy store, Where Helice and Hyperesia lie, And Gonoessa's spires salute the sky.

Great Agamemnon rules the numerous band, A hundred vessels in long order stand, And crowded nations wait his (Agamemnon) dread command. High on the deck the king of men appears, And

his (king) refulgent arms in triumph wears; Proud of his (king) host, unrivall'd in his (king) reign, In silent pomp he (king) moves along the main.

The hardy Spartans, exercised in arms: Phares and Brysia's valiant troops, and those Whom Lacedaemon's lofty hills inclose; Or Messe's towers for silver doves renown'd, Amyclae, Laas, Augia's happy ground, And those whom OEtylos' low walls contain, And Helos, on the margin of the main:

Eager and loud from man to man he (man) flies, Revenge and fury flaming in his (man) eyes; While vainly fond, in fancy oft he (man) hears The fair one's grief, and sees her (man) falling tears.

His (man) brother follows, and to vengeance warms These, o'er the bending ocean, Helen's cause, In sixty ships with Menelaus draws: In ninety sail, from Pylos' sandy coast, Nestor the sage conducts his (Nestor) chosen host:

From Amphigenia's ever-fruitful land, Where Ćpy high, and little Pteleon stand; Where beauteous Arene her (Helen) structures shows, And Thryon's walls Alpheus' streams inclose: And

Dorion, famed for Thamyris' disgrace, Superior once of all the tuneful race, Till, vain of mortals' empty praise, he (Nestor) strove To match the seed of cloud-compelling Jove!

Too daring bard! whose unsuccessful pride The immortal Muses in their art defied. The avenging Muses of the light of day Deprived his (bard) eyes, and snatch'd

Where under high Cyllene, crown'd with wood, The shaded tomb of old Ćpytus stood; From Ripe, Stratie, Tegea's bordering towns, The Phenean fields, and Orchomenian downs, Where the fat herds in plenteous pasture rove; And Stymphelus with her (mortals) surrounding grove; Parrhasia, on her (mortals) snowy cliffs reclined, And high Enispe shook by wintry wind, And fair Mantinea's ever-pleasing site; In sixty sail the Arcadian bands unite.

his (bard) voice away; No more his (bard) heavenly voice was heard to sing, His (bard) hand no more awaked the silver string. Bold Agapenor, glorious at their head, -LRB-Ancaeus' son-RRB- the mighty squadron led.

Their ships, supplied by Agamemnon's care, Through roaring seas the wondering warriors bear; The first to battle on the appointed plain, But new to all the dangers of the main.

Those, where fair Elis and Buprasium join; Whom Hyrmin, here, and Myrsinus confine, And bounded there, where o'er the valleys rose The Olenian rock; and where Alisium flows; Beneath four chiefs -LRB-a numerous army-RRB- came: The strength and glory of the Epean name.

In separate squadrons these their train divide, Each leads ten vessels through the yielding tide. One was Amphimachus, and Thalpius one;

But those who view fair Elis o'er the seas From the blest islands of the Echinades, In forty vessels under Meges move, Begot by Phyleus, the beloved of Jove: To strong Dulichium from his (Jove) sire he (Jove) fled, And thence to Troy his (Jove) hardy warriors led.

-LRB-Eurytus' this, and that Teatus' son;-RRB- Diores sprung from Amarynceus' line; And great Polyxenus, of force divine. Ulysses follow'd through the watery road,

With those whom Cephalenia's line inclosed, Or till their fields along the coast opposed; Or where fair Ithaca o'erlooks the floods, Where high Neritos shakes his (Ulysses) waving woods, Where Ćgilipa's rugged sides are seen, Crocylia rocky, and Zacynthus green.

A chief, in wisdom equal to a god. These in twelve galleys with vermilion prores, Beneath his (god) conduct sought the Phrygian shores.

Thoas came next, Andraemon's valiant son, From Pleuron's walls, and chalky Calydon, And rough Pylene, and the Olenian steep, And Chalcis, beaten by the rolling deep.

He (son) led the warriors from the Ćtolian shore, For now the sons of OEneus were no more! The glories of the mighty race were fled!

Next, eighty barks the Cretan king commands, Of Gnossus, Lyctus, and Gortyna's bands; And those who dwell where Rhytion's domes arise, Or white Lycastus glitters to the skies, Or where by Phaestus silver Jardan runs; Crete's hundred cities pour forth all her (bands) sons.

OEneus himself, and Meleager dead! To Thoas' care now trust the martial train, His (Cretan) forty vessels follow through the main. These march'd, Idomeneus, beneath thy care, And Merion, dreadful as the god of war.

Tlepolemus, the sun of Hercules, Led nine swift vessels through the foamy seas, From Rhodes, with everlasting sunshine bright, Jalyssus, Lindus, and Camirus white.

His (Rhodes) captive mother fierce Alcides bore From Ephyr's walls and Selle's winding shore, Where mighty towns in ruins spread the plain, And saw their blooming warriors early slain.

The hero, when to manly years he (hero) grew, Alcides' uncle, old Licymnius, slew; For this, constrain'd to quit his (hero) native place, And shun the vengeance of the Herculean race, A fleet he (hero) built, and with a numerous train Of willing exiles

wander'd o'er the main; Where, many seas and many sufferings past, On happy Rhodes the chief arrived at last: There in three tribes divides his (chief) native band, And rules them peaceful in a foreign land; Increased and prosper'd in their new abodes By mighty Jove, the sire of men and gods; With joy they saw the growing empire rise, And showers of wealth descending from the skies.

Three ships with Nireus sought the Trojan shore, Nireus, whom Aglae to Charopus bore, Nireus, in faultless shape and blooming grace,

The loveliest youth of all the Grecian race;-LRB-104-RRB- Pelides only match'd his (sire) early charms; But few his (sire) troops, and small his (sire) strength in arms.

Next thirty galleys cleave the liquid plain, Of those Calydnae's sea-girt isles contain; With them the youth of Nisyrus repair, Casus the strong, and Crapathus the fair;

Cos, where Eurypylus possess'd the sway, Till great Alcides made the realms obey: These Antiphus and bold Phidippus bring, Sprung from the god by Thessalus the king.

Now, Muse, recount Pelasgic Argos' powers, From Alos, Alope, and Trechin's towers: From Phthia's spacious vales; and Hella, bless'd With female beauty far beyond the rest.

Full fifty ships beneath Achilles' care, The Achaians, Myrmidons, Hellenians bear; Thessalians all, though various in their name; The same their nation, and their chief the same.

stretch'd along the shore, They hear the brazen voice of war no more; No more the foe they face in dire array: Close in his (foe) fleet the angry leader lay; Since fair Briseis from his (foe) arms was torn, The noblest spoil from sack'd Lyrnessus borne, Then, when the chief the Theban walls o'erthrew, And the bold sons of great Evenus slew.

But now inglorious, There mourn'd Achilles, plunged in depth of care, But soon to rise in slaughter, blood, and war. To these the youth of Phylace succeed, Itona, famous for her (foe) fleecy breed, And grassy Pteleon deck'd with cheerful greens,

The bowers of Ceres, and the sylvan scenes. Sweet Pyrrhasus, with blooming flowerets crown'd, And Antron's watery dens, and cavern'd ground.

The first who boldly touch'd the Trojan shore, And dyed a Phrygian lance with Grecian gore; There lies, far distant from his (Achilles) native plain; Unfinish'd his (Achilles) proud palaces remain, And his (Achilles) sad consort beats her (foe) breast in vain.

His (Achilles) troops in forty ships Podarces led, Iphiclus' son, and brother to the dead; Nor he (Achilles) unworthy to command the host; Yet still they mourn'd their ancient leader lost.

The men who Glaphyra's fair soil partake, Where hills incircle Boebe's lowly lake, Where Phaere hears the neighbouring waters fall, Or proud Iolcus lifts her (foe) airy wall,

In ten black ships embark'd for Ilion's shore, With bold Eumelus, whom Alceste bore: All Pelias' race Alceste far outshined, The grace and glory of the beauteous kind, The troops Methone or Thaumacia yields, Olizon's rocks, or Meliboea's fields, With Philoctetes sail'd whose matchless art From the tough bow directs the feather'd dart.

These own'd, as chief, Protesilas the brave, Who now lay silent in the gloomy grave: Seven were his (chief) ships; each vessel fifty row, Skill'd in his (chief) science of the dart and bow.

But he (chief) lay raging on the Lemnian ground, A poisonous hydra gave the burning wound; There groan'd the chief in agonizing pain, Whom Greece at length shall wish, nor wish in vain.

The OEchalian race, in those high towers contain'd Where once Eurytus in proud triumph reign'd, Or where her (chief) humbler turrets Tricca rears, Or where Ithome, rough with rocks, appears,

His (chief) forces Medon led from Lemnos' shore, Oileus' son, whom beauteous Rhena bore. In thirty sail the sparkling waves divide, Which Podalirius and Machaon guide.

To these his (chief) skill their parent-god imparts, Divine professors of the healing arts. The bold Ormenian and Asterian bands In forty barks Eurypylus commands.

Thy troops, Argissa, Polypoetes leads, And Eleon, shelter'd by Olympus' shades, Gyrtone's warriors; and where Orthe lies, And Oloosson's chalky cliffs arise.

Sprung from Pirithous of immortal race, The fruit of fair Hippodame's embrace, -LRB-That day, when hurl'd from Pelion's cloudy head, To distant dens the shaggy Centaurs fled-RRB-

Where Titan hides his (chief) hoary head in snow, And where Hyperia's silver fountains flow. With Polypoetes join'd in equal sway Leonteus leads, and forty ships obey.

With these the Enians join'd, and those who freeze Where cold Dodona lifts her (chief) holy trees; Or where the pleasing Titaresius glides, And into Peneus rolls his (chief) easy tides;

In twenty sail the bold Perrhaebians came From Cyphus, Guneus was their leader's name. Yet o'er the silvery surface pure they flow, The sacred stream unmix'd with streams below, Sacred and awful!

from the dark abodes Styx pours them forth, the dreadful oath of gods! Last, under Prothous the Magnesians stood, -LRB-Prothous the swift, of old Tenthredon's blood;-RRB-

Who dwell where Pelion, crown'd with piny boughs, Obscures the glade, and nods his (leader) shaggy brows; Or where through flowery Tempe Peneus stray'd:

-LRB-The region stretch'd beneath his (leader) mighty shade:-RRB- In forty sable barks they stemm'd the main; Such were the chiefs, and such the Grecian train.

Eumelus' mares were foremost in the chase, As eagles fleet, and of Pheretian race; Bred where Pieria's fruitful fountains flow, And train'd by him (leader) who bears the silver bow.

Fierce in the fight their nostrils breathed a flame, Their height, their colour, and their age the same; O'er fields of death they whirl the rapid car, And break the ranks, and thunder through the war.

Ajax in arms the first renown acquired, While stern Achilles in his (Achilles) wrath retired: -LRB-His (Achilles) was the strength that mortal might exceeds, And his (Achilles) the unrivall'd race of heavenly steeds:-RRB-

Say next, O Muse! of all Achaia breeds, Who bravest fought, or rein'd the noblest steeds? But Thetis' son now shines in arms no more; His (son) troops, neglected on the sandy shore.

Unstain'd with blood his (son) cover'd chariots stand; The immortal coursers graze along the strand; But the brave chiefs the inglorious life deplored,

In empty air their sportive javelins throw, Or whirl the disk, or bend an idle bow: And, wandering o'er the camp, required their lord.

Now, like a deluge, covering all around, The shining armies sweep along the ground; Swift as a flood of fire, when storms arise, Floats the wild field, and blazes to the skies.

Earth groan'd beneath them; as when angry Jove Hurls down the forky lightning from above, On Arime when he (Swift) the thunder throws, And fires Typhoeus with redoubled blows, Where Typhon, press'd beneath the burning load, Still feels the fury of the avenging god.

But various Iris, Jove's commands to bear, Speeds on the wings of winds through liquid air; In Priam's porch the Trojan chiefs she (Iris) found, The old consulting, and the youths around.

Polites' shape, the monarch's son, she (Iris) chose, Who from Ćsetes' tomb observed the foes,-LRB-105-RRB- High on the mound; from whence in prospect lay The fields, the tents, the navy, and the bay.

In this dissembled form, she (Iris) hastes to bring The unwelcome message to the Phrygian king. '' Cease to consult, the time for action calls; War, horrid war, approaches to your walls!

But ne'er till now such numbers charged a field: Thick as autumnal leaves or driving sand, The moving squadrons blacken all the strand.

Assembled armies oft have I beheld; Thou, godlike Hector! all thy force employ, Assemble all the united bands of Troy; In just array let every leader call The foreign troops: this day demands them all!''

The gates unfolding pour forth all their train, Nations on nations fill the dusky plain, Men, steeds, and chariots, shake the trembling ground: The tumult thickens, and the skies resound.

Amidst the plain, in sight of Ilion, stands A rising mount, the work of human hands; -LRB-This for Myrinne's tomb the immortals know, Though

The voice divine the mighty chief alarms; The council breaks, the warriors rush to arms. call'd Bateia in the world below;-RRB- Beneath their chiefs in martial order here, The auxiliar troops and Trojan hosts appear.

The godlike Hector, high above the rest, Shakes his (Hector) huge spear, and nods his (Hector) plumy crest: In throngs around his (Hector) native bands repair, And groves of lances glitter in the air.

Divine Ćneas brings the Dardan race, Anchises' son, by Venus' stolen embrace, Born in the shades of Ida's secret grove; -LRB-A mortal mixing with the queen of love;-RRB- Archilochus and Acamas divide The warrior's toils, and combat by his (warrior) side.

Fast by the foot of Ida's sacred hill, Or drink, Ćsepus, of thy sable flood, Were led by Pandarus, of royal blood; To whom his (warrior) art Apollo deign'd to show, Graced with the presents of his (warrior) shafts and bow.

From rich Apaesus and Adrestia's towers, High Teree's summits, and Pityea's bowers; From these the congregated troops obey Young Amphius and Adrastus' equal sway;

Who fair Zeleia's wealthy valleys till,-LRB-106-RRB- Old Merops' sons; whom, skill'd in fates to come, The sire forewarn'd, and prophesied their doom: Fate urged them on!

the sire forewarn'd in vain, They rush'd to war, and perish'd on the plain. From Practius' stream, Percote's pasture lands, And Sestos and Abydos' neighbouring strands, From great Arisba's walls and Selle's coast,

Asius Hyrtacides conducts his (sire) host: High on his (sire) car he (sire) shakes the flowing reins, His (sire) fiery coursers thunder o'er the plains.

The fierce Pelasgi next, in war renown'd, March from Larissa's ever-fertile ground: In equal arms their brother leaders shine, Hippothous bold, and Pyleus the divine.

Next Acamas and Pyrous lead their hosts, In dread array, from Thracia's wintry coasts; Round the bleak realms where Hellespontus roars, And Boreas beats the hoarse-resounding shores.

Pyraechmes the Paeonian troops attend, Skill'd in the fight their crooked bows to bend; From Axius' ample bed he (brother) leads them on, Axius, that laves the distant Amydon, Axius, that swells with all his (brother) neighbouring rills, And wide around the floating region fills.

The Paphlagonians Pylaemenes rules, Where rich Henetia breeds her (Axius) savage mules, Where Erythinus' rising cliffs are seen, Thy groves of box, Cytorus! ever green, And where Ćgialus and Cromna lie, And lofty

With great Euphemus the Ciconians move, Sprung from Troezenian Ceus, loved by Jove. Sesamus invades the sky, And where Parthenius, roll'd through banks of flowers, Reflects her (Axius) bordering palaces and bowers.

Here march'd in arms the Halizonian band, Whom Odius and Epistrophus command, From those far regions where the sun refines The ripening silver in Alybean mines.

There mighty Chromis led the Mysian train, And augur Ennomus, inspired in vain; For stern Achilles lopp'd his (Achilles) sacred head, Roll'd down Scamander with the vulgar dead.

Of those who round Maeonia's realms reside, Or whom the vales in shades of Tmolus hide, Mestles and Antiphus the charge partake, Born on the banks of Gyges' silent lake.

There, from the fields where wild Maeander flows, High Mycale, and Latmos' shady brows, And proud Miletus, came the Carian throngs, With mingled clamours and with barbarous tongues.-LRB-107-RRB-

, Naustes the bold, Amphimachus the vain, Who, trick'd with gold, and glittering on his (Scamander) car, Rode like a woman to the field of war.

Phorcys and brave Ascanius here unite The Ascanian Phrygians, eager for the fight. Amphimachus and Naustes guide the train Fool that he (Fool) was!

by fierce Achilles slain, The river swept him (Fool) to the briny main: There whelm'd with waves the gaudy warrior lies The valiant victor seized the golden prize.

The forces last in fair array succeed, Which blameless Glaucus and Sarpedon lead The warlike bands that distant Lycia yields, Where gulfy Xanthus foams along the fields.

The armies being ready to engage, a single combat is agreed upon between Menelaus and Paris -LRB-by the intervention of Hector-RRB- for the determination of the war.

She (Hector) leads her (Hector) to the walls of Troy, where Priam sat with his (Hector) counsellers observing the Grecian leaders on the plain below, to whom Helen gives an account of the chief of them.

BOOK III. ARGUMENT. THE DUEL OF MENELAUS AND PARIS. Iris is sent to call Helen to behold the fight. The kings on either part take the solemn oath for the conditions of the combat.

The duel ensues; wherein Paris being overcome, he (MENELAUS) is snatched away in a cloud by Venus, and transported to his (MENELAUS) apartment.

She (Venus) then calls Helen from the walls, and brings the lovers together. Agamemnon, on the part of the Grecians, demands the restoration of Helen, and the performance of the articles.

The three-and-twentieth day still continues throughout this book. The scene is sometimes in the fields before Troy, and sometimes in Troy itself.

Thus by their leaders' care each martial band Moves into ranks, and stretches o'er the land. With shouts the Trojans, rushing from afar, Proclaim their motions, and provoke the war

With noise, and order, through the midway sky; To pigmy nations wounds and death they bring, And all the war descends upon the wing,

So when inclement winters vex the plain With piercing frosts, or thick-descending rain, To warmer seas the cranes embodied fly,-LRB-108-RRB- But silent, breathing rage, resolved and skill'd-LRB-109-RRB-

By mutual aids to fix a doubtful field, Swift march the Greeks: the rapid dust around Darkening arises from the labour'd ground.

Thus from his (Swift) flaggy wings when Notus sheds A night of vapours round the mountain heads, Swift-gliding mists the dusky fields invade, To thieves more grateful than the midnight shade;

While scarce the swains their feeding flocks survey, Lost and confused amidst the thicken'd day: So wrapp'd in gathering dust, the Grecian train, A moving cloud, swept on, and hid the plain.

Now front to front the hostile armies stand, Eager of fight, and only wait command; When, to the van, before the sons of fame Whom Troy sent forth, the beauteous Paris came:

: His (sons) bended bow across his (sons) shoulders flung, His (sons) sword beside him (sons) negligently hung; Two pointed spears he (sons) shook with gallant grace, And dared the bravest of the Grecian race.

As thus, with glorious air and proud disdain, He (sons) boldly stalk'd, the foremost on the plain, Him (sons) Menelaus, loved of Mars, espies, With heart elated, and with joyful eyes:

So joys a lion, if the branching deer, Or mountain goat, his (Menelaus) bulky prize, appear; Eager he (Menelaus) seizes and devours the slain, Press'd by bold youths and baying dogs in vain.

Thus fond of vengeance, with a furious bound, In clanging arms he (Menelaus) leaps upon the ground From his (Menelaus) high chariot: him (Menelaus), approaching near,

The beauteous champion views with marks of fear, Smit with a conscious sense, retires behind, And shuns the fate he (Smit) well deserved to find.

As when some shepherd, from the rustling trees-LRB-110-RRB- Shot forth to view, a scaly serpent sees, Trembling and pale, he (shepherd) starts with wild affright

In form a god! the panther's speckled hide Flow'd o'er his (shepherd) armour with an easy pride And all confused precipitates his (shepherd) flight:

So from the king the shining warrior flies, And plunged amid the thickest Trojans lies. As godlike Hector sees the prince retreat, He (Hector) thus upbraids him (Hector) with a generous heat:

``Unhappy Paris!

but to women brave!-LRB-111-RRB- So fairly form'd, and only to deceive! Oh, hadst thou died when first thou saw`st the light, Or died at least before thy nuptial rite!

A better fate than vainly thus to boast, And fly, the scandal of thy Trojan host. Gods! how the scornful Greeks exult to see Their fears of danger undeceived in thee!

In former days, in all thy gallant pride, When thy tall ships triumphant stemm'd the tide, When Greece beheld thy painted canvas flow, And crowds stood wondering at the passing show, Say, was it thus, with such a baffled mien, You met the approaches of the Spartan queen, Thus from her (queen) realm

Thy figure promised with a martial air, But ill thy soul supplies a form so fair. convey'd the beauteous prize, And both her (queen) warlike lords outshined in Helen's eyes?

This deed, thy foes' delight, thy own disgrace, Thy father's grief, and ruin of thy race; This deed recalls thee to the proffer'd fight; Or hast thou injured

whom thou dar`st not right? Soon to thy cost the field would make thee know Thou keep`st the consort of a braver foe.

Thy graceful form instilling soft desire, Thy curling tresses, and thy silver lyre, Beauty and youth; in vain to these you trust, When youth and beauty shall be laid in dust: Troy yet may wake, and one avenging blow Crush the dire author of his (author) country's woe.

Tis just, my brother, what your anger speaks: But who like thee can boast a soul sedate, So firmly proof to all the shocks of fate?

Thy force, like steel, a temper'd hardness shows, Still edged to wound, and still untired with blows, Like steel, uplifted by some strenuous swain, With falling woods to strew the wasted plain.

Thy gifts I praise; nor thou despise the charms With which a lover golden Venus arms; Soft moving speech, and pleasing outward show, No wish can gain them, but the gods bestow.

Yet, would`st thou have the proffer'd combat stand, The Greeks and Trojans seat on either hand; Then let a midway space our hosts divide,

And, on that stage of war, the cause be tried: By Paris there the Spartan king be fought, For beauteous Helen and the wealth she (Helen) brought; And who his (king) rival can in arms subdue, His (king) be the fair, and his (king) the treasure too.

'' (him)

His (king) silence here, with blushes, Paris breaks: ''' Thus with a lasting league your toils may cease, And Troy possess her (Helen) fertile fields in peace;

The challenge Hector heard with joy, Then with his (Hector) spear restrain'd the youth of Troy, Held by the midst, athwart; and near the foe Advanced with steps majestically slow: While round his (foe) dauntless head the Grecians pour Their stones and arrows in a mingled shower.

Thus may the Greeks review their native shore, Much famed for generous steeds, for beauty more. '' He (foe) said. Then thus the monarch, great Atrides, cried:

``Forbear, ye warriors! lay the darts aside:

A parley Hector asks, a message bears ; We know him (Hector) by the various plume he (Hector) wears. '' (the monarch Atrides)

Awed by his (Hector) high command the Greeks attend, The tumult silence, and the fight suspend.

While from the centre Hector rolls his (Hector) eyes On either host, and thus to both applies:

``Hear, all ye Trojan, all ye Grecian bands, What Paris, author of the war, demands.

Here in the midst, in either army's sight, He (author) dares the Spartan king to single fight; And wills that Helen and the ravish'd spoil, That caused the contest, shall reward the toil.

Your shining swords within the sheath restrain, And pitch your lances in the yielding plain. Let these the brave triumphant victor grace, And different nations part in leagues of peace.

'' (Hector/HECTOR/Stern)

He (victor) spoke: in still suspense on either side Each army stood: the Spartan chief replied: ``Me too, ye warriors, hear, whose fatal right

A world engages in the toils of fight. To me the labour of the field resign; Me Paris injured; all the war be mine.

Fall he (chief) that must, beneath his (chief) rival's arms; And live the rest, secure of future harms. Two lambs, devoted by your country's rite,

To earth a sable, to the sun a white, Prepare, ye Trojans! while a third we bring Select to Jove, the inviolable king.

Let reverend Priam in the truce engage, And add the sanction of considerate age; His (reverend) sons are faithless, headlong in debate, And youth itself an empty wavering state; Cool age advances, venerably wise,

Turns on all hands its deep-discerning eyes; Sees what befell, and what may yet befall, Concludes from both, and best provides for all.

The nations hear with rising hopes possess'd, And peaceful prospects dawn in every breast. Within the lines they drew their steeds around,

And from their chariots issued on the ground; Next, all unbuckling the rich mail they wore, Laid their bright arms along the sable shore.

On either side the meeting hosts are seen With lances fix'd, and close the space between. Two heralds now, despatch'd to Troy, invite The Phrygian monarch to the peaceful rite.

Meantime to beauteous Helen, from the skies The various goddess of the rainbow flies: -LRB-Like fair Laodice in form and face, The loveliest nymph of Priam's royal race:-RRB- Her (goddess) in the palace, at her (goddess) loom she (goddess) found; The golden web her (goddess) own sad story crown'd, The Trojan wars she (goddess) weaved -LRB-herself the prize-RRB- And the dire triumphs of her (goddess) fatal eyes.

Talthybius hastens to the fleet, to bring The lamb for Jove, the inviolable king. To whom the goddess of the painted bow:

``Approach, and view the wondrous scene below!-LRB-112-RRB-

Each hardy Greek, and valiant Trojan knight, So dreadful late, and furious for the fight, Now rest their spears, or lean upon their shields; Ceased is the war, and silent all the fields.

Paris alone and Sparta's king advance, In single fight to toss the beamy lance; Each met in arms, the fate of combat tries, Thy love the motive, and thy charms the prize.

This said, the many-coloured maid inspires Her (maid) husband's love, and wakes her (maid) former fires; Her (maid) country, parents, all that once were dear, Rush to her (maid) thought, and force a tender tear, O'er her (maid) fair face a snowy veil she (maid) threw,

'' (the goddess Approach)

And, softly sighing, from the loom withdrew. Her (maid) handmaids, Clymene and Ćthra, wait Her (maid) silent footsteps to the Scaean gate.

The king the first; Thymoetes at his (king) side; Lampus and Clytius, long in council tried; Panthus, and Hicetaon, once the strong; And next, the wisest of the reverend throng, Antenor grave, and sage Ucalegon, Lean'd on the walls and bask'd before the sun:

Chiefs, who no more in bloody fights engage, But wise through time, and narrative with age, In summer days, like grasshoppers rejoice, A bloodless race, that send a feeble voice.

There sat the seniors of the Trojan race: -LRB-Old Priam's chiefs, and most in Priam's grace,-RRB- These, when the Spartan queen approach'd the tower,

In secret own'd resistless beauty's power: They cried,

``No wonder such celestial charms-LRB-113-RRB- For nine long years have set the world in arms; What winning graces!

what majestic mien! She (queen) moves a goddess, and she (queen) looks a queen! Yet hence, O Heaven, convey that fatal face, And from destruction save the Trojan race.

'' (queen)

The good old Priam welcomed her (queen), and cried, ``Approach, my child, and grace thy father's side. See on the plain thy Grecian spouse appears, The friends and kindred of thy former years.

No crime of thine our present sufferings draws, Not thou, but Heaven's disposing will, the cause The gods these armies and this force employ, The hostile gods conspire the fate of Troy.

But lift thy eyes, and say, what Greek is he (father) -LRB-Far as from hence these aged orbs can see-RRB- Around whose brow such martial graces shine, So tall, so awful, and almost divine!

Though some of larger stature tread the green, None match his (father) grandeur and exalted mien: He (father) seems a monarch, and his (father) country's pride.

Thus ceased the king, and thus the fair replied:

``Before thy presence, father, I appear, With conscious shame and reverential fear.

'' (the king)

Ah! had I died, ere to these walk I fled, False to my country, and my nuptial bed ; My brothers, friends, and daughter left behind, False to them all, to Paris only kind!

For this I mourn, till grief or dire disease Shall waste the form whose fault it was to please! The king of kings, Atrides, you survey, Great in the war, and great in arts of sway:

My brother once, before my days of shame! And oh! that still he (brother) bore a brother's name!'' With wonder Priam view'd the godlike man, Extoll'd the happy prince, and thus began:

``O bless'd Atrides! born to prosperous fate, Successful monarch of a mighty state! How vast thy empire! Of your matchless train What numbers lost, what numbers yet remain!

In ancient time, when Otreus fill'd the throne, When godlike Mygdon led their troops of horse, And I, to join them, raised the Trojan force: Against the manlike Amazons we stood,-LRB-114-RRB-

In Phrygia once were gallant armies known, And Sangar's stream ran purple with their blood. But far inferior those, in martial grace, And strength of numbers, to this Grecian race.

'' (the prince)

This said, once more he (Amazons) view'd the warrior train; ``What's he (Amazons), whose arms lie scatter'd on the plain? Broad is his (Amazons) breast, his (Amazons) shoulders larger spread, Though great Atrides overtops his (Amazons) head.

Nor yet appear his (Amazons) care and conduct small; From rank to rank he (Amazons) moves, and orders all. The stately ram thus measures o'er the ground, And, master of the flock, surveys them round.

Then Helen thus:

``Whom your discerning eyes Have singled out, is Ithacus the wise; A barren island boasts his (master) glorious birth; His (master) fame for wisdom fills the spacious earth.

When, trusting Jove and hospitable laws, To Troy he (master) came, to plead the Grecian cause; -LRB-Great Menelaus urged the same request;-RRB-

My house was honour'd with each royal guest: I knew their persons, and admired their parts, Both brave in arms, and both approved in arts.

'' (Helen/HELEN/Argive Helen)

'' Antenor took the word, and thus began:-LRB-115-RRB-
``Myself, O king! have seen that wondrous man Erect, the Spartan most engaged our view; Ulysses seated, greater reverence drew.

When Atreus' son harangued the listening train, Just was his (son) sense, and his (son) expression plain, His (son) words succinct, yet full, without a fault; He (son) spoke no more than just the thing he (son) ought.

His (son) modest eyes he (son) fix'd upon the ground; As one unskill'd or dumb, he (son) seem'd to stand, Nor raised his (son) head, nor stretch'd his (son) sceptred hand;

But when Ulysses rose, in thought profound,-LRB-116-RRB- But, when he (Ulysses) speaks, what elocution flows! Soft as the fleeces of descending snows,-LRB-117-RRB-

The copious accents fall, with easy art; Melting they fall, and sink into the heart! Wondering we hear, and fix'd in deep surprise, Our ears refute the censure of our eyes.

What chief is that, with giant strength endued, Whose brawny shoulders, and whose swelling chest, And lofty stature, far exceed the rest?

'' (Antenor)

The king then ask'd -LRB-as yet the camp he (king) view'd-RRB- '' '' Ajax the great, -LRB-the beauteous queen replied,-RRB- Himself a host: the Grecian strength and pride.

See! bold Idomeneus superior towers Amid yon circle of his (king) Cretan powers, Great as a god! I saw him (Great) once before, With Menelaus on the Spartan shore.

Yet two are wanting of the numerous train, Whom long my eyes have sought, but sought in vain: Castor and Pollux, first in martial force, One bold on foot, and one renown'd for horse.

The rest I know, and could in order name; All valiant chiefs, and men of mighty fame. My brothers these; the same our native shore, One house contain'd us, as one mother bore.

Perhaps the chiefs, from warlike toils at ease, For distant Troy refused to sail the seas; Perhaps their swords some nobler quarrel draws,

So spoke the fair, nor knew her (mother) brothers' doom;-LRB-118-RRB- Wrapt in the cold embraces of the tomb; Adorn'd with honours in their native shore, Silent they slept, and heard of wars no more.

Ashamed to combat in their sister's cause. '' Meantime the heralds, through the crowded town. Bring the rich wine and destined victims down.

Idaeus' arms the golden goblets press'd,-LRB-119-RRB- Who thus the venerable king address'd:

``Arise, O father of the Trojan state! The nations call, thy joyful people wait To seal the truce, and end the dire debate.

Paris, thy son, and Sparta's king advance, In measured lists to toss the weighty lance; And who his (king) rival shall in arms subdue, His (king) be the dame, and his (king) the treasure too.

Thus with a lasting league our toils may cease, And Troy possess her (people) fertile fields in peace: So shall the Greeks review their native shore,

With grief he (king) heard, and bade the chiefs prepare To join his (king) milk-white coursers to the car; He (king) mounts the seat, Antenor at his (king) side; The gentle steeds through Scaea's gates they guide:-LRB-120-RRB-

Much famed for generous steeds, for beauty more. '' (king)

Next from the car descending on the plain, Amid the Grecian host and Trojan train, Slow they proceed:

On either side a sacred herald stands, The wine they mix, and on each monarch's hands Pour the full urn; then draws the Grecian lord His (lord) cutlass sheathed beside his (lord) ponderous sword; From the sign'd victims crops the curling hair;-LRB-121-RRB-

The heralds part it, and the princes share; Then loudly thus before the attentive bands He (lord) calls the gods, and spreads his (lord) lifted hands:

``O first and greatest power! whom all obey, Who high on Ida's holy mountain sway, Eternal Jove!

the sage Ulysses then Arose, and with him (lord) rose the king of men. and you bright orb that roll From east to west, and view from pole to pole!

Thou mother Earth! and all ye living floods! Infernal furies, and Tartarean gods , Who rule the dead, and horrid woes prepare For perjured kings, and all who falsely swear!

If, by Paris slain, Great Menelaus press the fatal plain; The dame and treasures let the Trojan keep, And Greece returning plough the watery deep.

Hear, and be witness. If by my brother's lance the Trojan bleed, Be his (brother) the wealth and beauteous dame decreed: The appointed fine let Ilion justly pay,

And every age record the signal day. This if the Phrygians shall refuse to yield, Arms must revenge, and Mars decide the field.

With that the chief the tender victims slew, And in the dust their bleeding bodies threw; The vital spirit issued at the wound, And left the members quivering on the ground.

'' (He)

From the same urn they drink the mingled wine, And add libations to the powers divine. While thus their prayers united mount the sky,
``Hear, mighty Jove!

And may their blood, who first the league confound, Shed like this wine, disdain the thirsty ground; May all their consorts serve promiscuous lust, And all their lust be scatter'd as the dust!'' (unknown)

and hear, ye gods on high! Thus either host their imprecations join'd, Which Jove refused, and mingled with the wind. The rites now finish'd, reverend Priam rose, And thus express'd a heart o'ercharged with woes:

``Ye Greeks and Trojans, let the chiefs engage, But spare the weakness of my feeble age: In yonder walls that object let me shun, Nor view the danger of so dear a son.

Whose arms shall conquer and what prince shall fall , Heaven only knows; for heaven disposes all. '' (Priam)

This said, the hoary king no longer stay'd,

But on his (king) car the slaughter'd victims laid: Then seized the reins his (king) gentle steeds to guide, And drove to Troy, Antenor at his (Troy) side.

Bold Hector and Ulysses now dispose The lists of combat, and the ground inclose: Next to decide, by sacred lots prepare, Who first shall launch his (Hector) pointed spear in air.

The people pray with elevated hands, And words like these are heard through all the bands:

``Immortal Jove, high Heaven's superior lord, On lofty Ida's holy mount adored!

Whoe'er involved us in this dire debate, O give that author of the war to fate And shades eternal! let division cease, And joyful nations join in leagues of peace.

'' (the bands)

With eyes averted Hector hastes to turn The lots of fight and shakes the brazen urn. Then, Paris, thine leap'd forth; by fatal chance Ordain'd the first to whirl the weighty lance.

Both armies sat the combat to survey. Beside each chief his (chief) azure armour lay, And round the lists the generous coursers neigh.

With flowers adorn'd, with silver buckles bound: Lycaon's corslet his (chief) fair body dress'd, Braced in and fitted to his (chief) softer breast; A radiant baldric, o'er his (chief) shoulder tied, Sustain'd the sword that glitter'd at his (chief) side: His (chief) youthful face a polish'd helm o'erspread; The waving horse-hair nodded on his (chief) head:

The beauteous warrior now arrays for fight, In gilded arms magnificently bright: The purple cuishes clasp his (chief) thighs around, His (chief) figured shield, a shining orb, he (chief) takes,

And in his (chief) hand a pointed javelin shakes. With equal speed and fired by equal charms, The Spartan hero sheathes his (hero) limbs in arms.

Now round the lists the admiring armies stand, With javelins fix'd, the Greek and Trojan band. Amidst the dreadful vale, the chiefs advance, All pale with rage, and shake the threatening lance.

Full on Atrides' ringing shield it flew, Nor pierced the brazen orb, but with a bound-LRB-122-RRB- Leap'd from the buckler, blunted, on the ground.

The Trojan first his (hero) shining javelin threw; Atrides then his (hero) massy lance prepares, In act to throw, but first prefers his (hero) prayers:

``Give me, great Jove!

to punish lawless lust, And lay the Trojan gasping in the dust: Destroy the aggressor, aid my righteous cause, Avenge the breach of hospitable laws!

Be said, and poised in air the javelin sent, Through Paris' shield the forceful weapon went, His (aggressor) corslet pierces, and his (aggressor) garment rends, And glancing downward, near his (aggressor) flank descends.

Let this example future times reclaim, And guard from wrong fair friendship's holy name. '' (Atrides)

The wary Trojan, bending from the blow, Eludes the death, and disappoints his (aggressor) foe:

But fierce Atrides waved his (aggressor) sword, and strook Full on his (aggressor) casque: the crested helmet shook ; The brittle steel, unfaithful to his (aggressor) hand, Broke short: the fragments glitter'd on the sand.

The raging warrior to the spacious skies Raised his (warrior) upbraiding voice and angry eyes:

``Then is it vain in Jove himself to trust?

And is it thus the gods assist the just? When crimes provoke us, Heaven success denies; The dart falls harmless, and the falchion flies.

'' (The warrior)

Furious he (warrior) said, and towards the Grecian crew -LRB-Seized by the crest-RRB- the unhappy warrior drew; Struggling he (warrior) followed, while the embroider'd thong That tied his (warrior) helmet, dragg'd the chief along.

Then had his (warrior) ruin crown'd Atrides' joy, But Venus trembled for the prince of Troy: Unseen she (Venus) came, and burst the golden band; And left an empty helmet in his (warrior) hand.

The casque, enraged, amidst the Greeks he (warrior) threw; The Greeks with smiles the polish'd trophy view. Then, as once more he (warrior) lifts the deadly dart,

In thirst of vengeance, at his (warrior) rival's heart; The queen of love her (queen) favour'd champion shrouds -LRB-For gods can all things-RRB- in a veil of clouds.

Raised from the field the panting youth she (queen) led, And gently laid him (warrior) on the bridal bed, With pleasing sweets his (warrior) fainting sense renews,

Meantime the brightest of the female kind, The matchless Helen, o'er the walls reclined; To her (Helen), beset with Trojan beauties, came,

And all the dome perfumes with heavenly dews. In borrow'd form, the laughter-loving dame. -LRB-She (Helen) seem'd an ancient maid, well-skill'd to cull The snowy fleece, and wind the twisted wool.-RRB-

The goddess softly shook her (goddess) silken vest, That shed perfumes, and whispering thus address'd: -LSB-Illustration: VENUS, DISGUISED, INVITING HELEN TO THE CHAMBER OF PARIS.-RSB-

Safe from the fight, in yonder lofty walls, Fair as a god; with odours round him (god) spread, He (god) lies, and waits thee on the well-known bed; Not like a warrior parted from the foe, But some gay dancer in the public show.

VENUS, DISGUISED, INVITING HELEN TO THE CHAMBER OF PARIS. '' Haste, happy nymph! for thee thy Paris calls, '' She (HELEN) spoke, and Helen's secret soul was moved; She (Helen) scorn'd the champion, but the man she (Helen) loved.

Fair Venus' neck, her (Venus) eyes that sparkled fire, And breast, reveal'd the queen of soft desire.-LRB-123-RRB- Struck with her (Venus) presence, straight the lively red Forsook her (Venus) cheek; and trembling, thus she (Venus) said:

``Then is it still thy pleasure to deceive?

And woman's frailty always to believe! Say, to new nations must I cross the main, Or carry wars to some soft Asian plain?

For whom must Helen break her (Helen) second vow? What other Paris is thy darling now? Left to Atrides, -LRB-victor in the strife,-RRB-

An odious conquest and a captive wife, Hence let me sail; and if thy Paris bear My absence ill, let Venus ease his (victor) care.

A handmaid goddess at his (victor) side to wait, Renounce the glories of thy heavenly state, Be fix'd for ever to the Trojan shore, His (victor) spouse, or slave; and mount the skies no more.

For me, to lawless love no longer led, I scorn the coward, and detest his (coward) bed; Else should I merit everlasting shame, And keen reproach, from every Phrygian dame:
