Ill suits it now the joys of love to know, Too deep my anguish, and too wild my woe.'' (she)

-LSB-Illustration: VENUS PRESENTING HELEN TO PARIS.-RSB-

``Obey the power from whom thy glories rise: Should Venus leave thee, every charm must fly, Fade from thy cheek, and languish in thy eye.

Cease to provoke me, lest I make thee more The world's aversion, than their love before; Now the bright prize for which mankind engage, Than, the sad victim, of the public rage.

At this, the fairest of her (Venus) sex obey'd, And veil'd her (Venus) blushes in a silken shade; Unseen, and silent, from the train she (Venus) moves, Led by the goddess of the Smiles and Loves.

VENUS PRESENTING HELEN TO PARIS. Then thus incensed, the Paphian queen replies: '' (The maids)

Arrived, and enter'd at the palace gate, The maids officious round their mistress wait

; Then, all dispersing, various tasks attend; The queen and goddess to the prince ascend. Full in her (goddess) Paris' sight, the queen of love Had placed the beauteous progeny of Jove; Where, as he (prince) view'd

her (goddess) charms, she (goddess) turn'd away Her (goddess) glowing eyes, and thus began to say: ``Is this the chief, who, lost to sense of shame, Late fled the field, and yet survives his (chief) fame?

O hadst thou died beneath the righteous sword Of that brave man whom once I call'd my lord! The boaster Paris oft desired the day

With Sparta's king to meet in single fray: Go now, once more thy rival's rage excite, Provoke Atrides, and renew the fight:

The prince replies:

``Ah cease, divinely fair, Nor add reproaches to the wounds I bear; This day the foe prevail'd by Pallas' power: We yet may vanquish in a happier hour: There want not gods to favour us above; But let the business of our life be love: These softer moments let delights employ, And kind embraces snatch the hasty joy.

Yet Helen bids thee stay, lest thou unskill'd Shouldst fall an easy conquest on the field. '' (The prince)

Not thus I loved thee, when from Sparta's shore

My forced, my willing heavenly prize I bore, When first entranced in Cranae's isle I lay,-LRB-124-RRB- Mix'd with thy soul, and all dissolved away!''

Thus having spoke, the enamour'd Phrygian boy Rush'd to the bed, impatient for the joy. Him (boy) Helen follow'd slow with bashful charms,

While these to love's delicious rapture yield, The stern Atrides rages round the field: So some fell lion whom the woods obey, Roars through the desert, and demands his (boy) prey.

And clasp'd the blooming hero in her (Helen) arms. Paris he (boy) seeks, impatient to destroy, But seeks in vain along the troops of Troy

; Even those had yielded to a foe so brave The recreant warrior, hateful as the grave. Then speaking thus, the king of kings arose,

``Ye Trojans, Dardans, all our generous foes!

Hear and attest! from Heaven with conquest crown'd, Our brother's arms the just success have found: Be therefore now the Spartan wealth restor'd

, Let Argive Helen own her (Helen) lawful lord; The appointed fine let Ilion justly pay, And age to age record this signal day.

'' (kings)

He (lord) ceased; his (lord) army's loud applauses rise, And the long shout runs echoing through the skies. -LSB-Illustration: VENUS.-RSB- VENUS. -LSB-Illustration: Map, titled
``Graeciae Antiquae'' (unknown)
.-RSB-

The gods deliberate in council concerning the Trojan war: they agree upon the continuation of it, and Jupiter sends down Minerva to break the truce.

Map, titled

``Graeciae Antiquae'' (unknown)
. BOOK IV. ARGUMENT. THE BREACH OF THE TRUCE, AND THE FIRST BATTLE. She (Minerva) persuades Pandarus to aim an arrow at Menelaus, who is wounded, but cured by Machaon.

Agamemnon is distinguished in all the parts of a good general; he (Agamemnon) reviews the troops, and exhorts the leaders, some by praises and others by reproof.

In the meantime some of the Trojan troops attack the Greeks. Nestor is particularly celebrated for his (Nestor) military discipline. The battle joins, and great numbers are slain on both sides.

The same day continues through this as through the last book -LRB-as it does also through the two following, and almost to the end of the seventh book-RRB-.

And now Olympus' shining gates unfold; The gods, with Jove, assume their thrones of gold: Immortal Hebe, fresh with bloom divine, The golden goblet crowns with purple wine: While the full bowls flow round, the powers employ Their careful eyes on long-contended Troy.

When Jove, disposed to tempt Saturnia's spleen, Thus waked the fury of his (Jove) partial queen,

``Two powers divine the son of Atreus aid, Imperial Juno, and the martial maid;-LRB-125-RRB-

The scene is wholly in the field before Troy. But high in heaven they sit, and gaze from far, The tame spectators of his (Jove) deeds of war.

Not thus fair Venus helps her (maid) favour'd knight, The queen of pleasures shares the toils of fight, Each danger wards, and constant in her (maid) care, Saves in the moment of the last despair.

Her (maid) act has rescued Paris' forfeit life, Though great Atrides gain'd the glorious strife. Then say, ye powers! what signal issue waits

To crown this deed, and finish all the fates! Shall Heaven by peace the bleeding kingdoms spare, Or rouse the furies, and awake the war?

Yet, would the gods for human good provide, Atrides soon might gain his (maid) beauteous bride, Still Priam's walls in peaceful honours grow, And through his (maid) gates the crowding nations flow.

Thus while he (maid) spoke, the queen of heaven, enraged, And queen of war, in close consult engaged: Apart they sit, their deep designs employ, And meditate the future woes of Troy.

Minerva's breast, The prudent goddess yet her (goddess) wrath suppress'd; But Juno, impotent of passion, broke Her (goddess) sullen silence, and with fury spoke:

'' (queen)

Though secret anger swell'd -LSB-Illustration: THE COUNCIL OF THE GODS.-RSB- THE COUNCIL OF THE GODS. '' Shall then, O tyrant of the ethereal reign!

My schemes, my labours, and my hopes be vain? Have I, for this, shook Ilion with alarms, Assembled nations, set two worlds in arms?

To spread the war, I flew from shore to shore; The immortal coursers scarce the labour bore. At length ripe vengeance o'er their heads impends, But Jove himself the faithless race defends.

Loth as thou art to punish lawless lust, Not all the gods are partial and unjust. '' The sire whose thunder shakes the cloudy skies, Sighs from his (sire) inmost soul, and thus replies:

``Oh lasting rancour! oh insatiate hate To Phrygia's monarch, and the Phrygian state! What high offence has fired the wife of Jove?

Can wretched mortals harm the powers above, That Troy, and Troy's whole race thou wouldst confound, And yon fair structures level with the ground!

Haste, leave the skies, fulfil thy stern desire, Burst all her (wife) gates, and wrap her (wife) walls in fire! Let Priam bleed!

if yet you thirst for more, Bleed all his (monarch) sons, and Ilion float with gore: To boundless vengeance the wide realm be given,

Till vast destruction glut the queen of heaven! So let it be, and Jove his (monarch) peace enjoy,-LRB-126-RRB- When heaven no longer hears the name of Troy.

On thy loved realms, whose guilt demands their fate; Presume not thou the lifted bolt to stay, Remember Troy, and give the vengeance way.

For know, of all the numerous towns that rise Beneath the rolling sun and starry skies, Which gods have raised, or earth-born men enjoy, None stands so dear to Jove as sacred Troy.

But should this arm prepare to wreak our hate No mortals merit more distinguish'd grace Than godlike Priam, or than Priam's race.

At this the goddess rolled her (goddess) radiant eyes, Then on the Thunderer fix'd them, and replies:

``Three towns are Juno's on the Grecian plains, More dear than all the extended earth contains, Mycenae, Argos, and the Spartan wall;-LRB-127-RRB-

Still to our name their hecatombs expire, And altars blaze with unextinguish'd fire. '' (Thunderer)

These thou mayst raze, nor I forbid their fall: 'Tis not in me the vengeance to remove;

The crime's sufficient that they share my love. Of power superior why should I complain? Resent I may, but must resent in vain.

Yet some distinction Juno might require, Sprung with thyself from one celestial sire, A goddess born, to share the realms above, And styled the consort of the thundering Jove; Nor thou a wife and sister's

Let both consent, and both by terms comply; So shall the gods our joint decrees obey, And heaven shall act as we direct the way.

See ready Pallas waits thy high commands To raise in arms the Greek and Phrygian bands; Their sudden friendship by her (sister) arts may cease,

The advice approved, and bade Minerva fly, Dissolve the league, and all her (Minerva) arts employ To make the breach the faithless act of Troy.

right deny;-LRB-128-RRB- And the proud Trojans first infringe the peace. '' The sire of men and monarch of the sky Fired with the charge, she (Minerva) headlong urged her (Minerva) flight, And shot like lightning from Olympus' height.

As the red comet, from Saturnius sent To fright the nations with a dire portent, -LRB-A fatal sign to armies on the plain, Or trembling sailors on the wintry main,-RRB- With sweeping glories glides along in air, And shakes the sparkles from its blazing hair:-LRB-129-RRB-

Between both armies thus, in open sight Shot the bright goddess in a trail of light, With eyes erect the gazing hosts admire The power descending, and the heavens on fire!

The gods -LRB-they cried-RRB-, the gods this signal sent, And fate now labours with some vast event: Jove seals the league, or bloodier scenes prepares;

'' Jove, the great arbiter of peace and wars. '' They said, while Pallas through the Trojan throng, -LRB-In shape a mortal,-RRB- pass'd disguised along.

Like bold Laodocus, her (goddess) course she (goddess) bent, Who from Antenor traced his (goddess) high descent. Amidst the ranks Lycaon's son she (goddess) found,

The warlike Pandarus, for strength renown'd; Whose squadrons, led from black Ćsepus' flood,-LRB-130-RRB- With flaming shields in martial circle stood. To him (goddess) the goddess:

``Phrygian!

canst thou hear A well-timed counsel with a willing ear? What praise were thine, couldst thou direct thy dart, Amidst his (counsel) triumph, to the Spartan's heart?

What gifts from Troy, from Paris wouldst thou gain, Thy country's foe, the Grecian glory slain? Then seize the occasion, dare the mighty deed, Aim at his (foe) breast, and may that aim succeed!

But first, to speed the shaft, address thy vow To Lycian Phoebus with the silver bow, And swear the firstlings of thy flock to pay, On Zelia's altars, to the god of day.'' (the goddess)

-LRB-131-RRB-

He (god) heard, and madly at the motion pleased, His (god) polish'd bow with hasty rashness seized. ' Twas form'd of horn, and smooth'd with artful toil:

Who pierced long since beneath his (god) arrows bled; The stately quarry on the cliffs lay dead, And sixteen palms his (god) brow's large honours spread: The workmen join'd, and shaped the bended horns, And beaten gold each taper point adorns.

This, by the Greeks unseen, the warrior bends, Screen'd by the shields of his (warrior) surrounding friends: There meditates the mark; and couching low, Fits the sharp arrow to the well-strung bow.

One from a hundred feather'd deaths he (warrior) chose, Fated to wound, and cause of future woes; Then offers vows with hecatombs to crown Apollo's altars in his (warrior) native town.

Now with full force the yielding horn he (warrior) bends, Drawn to an arch, and joins the doubling ends; Close to his (warrior) breast he (warrior) strains the nerve below,

Till the barb'd points approach the circling bow; The impatient weapon whizzes on the wing; Sounds the tough horn, and twangs the quivering string.

A mountain goat resign'd the shining spoil. But thee, Atrides! in that dangerous hour The gods forget not, nor thy guardian power, Pallas assists, and -LRB-weakened in its force-RRB-

Diverts the weapon from its destined course: So from her (thee) babe, when slumber seals his (warrior) eye, The watchful mother wafts the envenom'd fly.

the shaft, which, hissing from above, Pass'd the broad belt, and through the corslet drove; The folds it pierced, the plaited linen tore,

Just where his (warrior) belt with golden buckles join'd, Where linen folds the double corslet lined, She (mother) turn'd And razed the skin, and drew the purple gore.

As when some stately trappings are decreed To grace a monarch on his (monarch) bounding steed, A nymph in Caria or Maeonia bred, Stains the pure ivory with a lively red; With equal lustre various colours vie, The shining whiteness, and the Tyrian dye: So great Atrides!

With horror seized, the king of men descried The shaft infix'd, and saw the gushing tide: Nor less the Spartan fear'd, before he (king) found The shining barb appear above the wound, Then, with a sigh, that heaved his (king) manly breast,

The royal brother thus his (king) grief express'd, And grasp'd his (king) hand; while all the Greeks around With answering sighs return'd the plaintive sound.

show'd thy sacred blood, As down thy snowy thigh distill'd the streaming flood. '' Oh, dear as life! did I for this agree The solemn truce, a fatal truce to thee!

Wert thou exposed to all the hostile train, To fight for Greece, and conquer, to be slain! The race of Trojans in thy ruin join, And faith is scorn'd by all the perjured line.

, Those hands we plighted, and those oaths we swore, Shall all be vain: when Heaven's revenge is slow, Jove but prepares to strike the fiercer blow.

The day shall come, that great avenging day, When Troy's proud glories in the dust shall lay, When Priam's powers and Priam's self shall fall, And one prodigious ruin swallow all.

Not thus our vows, confirm'd with wine and gore I see the god, already, from the pole Bare his (god) red arm, and bid the thunder roll

; I see the Eternal all his (god) fury shed, And shake his (god) aegis o'er their guilty head. Such mighty woes on perjured princes wait;

But thou, alas! deserv`st a happier fate. Still must I mourn the period of thy days, And only mourn, without my share of praise?

Deprived of thee, the heartless Greeks no more Shall dream of conquests on the hostile shore; Troy seized of Helen, and our glory lost, Thy bones shall moulder on a foreign coast; While some proud Trojan thus insulting cries, -LRB-And spurns the dust where Menelaus lies,-RRB- '

Such are the trophies Greece from Ilion brings, And such the conquest of her (Helen) king of kings! Lo his (Lo) proud vessels

scatter'd o'er the main, And unrevenged, his (Lo) mighty brother slain.' Oh! ere that dire disgrace shall blast my fame, O'erwhelm me, earth! and hide a monarch's shame.

He (monarch) said: a leader's and a brother's fears Possess his (monarch) soul, which thus the Spartan cheers:

``Let not thy words the warmth of Greece abate; The feeble dart is guiltless of my fate: Stiff with the rich embroider'd work around, My varied belt repell'd the flying wound.

'' (a brother)

'' To whom the king: ``My brother and my friend, Thus, always thus, may Heaven thy life defend! Now seek some skilful hand, whose powerful art May stanch the effusion, and extract the dart.

Herald, be swift, and bid Machaon bring His (brother) speedy succour to the Spartan king; Pierced with a winged shaft -LRB-the deed of Troy-RRB-, The Grecian's sorrow, and the Dardan's joy.

With hasty zeal the swift Talthybius flies; Through the thick files he (brother) darts his (brother) searching eyes, And finds Machaon, where sublime he (brother) stands-LRB-132-RRB-

Then thus:

``Machaon, to the king repair, His (king) wounded brother claims thy timely care; Pierced by some Lycian or Dardanian bow, A grief to us, a triumph to the foe.

'' (he)

In arms incircled with his (foe) native bands. '' The heavy tidings grieved the godlike man Swift to his (Swift) succour through the ranks he (Swift) ran.

The dauntless king yet standing firm he (Swift) found, And all the chiefs in deep concern around. Where to the steely point the reed was join'd,

Straight the broad belt with gay embroidery graced, He (Swift) loosed; the corslet from his (Swift) breast unbraced; Then suck'd the blood, and sovereign balm infused,-LRB-133-RRB-

While round the prince the Greeks employ their care, The Trojans rush tumultuous to the war; Once more they glitter in refulgent arms, Once more the fields are fill'd with dire alarms.

The shaft he (prince) drew, but left the head behind. Which Chiron gave, and Ćsculapius used. Nor had you seen the king of men appear Confused, unactive, or surprised with fear;

No longer with his (king) warlike steeds he (king) stay'd, Or press'd the car with polish'd brass inlaid But left Eurymedon the reins to guide; The fiery coursers snorted at his (king) side.

But fond of glory, with severe delight, His (king) beating bosom claim'd the rising fight. On foot through all the martial ranks he (king) moves

he (king) cries, -LRB-to such who boldly dare Urge their swift steeds to face the coming war-RRB-,

``Your ancient valour on the foes approve; Jove is with Greece, and let us trust in Jove. '

, Whose crimes sit heavy on her (king) perjured head; Her (king) sons and matrons Greece shall lead in chains, And her (king) dead warriors strew the mournful plains.

And these encourages, and those reproves. '' (he)

Brave men! '' Tis not for us, but guilty Troy, to dread '' Thus with new ardour he (king) the brave inspires; Or thus the fearful with reproaches fires:

``Shame to your country, scandal of your kind; Born to the fate ye well deserve to find! Why stand ye gazing round the dreadful plain, Prepared for flight, but doom'd to fly in vain?

Confused and panting thus, the hunted deer Falls as he (king) flies, a victim to his (king) fear. Still must ye wait the foes, and still retire, Till yon tall vessels blaze with Trojan fire?

This said, he (king) stalk'd with ample strides along, To Crete's brave monarch and his (king) martial throng; High at their head he (king) saw the chief appear, And bold Meriones excite the rear.

Or trust ye , Jove a valiant foe shall chase, To save a trembling, heartless, dastard race?'' (he)

At this the king his (king) generous joy

express'd, And clasp'd the warrior to his (king) armed breast. '' Divine Idomeneus! what thanks we owe To worth like thine! what praise shall we bestow?

For this, in banquets, when the generous bowls Restore our blood, and raise the warriors' souls, Though all the rest with stated rules we bound, Unmix'd, unmeasured, are thy goblets crown'd.

To thee the foremost honours are decreed, First in the fight and every graceful deed. Be still thyself, in arms a mighty name; Maintain thy honours, and enlarge thy fame.

'' To whom the Cretan thus his (Cretan) speech address'd:

``Secure of me, O king! exhort the rest. Fix'd to thy side, in every toil I share, Thy firm associate in the day of war.

But let the signal be this moment given; To mix in fight is all I ask of Heaven. The field shall prove how perjuries succeed, And chains or death avenge the impious deed.

Charm'd with this heat, the king his (king) course pursues, And next the troops of either Ajax views: In one firm orb the bands were ranged around,

'' (the Cretan)

A cloud of heroes blacken'd all the ground. Thus from the lofty promontory's brow A swain surveys the gathering storm below;

Slow from the main the heavy vapours rise, Spread in dim streams, and sail along the skies, Till black as night the swelling tempest shows, The cloud condensing as the west-wind blows:

He (swain) dreads the impending storm, and drives his (swain) flock To the close covert of an arching rock. Such, and so thick, the embattled squadrons stood,

With spears erect, a moving iron wood: A shady light was shot from glimmering shields, And their brown arms obscured the dusky fields.

Whose godlike virtue we but urge in vain, -LRB-Exclaim'd the king-RRB-, who raise your eager bands With great examples, more than loud commands.

would the gods but breathe in all the rest Such souls as burn in your exalted breast, Soon should our arms with just success be

'' O heroes! worthy such a dauntless train, Ah! crown'd, And Troy's proud walls lie smoking on the ground. '' Then to the next the general bends his (king) course; -LRB-His (king) heart exults, and glories in his (king) force-RRB-

; There reverend Nestor ranks his (Nestor) Pylian bands, And with inspiring eloquence commands; With strictest order sets his (Nestor) train in arms, The chiefs advises, and the soldiers warms.

The horse and chariots to the front assign'd, The foot -LRB-the strength of war-RRB- he (Nestor) ranged behind; The middle space suspected troops supply, Inclosed by both, nor left the power to fly; He (Nestor) gives command to

``curb the fiery steed, Nor cause confusion, nor the ranks exceed: Before the rest let none too rashly ride; No strength nor skill, but just in time, be tried: The charge once made, no warrior turn the rein,

Alastor, Chromius, Haemon, round him (warrior) wait, Bias the good, and Pelagon the great. But fight, or fall; a firm embodied train.

He (warrior) whom the fortune of the field shall cast From forth his (warrior) chariot, mount the next in haste; Nor seek unpractised to direct the car, Content with javelins to provoke the war.

Our great forefathers held this prudent course, Thus ruled their ardour, thus preserved their force; By laws like these immortal conquests made, And earth's proud tyrants low in ashes laid.

'' (He)

So spoke the master of the martial art, And touch'd with transport great Atrides' heart. '' Oh! hadst thou strength to match thy brave desires, And nerves to second what thy soul inspires!

But wasting years, that wither human race, Exhaust thy spirits, and thy arms unbrace. What once thou wert, oh ever mightst thou be!

Thus to the experienced prince Atrides cried; He (prince) shook his (prince) hoary locks, and thus replied:

``Well might I wish, could mortal wish renew-LRB-134-RRB-

That strength which once in boiling youth I knew; Such as I was, when Ereuthalion, slain Beneath this arm, fell prostrate on the plain.

But heaven its gifts not all at once bestows, These years with wisdom crowns, with action those: The field of combat fits the young and bold, The solemn council best becomes the old:

And age the lot of any chief but thee. '' (He)

To you the glorious conflict I resign, Let sage advice, the palm of age, be mine.

With joy the monarch march'd before, And found Menestheus on the dusty shore, With whom the firm Athenian phalanx stands; And next Ulysses, with his (Ulysses) subject bands.

Remote their forces lay, nor knew so far The peace infringed, nor heard the sounds of war; The tumult late begun, they stood intent

The king, who saw their squadrons yet unmoved, With hasty ardour thus the chiefs reproved:

``Can Peleus' son forget a warrior's part.

'' (the chiefs)

He (son) said. To watch the motion, dubious of the event. And fears Ulysses, skill'd in every art? Why stand you distant, and the rest expect To mix in combat which yourselves neglect?

From you 'twas hoped among the first to dare The shock of armies, and commence the war; For this your names are call'd before the rest, To share the pleasures of the genial feast:

And can you, chiefs! without a blush survey Whole troops before you labouring in the fray? Say, is it thus those honours you requite?

The first in banquets, but the last in fight. '' Ulysses heard: the hero's warmth o'erspread His (Ulysses) cheek with blushes: and severe, he (Ulysses) said:

``Take back the unjust reproach!

Behold we stand Sheathed in bright arms, and but expect command. If glorious deeds afford thy soul delight, Behold me plunging in the thickest fight.

Then give thy warrior-chief a warrior's due, Who dares to act whate'er thou dar`st to view. '' (he)

Struck with his (warrior) generous wrath, the king replies:
``O great in action, and in council wise!

With ours, thy care and ardour are the same, Nor need I to commend, nor aught to blame. Sage as thou art, and learn'd in human kind, Forgive the transport of a martial mind.

He (warrior) said, and pass'd where great Tydides lay, His (warrior) steeds and chariots wedged in firm array; -LRB-The warlike Sthenelus attends his (warrior) side;-RRB--LRB-135-RRB-

Haste to the fight, secure of just amends; The gods that make, shall keep the worthy, friends. '' (the king)

To whom with stern reproach the monarch cried: ``O son of Tydeus!

-LRB-he (monarch), whose strength could tame The bounding steed, in arms a mighty name-RRB- Canst thou, remote, the mingling hosts descry, With hands unactive, and a careless eye?

Not thus thy sire the fierce encounter fear'd ; Still first in front the matchless prince appear'd : What glorious toils, what wonders they recite, Who view'd

I saw him (prince) once, when gathering martial powers, A peaceful guest, he (guest) sought Mycenae's towers; Armies he (guest) ask'd, and armies had been given, Not we denied, but Jove forbade from heaven; While dreadful comets glaring from afar, Forewarn'd the horrors of the Theban war.-LRB-136-RRB-

him (guest) labouring through the ranks of fight? Next, sent by Greece from where Asopus flows, A fearless envoy, he (envoy) approach'd the foes; Thebes' hostile walls unguarded and alone, Dauntless he (envoy) enters, and demands the throne.

And dared to combat all those chiefs around: Dared, and subdued before their haughty lord; For Pallas strung his (lord) arm and edged his (lord) sword.

To bar his (lord) passage fifty warriors lay; Two heroes led the secret squadron on, Mason the fierce, and hardy Lycophon; Those fifty slaughter'd in the gloomy vale.

The tyrant feasting with his (tyrant) chiefs he (tyrant) found, Stung with the shame, within the winding way, He (tyrant) spared but one to bear the dreadful tale, Such Tydeus was, and such his (tyrant) martial fire;

But heard respectful, and in secret burn'd: Not so fierce Capaneus' undaunted son; Stern as his (Stern) sire, the boaster thus begun:

``What needs, O monarch!

Gods! how the son degenerates from the sire!'' (the boaster)

No words the godlike Diomed return'd, this invidious praise, Ourselves to lessen, while our sire you raise?

Dare to be just, Atrides! and confess Our value equal, though our fury less. With fewer troops we storm'd the Theban wall, And happier saw the sevenfold city fall,-LRB-137-RRB-

In impious acts the guilty father died; The sons subdued, for Heaven was on their side. Far more than heirs of all our parents' fame, Our glories darken their diminish'd name.

: His (father) high concern may well excuse this rage, Whose cause we follow, and whose war we wage: His (father) the first praise, were Ilion's towers o'erthrown, And, if we fail, the chief disgrace his (chief) own.

'' To him (chief) Tydides thus:

``My friend, forbear; Suppress thy passion, and the king revere Let him (king) the Greeks to hardy toils excite, 'Tis ours to labour in the glorious fight.

'' (Tydides)

He (king) spoke, and ardent, on the trembling ground Sprung from his (king) car: his (king) ringing arms resound. Dire was the clang, and dreadful from afar, Of arm'd Tydides rushing to the war.

As when the winds, ascending by degrees,-LRB-138-RRB- First move the whitening surface of the seas, The billows float in order to the shore, The wave behind rolls on the wave before; Till, with the growing storm, the deeps arise, Foam o'er the rocks, and thunder to the skies.

So to the fight the thick battalions throng, Shields urged on shields, and men drove men along Sedate and silent move the numerous bands;

No sound, no whisper, but the chief's commands, Those only heard; with awe the rest obey, As if some god had snatch'd their voice away.

As when the fleecy flocks unnumber'd stand In wealthy folds, and wait the milker's hand, The hollow vales incessant bleating fills, The lambs reply from all the neighbouring hills: Such clamours rose from various nations round, Mix'd was the murmur, and confused the sound.

Each host now joins, and each a god inspires, These Mars incites, and those Minerva fires, Pale flight around, and dreadful terror reign; And discord raging bathes the purple plain; Discord!

Not so the Trojans; from their host ascends A general shout that all the region rends. dire sister of the slaughtering power,

Small at her (sister) birth, but rising every hour, While scarce the skies her (sister) horrid head can bound, She (sister) stalks on earth, and shakes the world around;-LRB-139-RRB-

The nations bleed, where'er her (sister) steps she (sister) turns, The groan still deepens, and the combat burns. Now shield with shield, with helmet helmet closed, To armour armour, lance to lance opposed,

Host against host with shadowy squadrons drew, The sounding darts in iron tempests flew, Victors and vanquish'd join'd promiscuous cries, And shrilling shouts and dying groans arise; With streaming blood the slippery fields are dyed, And slaughter'd heroes swell the dreadful tide.

As torrents roll, increased by numerous rills, With rage impetuous, down their echoing hills Rush to the vales, and pour'd along the plain.

Roar through a thousand channels to the main: The distant shepherd trembling hears the sound; So mix both hosts, and so their cries rebound.

The bold Antilochus the slaughter led, The first who struck a valiant Trojan dead: At great Echepolus the lance arrives, Razed his (shepherd) high crest, and through his (shepherd) helmet drives; Warm'd in the brain the brazen weapon lies, And shades eternal settle o'er his (shepherd) eyes.

So sinks a tower, that long assaults had stood Of force and fire , its walls besmear'd with blood. Him (shepherd), the bold leader of the Abantian throng,-LRB-140-RRB- Seized to despoil, and dragg'd the corpse along:

His (shepherd) flank, unguarded by his (shepherd) ample shield, Admits the lance: he (shepherd) falls, and spurns the field; The nerves, unbraced, support his (shepherd) limbs no more; The soul comes floating in a tide of gore.

Trojans and Greeks now gather round the slain; The war renews, the warriors bleed again: As o'er their prey rapacious wolves engage, Man dies on man, and all is blood and rage.

But while he (Man) strove to tug the inserted dart, Agenor's javelin reach'd the hero's heart. In blooming youth fair Simoisius fell, Sent by great Ajax to the shades of hell;

Fair Simoisius, whom his (Man) mother bore Amid the flocks on silver Simois' shore: The nymph descending from the hills of Ide, To seek her (mother) parents on his (Man) flowery side, Brought forth the babe, their common care and joy, And thence from Simois named the lovely boy.

So falls a poplar, that in watery ground Raised high the head, with stately branches crown'd, -LRB-Fell'd by some artist with his (artist) shining steel, To shape the circle of the bending wheel,-RRB- Cut down it lies, tall, smooth, and largely spread, With all its beauteous honours on its head There, left a subject to the wind and rain, And scorch'd by suns, it withers on the plain

Short was his (Short) date! by dreadful Ajax slain, He (Short) falls, and renders all their cares in vain! Thus pierced by Ajax, Simoisius lies

Stretch'd on the shore, and thus neglected dies. At Ajax, Antiphus his (Short) javelin threw; The pointed lance with erring fury flew, And Leucus, loved by wise Ulysses, slew.

This saw Ulysses, and with grief enraged, Strode where the foremost of the foes engaged; Arm'd with his (Ulysses) spear, he (Ulysses) meditates the wound,

In act to throw; but cautious look'd around, Struck at his (Struck) sight the Trojans backward drew, And trembling heard the javelin as it flew.

He (Struck) drops the corpse of Simoisius slain, And sinks a breathless carcase on the plain. A chief stood nigh, who from Abydos came, Old Priam's son, Democoon was his (son) name.

The weapon entered close above his (son) ear, Cold through his (son) temples glides the whizzing spear;-LRB-141-RRB- With piercing shrieks the youth resigns his (son) breath, His (son) eye-balls darken with the shades of death; Ponderous he (son) falls;

Seized with affright the boldest foes appear; E'en godlike Hector seems himself to fear; Slow he (Hector) gave way, the rest tumultuous fled; The Greeks with shouts press on, and spoil the dead: But Phoebus now from Ilion's towering height Shines forth reveal'd, and animates the fight.

his (Hector) clanging arms resound, And his (Hector) broad buckler rings against the ground. '' Trojans, be bold, and force with force oppose;

Your foaming steeds urge headlong on the foes! Nor are their bodies rocks, nor ribb'd with steel; Your weapons enter, and your strokes they feel.

Have ye forgot what seem'd your dread before? The great, the fierce Achilles fights no more. '' Apollo thus from Ilion's lofty towers, Array'd in terrors, roused the Trojan powers:

While war's fierce goddess fires the Grecian foe, And shouts and thunders in the fields below. Then great Diores fell, by doom divine, In vain his (foe) valour and illustrious line.

A broken rock the force of Pyrus threw, -LRB-Who from cold Ćnus led the Thracian crew,-RRB--LRB-142-RRB- Full on his (foe) ankle dropp'd

Supine he (foe) tumbles on the crimson sands, Before his (foe) helpless friends, and native bands, And spreads for aid his (foe) unavailing hands.

the ponderous stone, Burst the strong nerves, and crash'd the solid bone. The foe rush'd furious as he (foe) pants for breath,

And through his (foe) navel drove the pointed death: His (foe) gushing entrails smoked upon the ground, And the warm life came issuing from the wound.

His (foe) lance bold Thoas at the conqueror sent, Deep in his (foe) breast above the pap it went, Amid the lungs was fix'd the winged wood, And quivering in his (foe) heaving bosom stood:

Till from the dying chief, approaching near, The Ćtolian warrior tugg'd his (warrior) weighty spear: Then sudden waved his (warrior) flaming falchion round,

To spoil his (warrior) arms the victor strove in vain; The Thracian bands against the victor press'd, A grove of lances glitter'd at his (victor) breast.

And gash'd his (victor) belly with a ghastly wound; The corpse now breathless on the bloody plain, Stern Thoas, glaring with revengeful eyes, In sullen fury slowly quits the prize.

Thus fell two heroes; one the pride of Thrace, And one the leader of the Epeian race; Death's sable shade at once o'ercast their eyes, In dust the vanquish'd and the victor lies.

Had some brave chief this martial scene beheld, By Pallas guarded through the dreadful field; Might darts be bid to turn their points away, And swords around him (victor) innocently play; The war's whole art with wonder had he (victor) seen, And counted heroes where he (victor) counted men.

With copious slaughter all the fields are red, And heap'd with growing mountains of the dead. So fought each host, with thirst of glory fired,

And crowds on crowds triumphantly expired. -LSB-Illustration: Map of the Plain of Troy.-RSB- Map of the Plain of Troy. BOOK V. ARGUMENT.

Pandarus wounds him (victor) with an arrow, but the goddess cures him (victor), enables him (victor) to discern gods from mortals, and prohibits him (victor) from contending with any of the former, excepting Venus.

Ćneas joins Pandarus to oppose him (victor); Pandarus is killed, and Ćneas in great danger but for the assistance of Venus; who, as she (Venus) is removing her (Venus) son from the fight, is wounded on the hand by Diomed.

Apollo seconds her (Venus) in his (son) rescue, and at length carries off Ćneas to Troy, where he (son) is healed in the temple of Pergamus.

THE ACTS OF DIOMED. Diomed, assisted by Pallas, performs wonders in this day's battle. Mars rallies the Trojans, and assists Hector to make a stand.

In the meantime Ćneas is restored to the field, and they overthrow several of the Greeks; among the rest Tlepolemus is slain by Sarpedon.

Juno and Minerva descend to resist Mars; the latter incites Diomed to go against that god; he (god) wounds him (god), and sends him (god) groaning to heaven.

The first battle continues through this book. The scene is the same as in the former. But Pallas now Tydides' soul inspires,-LRB-143-RRB-

Fills with her (Minerva) force, and warms with all her (Minerva) fires, Above the Greeks his (god) deathless fame to raise, And crown her (Minerva) hero with distinguish'd praise.

High on his (god) helm celestial lightnings play, His (god) beamy shield emits a living ray; The unwearied blaze incessant streams supplies, Like the red star that fires the autumnal skies, When fresh he (god) rears his (god) radiant orb to sight, And, bathed in ocean, shoots a keener light.

Such glories Pallas on the chief bestow'd, Such, from his (god) arms, the fierce effulgence flow'd: Onward she (Minerva) drives him (god), furious to engage, Where the fight burns, and where the thickest rage.

The sons of Dares first the combat sought, A wealthy priest, but rich without a fault; In Vulcan's fane the father's days were led, The sons to toils of glorious battle bred; These singled from their troops the fight maintain, These, from their steeds, Tydides on the plain.

Fierce for renown the brother-chiefs draw near, And first bold Phegeus cast his (father) sounding spear, Which o'er the warrior's shoulder took its course, And spent in empty air its erring force.

Not so, Tydides, flew thy lance in vain, But pierced his (father) breast, and stretch'd him (father) on the plain. Seized with unusual fear, Idaeus fled, Left the rich chariot, and his (father) brother dead.

And had not Vulcan lent celestial aid, He (father) too had sunk to death's eternal shade; But in a smoky cloud the god of fire Preserved the son, in pity to the sire.

Struck with amaze and shame, the Trojan crew, Or slain, or fled, the sons of Dares view; When by the blood-stain'd hand Minerva

The steeds and chariot, to the navy led, Increased the spoils of gallant Diomed. press'd The god of battles, and this speech address'd:

``Stern power of war!

Let the brave chiefs their glorious toils divide; And whose the conquest, mighty Jove decide: While we from interdicted fields retire, Nor tempt the wrath of heaven's avenging sire.

Her (Minerva) words allay the impetuous warrior's heat, The god of arms and martial maid retreat; Removed from fight, on Xanthus' flowery bounds They sat, and listen'd to the dying sounds.

Meantime, the Greeks the Trojan race pursue, And some bold chieftain every leader slew: First Odius falls, and bites the bloody sand,

His (leader) death ennobled by Atrides' hand: As he (leader) to flight his (leader) wheeling car address'd, The speedy javelin drove from back to breast.

by whom the mighty fall, Who bathe in blood, and shake the lofty wall! '' (The god address)

In dust the mighty Halizonian lay, His (leader) arms resound, the spirit wings its way.

Thy fate was next, O Phaestus! doom'd to feel The great Idomeneus' protended steel; Whom Borus sent -LRB-his (leader) son and only joy-RRB-

The Cretan javelin reach'd him (leader) from afar, And pierced his (leader) shoulder as he (leader) mounts his (leader) car; Back from the car he (leader) tumbles to the ground, And everlasting shades his (leader) eyes surround.

Then died Scamandrius, expert in the chase, In woods and wilds to wound the savage race; Diana taught him (leader) all her (Diana) sylvan arts, To bend the bow, and aim unerring darts:

But vainly here Diana's arts he (leader) tries, The fatal lance arrests him (leader) as he (leader) flies; From Menelaus' arm the weapon sent, Through his (leader) broad back and heaving bosom went:

From fruitful Tarne to the fields of Troy. Down sinks the warrior with a thundering sound, His (warrior) brazen armour rings against the ground.

Next artful Phereclus untimely fell; Bold Merion sent him (warrior) to the realms of hell. Thy father's skill, O Phereclus! was thine

, The graceful fabric and the fair design; For loved by Pallas, Pallas did impart To him (father) the shipwright's and the builder's art.

The fatal cause of all his (father) country's woes; But he (father), the mystic will of heaven unknown, Nor saw his (father) country's peril, nor his (father) own.

Beneath his (father) hand the fleet of Paris rose, The hapless artist, while confused he (father) fled, The spear of Merion mingled with the dead.

Through his (father) right hip, with forceful fury cast, Between the bladder and the bone it pass'd; Prone on his (father) knees he (father) falls with fruitless cries, And death in lasting slumber seals his (father) eyes.

From Meges' force the swift Pedaeus fled, Antenor's offspring from a foreign bed, Whose generous spouse, Theanor, heavenly fair, Nursed the young stranger with a mother's care.

How vain those cares! when Meges in the rear Full in his (stranger) nape infix'd the fatal spear; Swift through his (Swift) crackling jaws the weapon glides, And the cold tongue and grinning teeth divides.

Then died Hypsenor, generous and divine, Sprung from the brave Dolopion's mighty line, Who near adored Scamander made abode, Priest of the stream, and honoured as a god.

On him (god), amidst the flying numbers found, Eurypylus inflicts a deadly wound; On his (god) broad shoulders fell the forceful brand, Thence glancing downwards, lopp'd his (god) holy hand, Which stain'd with sacred blood the blushing sand.

Down sunk the priest : the purple hand of death Closed his (priest) dim eye, and fate suppress'd his (priest) breath. Thus toil'd the chiefs, in different parts engaged.

In every quarter fierce Tydides raged; Amid the Greek, amid the Trojan train, Rapt through the ranks he (priest) thunders o'er the plain; Now here, now there, he (priest) darts from place to place,

Pours on the rear, or lightens in their face. Thus from high hills the torrents swift and strong Deluge whole fields, and sweep the trees along,

Through ruin'd moles the rushing wave resounds, O'erwhelm's the bridge, and bursts the lofty bounds; The yellow harvests of the ripen'd year, And flatted vineyards, one sad waste appear!-LRB-144-RRB-

While Jove descends in sluicy sheets of rain, And all the labours of mankind are vain. So raged Tydides, boundless in his (priest) ire, Drove armies back, and made all Troy retire.

With grief the leader of the Lycian band Saw the wide waste of his (leader) destructive hand: His (leader) bended bow against the chief he (leader) drew; Swift to the mark the thirsty arrow flew, Whose forky point the hollow breastplate tore,

Deep in his (Swift) shoulder pierced, and drank the gore: The rushing stream his (Swift) brazen armour dyed, While the proud archer thus exulting cried:

``Hither, ye Trojans, hither drive your steeds!

by our hand the bravest Grecian bleeds, Not long the deathful dart he (Swift) can sustain; Or Phoebus urged me to these fields in vain.

Lo! '' (the archer)

So spoke he (Lo), boastful: but the winged dart Stopp'd short of life, and mock'd the shooter's art. The wounded chief, behind his (chief) car retired, The helping hand of Sthenelus required;

Swift from his (Swift) seat he (Swift) leap'd upon the ground, And tugg'd the weapon from the gushing wound; When thus the king his (king) guardian power address'd, The purple current wandering o'er

If e'er my godlike sire deserved thy aid, If e'er I felt thee in the fighting field; Now, goddess, now, thy sacred succour yield.

his (sire) vest:

``O progeny of Jove! unconquer'd maid! O give my lance to reach the Trojan knight, Whose arrow wounds the chief thou guard`st in fight

Thus pray'd Tydides, and Minerva heard, His (chief) nerves confirm'd, his (chief) languid spirits cheer'd; He (chief) feels each limb with wonted vigour light;

; And lay the boaster grovelling on the shore, That vaunts these eyes shall view the light no more.'' (unknown)

His (chief) beating bosom claim'd the promised fight.

in every combat shine, War be thy province, thy protection mine; Rush to the fight, and every foe control; Wake each paternal virtue in thy soul: Strength swells thy boiling breast, infused by me, And all thy godlike father breathes in thee; Yet more, from mortal mists

'' Be bold, -LRB-she (foe) cried-RRB-, I purge thy eyes,-LRB-145-RRB- And set to view the warring deities. These see thou shun, through all the embattled plain; Nor rashly strive where human force is vain.

If Venus mingle in the martial band, Her (Venus) shalt thou wound: so Pallas gives command. '' With that, the blue-eyed virgin wing'd her (Venus) flight;

The hero rush'd impetuous to the fight; With tenfold ardour now invades the plain, Wild with delay, and more enraged by pain.

As on the fleecy flocks when hunger calls, Amidst the field a brindled lion falls; If chance some shepherd with a distant dart The savage wound, he (shepherd) rouses at the smart,

He (shepherd) foams, he (shepherd) roars; the shepherd dares not stay, But trembling leaves the scattering flocks a prey; Heaps fall on heaps; he (shepherd) bathes with blood the ground, Then leaps victorious o'er the lofty mound.

And two brave leaders at an instant slew; Astynous breathless fell, and by his (shepherd) side, His (shepherd) people's pastor, good Hypenor, died; Astynous' breast the deadly lance receives, Hypenor's shoulder his (shepherd) broad falchion cleaves.

Those slain he (shepherd) left, and sprung with noble rage Abas and Polyidus to engage; Sons of Eurydamus, who, wise and old, Could fate foresee, and mystic dreams unfold; The youths return'd not from the doubtful plain, And the sad father tried his (father) arts in vain; No mystic dream could make their fates appear, Though now determined by Tydides' spear.

Young Xanthus next, and Thoon felt his (Young) rage; The joy and hope of Phaenops' feeble age: Vast was his (Young) wealth, and these the only heirs Of all his (Young) labours and a life of cares.

Cold death o'ertakes them in their blooming years, And leaves the father unavailing tears: To strangers now descends his (father) heapy store, The race forgotten, and the name no more.

Not with less fury stern Tydides flew; Two sons of Priam in one chariot ride, Glittering in arms, and combat side by side.

As when the lordly lion seeks his (father) food Where grazing heifers range the lonely wood, He (father) leaps amidst them with a furious bound,

Bends their strong necks, and tears them to the ground: So from their seats the brother chiefs are torn, Their steeds and chariot to the navy borne.

The foe prevailing, and his (foe) friends pursued; Through the thick storm of singing spears he (foe) flies, Exploring Pandarus with careful eyes.

At length he (foe) found Lycaon's mighty son; To whom the chief of Venus' race begun: ``Where, Pandarus, are all thy honours now, Thy winged arrows and unerring bow, Thy matchless skill, thy yet unrivall'd fame, And boasted glory of the Lycian name?

O pierce that mortal! if we mortal call That wondrous force by which whole armies fall; Or god incensed, who quits the distant skies To punish Troy for slighted sacrifice; -LRB-Which, oh avert from our unhappy state!

With deep concern divine Ćneas view'd For what so dreadful as celestial hate-RRB-? Whoe'er he (god) be, propitiate Jove with prayer; If man, destroy; if god, entreat to spare.

To him (god) the Lycian:

``Whom your eyes behold, If right I judge, is Diomed the bold: Such coursers whirl him (judge) o'er the dusty field, So towers his (judge) helmet, and so flames his (judge) shield.

If 'tis a god, he (judge) wears that chief's disguise: Or if that chief, some guardian of the skies, Involved in clouds, protects him (chief) in the fray, And turns unseen the frustrate dart away.

'' (him)

I wing'd an arrow, which not idly fell, The stroke had fix'd him (chief) to the gates of hell; And, but some god, some angry god withstands, His (god) fate was due to these unerring hands.

Skill'd in the bow, on foot I sought the war, Nor join'd swift horses to the rapid car. Ten polish'd chariots I possess'd at home,

And still they grace Lycaon's princely dome: There veil'd in spacious coverlets they stand; And twice ten coursers wait their lord's command.

The good old warrior bade me trust to these, When first for Troy I sail'd the sacred seas; In fields, aloft, the whirling car to guide, And through the ranks of death triumphant ride.

But vain with youth, and yet to thrift inclined, I heard his (warrior) counsels with unheedful mind, And thought the steeds -LRB-your large supplies unknown-RRB- Might fail of forage in the straiten'd town

; So took my bow and pointed darts in hand And left the chariots in my native land. '' Too late, O friend!

my rashness I deplore ; These shafts, once fatal, carry death no more. Tydeus' and Atreus' sons their points have found, And undissembled gore pursued the wound.

In vain they bleed: this unavailing bow Serves, not to slaughter, but provoke the foe. In evil hour these bended horns I strung, And seized the quiver where it idly hung.

Cursed be the fate that sent me to the field Without a warrior's arms, the spear and shield! If e'er with life I quit the Trojan plain,

If e'er I see my spouse and sire again, This bow, unfaithful to my glorious aims, Broke by my hand, shall feed the blazing flames.

'' To whom the leader of the Dardan race:

``Be calm, nor Phoebus' honour'd gift disgrace. The distant dart be praised, though here we need The rushing chariot and the bounding steed.

Now mount my seat, and from the chariot's height Observe my father's steeds, renown'd in fight; Practised alike to turn, to stop, to chase, To dare the shock, or urge the rapid race; Secure with these, through fighting fields we go; Or safe to Troy, if Jove assist the foe.

Haste, seize the whip, and snatch the guiding rein; The warrior's fury let this arm sustain; Or, if to combat thy bold heart incline, Take thou the spear, the chariot's care be mine.

Against yon hero let us bend our course, And, hand to hand, encounter force with force. '' (Dardan)

``O prince! -LRB-Lycaon's valiant son replied-RRB-

As thine the steeds, be thine the task to guide. The horses, practised to their lord's command, Shall bear the rein, and answer to thy hand;

But, if, unhappy, we desert the fight, Thy voice alone can animate their flight; Else shall our fates be number'd with the dead, And these, the victor's prize, in triumph led.

And now both heroes mount the glittering car; The bounding coursers rush amidst the war; Their fierce approach bold Sthenelus espied,

Thine be the guidance, then: with spear and shield Myself will charge this terror of the field. '' (unknown)

Who thus, alarm'd, to great Tydides cried: ``O friend!

two chiefs of force immense I see, Dreadful they come, and bend their rage on thee: Lo the brave heir of old Lycaon's line, And great Ćneas, sprung from race divine!

At this the hero cast a gloomy look, Fix'd on the chief with scorn; and thus he (chief) spoke:

``Me dost thou bid to shun the coming fight?

Enough is given to fame. Ascend thy car! And save a life, the bulwark of our war. '' (he)

Me wouldst thou move to base, inglorious flight?

I hate the cumbrous chariot's slow advance, And the long distance of the flying lance; But while my nerves are strong, my force entire, Thus front the foe, and emulate my sire.

Know, 'tis not honest in my soul to fear, Nor was Tydides born to tremble here. Nor shall yon steeds, that fierce to fight convey Those threatening heroes, bear them both away;

But if she (foe) dooms, and if no god withstand, That both shall fall by one victorious hand, Then heed my words: my horses here detain, Fix'd to the chariot by the straiten'd rein; Swift to Ćneas' empty seat proceed, And seize the coursers of ethereal breed; The race of those, which once the thundering god-LRB-146-RRB-

One chief at least beneath this arm shall die; So Pallas tells me, and forbids to fly. For ravish'd Ganymede on

Hence great Anchises stole a breed unknown, By mortal mares, from fierce Laomedon: Four of this race his (chief) ample stalls contain, And two transport Ćneas o'er the plain.

Tros bestow'd, The best that e'er on earth's broad surface run, Beneath the rising or the setting sun. These, were the rich immortal prize our own,

Through the wide world should make our glory known. '' Thus while they spoke, the foe came furious on, And stern Lycaon's warlike race begun: ``Prince, thou art met.

He (Prince) said, then shook the ponderous lance, and flung; On his (Prince) broad shield the sounding weapon rung, Pierced the tough orb, and in his (Prince) cuirass hung,

``He (Prince) bleeds!

Though late in vain assail'd, The spear may enter where the arrow fail'd. '' (He)

the pride of Greece! -LRB-the boaster cries,-RRB-

Our triumph now, the mighty warrior lies!''

``Mistaken vaunter! -LRB-Diomed replied;-RRB- Thy dart has erred, and now my spear be tried; Ye `scape not both; one, headlong from his (Ye) car,

With hostile blood shall glut the god of war. '' (He)

He (Ye) spoke, and rising hurl'd his (Ye) forceful dart, Which, driven by Pallas, pierced a vital part;

Full in his (Ye) face it enter'd, and betwixt The nose and eye-ball the proud Lycian fix'd; Crash'd all his (Ye) jaws, and cleft the tongue within, Till the bright point look'd out beneath the chin.

Headlong he (Ye) falls, his (Ye) helmet knocks the ground: Earth groans beneath him (Ye), and his (Ye) arms resound; The starting coursers tremble with affright; The soul indignant seeks the realms of night.

To guard his (Ye) slaughter'd friend, Ćneas flies, His (Ye) spear extending where the carcase lies; Watchful he (Ye) wheels, protects it every way,

As the grim lion stalks around his (Ye) prey. O'er the fall'n trunk his (Ye) ample shield display'd , He (Ye) hides the hero with his (Ye) mighty shade, And threats aloud!

the Greeks with longing eyes Behold at distance, but forbear the prize. Then fierce Tydides stoops; and from the fields Heaved with vast force, a rocky fragment wields.

Not two strong men the enormous weight could raise, Such men as live in these degenerate days:-LRB-147-RRB- He (Ye) swung it round; and, gathering strength to throw, Discharged the ponderous ruin at the foe.

Full on the bone the pointed marble lights; Through both the tendons broke the rugged stone, And stripp'd the skin, and crack'd the solid bone.

Sunk on his (foe) knees, and staggering with his (foe) pains, His (foe) falling bulk his (foe) bended arm sustains; Lost in a dizzy mist the warrior lies; A sudden cloud comes swimming o'er his (warrior) eyes.

There the brave chief, who mighty numbers sway'd, Oppress'd had sunk to death's eternal shade, But heavenly Venus, mindful of the love She (Venus) bore Anchises in the Idaean grove, His (warrior) danger views with anguish and despair, And guards her (Venus) offspring with a mother's care.

Where to the hip the inserted thigh unites, About her (Venus) much-loved son her (Venus) arms she (Venus) throws, Her (Venus) arms whose whiteness match the falling snows.

Screen'd from the foe behind her (Venus) shining veil, The swords wave harmless, and the javelins fail ; Safe through the rushing horse, and feather'd flight Of sounding shafts, she (Venus) bears him (foe) from the fight.

Nor Sthenelus, with unassisting hands, Remain'd unheedful of his (foe) lord's commands: His (foe) panting steeds, removed from out the war, He (foe) fix'd with straiten'd traces to the car,

Next, rushing to the Dardan spoil, detains The heavenly coursers with the flowing manes: These in proud triumph to the fleet convey'd,

No longer now a Trojan lord obey'd. That charge to bold Deipylus he (lord) gave, -LRB-Whom most he (lord) loved, as brave men love the brave,-RRB-

Then mounting on his (lord) car, resumed the rein, And follow'd where Tydides swept the plain. Meanwhile -LRB-his (lord) conquest ravished from his (lord) eyes-RRB-

commission'd to the field, Like Pallas dreadful with her (lord) sable shield, Or fierce Bellona thundering at the wall, While flames ascend, and mighty ruins fall; He (lord) knew soft combats suit the tender dame,

The raging chief in chase of Venus flies: No goddess she (Venus), New to the field, and still a foe to fame.

Through breaking ranks his (foe) furious course he (foe) bends, And at the goddess his (foe) broad lance extends; Through her (goddess) bright veil the daring weapon drove,

The ambrosial veil which all the Graces wove; Her (goddess) snowy hand the razing steel profaned, And the transparent skin with crimson

stain'd , From the clear vein a stream immortal flow'd, Such stream as issues from a wounded god;-LRB-148-RRB- Pure emanation! uncorrupted flood!

Unlike our gross, diseased, terrestrial blood: -LRB-For not the bread of man their life sustains, Nor wine's inflaming juice supplies their veins:-RRB-

With tender shrieks the goddess fill'd the place, And dropp'd her (goddess) offspring from her (goddess) weak embrace. Him (man) Phoebus took: he (man) casts a cloud around The fainting chief, and wards the mortal wound.

``Ill with Jove's daughter bloody fights agree, The field of combat is no scene for thee: Go, let thy own soft sex employ thy care,

Then with a voice that shook the vaulted skies, The king insults the goddess as she (goddess) flies: Go, lull the coward, or delude the fair.

Taught by this stroke renounce the war's alarms, And learn to tremble at the name of arms. '' (unknown)

Tydides thus. The goddess, seized with dread, Confused, distracted, from the conflict fled.

To aid her (goddess), swift the winged Iris flew, Wrapt in a mist above the warring crew. The queen of love with faded charms she (queen) found.

Far, on the left, with clouds involved he (coward) lay; Beside him (coward) stood his (coward) lance, distain'd with gore, And, rein'd with gold, his (coward) foaming steeds before.

Pale was her (queen) cheek, and livid look'd the wound. To Mars, who sat remote, they bent their way: Low at his (coward) knee, she (queen) begg'd with streaming eyes Her (queen) brother's car, to mount the distant skies,

Stern Mars attentive hears the queen complain, And to her (queen) hand commits the golden rein; She (queen) mounts the seat, oppress'd with silent woe,

And show'd the wound by fierce Tydides given, A mortal man, who dares encounter heaven. Driven by the goddess of the painted bow.

They stopp'd the car, and there the coursers stood, Fed by fair Iris with ambrosial food; Before her (Iris) mother, love's bright queen appears, O'erwhelmed with anguish, and dissolved in tears: She (Iris) raised her (Iris) in her (Iris) arms, beheld her (Iris) bleed,

The lash resounds, the rapid chariot flies, And in a moment scales the lofty skies: And ask'd what god had wrought this guilty deed?

-LSB-Illustration: VENUS, WOUNDED IN THE HAND, CONDUCTED BY IRIS TO MARS.-RSB- VENUS, WOUNDED IN THE HAND, CONDUCTED BY IRIS TO MARS.

Then she (IRIS): ``This insult from no god I found, An impious mortal gave the daring wound! Behold the deed of haughty Diomed! '

Twas in the son's defence the mother bled. The war with Troy no more the Grecians wage; But with the gods -LRB-the immortal gods-RRB- engage.

Dione then:

``Thy wrongs with patience bear, And share those griefs inferior powers must share: Unnumber'd woes mankind from us sustain, And men with woes afflict the gods again.

'' (Dione wrongs)

The mighty Mars in mortal fetters bound,-LRB-149-RRB- And lodged in brazen dungeons underground, Full thirteen moons imprison'd roar'd in vain; Otus and Ephialtes held the chain: Perhaps had perish'd

Great Juno's self has borne her (Dione) weight of pain, The imperial partner of the heavenly reign; Amphitryon's son infix'd the deadly dart,-LRB-150-RRB-

had not Hermes' care Restored the groaning god to upper air. And fill'd with anguish her (Dione) immortal heart. E'en hell's grim king

, The shaft found entrance in his (king) iron breast; To Jove's high palace for a cure he (king) fled, Pierced in his (king) own dominions of the dead; Where Paeon, sprinkling heavenly balm around, Assuaged the glowing pangs, and closed the wound.

Alcides' power confess'd Rash, impious man! to stain the bless'd abodes, And drench his (man) arrows in the blood of gods! -LSB-Illustration: OTUS AND EPHIALTES HOLDING MARS CAPTIVE.-RSB-

But thou -LRB-though Pallas urged thy frantic deed-RRB-, Whose spear ill-fated makes a goddess bleed, Know thou, whoe'er with heavenly power contends, Short is his (Short) date, and soon his (Short) glory ends;

OTUS AND EPHIALTES HOLDING MARS CAPTIVE. '' From fields of death when late he (Short) shall retire, No infant on his (Short) knees shall call him (Short) sire.

Strong as thou art, some god may yet be found, To stretch thee pale and gasping on the ground; Thy distant wife, Ćgiale the fair,-LRB-151-RRB- Starting from sleep with a distracted air, Shall rouse thy slaves, and her (wife) lost lord deplore, The brave, the great, the glorious now no more!''

This said, she (wife) wiped from Venus' wounded palm The sacred ichor, and infused the balm. Juno and Pallas with a smile survey'd,

to tell How this mischance the Cyprian queen befell, As late she (queen) tried with passion to inflame The tender bosom of a Grecian dame

; Allured the fair, with moving thoughts of joy, To quit her (queen) country for some youth of Troy; The clasping zone, with golden buckles bound, Razed her (queen) soft hand with this lamented wound.

The sire of gods and men superior smiled, And, calling Venus, thus address'd his (sire) child: ``Not these, O daughter are thy proper cares, Thee milder arts befit, and softer wars; Sweet smiles are thine, and kind endearing charms; To Mars and Pallas leave the deeds of arms.

Thus they in heaven: while on the plain below The fierce Tydides charged his (sire) Dardan foe, Flush'd with celestial blood pursued his (sire) way, And fearless dared the threatening god of day; Already in his (sire) hopes he (sire) saw him (sire) kill'd, Though screen'd behind Apollo's mighty shield.

Thrice rushing furious, at the chief he (chief) strook; His (chief) blazing buckler thrice Apollo shook: He (chief) tried the fourth: when, breaking from the cloud, A more than mortal voice was heard aloud.

And thus to Jove began the blue-eyed maid:

``Permit thy daughter, gracious Jove! '' (the maid)
'' '' O son of Tydeus, cease! be wise and see How vast the difference of the gods and thee;

Distance immense! between the powers that shine Above, eternal, deathless, and divine, And mortal man! a wretch of humble birth, A short-lived reptile in the dust of earth.

'' So spoke the god who darts celestial fires: He (god) dreads his (god) fury, and some steps retires. Then Phoebus bore the chief of Venus' race To Troy's high fane, and to his (god) holy place;

This done, the patron of the silver bow A phantom raised, the same in shape and show With great Ćneas; such the form he (god) bore, And such in fight the radiant arms he (god) wore.

Latona there and Phoebe heal'd the wound, With vigour arm'd him (god), and with glory crown'd. Around the spectre bloody wars are waged, And Greece and Troy with clashing shields engaged.

``Stern power of arms, by whom the mighty fall; Who bathest in blood, and shakest the embattled wall, Rise in thy wrath!

Meantime on Ilion's tower Apollo stood, And calling Mars, thus urged the raging god: to hell's abhorr'd abodes Despatch yon Greek, and vindicate the gods.

First rosy Venus felt his (god) brutal rage; Me next he (god) charged, and dares all heaven engage: The wretch would brave high heaven's immortal sire, His (sire) triple thunder, and his (sire) bolts of fire.

The god of battle issues on the plain, Stirs all the ranks, and fires the Trojan train; In form like Acamas, the Thracian guide, Enraged to Troy's retiring chiefs he (Troy) cried:

``How long, ye sons of Priam! will ye fly, And

'' (he)

unrevenged see Priam's people die? Still unresisted shall the foe destroy, And stretch the slaughter to the gates of Troy?

Lo, brave Ćneas sinks beneath his (Lo) wound, Not godlike Hector more in arms renown'd: Haste all, and take the generous warrior's part.

He (warrior) said;--new courage swell'd each hero's heart. Sarpedon first his (warrior) ardent soul express'd, And, turn'd to Hector, these bold words address'd:

``Say, chief, is all thy ancient valour lost?

Where are thy threats, and where thy glorious boast, That propp'd alone by Priam's race should stand Troy's sacred walls, nor need a foreign hand?

Now, now thy country calls her (thy) wonted friends, And the proud vaunt in just derision ends. Remote they stand while alien troops engage, Like trembling hounds before the lion's rage.

Far distant hence I held my wide command, Where foaming Xanthus laves the Lycian land; With ample wealth -LRB-the wish of mortals-RRB- bless'd, A beauteous wife, and infant at her (wife) breast; With those I left whatever dear could be: Greece, if she (wife) conquers, nothing wins from me;

Yet first in fight my Lycian bands I cheer, And long to meet this mighty man ye fear; While Hector idle stands, nor bids the brave Their wives, their infants, and their altars save.

Haste, warrior, haste! preserve thy threaten'd state, Or one vast burst of all-involving fate Full o'er your towers shall fall, and sweep away Sons, sires, and wives, an undistinguish'd prey.

Rouse all thy Trojans, urge thy aids to fight; These claim thy thoughts by day, thy watch by night; With force incessant the brave Greeks oppose; Such cares thy friends deserve, and such thy foes.'' (Hector/HECTOR/Stern)

Stung to the heart the generous Hector hears, But just reproof with decent silence bears. From his (Hector) proud car the prince impetuous springs, On earth he (Hector) leaps, his (Hector) brazen armour rings.

Two shining spears are brandish'd in his (Hector) hands; Thus arm'd, he (Hector) animates his (Hector) drooping bands, Revives their ardour, turns their steps from flight, And wakes anew the dying flames of fight.

As when, on Ceres' sacred floor, the swain Spreads the wide fan to clear the golden grain, And the light chaff, before the breezes borne, Ascends in clouds from off the heapy corn; The grey dust, rising with collected winds, Drives o'er the barn, and whitens all the hinds: So white with dust the Grecian host appears.

From trampling steeds, and thundering charioteers; The dusky clouds from labour'd earth arise, And roll in smoking volumes to the skies.

They turn, they stand; the Greeks their fury dare, Condense their powers, and wait the growing war. Mars hovers o'er them with his (hinds) sable shield, And adds new horrors to the darken'd field:

Pleased with his (hinds) charge, and ardent to fulfil, In Troy's defence, Apollo's heavenly will: Soon as from fight the blue-eyed maid retires, Each Trojan bosom with new warmth he (hinds) fires.

And now the god, from forth his (hinds) sacred fane, Produced Ćneas to the shouting train; Alive, unharm'd, with all his (hinds) peers around,

Inquiries none they made; the dreadful day No pause of words admits, no dull delay; Fierce Discord storms, Apollo loud exclaims, Fame calls, Mars thunders, and the field's in flames.

Erect he (hinds) stood, and vigorous from his (hinds) wound: Stern Diomed with either Ajax stood, And great Ulysses, bathed in hostile blood.

Embodied close, the labouring Grecian train The fiercest shock of charging hosts sustain. Unmoved and silent, the whole war they wait Serenely dreadful, and as fix'd as fate.

So when the embattled clouds in dark array, Along the skies their gloomy lines display; When now the North his (hinds) boisterous rage has spent, And peaceful sleeps the liquid element:

The low-hung vapours, motionless and still, Rest on the summits of the shaded hill; Till the mass scatters as the winds arise, Dispersed and broken through the ruffled skies.

Nor was the general wanting to his (hinds) train; From troop to troop he (hinds) toils through all the plain,

``Ye Greeks, be men!

the charge of battle bear; Your brave associates and yourselves revere! Let glorious acts more glorious acts inspire, And catch from breast to breast the noble fire!

On valour's side the odds of combat lie, The brave live glorious, or lamented die; The wretch who trembles in the field of fame, Meets death, and worse than death, eternal shame!'' (he)

These words he (hinds) seconds with his (hinds) flying lance, To meet whose point was strong Deicoon's chance: Ćneas' friend, and in his (friend) native place Honour'd and loved like Priam's royal race: Long had he (Long) fought the foremost in the field, But now the monarch's lance transpierced his (Long) shield: His (Long) shield too weak the furious dart to stay, Through his (Long) broad belt the weapon forced its way:

The grisly wound dismiss'd his (Long) soul to hell, His (Long) arms around him (Long) rattled as he (Long) fell. Then fierce Ćneas, brandishing his (Long) blade, In dust Orsilochus and Crethon laid, Whose sire Diocleus, wealthy, brave and great,

In well-built Pherae held his (Long) lofty seat:-LRB-152 -RRB- Sprung from Alpheus' plenteous stream, that yields Increase of harvests to the Pylian fields.

In sable ships they left their native soil, To avenge Atrides: now, untimely slain, They fell with glory on the Phrygian plain.

He (Long) got Orsilochus, Diocleus he (Long), And these descended in the third degree. Too early expert in the martial toil, So two young mountain lions, nursed with blood

In deep recesses of the gloomy wood, Rush fearless to the plains, and uncontroll'd Depopulate the stalls and waste the fold:

Till pierced at distance from their native den, O'erpowered they fall beneath the force of men. Prostrate on earth their beauteous bodies lay, Like mountain firs, as tall and straight as they.

Great Menelaus views with pitying eyes, Lifts his (Menelaus) bright lance, and at the victor flies; Mars urged him (Menelaus) on; yet, ruthless in his (Menelaus) hate,

He (Menelaus) thus advancing, Nestor's valiant son Shakes for his (son) danger, and neglects his (son) own; Struck with the thought, should Helen's lord be slain, And all his (lord) country's glorious labours vain.

The god but urged him (lord) to provoke his (lord) fate. Already met, the threatening heroes stand; The spears already tremble in their hand: In rush'd

Antilochus, his (lord) aid to bring, And fall or conquer by the Spartan king. These seen, the Dardan backward turn'd his (lord) course, Brave as he (lord) was, and shunn'd unequal force.

The breathless bodies to the Greeks they drew, Then mix in combat, and their toils renew. First, Pylaemenes, great in battle, bled,

Who sheathed in brass the Paphlagonians led. Atrides mark'd him (lord) where sublime he (lord) stood; Fix'd in his (lord) throat the javelin drank his (lord) blood.

The faithful Mydon, as he (lord) turn'd from fight His (lord) flying coursers, sunk to endless night; A broken rock by Nestor's son was thrown: His (Nestor) bended arm received the falling stone; From his (Nestor) numb'd hand the ivory-studded reins, Dropp'd in the dust, are trail'd along the plains:

Meanwhile his (Nestor) temples feel a deadly wound; He (Nestor) groans in death, and ponderous sinks to ground: Deep drove his (Nestor) helmet in the sands, and there The head stood fix'd, the quivering legs in air,

Till trampled flat beneath the coursers' feet: The youthful victor mounts his (victor) empty seat, And bears the prize in triumph to the fleet.

the Trojan troops pursue: He (victor) fires his (victor) host with animating cries, And brings along the furies of the skies, Mars, stern destroyer!

Great Hector saw, and, raging at the view, Pours on the Greeks: and Bellona dread, Flame in the front, and thunder at their head

: This swells the tumult and the rage of fight; That shakes a spear that casts a dreadful light. Where Hector march'd, the god of battles shined, Now storm'd before him (Hector), and now raged behind.

As when some simple swain his (swain) cot forsakes, And wide through fens an unknown journey takes: If chance a swelling brook his (swain) passage stay, And foam impervious `cross the wanderer's way, Confused he (swain) stops, a length of country pass'd, Eyes the rough waves, and tired, returns at last.

Tydides paused amidst his (swain) full career; Then first the hero's manly breast knew fear. Amazed no less the great Tydides stands:

``No wonder, Greeks! that all to Hector yield; Secure of favouring gods, he (Hector) takes the field; His (Hector) strokes they second, and avert our spears.

He (Hector) stay'd, and turning thus address'd his (Hector) bands: Behold where Mars in mortal arms appears! Retire then, warriors, but sedate and slow; Retire, but with your faces to the foe.

Now near the Greeks the black battalions drew; And first two leaders valiant Hector slew: His (Hector) force Anchialus and Mnesthes found,

Trust not too much your unavailing might; 'Tis not with Troy, but with the gods ye fight. '' (unknown)

In every art of glorious war renown'd

; In the same car the chiefs to combat ride, And fought united, and united died. Struck at the sight, the mighty Ajax glows With thirst of vengeance, and assaults the foes.

possess'd, With herds abounding, and with treasure bless'd; But fate resistless from his (Struck) country led The chief, to perish at his (Struck) people's head.

Shook with his (Struck) fall his (Struck) brazen armour rung, And fierce, to seize it, conquering Ajax sprung; Around his (Struck) head an iron tempest rain'd; A wood of spears his (Struck) ample shield sustain'd:

His (Struck) massy spear with matchless fury sent, Through Amphius' belt and heaving belly went; Amphius Apaesus' happy soil Beneath one foot the yet warm corpse he (Struck) press'd,

And drew his (Struck) javelin from the bleeding breast: He (Struck) could no more; the showering darts denied To spoil his (Struck) glittering arms, and plumy pride.

Now foes on foes came pouring on the fields, With bristling lances, and compacted shields; Till in the steely circle straiten'd round, Forced he (Struck) gives way, and sternly quits the ground.

While thus they strive, Tlepolemus the great,-LRB-153-RRB- Urged by the force of unresisted fate, Burns with desire Sarpedon's strength to prove

; Alcides' offspring meets the son of Jove. Sheathed in bright arms each adverse chief came on. Jove's great descendant, and his (chief) greater son.

Prepared for combat, ere the lance he (chief) toss'd, The daring Rhodian vents his (chief) haughty boast:

``What brings this Lycian counsellor so far, To tremble at our arms, not mix in war!

Know thy vain self, nor let their flattery move, Who style thee son of cloud-compelling Jove. How far unlike those chiefs of race

divine, How vast the difference of their deeds and thine! Jove got such heroes as my sire, whose soul No fear could daunt, nor earth nor hell control.

Troy felt his (Troy) arm, and yon proud ramparts stand Raised on the ruins of his (Troy) vengeful hand: With six small ships, and but a slender train, He (Troy) left the town a wide-deserted plain.

But what art thou, who deedless look`st around, While unrevenged thy Lycians bite the ground! Small aid to Troy thy feeble force can be;

But wert thou greater, thou must yield to me. Pierced by my spear, to endless darkness go! I make this present to the shades below.

'' (he)

The son of Hercules, the Rhodian guide, Thus haughty spoke. The Lycian king replied:
``Thy sire, O prince! o'erturn'd the Trojan state,

Whose perjured monarch well deserved his (monarch) fate; Those heavenly steeds the hero sought so far, False he (monarch) detain'd, the just reward of war.

But you, unworthy the high race you boast, Shall raise my glory when thy own is lost: Now meet thy fate, and by Sarpedon slain, Add one more ghost to Pluto's gloomy reign.

Nor so content, the generous chief defied, With base reproaches and unmanly pride. '' (The king)

He (chief) said: both javelins at an instant flew; Both struck, both wounded, but Sarpedon's slew:

Full in the boaster's neck the weapon stood, Transfix'd his (chief) throat, and drank the vital blood; The soul disdainful seeks the caves of night, And his (chief) seal'd eyes for ever lose the light.

Yet not in vain, Tlepolemus, was thrown Thy angry lance; which piercing to the bone Sarpedon's thigh, had robb'd the chief of breath;

But Jove was present, and forbade the death. Borne from the conflict by his (chief) Lycian throng, The wounded hero dragg'd the lance along.

-LRB-His (chief) friends, each busied in his (chief) several part, Through haste, or danger, had not drawn the dart.-RRB- The Greeks with slain Tlepolemus retired;

Whose fall Ulysses view'd, with fury fired; Doubtful if Jove's great son he (son) should pursue, Or pour his (son) vengeance on the Lycian crew.

But heaven and fate the first design withstand, Nor this great death must grace Ulysses' hand. Minerva drives him (Ulysses) on the Lycian train; Alastor, Cronius, Halius, strew'd the plain, Alcander, Prytanis, Noemon fell:-LRB-154-RRB-

And numbers more his (Ulysses) sword had sent to hell, But Hector saw; and, furious at the sight, Rush'd terrible amidst the ranks of fight.

With joy Sarpedon view'd the wish'd relief, And, faint, lamenting, thus implored the chief:

``O suffer not the foe to bear away

; If I, unbless'd, must see my son no more, My much-loved consort, and my native shore, Yet let me die in Ilion's sacred wall; Troy, in whose cause I fell, shall mourn my fall.

My helpless corpse, an unassisted prey '' (the chief O)

He (Troy) said, nor Hector to the chief replies, But shakes his (Troy) plume, and fierce to combat flies;

Swift as a whirlwind, drives the scattering foes; And dyes the ground with purple as he (Swift) goes. Beneath a beech, Jove's consecrated shade, His (Swift) mournful friends divine Sarpedon laid: Brave Pelagon, his (Swift) favourite chief, was nigh,

Who wrench'd the javelin from his (Swift) sinewy thigh. The fainting soul stood ready wing'd for flight, And o'er his (Swift) eye-balls swam the shades of night;

The generous Greeks recede with tardy pace, Though Mars and Hector thunder in their face; None turn their backs to mean ignoble flight, Slow they retreat, and even retreating fight.

But Boreas rising fresh, with gentle breath, Recall'd his (Hector) spirit from the gates of death. Who first, who last, by Mars' and Hector's hand, Stretch'd in their blood, lay gasping on the sand?

renown'd For managed steeds, and Trechus press'd the ground;, Next OEnomaus and OEnops' offspring died; Oresbius last fell groaning at their side:

Oresbius, in his (Hector) painted mitre gay, In fat Boeotia held his (Hector) wealthy sway, Where lakes surround low Hyle's watery plain; A prince and people studious of their gain.

Tenthras the great, Orestes the The carnage Juno from the skies survey'd, And touch'd with grief bespoke the blue-eyed maid:

``Oh, sight accursed!

How vain the word to Menelaus given By Jove's great daughter and the queen of heaven, Beneath his (Menelaus) arms that Priam's towers should fall, If warring gods for ever guard the wall!

Shall faithless Troy prevail, And shall our promise to our people fail? Mars, red with slaughter, aids our hated foes: Haste, let us arm, and force with force oppose!

'' (the maid)

She (queen) spoke; Minerva burns to meet the war: And now heaven's empress calls her (empress) blazing car. At her (empress) command rush forth the steeds divine; Rich with immortal gold their trappings shine.
