Bright Hebe waits; by Hebe, ever young, The whirling wheels are to the chariot hung. On the bright axle turns the bidden wheel Of sounding brass; the polished axle steel.

Eight brazen spokes in radiant order flame; The circles gold, of uncorrupted frame, Such as the heavens produce: and round the gold Two brazen rings of work divine were roll'd.

The bossy naves of sold silver shone; Braces of gold suspend the moving throne: The car, behind, an arching figure bore;

The bending concave form'd an arch before. Silver the beam, the extended yoke was gold, And golden reins the immortal coursers hold.

Pallas disrobes; her (Pallas) radiant veil untied, With flowers adorn'd, with art diversified, -LRB-The laboured veil her (Pallas) heavenly fingers wove,-RRB- Flows on the pavement of the court of Jove.

Now heaven's dread arms her (Pallas) mighty limbs invest, Jove's cuirass blazes on her (Pallas) ample breast; Deck'd in sad triumph for the mournful field, O'er her (Pallas) broad shoulders hangs his (Silver) horrid shield, Dire, black, tremendous!

Herself, impatient, to the ready car, The coursers joins, and breathes revenge and war. Round the margin roll'd, A fringe of serpents hissing guards the gold: Here all the terrors of grim War appear,

Here rages Force, here tremble Flight and Fear, Here storm'd Contention, and here Fury frown'd, And the dire orb portentous Gorgon crown'd.

, That dreadful nods with four o'ershading plumes; So vast, the broad circumference contains A hundred armies on a hundred plains.

The goddess thus the imperial car ascends; Shook by her (goddess) arm the mighty javelin bends, Ponderous and huge; that when her (goddess) fury burns, Proud tyrants humbles, and whole hosts o'erturns.

The massy golden helm she (goddess) next assumes Swift at the scourge the ethereal coursers fly, While the smooth chariot cuts the liquid sky.

Heaven's gates spontaneous open to the powers,-LRB-155-RRB- Heaven's golden gates, kept by the winged Hours;-LRB-156-RRB- Commission'd in alternate watch they stand

, The sun's bright portals and the skies command, Involve in clouds the eternal gates of day, Or the dark barrier roll with ease away.

The chariot mounts, where deep in ambient skies, Confused, Olympus' hundred heads arise; Where far apart the Thunderer fills his (Thunderer) throne, O'er all the gods superior and alone.

The sounding hinges ring on either side The gloomy volumes, pierced with light, divide. There with her (Thunderer) snowy hand the queen restrains The fiery steeds, and thus to Jove

complains:

``O sire! can no resentment touch thy soul? Can Mars rebel, and does no thunder roll? What lawless rage on yon forbidden plain,

What rash destruction! and what heroes slain! Venus, and Phoebus with the dreadful bow, Smile on the slaughter, and enjoy my woe.

Mad, furious power! whose unrelenting mind No god can govern, and no justice bind. Say, mighty father! shall we scourge this pride, And drive from fight the impetuous homicide?

'' (Jove/Which Jove)

To whom assenting, thus the Thunderer said:
``Go! and the great Minerva be thy aid. To tame the monster-god Minerva knows, And oft afflicts his (father) brutal breast with woes.

He (father) said; Saturnia, ardent to obey, Lash'd her (Minerva) white steeds along the aerial way Swift down the steep of heaven the chariot rolls, Between the expanded earth and starry poles Far as a shepherd, from some point on high,-LRB-157-RRB-

O'er the wide main extends his (shepherd) boundless eye, Through such a space of air, with thundering sound, At every leap the immortal coursers bound Troy now

'' (the Thunderer)

they reach'd and touch'd those banks divine , Where silver Simois and Scamander join There Juno stopp'd , and -LRB-her (Minerva) fair steeds unloosed-RRB-

Of air condensed a vapour circumfused For these, impregnate with celestial dew, On Simois, brink ambrosial herbage grew. Thence to relieve the fainting Argive throng, Smooth as the sailing doves they glide along.

Such was their look as lions bathed in blood, Or foaming boars, the terror of the wood Heaven's empress mingles with the mortal crowd, And shouts, in Stentor's sounding voice, aloud; Stentor the strong, endued with brazen lungs,-LRB-158-RRB-

The best and bravest of the Grecian band -LRB-A warlike circle-RRB- round Tydides stand. Whose throats surpass'd the force of fifty tongues.

Once from the walls your timorous foes engaged, While fierce in war divine Achilles raged; Now issuing fearless they possess the plain, Now win the shores, and scarce the seas remain.

'' Inglorious Argives! to your race a shame, And only men in figure and in name! '' Her (they) speech new fury to their hearts convey'd

The king beside his (king) panting steeds she (they) found, O'erspent with toil reposing on the ground; To cool his (king) glowing wound he (king) sat apart, -LRB-The wound inflicted by the Lycian dart.-RRB-

Large drops of sweat from all his (king) limbs descend, Beneath his (king) ponderous shield his (king) sinews bend, Whose ample belt, that o'er his (king) shoulder lay, He (king) eased; and wash'd the clotted gore away.

; While near Tydides stood the Athenian maid; The goddess leaning o'er the bending yoke, Beside his (king) coursers, thus her (goddess) silence broke:

, Whose little body lodged a mighty mind; Foremost he (king) press'd in glorious toils to share, And scarce refrain'd when I forbade the war.

Alone, unguarded, once he (king) dared to go, And feast, incircled by the Theban foe; There braved, and vanquish'd, many a hardy knight; Such nerves I gave him (knight), and such force in fight.

``Degenerate prince! and not of Tydeus' kind Thou too no less hast been my constant care ; Thy hands I arm'd, and sent thee forth to war:

But thee or fear deters, or sloth detains; No drop of all thy father warms thy veins. '' (unknown)

The chief thus answered mild:

``Immortal maid! I own thy presence, and confess thy aid. Not fear, thou know`st, withholds me from the plains, Nor sloth hath seized me, but thy word restrains:

From warring gods thou bad`st me turn my spear, And Venus only found resistance here. Hence, goddess! heedful of thy high commands, Loth I gave way, and warn'd our Argive bands:

For Mars, the homicide, these eyes beheld, With slaughter red, and raging round the field. '' (Minerva Tydides)

Then thus Minerva:--
``Brave Tydides, hear!

Not Mars himself, nor aught immortal, fear. Full on the god impel thy foaming horse: Pallas commands, and Pallas lends thee force.

And every side of wavering combat tries; Large promise makes, and breaks the promise made: Now gives the Grecians, now the Trojans aid.'' (Minerva Tydides)

-LRB-159-RRB-

Rash, furious, blind, from these to those he (god) flies, She (Minerva) said, and to the steeds approaching near, Drew from his (Drew) seat the martial charioteer.

The vigorous power the trembling car ascends, Fierce for revenge; and Diomed attends: The groaning axle bent beneath the load; So great a hero, and so great a god.

She (Minerva) snatch'd the reins, she (Minerva) lash'd with all her (Minerva) force, And full on Mars impelled the foaming horse: But first, to hide her (Minerva) heavenly visage, spread Black Orcus' helmet o'er her (Minerva) radiant head.

Just then gigantic Periphas lay slain, The strongest warrior of the Ćtolian train; The god, who slew him (god), leaves his (god) prostrate prize Stretch'd where he (god) fell, and at Tydides flies.

-LSB-Illustration: DIOMED CASTING HIS (god) SPEAR AT MARS.-RSB- DIOMED CASTING HIS (god) SPEAR AT MARS. Now rushing fierce, in equal arms appear The daring Greek, the dreadful god of war!

Full at the chief, above his (chief) courser's head, From Mars's arm the enormous weapon fled: Pallas opposed her (Minerva) hand, and caused to glance Far from the car the strong immortal lance.

Then threw the force of Tydeus' warlike son; The javelin hiss'd; the goddess urged it on: Where the broad cincture girt his (son) armour round, It pierced the god: his (son) groin received the wound.

From the rent skin the warrior tugs again The smoking steel. Mars bellows with the pain: Loud as the roar encountering armies yield, When shouting millions shake the thundering field.

Both armies start, and trembling gaze around; And earth and heaven re-bellow to the sound. As vapours blown by Auster's sultry breath, Pregnant with plagues, and shedding seeds of death,

Beneath the rage of burning Sirius rise, Choke the parch'd earth, and blacken all the skies; In such a cloud the god from combat driven, High o'er the dusky whirlwind scales the heaven.

Wild with his (god) pain, he (god) sought the bright abodes, There sullen sat beneath the sire of gods, Show'd the celestial blood, and with a groan

Thus pour'd his (god) plaints before the immortal throne:

``Can Jove, supine, flagitious facts survey, And brook the furies of this daring day?

For mortal men celestial powers engage, And gods on gods exert eternal rage: From thee, O father! all these ills we bear, And thy fell daughter with the shield and spear

; Thou gavest that fury to the realms of light, Pernicious, wild, regardless of the right. All heaven beside reveres thy sovereign sway, Thy voice we hear, and thy behests obey: '

Tis hers to offend, and even offending share Thy breast, thy counsels, thy distinguish'd care: So boundless she (daughter), and thou so partial grown

Now frantic Diomed, at her (daughter) command, Against the immortals lifts his (father) raging hand: The heavenly Venus first his (father) fury found, Me next encountering, me he (father) dared to wound; Vanquish'd I fled; even I, the god of fight, From mortal madness scarce was saved by flight.

, Well may we deem the wondrous birth thy own. Else hadst thou seen me sink on yonder plain, Heap'd round, and heaving under loads of slain!

Or pierced with Grecian darts, for ages lie, Condemn'd to pain, though fated not to die. '' (the sire)

Him (Heap) thus upbraiding, with a wrathful look The lord of thunders view'd, and stern bespoke:
``To me, perfidious!

this lamenting strain? Of lawless force shall lawless Mars complain? Of all the gods who tread the spangled skies, Thou most unjust, most odious in our eyes!

Inhuman discord is thy dire delight, The waste of slaughter, and the rage of fight. No bounds, no law, thy fiery temper quells, And all thy mother in thy soul rebels.

In vain our threats, in vain our power we use; She (mother) gives the example, and her (mother) son pursues. Yet long the inflicted pangs thou shall not mourn, Sprung since thou art from Jove, and heavenly-born.

Else, singed with lightning, hadst thou hence been thrown, Where chain'd on burning rocks the Titans groan. '' (The lord)

Thus he (son) who shakes Olympus with his (son) nod; Then gave to Paeon's care the bleeding god.-LRB-160-RRB-

As when the fig's press'd juice, infused in cream, To curds coagulates the liquid stream, Sudden the fluids fix the parts combined; Such, and so soon, the ethereal texture join'd.

With gentle hand the balm he (son) pour'd around, And heal'd the immortal flesh, and closed the wound. Cleansed from the dust and gore, fair Hebe dress'd His (son) mighty limbs in an immortal vest.

Glorious he (son) sat, in majesty restored, Fast by the throne of heaven's superior lord. Juno and Pallas mount the bless'd abodes, Their task perform'd, and mix among the gods.

-LSB-Illustration: JUNO.-RSB- JUNO. BOOK VI. ARGUMENT. THE EPISODES OF GLAUCUS AND DIOMED, AND OF HECTOR AND ANDROMACHE. The gods having left the field, the Grecians prevail.

Helenus, the chief augur of Troy, commands Hector to return to the city, in order to appoint a solemn procession of the queen and the Trojan matrons to the temple of Minerva, to entreat her (Minerva) to remove Diomed from the fight.

The battle relaxing during the absence of Hector, Glaucus and Diomed have an interview between the two armies; where, coming to the knowledge, of the friendship and hospitality passed between their ancestors, they make exchange of their arms.

Hector, having performed the orders of Helenus, prevails upon Paris to return to the battle, and, taking a tender leave of his (Hector) wife Andromache, hastens again to the field.

Now heaven forsakes the fight: the immortals yield To human force and human skill the field: Dark showers of javelins fly from foes to foes; Now here, now there, the tide of combat flows; While Troy's famed streams, that bound the deathful plain On either side, run purple to the main.

The scene is first in the field of battle, between the rivers Simois and Scamander, and then changes to Troy. Great Ajax

first to conquest led the way, Broke the thick ranks, and turn'd the doubtful day. The Thracian Acamas his (Great) falchion found,

Where the black horse-hair nodded o'er his (Great) crest; Fix'd in his (Great) front the brazen weapon lies, And seals in endless shades his (Great) swimming eyes.

Next Teuthras' son distain'd the sands with blood, Axylus, hospitable, rich, and good: In fair Arisbe's walls -LRB-his (Great) native place-RRB--LRB-161-RRB- He (Great) held his (Great) seat!

And hew'd the enormous giant to the ground; His (Great) thundering arm a deadly stroke impress'd a friend to human race. Fast by the road, his (friend) ever-open door Obliged the wealthy, and relieved the poor.

To stern Tydides now he (friend) falls a prey, No friend to guard him (friend) in the dreadful day! Breathless the good man fell, and by his (man) side His (man) faithful servant, old Calesius died.

Two twins were near, bold, beautiful, and young, From a fair naiad and Bucolion sprung: -LRB-Laomedon's white flocks Bucolion fed, That monarch's first-born by a foreign bed; In secret woods he (monarch) won the naiad's grace, And two fair infants crown'd his (monarch) strong embrace:-RRB- Here dead they lay in all their youthful charms; The ruthless victor stripp'd their shining arms.

Astyalus by Polypoetes fell; Ulysses' spear Pidytes sent to hell; By Teucer's shaft brave Aretaon bled, And Nestor's son laid stern Ablerus dead; Great Agamemnon, leader of the brave, The mortal wound of rich Elatus gave, Who held in Pedasus his (Agamemnon) proud abode,-LRB-162-RRB- And till'd the banks where silver Satnio flow'd. Melanthius by Eurypylus was slain; And Phylacus from Leitus flies in vain.

By great Euryalus was Dresus slain, And next he (Agamemnon) laid Opheltius on the plain. Unbless'd Adrastus next at mercy lies Beneath the Spartan spear, a living prize.

His (Agamemnon) headlong steeds, precipitate in flight, Rush'd on a tamarisk's strong trunk, and broke The shatter'd chariot from the crooked yoke; Wide o'er the field, resistless as the wind, For Troy they fly, and leave their lord behind.

Atrides o'er him (lord) shakes his (lord) vengeful steel; The fallen chief in suppliant posture press'd The victor's knees, and thus his (lord) prayer address'd:

Scared with the din and tumult of the fight, Prone on his (lord) face he (lord) sinks beside the wheel:

``O spare my youth, and for the life I owe Large gifts of price my father shall bestow.

When fame shall tell, that, not in battle slain, Thy hollow ships his (father) captive son detain: Rich heaps of brass shall in thy tent be told,-LRB-163-RRB-

And steel well-temper'd, and persuasive gold. '' (he)

He (father) said: compassion touch'd the hero's heart He (father) stood, suspended with the lifted dart:

As pity pleaded for his (father) vanquish'd prize, Stern Agamemnon swift to vengeance flies, And, furious, thus:

``Oh impotent of mind!-LRB-164-RRB- Shall these, shall these Atrides' mercy find?

Not one of all the race, nor sex, nor age, Shall save a Trojan from our boundless rage: Ilion shall perish whole, and bury all; Her (Stern) babes, her (Stern) infants at the breast, shall fall;-LRB-165-RRB-

Well hast thou known proud Troy's perfidious land, And well her (Stern) natives merit at thy hand! A dreadful lesson of exampled fate, To warn the nations, and to curb the great!'' (Agamemnon)

The monarch spoke; the words, with warmth address'd, To rigid justice steel'd his (monarch) brother's breast Fierce from his (monarch) knees the hapless chief he (monarch) thrust; The monarch's javelin stretch'd him (monarch) in the dust, Then pressing with his (monarch) foot his (monarch) panting heart, Forth from the slain

thus the vigorous combat wage; No son of Mars descend, for servile gains, To touch the booty, while a foe remains.

he (foe) tugg'd the reeking dart. Old Nestor saw, and roused the warrior's rage;

``Thus, heroes! Behold yon glittering host, your future spoil!

First gain the conquest, then reward the toil. '' (the warrior)

And now had Greece eternal fame acquired, And frighted Troy within her (heroes) walls, retired, Had not sage Helenus her (heroes) state

redress'd, Taught by the gods that moved his (Nestor) sacred breast. Where Hector stood, with great Ćneas join'd, The seer reveal'd the counsels of his (seer) mind:

on whom the immortals lay The cares and glories of this doubtful day; On whom your aids, your country's hopes depend; Wise to consult, and active to defend!

Here, at our gates, your brave efforts unite, Turn back the routed, and forbid the flight, Ere yet their wives' soft arms the cowards gain, The sport and insult of the hostile train.

When your commands have hearten'd every band, Ourselves, here fix'd, will make the dangerous stand; Press'd as we are, and sore of former fight, These straits demand our last remains of might.

Meanwhile thou, Hector, to the town retire, And teach our mother what the gods require: Direct the queen to lead the assembled train Of Troy's chief matrons to Minerva's fane;-LRB-166-RRB- Unbar the sacred gates, and seek the power, With offer'd vows, in Ilion's topmost tower.

The largest mantle her (Minerva) rich wardrobes hold, Most prized for art, and labour'd o'er with gold, Before the goddess' honour'd knees be spread, And twelve young heifers to her (goddess) altars led:

If so the power, atoned by fervent prayer, Our wives, our infants, and our city spare, And far avert Tydides' wasteful ire, That mows whole troops, and makes all Troy retire; Not thus Achilles taught our hosts to dread, Sprung though he (Achilles) was from more than mortal bed; Not thus resistless ruled the stream of fight,

Hector obedient heard: and, with a bound, Leap'd from his (Hector) trembling chariot to the ground; Through all his (Hector) host inspiring force he (Hector) flies, And bids the thunder of the battle rise.

``Ye generous chiefs! In rage unbounded, and unmatch'd in might. '' (Trojans)
With rage recruited the bold Trojans glow, And turn the tide of conflict on the foe:

Fierce in the front he (foe) shakes two dazzling spears; All Greece recedes, and `midst her (Trojans) triumphs fears; Some god, they thought, who ruled the fate of wars, Shot down avenging from the vault of stars.

Then thus aloud:

``Ye dauntless Dardans, hear! And you whom distant nations send to war! Be mindful of the strength your fathers bore; Be still yourselves, and Hector asks no more.

One hour demands me in the Trojan wall, To bid our altars flame, and victims fall: Nor shall, I trust, the matrons' holy train, And reverend elders, seek the gods in vain.

The shield's large orb behind his (reverend) shoulder cast, His (reverend) neck o'ershading, to his (reverend) ankle hung; And as he (reverend) march'd the brazen buckler rung.

Where daring Glaucus and great Tydeus' son Between both armies met: the chiefs from far Observed each other, and had mark'd for war.

'' (hero)

This said, with ample strides the hero pass'd; Now paused the battle -LRB-godlike Hector gone-RRB-,-LRB-167-RRB- Near as they drew, Tydides thus began:
``What art thou, boldest of the race of man?

Our eyes till now that aspect ne'er beheld, Where fame is reap'd amid the embattled field; Yet far before the troops thou dar`st appear, And meet a lance

the fiercest heroes fear. Unhappy they, and born of luckless sires, Who tempt our fury when Minerva fires! But if from heaven, celestial, thou descend, Know with immortals we no more contend.

Not long Lycurgus view'd the golden light, That daring man who mix'd with gods in fight. Bacchus, and Bacchus' votaries, he (Bacchus) drove, With brandish'd steel, from Nyssa's sacred grove:

Their consecrated spears lay scatter'd round, With curling vines and twisted ivy bound; While Bacchus headlong sought the briny flood, And Thetis' arms received the trembling god.

-LRB-The immortals bless'd with endless ease above;-RRB- Deprived of sight by their avenging doom, Cheerless he (god) breathed, and wander'd in the gloom, Then sunk unpitied to the dire abodes, A wretch accursed, and hated by the gods!

I brave not heaven: but if the fruits of earth Sustain thy life, and human be thy birth, Bold as thou art, too prodigal of breath, Approach, and enter the dark gates of death.

Nor fail'd the crime the immortals' wrath to move; '' (Tydides)

``What, or from whence I am, or who my sire, -LRB-Replied the chief,-RRB- can Tydeus' son inquire?

Like leaves on trees the race of man is found, Now green in youth, now withering on the ground ; Another race the following spring supplies; They fall successive, and successive rise:

So generations in their course decay; So flourish these, when those are pass'd away. But if thou still persist to search my birth, Then hear a tale that fills the spacious earth.

'' (Argos)

A city stands on Argos' utmost bound, -LRB-Argos the fair, for warlike steeds renown'd,-RRB- Aeolian Sisyphus, with wisdom bless'd, In ancient time the happy wall

possess'd, Then call'd Ephyre: Glaucus was his (Sisyphus) son; Great Glaucus, father of Bellerophon, Who o'er the sons of men in beauty shined,

Loved for that valour which preserves mankind. Then mighty Praetus Argos' sceptre sway'd, Whose hard commands Bellerophon obey'd. With direful jealousy the monarch raged, And the brave prince in numerous toils engaged.

And strove to tempt him (monarch) from the paths of fame: In vain she (monarch) tempted the relentless youth, Endued with wisdom, sacred fear, and truth.

For him (monarch) Antaea burn'd with lawless flame, Fired at his (monarch) scorn the queen to Praetus fled, And begg'd revenge for her (queen) insulted bed: Incensed he (monarch) heard, resolving on his (monarch) fate; But hospitable laws restrain'd his (monarch) hate:

To Lycia the devoted youth he (monarch) sent, With tablets seal'd, that told his (monarch) dire intent.-LRB-168-RRB- Now bless'd by every power who guards the good, The chief arrived at Xanthus' silver flood:

There Lycia's monarch paid him (monarch) honours due, Nine days he (monarch) feasted, and nine bulls he (monarch) slew. But when the tenth bright morning orient glow'd,

The faithful youth his (monarch) monarch's mandate show'd: The fatal tablets, till that instant seal'd, The deathful secret to the king reveal'd.

Behind, a dragon's fiery tail was spread; A goat's rough body bore a lion's head; Her (monarch) pitchy nostrils flaky flames expire; Her (monarch) gaping throat emits infernal fire.

This pest he (king) slaughter'd, -LRB-for he (king) read the skies, And trusted heaven's informing prodigies,-RRB- Then met in arms the Solymaean crew,-LRB-169-RRB-

-LRB-Fiercest of men,-RRB- and those the warrior slew; Next the bold Amazons' whole force defied; And conquer'd still, for heaven was on his (warrior) side.

Nor ended here his (warrior) toils: his (warrior) Lycian foes, At his (warrior) return, a treacherous ambush rose, With levell'd spears along the winding shore:

First, dire Chimaera's conquest was enjoin'd; A mingled monster of no mortal kind! '' '' There fell they breathless, and return'd no more.

At length the monarch, with repentant grief, Confess'd the gods, and god-descended chief; His (chief) daughter gave, the stranger to detain, With half the honours of his (chief) ample reign: The Lycians grant a chosen space of ground, With woods, with vineyards, and with harvests

There long the chief his (chief) happy lot possess'd, With two brave sons and one fair daughter bless'd; -LRB-Fair e`en in heavenly eyes: her (daughter) fruitful love Crown'd with Sarpedon's birth the embrace of Jove;-RRB-

But when at last, distracted in his (chief) mind, Forsook by heaven, forsaking humankind, Wide o'er the Aleian field he (chief) chose to stray, A long, forlorn, uncomfortable way!-LRB-170-RRB-

'' crown'd. Woes heap'd on woes consumed his (chief) wasted heart: His (chief) beauteous daughter fell by Phoebe's dart; His (chief) eldest born by raging Mars was slain,

Hippolochus survived: from him (chief) I came, The honour'd author of my birth and name; By his (chief) decree I sought the Trojan town; By his (chief) instructions learn to win renown, To stand the first in worth as in command, To add new honours to my native land, Before my eyes my mighty sires to place, And emulate the glories of our race.

He (chief) spoke, and transport fill'd Tydides' heart; In earth the generous warrior fix'd his (warrior) dart, Then friendly, thus the Lycian prince address'd:

``Welcome, my brave hereditary guest!

In combat on the Solymaean plain. '' (prince)

Thus ever let us meet, with kind embrace, Nor stain the sacred friendship of our race.

Know, chief, our grandsires have been guests of old; OEneus the strong, Bellerophon the bold: Our ancient seat his (chief) honour'd presence graced, Where twenty days in genial rites he (chief) pass'd.

The parting heroes mutual presents left; A golden goblet was thy grandsire's gift; OEneus a belt of matchless work bestowed, That rich with Tyrian dye refulgent glow'd.

-LRB-This from his (chief) pledge I learn'd, which, safely stored Among my treasures, still adorns my board: For Tydeus left me young, when Thebe's wall Beheld the sons of Greece untimely fall.-RRB-

Mindful of this, in friendship let us join; If heaven our steps to foreign lands incline, My guest in Argos thou, and I in Lycia thine.

Enough of Trojans to this lance shall yield, In the full harvest of yon ample field; Enough of Greeks shall dye thy spear with gore;

But thou and Diomed be foes no more. Now change we arms, and prove to either host We guard the friendship of the line we boast.

Thus having said, the gallant chiefs alight, Their hands they join, their mutual faith they plight; Brave Glaucus then each narrow thought resign'd, -LRB-Jove warm'd his (guest) bosom, and enlarged his (guest) mind,-RRB-

For Diomed's brass arms, of mean device, For which nine oxen paid, -LRB-a vulgar price,-RRB- He (guest) gave his (guest) own, of gold divinely wrought,-LRB-171-RRB-

'' A hundred beeves the shining purchase bought. Meantime the guardian of the Trojan state, Great Hector, enter'd at the Scaean gate.-LRB-172-RRB-

Beneath the beech-tree's consecrated shades, The Trojan matrons and the Trojan maids Around him (Hector) flock'd, all press'd with pious care For husbands, brothers, sons, engaged in war.

He (Hector) bids the train in long procession go, And seek the gods, to avert the impending woe. And now to Priam's stately courts he (Hector) came, Rais'd on arch'd columns of stupendous frame

; O'er these a range of marble structure runs, The rich pavilions of his (Hector) fifty sons, In fifty chambers lodged: and rooms of state,-LRB-173-RRB-

Opposed to those, where Priam's daughters sate. Twelve domes for them and their loved spouses shone, Of equal beauty, and of polish'd stone.

Hither great Hector pass'd, nor pass'd unseen Of royal Hecuba, his (Hector) mother-queen. -LRB-With her (Priam) Laodice, whose beauteous face Surpass'd the nymphs of Troy's illustrious race.-RRB-

``O Hector! say, what great occasion calls My son from fight, when Greece surrounds our walls; Com`st thou to supplicate the almighty power With lifted hands, from Ilion's lofty tower?

Long in a strict embrace she (Priam) held her (Priam) son, And press'd his (son) hand, and tender thus begun: Stay, till I bring the cup with

Then with a plenteous draught refresh thy soul, And draw new spirits from the generous bowl; Spent as thou art with long laborious fight, The brave defender of thy country's right.'' (Jove/Which Jove)

Bacchus crown'd, In Jove's high name, to sprinkle on the ground, And pay due vows to all the gods around.

``Far hence be Bacchus' gifts; -LRB-the chief rejoin'd;-RRB-

Inflaming wine, pernicious to mankind, Unnerves the limbs, and dulls the noble mind. Let chiefs abstain, and spare the sacred juice To sprinkle to the gods, its better use.

By me that holy office were profaned; Ill fits it me, with human gore distain'd, To the pure skies these horrid hands to raise, Or offer heaven's great Sire polluted praise.

The largest mantle your full wardrobes hold, Most prized for art, and labour'd o'er with gold, Before the goddess' honour'd knees be spread, And twelve young heifers to her (goddess) altar led.

So may the power, atoned by fervent prayer, Our wives, our infants, and our city spare; And far avert Tydides' wasteful ire,

You, with your matrons, go! a spotless train, And burn rich odours in Minerva's fane. Who mows whole troops, and makes all Troy retire.

Be this, O mother, your religious care: I go to rouse soft Paris to the war; If yet not lost to all the sense of shame, The recreant warrior hear the voice of fame.

Oh, would kind earth the hateful wretch embrace, That pest of Troy, that ruin of our race!-LRB-174-RRB- Deep to the dark abyss might he (warrior) descend, Troy yet should flourish, and my sorrows end.

'' (she)

This heard, she (mother) gave command: and summon'd came Each noble matron and illustrious dame. The Phrygian queen to her (queen) rich wardrobe went, Where treasured odours breathed a costly scent.

There lay the vestures of no vulgar art, Sidonian maids embroider'd every part, Whom from soft Sidon youthful Paris bore, With Helen touching on the Tyrian shore.

The various textures and the various dyes, She (Helen) chose a veil that shone superior far, And glow'd refulgent as the morning star.

Here, as the queen revolved with careful eyes Herself with this the long procession leads; The train majestically slow proceeds. Soon as to Ilion's topmost tower they come, And awful reach

the high Palladian dome, Antenor's consort, fair Theano, waits As Pallas' priestess, and unbars the gates. With hands uplifted and imploring eyes, They fill the dome with supplicating cries.

The priestess then the shining veil displays, Placed on Minerva's knees, and thus she (Minerva) prays:

``Oh awful goddess! ever-dreadful maid, Troy's strong defence, unconquer'd Pallas, aid!

Break thou Tydides' spear, and let him (Troy) fall Prone on the dust before the Trojan wall! So twelve young heifers, guiltless of the yoke, Shall fill thy temple with a grateful smoke.

But thou, atoned by penitence and prayer, Ourselves, our infants, and our city spare!'' (she)

So pray'd the priestess in her (priestess) holy fane; So vow'd the matrons, but they vow'd in vain.

While these appear before the power with prayers, Hector to Paris' lofty dome repairs.-LRB-175-RRB- Himself the mansion raised, from every part Assembling architects of matchless art.

Near Priam's court and Hector's palace stands The pompous structure, and the town commands. A spear the hero bore of wondrous strength, Of full ten cubits was the lance's length,

Before him (hero) brandish'd, at each motion shined Thus entering, in the glittering rooms he (hero) found His (hero) brother-chief, whose useless arms lay round, His (hero) eyes delighting with their splendid show, Brightening the shield, and polishing the bow.

The steely point with golden ringlets join'd, Beside him (hero) Helen with her (Helen) virgins stands, Guides their rich labours, and instructs their hands.

Him (hero) thus inactive, with an ardent look The prince beheld, and high-resenting spoke. '' Thy hate to Troy, is this the time to show?

-LRB-O wretch ill-fated, and thy country's foe!-RRB- Paris and Greece against us both conspire, Thy close resentment, and their vengeful ire.

For thee great Ilion's guardian heroes fall, Till heaps of dead alone defend her (Helen) wall, For thee the soldier bleeds, the matron mourns, And wasteful war in all its fury burns.

Ungrateful man! deserves not this thy care, Our troops to hearten, and our toils to share? Rise, or behold the conquering flames ascend, And all the Phrygian glories at an end.''

'' Brother, 'tis just, -LRB-replied the beauteous youth,-RRB- Thy free remonstrance proves thy worth and truth: Yet charge my absence less, O generous chief!

On hate to Troy, than conscious shame and grief: Here, hid from human eyes, thy brother sate, And mourn'd, in secret, his (brother) and Ilion's fate. '

Tis now enough; now glory spreads her (our) charms, And beauteous Helen calls her (Helen) chief to arms. Conquest to-day my happier sword may bless, 'Tis man's to fight, but heaven's to give success.

But while I arm, contain thy ardent mind; Or go, and Paris shall not lag behind. '' -LSB-Illustration: HECTOR CHIDING PARIS.-RSB-

HECTOR CHIDING PARIS. He (HECTOR) said, nor answer'd Priam's warlike son; When Helen thus with lowly grace begun: ``Oh, generous brother! -LRB-if the guilty dame That caused these woes deserve a sister's name!-RRB-

Would heaven, ere all these dreadful deeds were done, The day that show'd me to the golden sun Had seen my death!

why did not whirlwinds bear The fatal infant to the fowls of air? Why sunk I not beneath the whelming tide, And midst the roarings of the waters died?

Heaven fill'd up all my ills, and I accursed Bore all, and Paris of those ills the worst. Helen at least a braver spouse might claim, Warm'd with some virtue, some regard of fame!

The gods have link'd our miserable doom, Our present woe, and infamy to come: Wide shall it spread, and last through ages long, Example sad!

Now tired with toils, thy fainting limbs recline, With toils, sustain'd for Paris' sake and mine and theme of future song.

The chief replied:

``This time forbids to rest; The Trojan bands, by hostile fury press'd, Demand their Hector, and his (Hector) arm require; The combat urges, and my soul's on fire.

'' (The chief)

Urge thou thy knight to march where glory calls, And timely join me, ere I leave the walls. Ere yet I mingle in the direful fray, My wife, my infant, claim a moment's stay;

This day -LRB-perhaps the last that sees me here-RRB- Demands a parting word, a tender tear: This day, some god who hates our Trojan land May vanquish Hector by a Grecian hand.

He (Hector) said, and pass'd with sad presaging heart To seek his (Hector) spouse, his (Hector) soul's far dearer part; At home he (Hector) sought her (wife), but he (Hector) sought in vain; She (wife), with one maid of all her (wife) menial train, Had hence retired; and with her (wife) second joy, The young Astyanax, the hope of Troy, Pensive she (wife) stood on Ilion's towery height, Beheld the war, and sicken'd at the sight; There her (wife) sad eyes in vain her (wife) lord explore, Or weep the wounds her (wife) bleeding country bore.

But he (lord) who found not whom his (lord) soul desired, Whose virtue charm'd him (lord) as her (wife) beauty fired, Stood in the gates, and ask'd

If to the fane she (wife) went, Where late the mourning matrons made resort; Or sought her (wife) sisters in the Trojan court?''

'' ``what way she (wife) bent Her (wife) parting step?

``Not to the court, -LRB-replied the attendant train,-RRB- Nor mix'd with matrons to Minerva's fane:

To Ilion's steepy tower she (Minerva) bent her (Minerva) way, To mark the fortunes of the doubtful day. Troy fled, she (Minerva) heard, before the Grecian sword; She (Minerva) heard, and trembled for her (Minerva) absent lord:

Distracted with surprise, she (Minerva) seem'd to fly , Fear on her (Minerva) cheek, and sorrow m her (Minerva) eye. The nurse attended with her (nurse) infant boy, The young Astyanax, the hope of Troy.

'' (Hector/HECTOR/Stern)

Hector this heard, return'd without delay; Swift through the town he (Swift) trod his (Swift) former way, Through streets of palaces, and walks of state; And met the mourner at the Scaean gate.

With haste to meet him (mourner) sprung the joyful fair. His (mourner) blameless wife, Aetion's wealthy heir: -LRB-Cilician Thebe great Aetion sway'd ,

The nurse stood near, in whose embraces press'd, His (mourner) only hope hung smiling at her (nurse) breast, Whom each soft charm and early grace adorn,

To this loved infant Hector gave the name Scamandrius, from Scamander's honour'd stream; Astyanax the Trojans call'd the boy, From his (boy) great father, the defence of Troy.

Silent the warrior smiled, and pleased resign'd To tender passions all his (warrior) mighty mind; His (warrior) beauteous princess cast a mournful look,

And Hippoplacus' wide extended shade:-RRB- Fair as the new-born star that gilds the morn. Hung on his (Hung) hand, and then dejected spoke

; Her (princess) bosom laboured with a boding sigh, And the big tear stood trembling in her (princess) eye. -LSB-Illustration: THE MEETING OF HECTOR AND ANDROMACHE.-RSB-

THE MEETING OF HECTOR AND ANDROMACHE. '' Too daring prince! ah, whither dost thou run? Ah, too forgetful of thy wife and son!

And think`st thou not how wretched we shall be, A widow I, a helpless orphan he (son)? For sure such courage length of life denies, And thou must fall, thy virtue's sacrifice.

Greece in her (widow) single heroes strove in vain; Now hosts oppose thee, and thou must be slain. O grant me, gods, ere Hector meets his (Hector) doom,

All I can ask of heaven, an early tomb! So shall my days in one sad tenor run, And end with sorrows as they first begun.

No parent now remains my griefs to share, No father's aid, no mother's tender care. The fierce Achilles wrapt our walls in fire, Laid Thebe waste, and slew my warlike sire!

Stern as he (Stern) was, he (Stern) yet revered the dead, His (Stern) radiant arms preserved from hostile spoil, And laid him (Stern) decent on the funeral pile; Then raised a mountain where his (Stern) bones were burn'd, The mountain-nymphs the rural tomb adorn'd, Jove's sylvan daughters bade their elms bestow

By the same arm my seven brave brothers fell; In one sad day beheld the gates of hell; While the fat herds and snowy flocks they fed, Amid their fields the hapless heroes bled!

My mother lived to wear the victor's bands, The queen of Hippoplacia's sylvan lands: Redeem'd too late, she (queen) scarce beheld again Her (queen) pleasing empire and her (queen) native plain, When ah! oppress'd by life-consuming woe, She (queen) fell a victim to Diana's bow.

His (victim) fate compassion in the victor bred; A barren shade, and in his (victim) honour grow. '' '' Yet while my Hector still survives, I see My father, mother, brethren, all, in thee: Alas!

my parents, brothers, kindred, all Once more will perish, if my Hector fall, Thy wife, thy infant, in thy danger share:

That quarter most the skilful Greeks annoy, Where yon wild fig-trees join the wall of Troy; Thou, from this tower defend the important post; There Agamemnon points his (Agamemnon) dreadful host, That pass Tydides, Ajax, strive to gain,

Oh, prove a husband's and a father's care! And there the vengeful Spartan fires his (father) train. Thrice our bold foes the fierce attack have given, Or led by hopes, or dictated from heaven.

Let others in the field their arms employ, But stay my Hector here, and guard his (Hector) Troy. '' The chief replied:

``That post shall be my care, Not that alone, but all the works of war.

How would the sons of Troy, in arms renown'd, And Troy's proud dames, whose garments sweep the ground Attaint the lustre of my former name, Should Hector basely quit the field of fame?

My early youth was bred to martial pains, My soul impels me to the embattled plains! Let me be foremost to defend the throne, And guard my father's glories, and my own.

'' (The chief)

Yet come it will, the day decreed by fates! -LRB-How my heart trembles while my tongue relates!-RRB- The day when thou, imperial Troy! must bend, And see thy warriors fall, thy glories end.

And yet no dire presage so wounds my mind, My mother's death, the ruin of my kind, Not Priam's hoary hairs defiled with gore, Not all my brothers gasping on the shore;

As thine, Andromache! Thy griefs I dread: I see thee trembling, weeping, captive led! In Argive looms our battles to design, And woes, of which so large a part was thine!

To bear the victor's hard commands, or bring The weight of waters from Hyperia's spring. There while you groan beneath the load of life, They cry, `Behold the mighty Hector's wife!'

Some haughty Greek, who lives thy tears to see, Imbitters all thy woes, by naming me. The thoughts of glory past, and present shame, A thousand griefs shall waken at the name!

May I lie cold before that dreadful day, Press'd with a load of monumental clay! Thy Hector, wrapt in everlasting sleep, Shall neither hear thee sigh, nor see thee weep.

'' Thus having spoke, the illustrious chief of Troy Stretch'd his (chief) fond arms to clasp the lovely boy. The babe clung crying to his (chief) nurse's breast, Scared at the dazzling helm, and nodding crest.

With secret pleasure each fond parent smiled, And Hector hasted to relieve his (Hector) child, The glittering terrors from his (Hector) brows unbound, And placed the beaming helmet on the ground;

Then kiss'd the child, and, lifting high in air, Thus to the gods preferr'd a father's prayer:

``O thou! whose glory fills the ethereal throne, And all ye deathless powers!

Grant him (Grant), like me, to purchase just renown, To guard the Trojans, to defend the crown, Against his (Grant) country's foes the war to wage, And rise the Hector of the future age!

So when triumphant from successful toils Of heroes slain he (Hector) bears the reeking spoils, Whole hosts may hail him (Hector) with deserved acclaim, And say, `This chief transcends his (chief) father's fame:' While pleased amidst the general shouts of Troy, His (chief) mother's conscious heart o'erflows with joy.

He (chief) spoke, and fondly gazing on her (mother) charms, Restored the pleasing burden to her (mother) arms; Soft on her (mother) fragrant breast the babe she (mother) laid, Hush'd to repose, and with a smile survey'd.

protect my son! '' (a father)

The troubled pleasure soon chastised by fear, She (mother) mingled with a smile a tender tear. The soften'd chief with kind compassion view'd,

And dried the falling drops, and thus pursued:

``Andromache! my soul's far better part, Why with untimely sorrows heaves thy heart?

No hostile hand can antedate my doom, Till fate condemns me to the silent tomb. Fix'd is the term to all the race of earth;

And such the hard condition of our birth: No force can then resist, no flight can save, All sink alike, the fearful and the brave.

No more--but hasten to thy tasks at home, There guide the spindle, and direct the loom: Me glory summons to the martial scene, The field of combat is the sphere for men.

Where heroes war, the foremost place I claim, The first in danger as the first in fame. '' (chief)

Thus having said, the glorious chief resumes His (chief) towery helmet, black with shading plumes.

His (chief) princess parts with a prophetic sigh, Unwilling parts, and oft reverts her (princess) eye That stream'd at every look; then, moving slow, Sought her (princess) own palace, and indulged her (princess) woe.

There, while her (princess) tears deplored the godlike man, Through all her (princess) train the soft infection ran; The pious maids their mingled sorrows shed, And mourn the living Hector, as the dead.

But now, no longer deaf to honour's call, Forth issues Paris from the palace wall. In brazen arms that cast a gleamy ray, Swift through the town the warrior bends his (warrior) way.

Breaks from his (warrior) stall, and beats the trembling ground; Pamper'd and proud, he (warrior) seeks the wonted tides, And laves, in height of blood his (warrior) shining sides; His (warrior) head now freed, he (warrior) tosses to the skies; His (warrior) mane dishevell'd o'er his (warrior) shoulders flies; He (warrior) snuffs the females in the distant plain, And springs, exulting, to his (warrior) fields again.

In arms refulgent as the god of day, The son of Priam, glorying in his (son) might, Rush'd forth with Hector to the fields of fight.

The wanton courser thus with reins unbound-LRB-176-RRB- With equal triumph, sprightly, bold, and gay, And now, the warriors passing on the way, The graceful Paris first excused his (Hector) stay.

To whom the noble Hector thus replied:

``O chief! in blood, and now in arms, allied! Thy power in war with justice none contest

; Known is thy courage, and thy strength confess'd. What pity sloth should seize a soul so brave, Or godlike Paris live a woman's slave!

My heart weeps blood at what the Trojans say, And hopes thy deeds shall wipe the stain away. Haste then, in all their glorious labours share, For much they suffer, for thy sake, in war.

These ills shall cease, whene'er by Jove's decree We crown the bowl to heaven and liberty: While the proud foe his (foe) frustrate triumphs mourns, And Greece indignant through her (woman) seas returns.

'' (Hector/HECTOR/Stern)

-LSB-Illustration: BOWS AND BOW CASE.-RSB- BOWS AND BOW CASE. -LSB-Illustration: IRIS.-RSB- IRIS. BOOK VII. ARGUMENT THE SINGLE COMBAT OF HECTOR AND AJAX.

The battle renewing with double ardour upon the return of Hector, Minerva is under apprehensions for the Greeks. Apollo, seeing her (Minerva) descend from Olympus, joins her (Minerva) near the Scaean gate.

They agree to put off the general engagement for that day, and incite Hector to challenge the Greeks to a single combat.

Nine of the princes accepting the challenge, the lot is cast and falls upon Ajax. These heroes, after several attacks, are parted by the night.

The Trojans calling a council, Antenor purposes the delivery of Helen to the Greeks, to which Paris will not consent, but offers to restore them her (Helen) riches.

Priam sends a herald to make this offer, and to demand a truce for burning the dead, the last of which only is agreed to by Agamemnon.

When the funerals are performed, the Greeks, pursuant to the advice of Nestor, erect a fortification to protect their fleet and camp, flanked with towers, and defended by a ditch and palisades.

Neptune testifies his (Nestor) jealousy at this work, but is pacified by a promise from Jupiter. Both armies pass the night in feasting but Jupiter disheartens the Trojans with thunder, and other signs of his (Nestor) wrath.

The three and twentieth day ends with the duel of Hector and Ajax, the next day the truce is agreed; another is taken up in the funeral rites of the slain and one more in building the fortification before the ships.

So that somewhat about three days is employed in this book. The scene lies wholly in the field. So spoke the guardian of the Trojan state, Then rush'd impetuous through the Scaean gate.

As when to sailors labouring through the main, That long have heaved the weary oar in vain, Jove bids at length the expected gales arise; The gales blow grateful, and the vessel flies.

Him (sailors) Paris follow'd to the dire alarms; Both breathing slaughter, both resolved in arms. So welcome these to Troy's desiring train, The bands are cheer'd, the war awakes again.

Bold Paris first the work of death begun On great Menestheus , Areithous' son, Sprung from the fair Philomeda's embrace, The pleasing Arne was his (Arne) native place.

Then sunk Eioneus to the shades below, Beneath his (Arne) steely casque he (Arne) felt the blow-LRB-177-RRB- Full on his (Arne) neck, from Hector's weighty hand; And roll'd, with limbs relax'd, along the land.

By Glaucus' spear the bold Iphmous bleeds, Fix'd in the shoulder as he (Hector) mounts his (Hector) steeds; Headlong he (Hector) tumbles: his (Hector) slack nerves unbound,

Drop the cold useless members on the ground. When now Minerva saw her (Minerva) Argives slain, From vast Olympus to the gleaming plain

Fierce she (Minerva) descends: Apollo marked her (Minerva) flight, Nor shot less swift from Ilion's towery height. Radiant they met, beneath the beechen shade; When thus Apollo to the blue-eyed maid:

``What cause, O daughter of Almighty Jove! Thus wings thy progress from the realms above? Once more impetuous dost thou bend thy way, To give to Greece the long divided day?

Too much has Troy already felt thy hate, Now breathe thy rage, and hush the stern debate; This day, the business of the field suspend; War soon shall kindle, and great Ilion bend; Since vengeful goddesses confederate join To raze her (daughter) walls, though built by hands divine.

To whom the progeny of Jove replies: ``I left, for this, the council of the skies: But who shall bid conflicting hosts forbear, What art shall calm the furious sons of war?

To her (daughter) the god:

``Great Hector's soul incite To dare the boldest Greek to single fight, Till Greece, provoked, from all her (daughter) numbers show A warrior worthy to be Hector's foe.

'' (the god)

'' '' At this agreed, the heavenly powers withdrew; Sage Helenus their secret counsels knew; Hector, inspired, he (Hector) sought: to him (Hector) address'd,

Thus told the dictates of his (Hector) sacred breast:

``O son of Priam! let thy faithful ear Receive my words: thy friend and brother hear!

Go forth persuasive, and a while engage The warring nations to suspend their rage; Then dare the boldest of the hostile train To mortal combat on the listed plain.

He (friend) said: the warrior heard the word with joy; Then with his (friend) spear restrain'd the youth of Troy, Held by the midst athwart.

For not this day shall end thy glorious date; The gods have spoke it, and their voice is fate. '' (him)

On either hand The squadrons part; the expecting Trojans stand; Great Agamemnon bids the Greeks forbear:

They breathe, and hush the tumult of the war. The Athenian maid, and glorious god of day,-LRB-178-RRB- With silent joy the settling hosts survey:

In form of vultures, on the beech's height They sit conceal'd, and wait the future fight. The thronging troops obscure the dusky fields, Horrid with bristling spears, and gleaming shields.

The waves scarce heave, the face of ocean sleeps, And a still horror saddens all the deeps; Thus in thick orders settling wide around, At length composed they sit, and shade the ground.

Great Hector first amidst both armies broke The solemn silence, and their powers bespoke:

``Hear, all ye Trojan, all ye Grecian bands, What my soul prompts, and what some god commands.

Great Jove, averse our warfare to compose, O'erwhelms the nations with new toils and woes; War with a fiercer tide once more returns, Till Ilion falls, or till yon navy burns.

You then, O princes of the Greeks! appear; 'Tis Hector speaks, and calls the gods to hear: From all your troops select the boldest knight,

As when a general darkness veils the main, -LRB-Soft Zephyr curling the wide wat`ry plain,-RRB- And him (knight), the boldest, Hector dares to fight.

Here if I fall, by chance of battle slain, Be his (Hector) my spoil, and his (Hector) these arms remain; But let my body, to my friends return'd,

And if Apollo, in whose aid I trust, Shall stretch your daring champion in the dust; If mine the glory to despoil the foe; On Phoebus' temple I'll his (foe) arms bestow:

The breathless carcase to your navy sent, Greece on the shore shall raise a monument; Which when some future mariner surveys, Wash'd by broad Hellespont's resounding seas, Thus shall he (foe) say, 'A valiant Greek lies there,

By Trojan hands and Trojan flames be burn'd. By Hector slain, the mighty man of war,' The stone shall tell your vanquish'd hero's name.

And distant ages learn the victor's fame. '' (Hector/HECTOR/Stern)

This fierce defiance Greece astonish'd heard, Blush'd to refuse, and to accept it fear'd.

Whose coward souls your manly form disgrace, How great the shame, when every age shall know That not a Grecian met this noble foe!

Stern Menelaus first the silence broke, And, inly groaning, thus opprobrious spoke:

``Women of Greece! O scandal of your race, Go then!

Be what ye seem, unanimated clay, Myself will dare the danger of the day; 'Tis man's bold task the generous strife to try,

resolve to earth, from whence ye grew, A heartless, spiritless, inglorious crew! But in the hands of God is victory. '' (Stern Menelaus)

These words scarce spoke, with generous ardour press'd, His (God) manly limbs in azure arms he (God) dress'd. That day, Atrides! a superior hand Had stretch'd

But all at once, thy fury to compose, The kings of Greece, an awful band, arose; Even he (God) their chief, great Agamemnon, press'd Thy daring hand, and this advice address'd:

thee breathless on the hostile strand;

``Whither, O Menelaus! wouldst thou run, And tempt a fate which prudence bids thee shun?

Grieved though thou art, forbear the rash design; Great Hectors arm is mightier far than thine: Even fierce Achilles learn'd its force to fear, And trembling met this dreadful son of war.

The mightiest warrior of the Achaian name, Though bold and burning with desire of fame, Content the doubtful honour might forego, So great the danger, and so brave the foe.

Sit thou secure, amidst thy social band; Greece in our cause shall arm some powerful hand. '' (Agamemnon)

He (foe) said, and turn'd his (foe) brother's vengeful mind

; He (foe) stoop'd to reason, and his (foe) rage resign'd, No longer bent to rush on certain harms; His (foe) joyful friends unbrace his (foe) azure arms.

He (foe) from whose lips divine persuasion flows, Grave Nestor, then, in graceful act arose; Thus to the kings he (Nestor) spoke:

``What grief, what shame Attend on Greece, and all the Grecian name!

How shall, alas! her (our) hoary heroes mourn Their sons degenerate, and their race a scorn! What tears shall down thy silvery beard be

Once with what joy the generous prince would hear Of every chief who fought this glorious war, Participate their fame, and pleased inquire

should he (chief) see our warriors trembling stand, And trembling all before one hostile hand; How would he (chief) lift his (chief) aged arms on high, Lament inglorious Greece, and beg to die!

roll'd, O Peleus, old in arms, in wisdom old! Each name, each action, and each hero's sire! Gods! Oh! would to all the immortal powers above, Minerva, Phoebus, and almighty Jove!

Years might again roll back, my youth renew, And give this arm the spring which once it knew When fierce in war, where Jardan's waters fall, I led my troops to Phea's trembling wall,

There Ereuthalion braved us in the field, Proud Areithous' dreadful arms to wield; Great Areithous, known from shore to shore By the huge, knotted, iron mace he (Great) bore; No lance he (Great) shook, nor bent the twanging bow, But broke, with this, the battle of the foe.

And with the Arcadian spears my prowess tried, Where Celadon rolls down his (foe) rapid tide.-LRB-179-RRB- Him (foe) not by manly force Lycurgus slew, Whose guileful javelin from the thicket flew,

Deep in a winding way his (foe) breast assailed, Nor aught the warrior's thundering mace avail'd. Supine he (foe) fell: those arms which Mars before Had given the vanquish'd, now the victor bore:

Furious with this he (victor) crush'd our levell'd bands, And dared the trial of the strongest hands; Nor could the strongest hands his (victor) fury stay: All saw, and fear'd, his (victor) huge tempestuous sway

But when old age had dimm'd Lycurgus' eyes, To Ereuthalion he (victor) consign'd the prize. Till I, the youngest of the host, appear'd, And, youngest, met whom all our army fear'd.

I fought the chief: my arms Minerva crown'd: Prone fell the giant o'er a length of ground. What then I was, O were your Nestor now!

But, warriors, you that youthful vigour boast, The flower of Greece, the examples of our host, Sprung from such fathers, who such numbers sway, Can you stand trembling, and desert the day?'' (he)

His (Nestor) warm reproofs the listening kings inflame; And nine, the noblest of the Grecian name, Up-started fierce: but far before the rest

Not Hector's self should want an equal foe. The king of men advanced his (king) dauntless breast: Then bold Tydides, great in arms,

And Merion, dreadful as the god of war: With these Eurypylus and Thoas stand, And wise Ulysses closed the daring band.

appear'd; And next his (Ulysses) bulk gigantic Ajax rear'd; Oileus follow'd; Idomen was there,-LRB-180-RRB- All these, alike inspired with noble rage, Demand the fight.

To whom the Pylian sage:

``Lest thirst of glory your brave souls divide, What chief shall combat, let the gods decide.

Whom heaven shall choose, be his (chief) the chance to raise His (chief) country's fame, his (chief) own immortal praise. '' (the sage)

The lots produced, each hero signs his (chief) own: Then in the general's helm the fates are thrown,-LRB-181-RRB-

in whose hand is fate, A worthy champion for the Grecian state: This task let Ajax or Tydides prove, Or he (champion), the king of kings, beloved by Jove.

The people pray, with lifted eyes and hands, And vows like these ascend from all the bands:

``Grant, thou Almighty! '' (all the bands)

This from the right to left the herald bears, Held out in order to the Grecian peers; Each to his (Almighty) rival yields the mark unknown, Till godlike Ajax finds the lot his (Almighty) own; Surveys the inscription with rejoicing eyes, Then casts before him (Almighty), and with transport cries:

Old Nestor shook the casque. By heaven inspired, Leap'd forth the lot, of every Greek desired.

``Warriors! I claim the lot, and arm with joy; Be mine the conquest of this chief of Troy.

Now while my brightest arms my limbs invest, To Saturn's son be all your vows address'd: But pray in secret, lest the foes should hear, And deem your prayers the mean effect of fear.

Said I in secret? No, your vows declare In such a voice as fills the earth and air, Lives there a chief whom Ajax ought to dread?

Ajax, in all the toils of battle bred! From warlike Salamis I drew my birth, And, born to combats, fear no force on earth.

'' (He)

He (chief) said. The troops with elevated eyes, Implore the god whose thunder rends the skies:
``O father of mankind, superior lord!

On lofty Ida's holy hill adored: Who in the highest heaven hast fix'd thy throne, Supreme of gods! unbounded and alone:

The praise and conquest of this doubtful day; Or, if illustrious Hector be thy care, That both may claim it, and that both may share.

Now Ajax braced his (Hector) dazzling armour on; Sheathed in bright steel the giant-warrior shone: He (Hector) moves to combat with majestic pace; So stalks in arms the grisly god of Thrace,-LRB-182-RRB-

Grant thou, that Telamon may bear away '' (the god)

When Jove to punish faithless men prepares, And gives whole nations to the waste of wars,

Thus march'd the chief, tremendous as a god; Grimly he (god) smiled; earth trembled as he (god) strode:-LRB-183-RRB- His (god) massy javelin quivering in his (god) hand, He (god) stood, the bulwark of the Grecian band.

Through every Argive heart new transport ran; All Troy stood trembling at the mighty man: Even Hector paused; and with new doubt oppress'd, Felt his (Hector) great heart suspended in his (Hector) breast: 'Twas vain to seek retreat, and vain to fear; Himself had challenged, and the foe drew near.

Huge was its orb, with seven thick folds o'ercast, Of tough bull-hides; of solid brass the last, -LRB-The work of Tychius, who in Hyle dwell'd

And in all arts of armoury excell'd,-RRB- This Ajax bore before his (foe) manly breast, And, threatening, thus his (foe) adverse chief address'd:

Stern Telamon behind his (foe) ample shield, As from a brazen tower, o'erlook'd the field.

``Hector! approach my arm, and singly know What strength thou hast, and what the Grecian foe.

: Let him (foe), unactive on the sea-beat shore, Indulge his (foe) wrath, and aid our arms no more; Whole troops of heroes Greece has yet to boast, And sends thee one, a sample of her (foe) host, Such as I am, I come to prove thy might;

Achilles shuns the fight; yet some there are, Not void of soul, and not unskill'd in war No more--be sudden, and begin the fight.

'' (unknown)

``O son of Telamon, thy country's pride! -LRB-To Ajax thus the Trojan prince replied-RRB- Me, as a boy, or woman, wouldst thou fright, New to the field, and trembling at the fight?

To combat born, and bred amidst alarms: I know to shift my ground, remount the car, Turn, charge, and answer every call of war; To right, to left, the dexterous lance I wield, And bear thick battle on my sounding shield

Thou meet`st a chief deserving of thy arms, But open be our fight, and bold each blow; I steal no conquest from a noble foe.

'' (He)

He (foe) said, and rising, high above the field Whirl'd the long lance against the sevenfold shield. Full on the brass descending from above Through six bull-hides the furious weapon drove,

Then Ajax threw; Through Hector's shield the forceful javelin flew, His (Hector) corslet enters, and his (Hector) garment rends, And glancing downwards, near his (Hector) flank descends.

Till in the seventh it fix'd. The wary Trojan shrinks, and bending low Beneath his (Hector) buckler, disappoints the blow. From their bored shields the chiefs their javelins drew, Then close impetuous, and the charge renew;

At Ajax, Hector his (Hector) long lance extends; The blunted point against the buckler bends; But Ajax, watchful as his (Hector) foe drew near, Drove through the Trojan targe the knotty spear;

Fierce as the mountain-lions bathed in blood, Or foaming boars, the terror of the wood. It reach'd his (Hector) neck, with matchless strength impell'd!

Yet ceased not Hector thus; but stooping down, In his (Hector) strong hand up-heaved a flinty stone, Black, craggy, vast: to this his (Black) force he (Black) bends; Full on the brazen boss the stone descends; The hollow brass resounded with the shock: Then Ajax seized the fragment of a rock, Applied each nerve, and swinging round on high,

With force tempestuous, let the ruin fly; The huge stone thundering through his (Black) buckler broke: His (Black) slacken'd knees received the numbing stroke; Great Hector falls extended on the field, His (Hector) bulk supporting on the shatter'd shield: Nor wanted heavenly aid:

Spouts the black gore, and dims his (Hector) shining shield. Apollo's might Confirm'd his (Hector) sinews, and restored to fight. And now both heroes their broad falchions drew

In flaming circles round their heads they flew; But then by heralds' voice the word was given. The sacred ministers of earth and heaven: Divine Talthybius, whom the Greeks employ.

And sage Idaeus on the part of Troy, Between the swords their peaceful sceptres rear'd ; And first Idaeus' awful voice was heard: -LSB-Illustration: HECTOR AND AJAX SEPARATED BY THE HERALDS.-RSB-

HECTOR AND AJAX SEPARATED BY THE HERALDS. '' Forbear, my sons! your further force to prove, Both dear to men, and both beloved of Jove.

To either host your matchless worth is known, Each sounds your praise, and war is all your own. But now the Night extends her (sage) awful shade; The goddess parts you; be the night obey'd.''-LRB-184-RRB-

Let him (HECTOR), who first provoked our chiefs to fight, Let him (HECTOR) demand the sanction of the night; If first he (HECTOR) ask'd it

To whom great Ajax his (HECTOR) high soul express'd:

``O sage! to Hector be these words address'd. , I content obey, And cease the strife when Hector shows the way.'' (Ajax/AJAX/Oilean Ajax)

``O first of Greeks! -LRB-his (Hector) noble foe rejoin'd-RRB- Whom heaven adorns, superior to thy kind, With strength of body, and with worth of mind!

Now martial law commands us to forbear; Hereafter we shall meet in glorious war, Some future day shall lengthen out the strife, And let the gods decide of death or life!

Return, brave Ajax, to thy Grecian friends, And joy the nations whom thy arm defends; As I shall glad each chief, and Trojan wife, Who wearies heaven with vows for Hector's life.

But let us, on this memorable day, Exchange some gift: that Greece and Troy may say, `Not hate, but glory, made these chiefs contend; And each brave foe was in his (foe) soul a friend.'

Since, then, the night extends her (wife) gloomy shade, And heaven enjoins it, be the night obey'd. '' (He)

With that, a sword with stars of silver graced, The baldric studded, and the sheath enchased, He (foe) gave the Greek.

The generous Greek bestow'd A radiant belt that rich with purple glow'd. Then with majestic grace they quit the plain; This seeks the Grecian, that the Phrygian train.

The Trojan bands returning Hector wait, And hail with joy the Champion of their state; Escaped great Ajax, they survey him (Hector) round, Alive, unarm'd, and vigorous from his (Hector) wound; To Troy's high gates the godlike man they bear Their present triumph, as their late despair.

But Ajax, glorying in his (Hector) hardy deed, The well-arm'd Greeks to Agamemnon lead. A steer for sacrifice the king design'd, Of full five years, and of the nobler kind.

The victim falls; they strip the smoking hide, The beast they quarter, and the joints divide; Then spread the tables, the repast prepare

, Each takes his (victim) seat, and each receives his (victim) share. The king himself -LRB-an honorary sign-RRB- Before great Ajax placed the mighty chine.-LRB-185-RRB-

When now the rage of hunger was removed, Nestor, in each persuasive art approved, The sage whose counsels long had sway'd

the rest, In words like these his (Nestor) prudent thought express'd:

``How dear, O kings! this fatal day has cost, What Greeks are perish'd! what a people lost!

What tides of blood have drench'd Scamander's shore! What crowds of heroes sunk to rise no more! Then hear me, chief! nor let the morrow's light

Awake thy squadrons to new toils of fight: Some space at least permit the war to breathe, While we to flames our slaughter'd friends bequeath, From the red field their scatter'd bodies bear, And nigh the fleet a funeral structure rear; So decent urns their snowy bones may keep, And pious children o'er their ashes weep.

Here, where on one promiscuous pile they blazed, High o'er them all a general tomb be raised; Next, to secure our camp and naval powers, Raise an embattled wall, with lofty towers; From space to space be ample gates around,

For passing chariots; and a trench profound. So Greece to combat shall in safety go, Nor fear the fierce incursions of the foe.

'' (Nestor The sage)

'Twas thus the sage his (foe) wholesome counsel moved; The sceptred kings of Greece his (foe) words approved. Meanwhile, convened at Priam's palace-gate,

The Trojan peers in nightly council sate; A senate void of order, as of choice : Their hearts were fearful, and confused their voice.

Tis heaven the counsel of my breast inspires, And I but move what every god requires: Let Sparta's treasures be this hour restored, And Argive Helen own her (Helen) ancient lord.

Antenor, rising, thus demands their ear:

``Ye Trojans, Dardans, and auxiliars, hear! ' The ties of faith, the sworn alliance, broke, Our impious battles the just gods provoke.

As this advice ye practise, or reject, So hope success, or dread the dire effect. '' (Antenor)

The senior spoke and sate.

But sound ungrateful in a warrior's ears: Old man, if void of fallacy or art, Thy words express the purpose of thy heart, Thou, in thy time, more sound advice hast given; But wisdom has its date, assign'd by heaven.

To whom replied The graceful husband of the Spartan bride:

``Cold counsels, Trojan, may become thy years Then hear me, princes of the Trojan name!

Their treasures I'll restore, but not the dame; My treasures too, for peace, I will resign; But be this bright possession ever mine.'' (the Spartan bride)

'Twas then, the growing discord to compose, Slow from his (husband) seat the reverend Priam rose: His (husband) godlike aspect deep attention drew: He (husband) paused, and these pacific words ensue:

``Ye Trojans, Dardans, and auxiliar bands!

Now take refreshment as the hour demands; Guard well the walls, relieve the watch of night. Till the new sun restores the cheerful light.

Next let a truce be ask'd, that Troy may burn Her (I) slaughter'd heroes, and their bones inurn; That done, once more the fate of war be tried, And whose the conquest, mighty Jove decide!

Then shall our herald, to the Atrides sent, Before their ships proclaim my son's intent. '' (He)

The monarch spoke: the warriors snatch'd with haste -LRB-Each at his (monarch) post in arms-RRB- a short repast.

Idaeus bent his (monarch) way; There, to the sons of Mars, in council found, He (monarch) raised his (monarch) voice: the host stood listening round.

Soon as the rosy morn had waked the day, To the black ships '' Ye sons of Atreus, and ye Greeks, give ear!

The words of Troy, and Troy's great monarch, hear. Pleased may ye hear -LRB-so heaven succeed my prayers-RRB- What Paris, author of the war, declares.

The spoils and treasures he (author) to Ilion bore -LRB-Oh had he (author) perish'd ere they touch'd our shore!-RRB- He (author) proffers injured Greece: with large increase Of added Trojan wealth to buy the peace.

But to restore the beauteous bride again, This Greece demands, and Troy requests in vain. Next, O ye chiefs! we ask a truce to burn Our slaughter'd heroes, and their bones inurn.

That done, once more the fate of war be tried, And whose the conquest, mighty Jove decide!'' The Greeks gave ear, but none the silence broke; At length Tydides rose, and rising spoke:

``Oh, take not, friends! defrauded of your fame, Their proffer'd wealth, nor even the Spartan dame. Let conquest make them ours: fate shakes their wall, And Troy already totters to her (Jove) fall.

'' (The Greeks)

The admiring chiefs, and all the Grecian name, With general shouts return'd him (Jove) loud acclaim. Then thus the king of kings rejects the peace:
``Herald!

in him (king) thou hear`st the voice of Greece For what remains; let funeral flames be fed With heroes' corps: I war not with the dead:

Go search your slaughtered chiefs on yonder plain, And gratify the manes of the slain. Be witness, Jove, whose thunder rolls on high!'' (kings)

He (witness) said, and rear'd his (witness) sceptre to the sky. To sacred Troy, where all her (king) princes lay To wait the event, the herald bent his (witness) way.

He (witness) came, and standing in the midst, explain'd The peace rejected, but the truce obtain'd. Straight to their several cares the Trojans move, Some search the plains, some fell the sounding grove:

And now from forth the chambers of the main, To shed his (witness) sacred light on earth again, Arose the golden chariot of the day, And tipp'd the mountains with a purple ray.

Nor less the Greeks, descending on the shore, Hew'd the green forests, and the bodies bore. In mingled throngs the Greek and Trojan train Through heaps of carnage search'd the mournful plain.

Scarce could the friend his (friend) slaughter'd friend explore, With dust dishonour'd, and deformed with gore. The wounds they wash'd, their pious tears they shed, And, laid along their cars, deplored the dead.

: with silent haste The bodies decent on the piles were placed: With melting hearts the cold remains they burn'd, And, sadly slow, to sacred Troy return'd.

Nor less the Greeks their pious sorrows shed, And decent on the pile dispose the dead; The cold remains consume with equal care; And slowly, sadly, to their fleet repair.

Now, ere the morn had streak'd with reddening light The doubtful confines of the day and night, About the dying flames

Sage Priam check'd their grief the Greeks appear'd, And round the pile a general tomb they rear'd. Then, to secure the camp and naval powers, They raised embattled walls with lofty towers:-LRB-186-RRB-

From space to space were ample gates around, For passing chariots, and a trench profound Of large extent; and deep in earth below, Strong piles infix'd stood adverse to the foe.

In shining circle round their father Jove, Amazed beheld the wondrous works of man: Then he (man), whose trident shakes the earth, began:

``What mortals henceforth shall our power adore, Our fanes frequent, our oracles implore, If the proud Grecians thus successful boast Their rising bulwarks on the sea-beat coast?

So toil'd the Greeks: meanwhile the gods above, See the long walls extending to the main, No god consulted, and no victim slain!

Their fame shall fill the world's remotest ends, Wide as the morn her (man) golden beam extends; While old Laomedon's divine abodes, Those radiant structures raised by labouring gods, Shall, razed and lost, in long oblivion sleep.

'' (he)

Thus spoke the hoary monarch of the deep. The almighty Thunderer with a frown replies, That clouds the world, and blackens half the skies:
``Strong god of ocean!

thou, whose rage can make The solid earth's eternal basis shake! What cause of fear from mortal works could move-LRB-187-RRB- The meanest subject of our realms above?

Where'er the sun's refulgent rays are cast, Thy power is honour'd, and thy fame shall last. But yon proud work no future age shall view, No trace remain where once the glory grew.

The sapp'd foundations by thy force shall fall, And, whelm'd beneath the waves, drop the huge wall: Vast drifts of sand shall change the former shore:

The ruin vanish'd, and the name no more. '' (The Thunderer)

Thus they in heaven: while, o'er the Grecian train, The rolling sun descending to the main Beheld the finish'd work.

Their bulls they slew; Back from the tents the savoury vapour flew. And now the fleet, arrived from Lemnos' strands, With Bacchus' blessings cheered the generous bands.

Of fragrant wines the rich Eunaeus sent A thousant measures to the royal tent. -LRB-Eunaeus, whom Hypsipyle of yore To Jason, shepherd of his (Jason) people, bore,-RRB-

The rest they purchased at their proper cost, And well the plenteous freight supplied the host: Each, in exchange, proportion'd treasures gave;-LRB-188-RRB- Some, brass or iron; some, an ox, or slave.

But Jove averse the signs of wrath display'd, And shot red lightnings through the gloomy shade: Humbled they stood; pale horror seized on all, While the deep thunder shook the aerial hall.

All night they feast, the Greek and Trojan powers: Those on the fields, and these within their towers. Each pour'd to Jove before the bowl was

crown'd; And large libations drench'd the thirsty ground: Then late, refresh'd with sleep from toils of fight, Enjoy'd the balmy blessings of the night.

-LSB-Illustration: GREEK AMPHORA--WINE VESSELS.-RSB- GREEK AMPHORA--WINE VESSELS. BOOK VIII. ARGUMENT. THE SECOND BATTLE, AND THE DISTRESS OF THE GREEKS. Jupiter assembles a council of the deities, and threatens them with the pains of Tartarus if they assist either side:

Minerva only obtains of him (they) that she (Minerva) may direct the Greeks by her (Minerva) counsels.-LRB-189-RRB- his (they) balances the fates of both, and affrights the Greeks with his (they) thunders and lightnings.

Nestor alone continues in the field in great danger: Diomed relieves him (Nestor); whose exploits, and those of Hector, are excellently described.

Juno endeavours to animate Neptune to the assistance of the Greeks, but in vain. The acts of Teucer, who is at length wounded by Hector, and carried off.

Juno and Minerva prepare to aid the Grecians, but are restrained by Iris, sent from Jupiter. The night puts an end to the battle.

Hector continues in the field, -LRB-the Greeks being driven to their fortifications before the ships,-RRB- and gives orders to keep the watch all night in the camp, to prevent the enemy from re-embarking and escaping by flight.

The time of seven and twenty days is employed from the opening of the poem to the end of this book.

They kindle fires through all the fields, and pass the night under arms. The scene here -LRB-except of the celestial machines-RRB- lies in the field towards the seashore.

Aurora now, fair daughter of the dawn, Sprinkled with rosy light the dewy lawn; When Jove convened the senate of the skies,

Where high Olympus' cloudy tops arise, The sire of gods his (sire) awful silence broke; The heavens attentive trembled as he (sire) spoke: ``Celestial states!

give ear, Hear our decree, and reverence what ye hear; The fix'd decree which not all heaven can move; Thou, fate!

What god but enters yon forbidden field, Who yields assistance, or but wills to yield, Back to the skies with shame he (god) shall be driven, Gash'd with dishonest wounds, the scorn of heaven; Or far, oh far, from steep Olympus thrown, Low in the dark Tartarean gulf shall groan, With burning chains fix'd to the brazen floors,

And lock'd by hell's inexorable doors; As deep beneath the infernal centre hurl'd,-LRB-190-RRB- As from that centre to the ethereal world. Let him (god) who tempts me, dread those dire abodes: And know, the Almighty is the god of gods.

immortal gods! fulfil it! and, ye powers, approve! League all your forces, then, ye powers above, Join all, and try the omnipotence of Jove.

Whose strong embrace holds heaven, and earth, and main Strive all, of mortal and immortal birth, To drag, by this, the Thunderer down to earth Ye strive in vain!

if I but stretch this hand, I heave the gods, the ocean, and the land; I fix the chain to great Olympus' height, And the vast world hangs trembling in my sight!

Let down our golden everlasting chain-LRB-191-RRB- For such I reign, unbounded and above; And such are men, and gods, compared to Jove.

A reverend horror silenced all the sky; Trembling they stood before their sovereign's look; At length his (reverend) best-beloved, the power of wisdom, spoke:

``O first and greatest!

'' (reverend)

The all-mighty spoke, nor durst the powers reply: God, by gods adored We own thy might, our father and our lord!

From fields forbidden we submiss refrain, With arms unaiding mourn our Argives slain; Yet grant my counsels still their breasts may move, Or all must perish in the wrath of Jove.

The cloud-compelling god her (reverend) suit approved, And smiled superior on his (god) best beloved; Then call'd his (god) coursers, and his (god) chariot took; The stedfast firmament beneath them shook:

But, ah! permit to pity human state: If not to help, at least lament their fate. '' Rapt by the ethereal steeds the chariot roll'd

; Brass were their hoofs, their curling manes of gold: Of heaven's undrossy gold the gods array, Refulgent, flash'd intolerable day.

But when to Ida's topmost height he (manes) came, -LRB-Fair nurse of fountains, and of savage game,-RRB- Where o'er her (nurse) pointed summits proudly raised, His (manes) fane breathed odours, and his (manes) altar blazed: There, from his (manes) radiant car, the sacred sire Of gods and men released the steeds of fire: Blue ambient mists the immortal steeds embraced; High on the cloudy point his (manes) seat he (manes) placed; Thence his (manes) broad eye the subject world surveys, The town, and tents, and navigable seas.

High on the throne he (manes) shines: his (manes) coursers fly Between the extended earth and starry sky. Now had the Grecians snatch'd a short repast, And buckled on their shining arms with haste.
