The gates unfolding pour forth all their train; Squadrons on squadrons cloud the dusky plain: Men, steeds, and chariots shake the trembling ground, The tumult thickens, and the skies resound; And now with shouts the shocking armies closed, To lances lances, shields to shields opposed, Host against host with shadowy legends drew, The sounding darts in iron tempests flew; Victors and vanquish'd join promiscuous cries, Triumphant shouts and dying groans arise; With streaming blood the slippery fields are dyed, And slaughter'd heroes swell the dreadful tide.

Long as the morning beams, increasing bright, O'er heaven's clear azure spread the sacred light, Commutual death the fate of war confounds, Each adverse battle gored with equal wounds.

Troy roused as soon; for on this dreadful day The fate of fathers, wives, and infants lay. But when the sun the height of heaven ascends, The sire of gods his (sire) golden scales suspends,-LRB-192-RRB-

With equal hand: in these explored the fate Of Greece and Troy, and poised the mighty weight: Press'd with its load, the Grecian balance lies Low sunk on earth, the Trojan strikes the skies.

Then Jove from Ida's top his (sire) horrors spreads; The clouds burst dreadful o'er the Grecian heads; Thick lightnings flash; the muttering thunder rolls; Their strength he (sire) withers, and unmans their souls.

Before his (sire) wrath the trembling hosts retire; The gods in terrors, and the skies on fire. Nor great Idomeneus that sight could bear, Nor each stern Ajax, thunderbolts of war:

Nor he (sire), the king of war, the alarm sustain'd Nestor alone, amidst the storm remain'd. Unwilling he (Nestor) remain'd, for Paris' dart

Had pierced his (Nestor) courser in a mortal part; Fix'd in the forehead, where the springing man Curl'd o'er the brow, it stung him (man) to the brain; Mad with his (Mad) anguish, he (Mad) begins to rear, Paw with his (Mad) hoofs aloft, and lash the air.

Scarce had his (Mad) falchion cut the reins, and freed The encumber'd chariot from the dying steed, When dreadful Hector, thundering through the war, Pour'd to the tumult on his (Hector) whirling car.

That day had stretch'd beneath his (Hector) matchless hand The hoary monarch of the Pylian band, But Diomed beheld; from forth the crowd

He (Hector) rush'd, and on Ulysses call'd aloud :

``Whither, oh whither does Ulysses run? Oh, flight unworthy great Laertes' son! Mix'd

with the vulgar shall thy fate be found, Pierced in the back, a vile, dishonest wound? Oh turn and save from Hector's direful rage The glory of the Greeks, the Pylian sage.

But bold Tydides to the rescue goes, A single warrior midst a host of foes; Before the coursers with a sudden spring

'' (He)

His (warrior) fruitless words are lost unheard in air, Ulysses seeks the ships, and shelters there. He (Ulysses) leap'd, and anxious thus bespoke the king:

``Great perils, father! wait the unequal fight; These younger champions will oppress thy might. Thy veins no more with ancient vigour glow, Weak is thy servant, and thy coursers slow.

Then haste, ascend my seat, and from the car Observe the steeds of Tros, renown'd in war. Practised alike to turn, to stop, to chase, To dare the fight, or urge the rapid race:

These late obey'd Ćneas' guiding rein; Leave thou thy chariot to our faithful train; With these against yon Trojans will we go, Nor shall great Hector want an equal foe;

Fierce as he (Hector) is, even he (Hector) may learn to fear The thirsty fury of my flying spear. '' (the king)

Thus said the chief; and Nestor, skill'd in war, Approves his (Nestor) counsel, and ascends the car:

The steeds he (Nestor) left, their trusty servants hold; Eurymedon, and Sthenelus the bold: The reverend charioteer directs the course, And strains his (reverend) aged arm to lash the horse.

Hector they face; unknowing how to fear, Fierce he (Hector) drove on; Tydides whirl'd his (Hector) spear. The spear with erring haste mistook its way, But plunged in Eniopeus' bosom lay.

His (Hector) opening hand in death forsakes the rein; The steeds fly back: he (Hector) falls, and spurns the plain. Great Hector sorrows for his (Hector) servant kill'd,

Yet unrevenged permits to press the field; Till, to supply his (Hector) place and rule the car, Rose Archeptolemus, the fierce in war.

And now had death and horror cover'd all;-LRB-193-RRB- Like timorous flocks the Trojans in their wall Inclosed had bled: but Jove with awful sound Roll'd the big thunder o'er the vast profound:

Full in Tydides' face the lightning flew; The ground before him (Hector) flamed with sulphur blue; The quivering steeds fell prostrate at the sight;

And Nestor's trembling hand confess'd his (Nestor) fright : He (Nestor) dropp'd the reins: and, shook with sacred dread, Thus, turning, warn'd the intrepid Diomed:

``O chief! too daring in thy friend's defence Retire advised, and urge the chariot hence. This day, averse, the sovereign of the skies Assists great Hector, and our palm denies.

Some other sun may see the happier hour, When Greece shall conquer by his (Hector) heavenly power. ' Tis not in man his (Hector) fix'd decree to move:

The great will glory to submit to Jove. '' (the Diomed)

``O reverend prince! -LRB-Tydides thus replies-RRB- Thy years are awful, and thy words are wise.

But ah, what grief! should haughty Hector boast I fled inglorious to the guarded coast. Before that dire disgrace shall blast my fame, O'erwhelm me, earth; and hide a warrior's shame!'' (Gerenian Nestor)

To whom Gerenian Nestor thus replied:-LRB-194-RRB-

``Gods! can thy courage fear the Phrygian's pride? Hector may vaunt, but who shall heed the boast?

Not those who felt thy arm, the Dardan host, Nor Troy, yet bleeding in her (thy) heroes lost; Not even a Phrygian dame, who dreads the sword That laid in dust her (thy) loved, lamented lord.

He (lord) said, and, hasty, o'er the gasping throng Drives the swift steeds: the chariot smokes along; The shouts of Trojans thicken in the wind; The storm of hissing javelins pours behind.

'' (Gerenian Nestor)

Then with a voice that shakes the solid skies, Pleased, Hector braves the warrior as he (Hector) flies. '' Go, mighty hero!

In seats of council and the sumptuous feast: Now hope no more those honours from thy train; Go less than woman, in the form of man!

To scale our walls, to wrap our towers in flames, To lead in exile the fair Phrygian dames, Thy once proud hopes, presumptuous prince! are fled; This arm shall reach thy heart, and stretch thee dead.

graced above the rest '' Now fears dissuade him (prince), and now hopes invite. To stop his (prince) coursers, and to stand the fight;

Thrice turn'd the chief, and thrice imperial Jove On Ida's summits thunder'd from above. Great Hector heard; he (Hector) saw the flashing light,

-LRB-The sign of conquest,-RRB- and thus urged the fight: ``Hear, every Trojan, Lycian, Dardan band, All famed in war, and dreadful hand to hand.

Be mindful of the wreaths your arms have won, Your great forefathers' glories, and your own. Heard ye the voice of Jove?

Success and fame Await on Troy, on Greece eternal shame. In vain they skulk behind their boasted wall, Weak bulwarks; destined by this arm to fall.

Soon as before yon hollow ships we stand, Fight each with flames, and toss the blazing brand; Till, their proud navy wrapt in smoke and fires, All Greece, encompass'd, in one blaze expires.

Furious he (Heard) said; then bending o'er the yoke, Encouraged his (Heard) proud steeds, while thus he (Heard) spoke:

``Now, Xanthus, Ćthon, Lampus, urge the chase, And thou, Podargus!

High o'er their slighted trench our steeds shall bound, And pass victorious o'er the levell'd mound. '' (he)

prove thy generous race; Be fleet, be fearless, this important day, And all your master's well-spent care repay.

For this, high-fed, in plenteous stalls ye stand, Served with pure wheat, and by a princess' hand; For this my spouse, of great Aetion's line, So oft has

uncontroll'd: Give me to seize rich Nestor's shield of gold; From Tydeus' shoulders strip the costly load, Vulcanian arms, the labour of a god: These if we gain, then victory, ye powers!

steep'd the strengthening grain in wine. Now swift pursue, now thunder This night, this glorious night, the fleet is ours! ''

``Thou, whose force can make The stedfast earth from her (princess) foundations shake, Seest thou the Greeks by fates unjust oppress'd, Nor swells thy heart in that immortal breast?

That heard, deep anguish stung Saturnia's soul; She (princess) shook her (princess) throne, that shook the starry pole: And thus to Neptune: Yet Ćgae, Helice, thy power obey,-LRB-195-RRB-

Would all the deities of Greece combine, In vain the gloomy Thunderer might repine: Sole should he (Thunderer) sit, with scarce a god to friend, And see his (Thunderer) Trojans to the shades descend:

And gifts unceasing on thine altars lay. Such be the scene from his (Thunderer) Idaean bower; Ungrateful prospect to the sullen power!'' (unknown)

Neptune with wrath rejects the rash design:

``What rage, what madness, furious queen! is thine? I war not with the highest.

Now godlike Hector, to whose matchless might Jove gave the glory of the destined fight, Squadrons on squadrons drives, and fills the fields With close-ranged chariots, and with thicken'd shields.

All above Submit and tremble at the hand of Jove. '' (troops)

Where the deep trench in length extended lay, Compacted troops stand wedged in firm array, A dreadful front!

they shake the brands, and threat With long-destroying flames the hostile fleet. The king of men, by Juno's self inspired, Toil'd through the tents, and all his (king) army fired.

Swift as he (Swift) moved, he (Swift) lifted in his (Swift) hand His (Swift) purple robe, bright ensign of command. High on the midmost bark the king

appear'd: There, from Ulysses' deck, his (Ulysses) voice was heard: To Ajax and Achilles reach'd the sound, Whose distant ships the guarded navy bound.

-LRB-he (Ulysses) cried: The hollow vessels to his (Ulysses) voice replied,-RRB- Where now are all your glorious boasts of yore, Your hasty triumphs on the Lemnian shore?

Each fearless hero dares a hundred foes, While the feast lasts, and while the goblet flows; But who to meet one martial man is found, When the fight rages, and the flames surround?

'' O Argives! shame of human race! O mighty Jove! O sire of the distress'd! Was ever king like me, like me oppress'd?

With power immense, with justice arm'd in vain; My glory ravish'd, and my people slain! To thee my vows were breathed from every shore;

What altar smoked not with our victims' gore? With fat of bulls I fed the constant flame, And ask'd destruction to the Trojan name.

Now, gracious god! far humbler our demand; Give these at least to `scape from Hector's hand, And save the relics of the Grecian land!''

Thus pray'd the king, and heaven's great father heard His (father) vows, in bitterness of soul preferr'd: The wrath appeased, by happy signs declares, And gives the people to their monarch's prayers.

His (monarch) eagle, sacred bird of heaven! he (monarch) sent, A fawn his (monarch) talons truss'd, -LRB-divine portent!-RRB- High o'er the wondering hosts he (monarch) soar'd above

, Who paid their vows to Panomphaean Jove; Then let the prey before his (monarch) altar fall; The Greeks beheld, and transport seized on all:

Tydides first, of all the Grecian force, O'er the broad ditch impell'd his (monarch) foaming horse, Pierced the deep ranks, their strongest battle tore, And dyed his (monarch) javelin red with Trojan gore.

Encouraged by the sign, the troops revive, And fierce on Troy with doubled fury drive. Young Agelaus -LRB-Phradmon was his (Young) sire-RRB-

With flying coursers shunn'd his (Young) dreadful ire; Struck through the back, the Phrygian fell oppress'd; The dart drove on, and issued at his (Struck) breast: Headlong he (Struck) quits the car: his (Struck) arms resound; His (Struck) ponderous buckler thunders on the ground.

Forth rush a tide of Greeks, the passage freed; The Atridae first, the Ajaces next succeed: Meriones, like Mars in arms renown'd, And godlike Idomen, now passed the mound; Evaemon's son next issues to the foe, And last young Teucer with his (son) bended bow.

Secure behind the Telamonian shield The skilful archer wide survey'd the field , With every shaft some hostile victim slew, Then close beneath the sevenfold orb withdrew:

The conscious infant so, when fear alarms, Retires for safety to the mother's arms. Thus Ajax guards his (victim) brother in the field,

Moves as he (victim) moves, and turns the shining shield. Who first by Teucer's mortal arrows bled? Orsilochus; then fell Ormenus dead:

The godlike Lycophon next press'd the plain, With Chromius, Daetor, Ophelestes slain: Bold Hamopaon breathless sunk to ground; The bloody pile great Melanippus crown'd.

Heaps fell on heaps, sad trophies of his (victim) art, A Trojan ghost attending every dart. Great Agamemnon views with joyful eye

Thus, always thus, thy early worth be tried; Thy brave example shall retrieve our host, Thy country's saviour, and thy father's boast!

The ranks grow thinner as his (father) arrows fly:

``O youth forever dear! -LRB-the monarch cried-RRB- Sprung from an alien's bed thy sire to grace, The vigorous offspring of a stolen embrace:

Now hear a monarch's vow: If heaven's high powers Give me to raze Troy's long-defended towers; Whatever treasures Greece for me design, The next rich honorary gift be thine:

Some golden tripod, or distinguished car, With coursers dreadful in the ranks of war: Or some fair captive, whom thy eyes approve, Shall recompense the warrior's toils with love.

Proud of his (warrior) boy, he (warrior) own'd the generous flame, And the brave son repays his (son) cares with fame. '' (this the chief)

To this the chief:
``With praise the rest inspire, Nor urge a soul already fill'd with fire.

What strength I have, be now in battle tried, Till every shaft in Phrygian blood be dyed. Since rallying from our wall we forced the foe, Still aim'd at Hector

have I bent my bow : Eight forky arrows from this hand have fled, And eight bold heroes by their points lie dead:

But sure some god denies me to destroy This fury of the field, this dog of Troy. '' (this the chief)

He (god) said, and twang'd the string.

The weapon flies At Hector's breast, and sings along the skies: He (Hector) miss'd the mark; but pierced Gorgythio's heart, And drench'd in royal blood the thirsty dart.

Decline the head, and drooping kiss the plain; So sinks the youth: his (Hector) beauteous head, depress'd Beneath his (Hector) helmet, drops upon his (Hector) breast.

-LRB-Fair Castianira, nymph of form divine, This offspring added to king Priam's line.-RRB- As full-blown poppies, overcharged with rain,-LRB-196-RRB- Another shaft the raging archer drew, That other shaft with erring fury flew, -LRB-From Hector, Phoebus turn'd the flying wound,-RRB-

Yet fell not dry or guiltless to the ground: Thy breast, brave Archeptolemus! it tore, And dipp'd its feathers in no vulgar gore.

Headlong he (Hector) falls: his (Hector) sudden fall alarms The steeds, that startle at his (Hector) sounding arms. Hector with grief his (Hector) charioteer beheld All pale and breathless on the sanguine field:

Then bids Cebriones direct the rein, Quits his (Hector) bright car, and issues on the plain. Dreadful he (Hector) shouts: from earth a stone he (Hector) took, And rush'd on Teucer with the lifted rock.

the forceful yew; The shaft already to his (Hector) shoulder drew; The feather in his (Hector) hand, just wing'd for flight, Touch'd where the neck and hollow chest unite; There, where the juncture knits the channel bone, The furious chief discharged the craggy stone:

He (chief) fell: but Ajax his (chief) broad shield display'd, And screen'd his (chief) brother with the mighty shade; Till great Alaster, and Mecistheus, bore The batter'd archer groaning to the shore.

The youth already strain'd The bow-string burst beneath the ponderous blow, And his (batter) numb'd hand dismiss'd his (batter) useless bow. Troy yet found grace before the Olympian sire,

He (batter) arm'd their hands, and fill'd their breasts with fire. The Greeks repulsed, retreat behind their wall, Or in the trench on heaps confusedly fall.

First of the foe, great Hector march'd along, With terror clothed, and more than mortal strong. As the bold hound, that gives the lion chase, With beating bosom, and with eager pace,

Hangs on his (Hector) haunch, or fastens on his (Hector) heels, Guards as he (Hector) turns, and circles as he (Hector) wheels; Thus oft the Grecians turn'd, but still they flew;

Thus following, Hector still the hindmost slew. When flying they had pass'd the trench profound, And many a chief lay gasping on the ground;

Before the ships a desperate stand they made, And fired the troops, and called the gods to aid. Fierce on his (chief) rattling chariot Hector came: His (Hector) eyes like Gorgon shot a sanguine flame

That wither'd all their host: like Mars he (Hector) stood: Dire as the monster, dreadful as the god! Their strong distress the wife of Jove survey'd;

Then pensive thus, to war's triumphant maid: ``O daughter of that god, whose arm can wield The avenging bolt, and shake the sable shield!

Now, in this moment of her (daughter) last despair, Shall wretched Greece no more confess our care, Condemn'd to suffer the full force of fate, And drain the dregs of heaven's relentless hate?

Gods! shall one raging hand thus level all? What numbers fell! what numbers yet shall fall! What power divine shall Hector's wrath assuage?

So spake the imperial regent of the skies; To whom the goddess with the azure eyes:

``Long since had Hector stain'd these fields with gore, Stretch'd by some Argive on his (Hector) native shore: But he (Hector) above, the sire of heaven, withstands, Mocks our attempts, and slights our just demands; The stubborn god, inflexible and hard, Forgets my service and deserved reward:

Still swells the slaughter, and still grows the rage!'' (the goddess)

Saved I, for this, his (god) favourite son distress'd, By stern Eurystheus with long labours press'd?

Oh had my wisdom known this dire event, When to grim Pluto's gloomy gates he (god) went; The triple dog had never felt his (god) chain,

He (god) begg'd, with tears he (god) begg'd, in deep dismay; I shot from heaven, and gave his (god) arm the day. Nor Styx been cross'd, nor hell explored in vain.

Averse to me of all his (god) heaven of gods, At Thetis' suit the partial Thunderer nods; To grace her (god) gloomy, fierce, resenting son, My hopes are frustrate, and my Greeks undone.

Some future day, perhaps, he (son) may be moved To call his (son) blue-eyed maid his (son) best beloved. Haste, launch thy chariot, through yon ranks to ride; Myself will arm, and thunder at thy side.

Then, goddess! say, shall Hector glory then? -LRB-That terror of the Greeks, that man of men-RRB- When Juno's self, and Pallas shall appear, All dreadful in the crimson walks of war!

What mighty Trojan then, on yonder shore, Expiring, pale, and terrible no more, Shall feast the fowls, and glut the dogs with gore?''

She (goddess) ceased, and Juno rein'd the steeds with care: -LRB-Heaven's awful empress, Saturn's other heir:-RRB- Pallas, meanwhile, her (empress) various veil unbound, With flowers adorn'd, with art immortal

crown'd; The radiant robe her (empress) sacred fingers wove Floats in rich waves, and spreads the court of Jove. Her (empress) father's arms her (empress) mighty limbs invest,

His (father) cuirass blazes on her (empress) ample breast. The vigorous power the trembling car ascends: Shook by her (empress) arm, the massy javelin bends:

Huge, ponderous, strong! that when her (empress) fury burns Proud tyrants humbles, and whole hosts o'erturns. Saturnia lends the lash; the coursers fly; Smooth glides the chariot through the liquid sky.

they stand, The sun's bright portals and the skies command; Close, or unfold, the eternal gates of day Bar heaven with clouds, or roll those clouds away.

Heaven's gates spontaneous open to the powers, Heaven's golden gates, kept by the winged Hours. Commission'd in alternate watch The sounding hinges ring, the clouds divide.

Prone down the steep of heaven their course they guide. But Jove, incensed, from Ida's top survey'd, And thus enjoin'd the many-colour'd maid.

-LSB-Illustration: JUNO AND MINERVA GOING TO ASSIST THE GREEKS.-RSB- JUNO AND MINERVA GOING TO ASSIST THE GREEKS. '' Thaumantia! mount the winds, and stop their car; Against the highest who shall wage the war?

If furious yet they dare the vain debate, Thus have I spoke, and what I speak is fate: Their coursers crush'd beneath the wheels shall lie,

My lightning these rebellious shall confound, And hurl them flaming, headlong, to the ground, Condemn'd for ten revolving years to weep The wounds

Their car in fragments, scatter'd o'er the sky: impress'd by burning thunder deep. So shall Minerva learn to fear our ire, Nor dare to combat hers and nature's sire.

Swift as the wind, the various-colour'd maid From Ida's top her (Ida) golden wings display'd; To great Olympus' shining gate she (Ida) flies, There meets the chariot rushing down the skies, Restrains their progress from the bright abodes, And speaks the mandate of the sire of gods.

For Juno, headstrong and imperious still, She (Ida) claims some title to transgress our will. '' '' What frenzy goddesses! what rage can move Celestial minds to tempt the wrath of Jove?

His (sire) lightning your rebellion shall confound, And hurl ye headlong, flaming, to the ground; Your horses crush'd beneath the wheels shall lie, Your car in fragments

Desist, obedient to his (sire) high command: This is his (sire) word; and know his (sire) word shall stand: scatter'd o'er the sky; Yourselves condemn'd ten rolling years to weep The wounds impress'd

by burning thunder deep. So shall Minerva learn to fear his (sire) ire, Nor dare to combat hers and nature's sire. For Juno, headstrong and imperious still, She (Minerva) claims some title to transgress his (sire) will:

Then, mounting on the pinions of the wind, She (Minerva) flew; and Juno thus her (Minerva) rage resign'd:

``O daughter of that god, whose arm can wield The avenging bolt, and shake the dreadful shield

No more let beings of superior birth Contend with Jove for this low race of earth; Triumphant now, now miserably slain, They breathe or perish as the fates ordain:

But thee, what desperate insolence has driven To lift thy lance against the king of heaven?'' (Juno)

But Jove's high counsels full effect shall find;

And, ever constant, ever rule mankind. '' She (Minerva) spoke, and backward turn'd her (Minerva) steeds of light, Adorn'd with manes of gold, and heavenly bright.

There tied, they rest in high celestial stalls; The chariot propp'd against the crystal walls, The pensive goddesses, abash'd, controll'd, Mix with the gods, and fill their seats of gold.

The Hours unloosed them, panting as they stood, And heap'd their mangers with ambrosial food. -LSB-Illustration: THE HOURS TAKING THE HORSES FROM JUNO'S CAR.-RSB-

THE HOURS TAKING THE HORSES FROM JUNO'S CAR. And now the Thunderer meditates his (manes) flight From Ida's summits to the Olympian height.

Swifter than thought, the wheels instinctive fly, Flame through the vast of air, and reach the sky. ' Twas Neptune's charge his (manes) coursers to unbrace, And fix the car on its immortal base

; There stood the chariot, beaming forth its rays, Till with a snowy veil he (manes) screen'd the blaze. He (manes), whose all-conscious eyes the world behold, The eternal Thunderer sat, enthroned in gold.

High heaven the footstool of his (manes) feet he (manes) makes, And wide beneath him (manes) all Olympus shakes. Trembling afar the offending powers appear'd, Confused and silent, for his (manes) frown they fear'd.

He (manes) saw their soul, and thus his (manes) word imparts:

``Pallas and Juno! say, why heave your hearts? Soon was your battle o'er: proud Troy retired Before your face, and in your wrath expired.

But know, whoe'er almighty power withstand! Unmatch'd our force, unconquer'd is our hand: Who shall the sovereign of the skies control?

Not all the gods that crown the starry pole. Your hearts shall tremble, if our arms we take, And each immortal nerve with horror shake.

For thus I speak, and what I speak shall stand; What power soe'er provokes our lifted hand, On this our hill no more shall hold his (Troy) place; Cut off, and exiled from the ethereal race.

'' (He)

Juno and Pallas grieving hear the doom, But feast their souls on Ilion's woes to come. Though secret anger swell'd

Minerva's breast, The prudent goddess yet her (goddess) wrath repress'd; But Juno, impotent of rage, replies: ``What hast thou said, O tyrant of the skies!

Strength and omnipotence invest thy throne; 'Tis thine to punish; ours to grieve alone. For Greece we grieve, abandon'd by her (goddess) fate To drink the dregs of thy unmeasured hate.

From fields forbidden we submiss refrain, With arms unaiding see our Argives slain ; Yet grant our counsels still their breasts may move, Lest all should perish in the rage of Jove.

The goddess thus; and thus the god replies, Who swells the clouds, and blackens all the skies:

``The morning sun, awaked by loud alarms, Shall see the almighty Thunderer in arms.

Nor shall great Hector cease the rage of fight, The navy flaming, and thy Greeks in flight, Even till the day when certain fates ordain That stern Achilles -LRB-his (Achilles) Patroclus slain-RRB-

'' (the god)

What heaps of Argives then shall load the plain, Those radiant eyes shall view, and view in vain. Shall rise in vengeance, and lay waste the plain.

For such is fate, nor canst thou turn its course With all thy rage, with all thy rebel force. Fly, if thy wilt, to earth's remotest bound, Where on her (Achilles) utmost verge the seas resound

; Where cursed Iapetus and Saturn dwell, Fast by the brink, within the streams of hell; No sun e'er gilds the gloomy horrors there; No cheerful gales refresh the lazy air:

Now deep in ocean sunk the lamp of light, And drew behind the cloudy veil of night: The conquering Trojans mourn his (rebel) beams decay'd

There arm once more the bold Titanian band; And arm in vain; for what I will, shall stand. '' ; The Greeks rejoicing bless the friendly shade.

The victors keep the field; and Hector calls A martial council near the navy walls; These to Scamander's bank apart he (Hector) led, Where thinly

A massy spear he (Hector) bore of mighty strength, Of full ten cubits was the lance's length; The point was brass, refulgent to behold, Fix'd to the wood with circling rings of gold: The noble Hector on his (Hector) lance reclined, And, bending forward, thus reveal'd his (Hector) mind:

scatter'd lay the heaps of dead. The assembled chiefs, descending on the ground, Attend his (Hector) order, and their prince surround.

``Ye valiant Trojans, with attention hear!

Ye Dardan bands, and generous aids, give ear! This day, we hoped, would wrap in conquering flame Greece with her (their) ships, and crown our toils with fame.

But darkness now, to save the cowards, falls, And guards them trembling in their wooden walls. Obey the night, and use her (their) peaceful hours

Straight from the town be sheep and oxen sought, And strengthening bread and generous wine be brought Wide o'er the field, high blazing to the sky

, Let numerous fires the absent sun supply, The flaming piles with plenteous fuel raise, Till the bright morn her (their) purple beam displays; Lest, in the silence and the shades of night, Greece on her (their) sable ships attempt her (their) flight.

Not unmolested let the wretches gain Their lofty decks, or safely cleave the main; Some hostile wound let every dart bestow, Some lasting token of the Phrygian foe, Wounds, that long hence may ask their spouses' care.

Our steeds to forage, and refresh our powers. And warn their children from a Trojan war. Now through the circuit of our Ilion wall, Let sacred heralds sound the solemn call; To bid the sires with

Firm be the guard, while distant lie our powers, And let the matrons hang with lights the towers; Lest, under covert of the midnight shade, The insidious foe the naked town invade.

hoary honours crown'd, And beardless youths, our battlements surround. Suffice, to-night, these orders to obey; A nobler charge shall rouse the dawning day.

The gods, I trust, shall give to Hector's hand From these detested foes to free the land, Who plough'd, with fates averse,

Our common safety must be now the care; But soon as morning paints the fields of air, Sheathed in bright arms let every troop engage, And the fired fleet behold the battle rage.

the watery way: For Trojan vultures a predestined prey. Then, then shall Hector and Tydides prove Whose fates are heaviest in the scales of Jove.

Shall see his (Hector) bloody spoils in triumph borne, With this keen javelin shall his (Hector) breast be gored, And prostrate heroes bleed around their lord.

Certain as this, oh! might my days endure, From age inglorious, and black death secure; So might my life and glory know no bound, Like Pallas worshipp'd, like the sun renown'd!

To-morrow's light -LRB-O haste the glorious morn!-RRB- As the next dawn, the last they shall enjoy, Shall crush the Greeks, and end the woes of Troy.

'' (The leader)

The leader spoke. From all his (leader) host around Shouts of applause along the shores resound. Each from the yoke the smoking steeds untied, And fix'd their headstalls to his (leader) chariot-side.

Fat sheep and oxen from the town are led, With generous wine, and all-sustaining bread, Full hecatombs lay burning on the shore:

The winds to heaven the curling vapours bore. Ungrateful offering to the immortal powers!-LRB-197-RRB- Whose wrath hung heavy o'er the Trojan towers:

Nor Priam nor his (leader) sons obtain'd their grace; Proud Troy they hated, and her (leader) guilty race. The troops exulting sat in order round, And beaming fires illumined all the ground.

O'er heaven's pure azure spreads her (leader) sacred light, When not a breath disturbs the deep serene, And not a cloud o'ercasts the solemn scene, Around her (leader) throne the vivid planets roll,

unnumber'd gild the glowing pole, O'er the dark trees a yellower verdure shed, And tip with silver every mountain's head: Then shine the vales, the rocks in prospect rise, A flood of glory bursts from all the skies: The conscious swains, rejoicing in the sight, Eye the blue vault, and bless the useful light.

As when the moon, refulgent lamp of night,-LRB-198-RRB- And stars So many flames before proud Ilion blaze, And lighten glimmering Xanthus with their rays.

The long reflections of the distant fires Gleam on the walls, and tremble on the spires. A thousand piles the dusky horrors gild, And shoot a shady lustre o'er the field.

Full fifty guards each flaming pile attend, Whose umber'd arms, by fits, thick flashes send, Loud neigh the coursers o'er their heaps of corn, And ardent warriors wait the rising morn.

-LSB-Illustration: THE SHIELD OF ACHILLES.-RSB- THE SHIELD OF ACHILLES. BOOK IX. ARGUMENT. THE EMBASSY TO ACHILLES. Agamemnon, after the last day's defeat, proposes to the Greeks to quit the siege, and return to their country.

He (Agamemnon) orders the guard to be strengthened, and a council summoned to deliberate what measures are to be followed in this emergency.

Agamemnon pursues this advice, and Nestor further prevails upon him (Nestor) to send ambassadors to Achilles, in order to move him (Nestor) to a reconciliation.

Diomed opposes this, and Nestor seconds him (Nestor), praising his (Nestor) wisdom and resolution. Ulysses and Ajax are made choice of, who are accompanied by old Phoenix.

They make, each of them, very moving and pressing speeches, but are rejected with roughness by Achilles, who notwithstanding retains Phoenix in his (Achilles) tent.

This book, and the next following, take up the space of one night, which is the twenty-seventh from the beginning of the poem.

The ambassadors return unsuccessfully to the camp, and the troops betake themselves to sleep. The scene lies on the sea-shore, the station of the Grecian ships.

Thus joyful Troy maintain'd the watch of night; While fear, pale comrade of inglorious flight,-LRB-199-RRB- And heaven-bred horror, on the Grecian part, Sat on each face, and sadden'd every heart.

As from its cloudy dungeon issuing forth, A double tempest of the west and north Swells o'er the sea, from Thracia's frozen shore, Heaps waves on waves, and bids the Ćgean roar:

This way and that the boiling deeps are toss'd: Such various passions urged the troubled host, Great Agamemnon grieved above the rest;

; Himself his (Agamemnon) orders to the heralds bears, To bid to council all the Grecian peers, But bid in whispers: these surround their chief, In solemn sadness and majestic grief.

Superior sorrows swell'd his (chief) royal breast The king amidst the mournful circle rose: Down his (chief) wan cheek a briny torrent flows.

With more than vulgar grief he (chief) stood oppress'd; Words, mix'd with sighs, thus bursting from his (chief) breast: ``Ye sons of Greece!

So silent fountains, from a rock's tall head, In sable streams soft-trickling waters shed. partake your leader's care; Fellows in arms and princes of the war!

Of partial Jove too justly we complain, And heavenly oracles believed in vain. A safe return was promised to our toils, With conquest honour'd and

enrich'd with spoils: Now shameful flight alone can save the host; Our wealth, our people, and our glory lost. So Jove decrees, almighty lord of all!

Jove, at whose nod whole empires rise or fall, Who shakes the feeble props of human trust, And towers and armies humbles to the dust.

Haste then, for ever quit these fatal fields, Haste to the joys our native country yields; Spread all your canvas, all your oars employ, Nor hope the fall of heaven-defended Troy.

till Tydeus' warlike son Roll'd on the king his (king) eyes, and thus begun:

``When kings advise us to renounce our fame, First let him (king) speak who first has suffer'd shame.

'' (the king)

He (king) said: deep silence held the Grecian band; Silent, unmov'd in dire dismay they stand; A pensive scene! If I oppose thee, prince!

thy wrath withhold, The laws of council bid my tongue be bold. Thou first, and thou alone, in fields of fight, Durst brand my courage, and defame my might:

Nor from a friend the unkind reproach appear'd, The Greeks stood witness, all our army heard. The gods, O chief! from whom our honours spring, The gods have made thee but

by halves a king : They gave thee sceptres, and a wide command; They gave dominion o'er the seas and land;

The noblest power that might the world control They gave thee not--a brave and virtuous soul. Is this a general's voice, that would suggest Fears like his (general) own to every Grecian breast?

from the embattled plain; Ships thou hast store, and nearest to the main; A noble care the Grecians shall employ, To combat, conquer, and extirpate Troy.

Here Greece shall stay; or, if all Greece retire, Myself shall stay, till Troy or I expire; Myself, and Sthenelus, will fight for fame; God bade us fight, and 'twas with God we came.

Confiding in our want of worth, he (God) stands; And if we fly, 'tis what our king commands. Go thou, inglorious! ''

rear'd; He (king) spoke: the host in still attention heard:-LRB-200-RRB- ``O truly great! in whom the gods have join'd Such strength of body with such force of mind: In conduct, as in courage, you excel, Still first to act what you advise so well.

He (king) ceased; the Greeks loud acclamations raise, And voice to voice resounds Tydides' praise. Wise Nestor then his (Nestor) reverend figure These wholesome counsels which thy wisdom moves, Applauding Greece with common voice approves.

Kings thou canst blame; a bold but prudent youth: And blame even kings with praise, because with truth. And yet those years that since thy birth have run Would hardly style thee Nestor's youngest son.

unfinish'd in that generous mind; Age bids me speak! nor shall the advice I bring Distaste the people, or offend the king:

``Cursed is the man, and void of law and right, Unworthy property, unworthy light, Unfit for public rule, or private care,

Then let me add what yet remains behind, A thought That wretch, that monster, who delights in war; Whose lust is murder, and whose horrid joy, To tear his (man) country, and his (man) kind destroy!

This night, refresh and fortify thy train; Between the trench and wall let guards remain: Be that the duty of the young and bold;

But thou, O king, to council call the old; Great is thy sway, and weighty are thy cares; Thy high commands must spirit all our wars.

With Thracian wines recruit thy honour'd guests, For happy counsels flow from sober feasts. Wise, weighty counsels aid a state distress'd, And such a monarch as can choose the best.

See what a blaze from hostile tents aspires, How near our fleet approach the Trojan fires! Who can, unmoved, behold the dreadful light?

What eye beholds them, and can close to-night? This dreadful interval determines all; To-morrow, Troy must flame, or Greece must fall.

'' (the king)

Thus spoke the hoary sage: the rest obey; Swift through the gates the guards direct their way. His (Swift) son was first to pass the lofty mound, The generous Thrasymed, in arms renown'd:

Next him (Swift), Ascalaphus, Ialmen, stood, The double offspring of the warrior-god: Deipyrus, Aphareus, Merion join, And Lycomed of Creon's noble line.

Seven were the leaders of the nightly bands, And each bold chief a hundred spears commands. The fires they light, to short repasts they fall, Some line the trench, and others man the wall.

The king of men, on public counsels bent, Convened the princes in his (king) ample tent, Each seized a portion of the kingly feast, But stay'd his (king) hand when thirst and hunger ceased.

whose superior sway Assembled states, and lords of earth obey, The laws and sceptres to thy hand are given, And millions own the care of thee and Heaven.

Then Nestor spoke, for wisdom long approved, And slowly rising, thus the council moved. '' Monarch of nations! O king! the counsels of my age attend; With thee my cares begin, with thee must end.

it fits alike to speak and hear, Pronounce with judgment, with regard give ear, To see no wholesome motion be withstood, And ratify the best for public good.

Thee, prince! Nor, though a meaner give advice, repine, But follow it, and make the wisdom thine. Hear then a thought, not now conceived in haste,

When from Pelides' tent you forced the maid, I first opposed, and faithful, durst dissuade; But bold of soul, when headlong fury fired, You wronged the man, by men and gods

At once my present judgment and my past. admired: Now seek some means his (man) fatal wrath to end, With prayers to move him (man), or with gifts to bend.

'' To whom the king. '' With justice hast thou shown A prince's faults, and I with reason own. That happy man, whom Jove still honours most, Is more than armies, and himself a host.

Bless'd in his (man) love, this wondrous hero stands; Heaven fights his (man) war, and humbles all our bands. Fain would my heart, which err'd through frantic rage, The wrathful chief and angry gods assuage.

If gifts immense his (chief) mighty soul can bow,-LRB-201-RRB- Hear, all ye Greeks, and witness what I vow. Ten weighty talents of the purest gold, And twice ten vases of refulgent mould:

Yet knows no office, nor has felt the flame; Twelve steeds unmatch'd in fleetness and in force, And still victorious in the dusty course; -LRB-Rich were the man whose ample stores exceed The prizes purchased by their winged speed;-RRB- Seven lovely captives of the Lesbian line, Skill'd in each art, unmatch'd in form divine, The same I chose for more than vulgar charms, When Lesbos sank beneath the hero's arms: All these, to buy his (hero) friendship, shall be paid, And join'd with these the long-contested maid; With all her (maid) charms, Briseis I resign, And solemn swear those charms were never mine;

Seven sacred tripods, whose unsullied frame Untouch'd she (maid) stay'd, uninjured she (maid) removes, Pure from my arms, and guiltless of my loves,-LRB-202-RRB-

These instant shall be his (hero); and if the powers Give to our arms proud Ilion's hostile towers, Then shall he (hero) store -LRB-when Greece the spoil divides-RRB-

With gold and brass his (hero) loaded navy's sides: Besides, full twenty nymphs of Trojan race With copious love shall crown his (hero) warm embrace, Such as himself will choose; who yield to none, Or yield to Helen's heavenly charms alone.

Yet hear me further: when our wars are o'er, If safe we land on Argos' fruitful shore, There shall he (hero) live my son, our honours share, And with Orestes' self divide my care.

Yet more--three daughters in my court are bred, And each well worthy of a royal bed; Laodice and Iphigenia fair,-LRB-203-RRB- And bright Chrysothemis with golden hair

; Her (Helen) let him (hero) choose whom most his (hero) eyes approve, I ask no presents, no reward for love: Myself will give the dower; so vast a store

Seven ample cities shall confess his (hero) sway, Him (hero) Enope, and Pherae him (hero) obey, Cardamyle with ample turrets crown'd, And sacred Pedasus for vines renown'd; Ćpea fair, the pastures Hira yields, And rich Antheia with her (Helen) flowery fields:-LRB-204-RRB-

The whole extent to Pylos' sandy plain, Along the verdant margin of the main There heifers graze, and labouring oxen toil

; Bold are the men, and generous is the soil; There shall he (Hira) reign, with power and justice crown'd, And rule the tributary realms around.

As never father gave a child before. All this I give, his (father) vengeance to control, And sure all this may move his (father) mighty soul.

Who feels no mercy, and who hears no prayers, Lives dark and dreadful in deep hell's abodes, And mortals hate him (father), as the worst of gods Great though he (father) be, it fits him (father) to obey, Since more than his (father) my years, and more my sway.''

Pluto, the grisly god, who never spares, -LSB-Illustration: PLUTO.-RSB- PLUTO. The monarch thus. The reverend Nestor then:

``Great Agamemnon! glorious king of men!

Such are thy offers as a prince may take, And such as fits a generous king to make. Let chosen delegates this hour be sent -LRB-Myself will name them-RRB- to Pelides' tent.

Let Phoenix lead, revered for hoary age, Great Ajax next, and Ithacus the sage. Yet more to sanctify the word you send, Let Hodius and Eurybates attend.

Now pray to Jove to grant what Greece demands; Pray in deep silence,-LRB-205-RRB- and with purest hands.'' (Nestor/Wise Nestor/Wise)

-LRB-206-RRB- -LSB-Illustration: THE EMBASSY TO ACHILLES.-RSB-

THE EMBASSY TO ACHILLES. He (Great) said; and all approved. The heralds bring The cleansing water from the living spring. The youth with wine the sacred goblets crown'd, And large libations drench'd the sands around.

, Then from the royal tent they take their way; Wise Nestor turns on each his (Nestor) careful eye, Forbids to offend, instructs them to apply; Much he (Nestor) advised them all,

The rite perform'd, the chiefs their thirst allay Ulysses most, To deprecate the chief, and save the host. Through the still night they march, and hear the roar Of murmuring billows on the sounding shore.

To Neptune, ruler of the seas profound, Whose liquid arms the mighty globe surround, They pour forth vows, their embassy to bless, And calm the rage of stern Ćacides.

The Myrmidonian tents and vessels lay; Amused at ease, the godlike man they found, Pleased with the solemn harp's harmonious sound.

And now, arrived, where on the sandy bay -LRB-The well wrought harp from conquered Thebae came; Of polish'd silver was its costly frame.-RRB-

With this he (man) soothes his (man) angry soul, and sings The immortal deeds of heroes and of kings. Patroclus only of the royal train, Placed in his (man) tent, attends the lofty strain:

Full opposite he (man) sat, and listen'd long, In silence waiting till he (man) ceased the song. Unseen the Grecian embassy proceeds To his (man) high tent; the great Ulysses leads.

Achilles starting, as the chiefs he (Achilles) spied, Leap'd from his (Achilles) seat, and laid the harp aside. With like surprise arose Menoetius' son: Pelides grasp'd their hands, and thus begun:

``Princes, all hail! whatever brought you here. Or strong necessity, or urgent fear; Welcome, though Greeks! for not as foes ye came; To me more dear than all that bear the name.

'' (Menoetius son)

With that, the chiefs beneath his (son) roof he (son) led, And placed in seats with purple carpets spread. Then thus--
``Patroclus, crown a larger bowl, Mix purer wine, and open every soul.

Of all the warriors yonder host can send, Thy friend most honours these, and these thy friend. '' (He)

He (friend) said: Patroclus o'er the blazing fire Heaps in a brazen vase

three chines entire: The brazen vase Automedon sustains, Which flesh of porker, sheep, and goat contains. Achilles at the genial feast presides, The parts transfixes, and with skill divides.

Then, when the languid flames at length subside, He (Achilles) strows a bed of glowing embers wide, Above the coals the smoking fragments turns And sprinkles sacred salt from lifted urns; With bread the glittering canisters they load, Which round the board Menoetius' son bestow'd; Himself, opposed to Ulysses full in sight, Each portion parts, and orders every rite.

The first fat offering to the immortals due, Amidst the greedy flames Patroclus threw; Then each, indulging in the social feast, His (Ulysses) thirst and hunger soberly repress'd. That done, to Phoenix Ajax gave the sign: Not unperceived; Ulysses crown'd with wine The foaming bowl, and instant thus began, His (Ulysses) speech addressing to the godlike man.

Meanwhile Patroclus sweats, the fire to raise; The tent is brighten'd with the rising blaze: '' Health to Achilles! happy are thy guests!

Not those more honour'd whom Atrides feasts: Though generous plenty crown thy loaded boards, That, Agamemnon's regal tent affords; But greater cares sit heavy on our souls, Nor eased by banquets or by flowing bowls.

The dead we mourn, and for the living fear; Greece on the brink of fate all doubtful stands, And owns no help

: Troy and her (man) aids for ready vengeance call; Their threatening tents already shade our wall: Hear how with shouts their conquest they proclaim, And point at every ship their vengeful flame!

What scenes of slaughter in yon fields appear! but from thy saving hands For them the father of the gods declares, Theirs are his (father) omens, and his (father) thunder theirs.

See, full of Jove, avenging Hector rise! See! heaven and earth the raging chief defies; What fury in his (chief) breast, what lightning in his (chief) eyes!

He (chief) waits but for the morn, to sink in flame The ships, the Greeks, and all the Grecian name. Heavens! how my country's woes distract my mind, Lest Fate accomplish all his (chief) rage design'd!

: oh return, though late, To save thy Greeks, and stop the course of Fate; If in that heart or grief or courage lies, Rise to redeem; ah, yet to conquer, rise!

And must we, gods! our heads inglorious lay In Trojan dust, and this the fatal day? Return, Achilles The day may come, when, all our warriors slain, That heart shall melt, that courage rise in vain:

When Peleus in his (Achilles) aged arms embraced His (Achilles) parting son, these accents were his (Achilles) last: ''`My child! with strength, with glory, and success, Thy arms may Juno and Minerva bless!

Regard in time, O prince divinely brave! Those wholesome counsels which thy father gave. Trust that to Heaven: but thou, thy cares engage To calm thy passions, and subdue thy rage:

From gentler manners let thy glory grow, And shun contention, the sure source of woe; That young and old may in thy praise combine, The virtues of humanity be thine--' This now-despised advice thy father gave; Ah! check thy anger; and be truly brave.

If thou wilt yield to great Atrides' prayers, Gifts worthy thee his (father) royal hand prepares; If not--but hear me, while I number o'er

The proffer'd presents, an exhaustless store. Ten weighty talents of the purest gold, And twice ten vases of refulgent mould; Seven sacred tripods, whose unsullied frame

; Twelve steeds unmatched in fleetness and in force, And still victorious in the dusty course; -LRB-Rich were the man, whose ample stores exceed The prizes purchased by their winged speed;-RRB- Seven lovely captives of the Lesbian line, Skill'd in each art, unmatch'd

Yet knows no office, nor has felt the flame in form divine, The same he (Rich) chose for more than vulgar charms, When Lesbos sank beneath thy conquering arms.

All these, to buy thy friendship shall be paid, And, join'd with these, the long-contested maid; With all her (maid) charms, Briseis he (Rich)'ll resign, And solemn swear those charms were only thine;

Untouch'd she (maid) stay'd, uninjured she (maid) removes, Pure from his (Rich) arms, and guiltless of his (Rich) loves. These instant shall be thine; and

if the powers Give to our arms proud Ilion's hostile towers, Then shalt thou store -LRB-when Greece the spoil divides-RRB- With gold and brass thy loaded navy's sides.

Besides, full twenty nymphs of Trojan race With copious love shall crown thy warm embrace; Such as thyself shall chose; who yield to none, Or yield to Helen's heavenly charms alone.

Yet hear me further: when our wars are o'er, If safe we land on Argos' fruitful shore, There shalt thou live his (thine) son, his (thine) honour share,

And with Orestes' self divide his (thine) care. Yet more--three daughters in his (thine) court are bred, And each well worthy of a royal bed:

whom most thy eyes approve; He (thine) asks no presents, no reward for love: Himself will give the dower; so vast a store

Laodice and Iphigenia fair, And bright Chrysothemis with golden hair: Her (thine) shalt thou wed As never father gave a child before.

Seven ample cities shall confess thy sway, The Enope and Pherae thee obey, Cardamyle with ample turrets crown'd, And sacred Pedasus, for vines renown'd:

Ćpea fair, the pastures Hira yields, And rich Antheia with her (thine) flowery fields; The whole extent to Pylos' sandy plain, Along the verdant margin of the main.

There heifers graze, and labouring oxen toil; Bold are the men, and generous is the soil. There shalt thou reign, with power and justice crown'd, And rule the tributary realms around.

But if all this, relentless, thou disdain, If honour and if interest plead in vain, Yet some redress to suppliant Greece afford, And be, amongst her (thine) guardian gods, adored.

Such are the proffers which this day we bring, Such the repentance of a suppliant king. If no regard thy suffering country claim, Hear thy own glory, and the voice of fame:

For now that chief, whose unresisted ire Made nations tremble, and whole hosts retire, Proud Hector, now, the unequal fight demands, And only triumphs to deserve thy hands.

'' Then thus the goddess-born:

``Ulysses, hear A faithful speech, that knows nor art nor fear; What in my secret soul is understood, My tongue shall utter, and my deeds make good.

Let Greece then know, my purpose I retain: Nor with new treaties vex my peace in vain. Who dares think one thing, and another tell, My heart detests him (Hector) as the gates of hell.

Then thus in short my fix'd resolves attend, Which nor Atrides nor his (Hector) Greeks can bend; Long toils, long perils in their cause I bore,

'' (unknown)

But now the unfruitful glories charm no more. Fight or not fight, a like reward we claim, The wretch and hero find their prize the same.

Alike regretted in the dust he (hero) lies, Who yields ignobly, or who bravely dies. Of all my dangers, all my glorious pains, A life of labours, lo!

As the bold bird her (their) helpless young attends, From danger guards them, and from want defends; In search of prey she (their) wings the spacious air,

For thankless Greece such hardships have I braved, Her (their) wives, her (their) infants, by my labours saved; Long sleepless nights in heavy arms I stood, And sweat laborious days in dust and blood.

And twelve lay smoking on the Trojan plain: Then at Atrides' haughty feet were laid The wealth I gathered, and the spoils I made.

what fruit remains? And with the untasted food supplies her (their) care: I sack'd twelve ample cities on the main,-LRB-207-RRB- Your mighty monarch these in peace possess'd; Some few my soldiers had, himself the rest.

Some present, too, to every prince was paid; And every prince enjoys the gift he (prince) made: I only must refund, of all his (prince) train; See what pre-eminence our merits gain!

his (prince) greedy soul delights: My spouse alone must bless his (prince) lustful nights: The woman, let him (prince) -LRB-as he (prince) may-RRB- enjoy; But what's the quarrel, then, of Greece to Troy?

My spoil alone What to these shores the assembled nations draws, What calls for vengeance but a woman's cause? Are fair endowments and a beauteous face

Beloved by none but those of Atreus' race? The wife whom choice and passion doth approve, Sure every wise and worthy man will love.

Nor did my fair one less distinction claim; Slave as she (wife) was, my soul adored the dame. Wrong'd in my love, all proffers I disdain; Deceived for once, I trust not kings again.

Ye have my answer--what remains to do, Your king, Ulysses, may consult with you. What needs he (Ulysses) the defence this arm can make?

Has he (Ulysses) not walls no human force can shake? Has he (Ulysses) not fenced his (Ulysses) guarded navy round With piles, with ramparts, and a trench profound?

And will not these -LRB-the wonders he (Ulysses) has done-RRB- Repel the rage of Priam's single son? There was a time -LRB-'twas when for Greece I fought-RRB-

When Hector's prowess no such wonders wrought; He (Hector) kept the verge of Troy, nor dared to wait Achilles' fury at the Scaean gate; He (Hector) tried it once, and scarce was saved by fate.

But now those ancient enmities are o'er ; To-morrow we the favouring gods implore; Then shall you see our parting vessels crown'd, And hear with oars the Hellespont resound.

The third day hence shall Pthia greet our sails,-LRB-208-RRB- If mighty Neptune send propitious gales; Pthia to her (Hector) Achilles shall restore The wealth he (Achilles) left for this detested shore:

The ruddy gold, the steel, and shining brass: My beauteous captives thither I'll convey, And all that rests of my unravish'd prey.

Thither the spoils of this long war shall pass, One only valued gift your tyrant gave, And that resumed--the fair Lyrnessian slave.

Then tell him (slave): loud, that all the Greeks may hear, And learn to scorn the wretch they basely fear; -LRB-For arm'd in impudence, mankind he (slave) braves, And meditates new cheats on all his (slave) slaves; Though shameless as he (slave) is, to face these eyes Is what he (slave) dares not: if he (slave) dares he (slave) dies;-RRB- Tell him (slave), all terms, all commerce I decline, Nor share his (slave) council, nor his (slave) battle join; For once deceiv'd, was his (slave); but twice were mine,

; His (slave) gifts are hateful: kings of such a kind Stand but as slaves before a noble mind, Not though he (slave) proffer'd all himself

possess'd, And all his (slave) rapine could from others wrest: Not all the golden tides of wealth that crown The many-peopled Orchomenian town;-LRB-209-RRB-

Thebes' unrivall'd walls contain, The world's great empress on the Egyptian plain -LRB-That spreads her (empress) conquests o'er a thousand states, And pours her (empress) heroes through a hundred gates, Two hundred horsemen and two hundred cars From each wide portal issuing to the wars-RRB-;-LRB-210-RRB-

Though bribes were heap'd on bribes, in number more Than dust in fields, or sands along the shore; Should all these offers for my friendship call, 'Tis he (empress) that offers, and I scorn them all.

Atrides' daughter never shall be led -LRB-An ill-match'd consort-RRB- to Achilles' bed; Like golden Venus though she (Venus) charm'd the heart, And vied with Pallas in the works of art; Some greater Greek let those high nuptials grace, I hate alliance with a tyrant's race.

If heaven restore me to my realms with life, The reverend Peleus shall elect my wife; Thessalian nymphs there are of form divine, And kings that sue to mix their blood with mine.

Bless'd in kind love, my years shall glide away, Content with just hereditary sway; There, deaf for ever to the martial strife, Enjoy the dear prerogative of life.

No--let the stupid prince, whom Jove deprives Of sense and justice, run where frenzy drives Not all proud Life is not to be bought with heaps of gold.

Not all Apollo's Pythian treasures hold, Or Troy once held, in peace and pride of sway, Can bribe the poor possession of a day!

Lost herds and treasures we by arms regain, And steeds unrivall'd on the dusty plain: But from our lips the vital spirit fled, Returns no more to wake the silent dead.

My fates long since by Thetis were disclosed, And each alternate, life or fame, proposed; Here, if I stay, before the Trojan town, Short is my date, but deathless my renown: If I return, I quit immortal praise For years on years, and long-extended days.

Convinced, though late, I find my fond mistake, And warn the Greeks the wiser choice to make; To quit these shores, their native seats enjoy, Nor hope the fall of heaven-defended Troy.

Go then to Greece, report our fix'd design; Bid all your counsels, all your armies join, Let all your forces, all your arts conspire, To save the ships, the troops, the chiefs, from fire.

Jove's arm display'd asserts her (troops) from the skies! Her (troops) hearts are strengthen'd, and her (troops) glories rise. One stratagem has fail'd, and others will: Ye find, Achilles is unconquer'd still.

Go then--digest my message as ye may-- But here this night let reverend Phoenix stay: His (Achilles) tedious toils and hoary hairs demand A peaceful death in Pthia's friendly land.

But whether he (Achilles) remain or sail with me, His (Achilles) age be sacred, and his (Achilles) will be free.'' -LSB-Illustration: GREEK GALLEY.-RSB- GREEK GALLEY.

The son of Peleus ceased: the chiefs around In silence wrapt, in consternation drown'd, Attend the stern reply. Then Phoenix rose; -LRB-Down his (son) white beard a stream of sorrow flows;-RRB-

And while the fate of suffering Greece he (son) mourn'd, With accent weak these tender words return'd. -LSB-Illustration: PROSERPINE.-RSB- PROSERPINE. '' Divine Achilles!

wilt thou then retire, And leave our hosts in blood, our fleets on fire? If wrath so dreadful fill thy ruthless mind

He (Achilles) sent thee early to the Achaian host; Thy youth as then in sage debates unskill'd, And new to perils of the direful field: He (Achilles) bade me teach thee all the ways of war, To shine in councils, and in camps to dare.

, How shall thy friend, thy Phoenix, stay behind? The royal Peleus, when from Pthia's coast Never, ah, never let me leave thy side!

No time shall part us, and no fate divide, Not though the god, that breathed my life, restore The bloom I boasted, and the port I bore, When Greece of old beheld my youthful flames -LRB-Delightful Greece, the land of lovely dames-RRB-, My father faithless to my mother's arms, Old as he (father) was, adored a stranger's charms.

I tried what youth could do -LRB-at her (mother) desire-RRB- To win the damsel, and prevent my sire. My sire with curses loads my hated head, And cries, `Ye furies!

barren be his (sire) bed.' Infernal Jove, the vengeful fiends below, And ruthless Proserpine, confirm'd his (sire) vow. Despair and grief distract my labouring mind!

To plunge the poniard in my father's breast; Then meditate my flight: my friends in vain With prayers entreat me, and with force detain.

On fat of rams, black bulls, and brawny swine, They daily feast, with draughts of fragrant wine; Strong guards they placed, and watch'd nine nights entire; The roofs and porches flamed with constant fire.

Gods! what a crime my impious heart design'd! I thought -LRB-but some kind god that thought suppress'd-RRB- The tenth, I forced the gates, unseen of all: And,

favour'd by the night, o'erleap'd the wall, My travels thence through spacious Greece extend; In Phthia's court at last my labours end.

Your sire received me, as his (sire) son caress'd, With gifts enrich'd, and with possessions bless'd. The strong Dolopians thenceforth own'd my reign, And all the coast that runs along the main.

By love to thee his (sire) bounties I repaid, And early wisdom to thy soul convey'd : Great as thou art, my lessons made thee brave:

A child I took thee, but a hero gave. Thy infant breast a like affection show'd; Still in my arms -LRB-an ever-pleasing load-RRB-

I pass my watchings o'er thy helpless years, The tender labours, the compliant cares, The gods -LRB-I thought-RRB- reversed their hard decree, And Phoenix felt a father's joys in thee

Or at my knee, by Phoenix wouldst thou stand ; No food was grateful but from Phoenix' hand.-LRB-211-RRB- : Thy growing virtues justified my cares, And promised comfort to my silver hairs.

The gods -LRB-the only great, and only wise-RRB- Are moved by offerings, vows, and sacrifice; Offending man their high compassion wins, And daily prayers atone for daily sins.

Prayers are Jove's daughters, of celestial race, Lame are their feet, and wrinkled is their face; With humble mien, and with dejected eyes, Constant they follow, where injustice flies.

Injustice swift, erect, and unconfined, Sweeps the wide earth, and tramples o'er mankind, While Prayers, to heal her (man) wrongs, move slow behind.

Who hears these daughters of almighty Jove, For him (almighty) they mediate to the throne above When man rejects the humble suit they make, The sire revenges for the daughters' sake;

Now be thy rage, thy fatal rage, resign'd; A cruel heart ill suits a manly mind: From Jove commission'd, fierce injustice then Descends to punish unrelenting men.

O let not headlong passion bear the sway These reconciling goddesses obey Due honours to the seed of Jove belong, Due honours calm the fierce, and bend the strong.

Were these not paid thee by the terms we bring, Were rage still harbour'd in the haughty king; Nor Greece nor all her (we) fortunes should engage Thy friend to plead against so just a rage.

But since what honour asks the general sends, And sends by those whom most thy heart commends; The best and noblest of the Grecian train; Permit not these to sue, and sue in vain!

Let me -LRB-my son-RRB- an ancient fact unfold, A great example drawn from times of old; Hear what our fathers were, and what their praise,

Once fought the Ćtolian and Curetian bands; To guard it those; to conquer, these advance; And mutual deaths were dealt with mutual chance.

Who conquer'd their revenge in former days. '' Where Calydon on rocky mountains stands-LRB-212-RRB- The silver Cynthia bade contention rise, In vengeance of neglected sacrifice; On OEneus fields she (Cynthia) sent a monstrous boar, That levell'd harvests, and whole forests tore:

This beast -LRB-when many a chief his (our) tusks had slain-RRB- Great Meleager stretch'd along the plain, Then, for his (our) spoils, a new debate arose, The neighbour nations thence commencing foes.

Strong as they were, the bold Curetes fail'd, While Meleager's thundering arm prevail'd : Till rage at length inflamed his (our) lofty breast -LRB-For rage invades the wisest and the best-RRB-.

-LRB-She (Cynthia) from Marpessa sprung, divinely fair, And matchless Idas, more than man in war: The god of day adored the mother's charms; Against the god the father bent his (father) arms: The afflicted pair, their sorrows to proclaim, From Cleopatra changed their daughter's name, And

``Cursed by Althaea, to his (father) wrath he (father) yields, And in his (father) wife's embrace forgets the fields. call'd Alcyone; a name to show The father's grief, the mourning mother's woe.-RRB-

To her (mother) the chief retired from stern debate, But found no peace from fierce Althaea's hate: Althaea's hate the unhappy warrior drew,

Whose luckless hand his (warrior) royal uncle slew; She (mother) beat the ground, and call'd the powers beneath On her (mother) own son to wreak her (mother) brother's death; Hell heard her (mother) curses from the realms profound, And the red fiends that walk the nightly round.

She (mother) sent ambassadors, a chosen band, Priests of the gods, and elders of the land; Besought the chief to save the sinking state: Their prayers were urgent, and their proffers great:

In vain Ćtolia her (mother) deliverer waits, War shakes her (mother) walls, and thunders at her (mother) gates. -LRB-Full fifty acres of the richest ground,

His (chief) sisters follow'd; even the vengeful dame, Althaea, sues; his (chief) friends before him (chief) fall: He (chief) stands relentless, and rejects them all.

Meanwhile the victor's shouts ascend the skies; The walls are scaled; the rolling flames arise; At length his (chief) wife -LRB-a form divine-RRB- appears, With piercing cries, and supplicating tears; She (wife) paints the horrors of a conquer'd town, The heroes slain, the palaces o'erthrown, The matrons ravish'd

Half pasture green, and half with vineyards crown'd:-RRB- His (chief) suppliant father, aged OEneus, came; , the whole race enslaved: The warrior heard, he (warrior) vanquish'd, and he (warrior) saved.

Learn hence, betimes to curb pernicious ire, Nor stay till yonder fleets ascend in fire; Accept the presents; draw thy conquering sword; And be amongst our guardian gods adored.

The Ćtolians, long disdain'd, now took their turn, And left the chief their broken faith to mourn. '' (daughter)

Thus he (chief): the stern Achilles thus replied:

Thy friend, believe me, no such gifts demands, And asks no honours from a mortal's hands; Jove honours me, and favours my designs; His (Achilles) pleasure guides me, and his (Achilles) will confines; And here I stay -LRB-if such his (Achilles) high behest-RRB-

``My second father, and my reverend guide: While life's warm spirit beats within my breast. Yet hear one word, and lodge it in thy heart:

No more molest me on Atrides' part: Is it for him (Achilles) these tears are taught to flow, For him (Achilles) these sorrows?

A generous friendship no cold medium knows, Burns with one love, with one resentment glows; One should our interests and our passions be; My friend must hate the man that injures me.

for my mortal foe? Do this, my Phoenix, 'tis a generous part; And share my realms, my honours, and my heart.

Let these return: our voyage, or our stay, Rest undetermined till the dawning day. '' (I)

He (foe) ceased; then order'd for the sage's bed A warmer couch with numerous carpets spread.

With that, stern Ajax his (foe) long silence broke, And thus, impatient, to Ulysses spoke:

``Hence let us go--why waste we time in vain?

See what effect our low submissions gain! Liked or not liked, his (Ulysses) words we must relate, The Greeks expect them, and our heroes wait.

Proud as he (Ulysses) is, that iron heart retains Its stubborn purpose, and his (Ulysses) friends disdains. Stern and unpitying! if a brother bleed, On just atonement, we remit the deed;

A sire the slaughter of his (sire) son forgives; The price of blood discharged, the murderer lives: The haughtiest hearts at length their rage resign, And gifts can conquer every soul but thine.-LRB-213-RRB-

The gods that unrelenting breast have steel'd, And cursed thee with a mind that cannot yield. One woman-slave was ravish'd from thy arms: Lo, seven are offer'd, and of equal charms.

Then hear, Achilles! be of better mind; Revere thy roof, and to thy guests be kind; And know the men of all the Grecian host, Who honour worth, and prize thy valour most.'' (Ulysses/ULYSSES)

``O soul of battles, and thy people's guide! -LRB-To Ajax thus the first of Greeks replied-RRB- Well hast thou spoke; but at the tyrant's name My rage rekindles, and my soul's on flame: '

, The glorious combat is no more my care; Not till, amidst yon sinking navy slain, The blood of Greeks shall dye the sable main; Not till the flames, by Hector's fury thrown, Consume your vessels, and approach my own; Just there, the impetuous homicide shall stand, There cease his (Hector) battle, and there feel our hand.

Tis just resentment, and becomes the brave: Disgraced, dishonour'd, like the vilest slave! Return, then, heroes! and our answer bear '' (each prince)

This said, each prince a double goblet crown'd, And cast a large libation on the ground; Then to their vessels, through the gloomy shades, The chiefs return; divine Ulysses leads.

Meantime Achilles' slaves prepared a bed, With fleeces, carpets, and soft linen spread: There, till the sacred morn restored the day,

But in his (Achilles) inner tent, an ampler space, Achilles slept; and in his (Achilles) warm embrace Fair Diomede of the Lesbian race.

Whose nightly joys the beauteous Iphis shared; Achilles to his (Achilles) friend consign'd her (Achilles) charms When Scyros fell before his (Achilles) conquering arms.

In slumber sweet the reverend Phoenix lay. Last, for Patroclus was the couch prepared, And now the elected chiefs whom Greece had sent, Pass'd through the hosts, and reach'd the royal tent.

Then rising all, with goblets in their hands, The peers and leaders of the Achaian bands Hail'd their return: Atrides first begun: ``Say what success? divine Laertes' son!

Achilles' high resolves declare to all:

``Returns the chief, or must our navy fall?'' (Achilles)
``Great king of nations! -LRB-Ithacus replied-RRB- Fix'd is his (king) wrath, unconquer'd is his (king) pride

; He (king) slights thy friendship, thy proposals scorns, And, thus implored, with fiercer fury burns. To save our army, and our fleets to free, Is not his (king) care; but left to Greece and thee.

Beneath his (king) oars the whitening billows fly; Us too he (king) bids our oars and sails employ, Nor hope the fall of heaven-protected Troy

Your eyes shall view, when morning paints the sky, ; For Jove o'ershades her (our) with his (king) arm divine, Inspires her (our) war, and bids her (our) glory shine.

Such was his (king) word: what further he (king) declared, These sacred heralds and great Ajax heard. But Phoenix in his (king) tent the chief retains, Safe to transport him (king) to his (king) native plains

When morning dawns; if other he (king) decree, His (king) age is sacred, and his (king) choice is free. '' (Ulysses/ULYSSES)

Ulysses ceased: the great Achaian host, With sorrow seized, in consternation lost, Attend the stern reply.

Tydides broke The general silence, and undaunted spoke. '' Why should we gifts to proud Achilles send, Or strive with prayers his (Achilles) haughty soul to bend?

His (Achilles) country's woes he (Achilles) glories to deride, And prayers will burst that swelling heart with pride. Be the fierce impulse of his (Achilles) rage obey'd,

Our battles let him (Achilles) or desert or aid; Then let him (Achilles) arm when Jove or he (Achilles) think fit: That, to his (Achilles) madness, or to Heaven commit: What for ourselves we can, is always ours; This night, let due repast refresh our powers; -LRB-For strength consists in spirits and in blood,

But when the rosy messenger of day Strikes the blue mountains with her (Achilles) golden ray, Ranged at the ships, let all our squadrons shine In flaming arms, a long-extended line:

And those are owed to generous wine and food;-RRB- In the dread front let great Atrides stand, The first in danger, as in high command.

Shouts of acclaim the listening heroes raise, Then each to Heaven the due libations pays; Till sleep, descending o'er the tents, bestows The grateful blessings of desired repose.''-LRB-214-RRB-

Upon the refusal of Achilles to return to the army, the distress of Agamemnon is described in the most lively manner.

He (Agamemnon) takes no rest that night, but passes through the camp, awaking the leaders, and contriving all possible methods for the public safety.

'' -LSB-Illustration: ACHILLES.-RSB- ACHILLES. BOOK X. ARGUMENT. THE NIGHT-ADVENTURE OF DIOMED AND ULYSSES. Menelaus, Nestor, Ulysses, and Diomed are employed in raising the rest of the captains.

They call a council of war, and determine to send scouts into the enemies' camp, to learn their posture, and discover their intentions.

Diomed undertakes this hazardous enterprise, and makes choice of Ulysses for his (Ulysses) companion. In their passage they surprise Dolon, whom Hector had sent on a like design to the camp of the Grecians.

From him (Hector) they are informed of the situation of the Trojan and auxiliary forces, and particularly of Rhesus, and the Thracians who were lately arrived.

They pass on with success; kill Rhesus, with several of his (Hector) officers, and seize the famous horses of that prince, with which they return in triumph to the camp.

All night the chiefs before their vessels lay, And lost in sleep the labours of the day: All but the king: with various thoughts oppress'd,-LRB-215-RRB-

As when by lightnings Jove's ethereal power Foretels the rattling hail, or weighty shower, Or sends soft snows to whiten all the shore, Or bids the brazen throat of war to roar; By fits one flash succeeds as one expires, And heaven flames thick with momentary fires:

The same night continues; the scene lies in the two camps. His (king) country's cares lay rolling in his (king) breast. So bursting frequent from Atrides' breast, Sighs following sighs his (king) inward fears confess'd.

Now o'er the fields, dejected, he (king) surveys From thousand Trojan fires the mounting blaze; Hears in the passing wind their music blow, And marks distinct the voices of the foe.

He (foe) rends his (foe) hair, in sacrifice to Jove, And sues to him (foe) that ever lives above: Inly he (foe) groans; while glory and despair Divide his (foe) heart, and wage a double war.

A thousand cares his (foe) labouring breast revolves; To seek sage Nestor now the chief resolves, With him (chief), in wholesome counsels, to debate What yet remains to save the afflicted state.

He (chief) rose, and first he (chief) cast his (chief) mantle round, Next on his (chief) feet the shining sandals bound; A lion's yellow spoils

Now looking backwards to the fleet and coast, Anxious he (chief) sorrows for the endangered host. his (chief) back conceal'd; His (chief) warlike hand a pointed javelin held.

Alike denied the gifts of soft repose, Laments for Greece, that in his (chief) cause before So much had suffer'd and must suffer more.

: A brazen helmet glitter'd on his (chief) head: Thus -LRB-with a javelin in his (chief) hand-RRB- he (chief) went To wake Atrides in the royal tent.

Meanwhile his (chief) brother, press'd with equal woes, A leopard's spotted hide his (chief) shoulders spread Already waked, Atrides he (chief) descried, His (chief) armour buckling at his (chief) vessel's side.

Joyful they met; the Spartan thus begun: ``Why puts my brother his (brother) bright armour on? Sends he (brother) some spy, amidst these silent hours, To try yon camp, and watch the Trojan powers?

But say, what hero shall sustain that task? Such bold exploits uncommon courage ask; Guideless, alone, through night's dark shade to go, And midst a hostile camp explore the foe.

To whom the king:

``In such distress we stand, No vulgar counsel our affairs demand; Greece to preserve, is now no easy part, But asks high wisdom, deep design, and art.

witness'd, or what ear believed, In one great day, by one great arm achieved, Such wondrous deeds as Hector's hand has done, And we beheld, the last revolving sun

'' (the king demand part art)

For Jove, averse, our humble prayer denies, And bows his (Hector) head to Hector's sacrifice. What eye has What honours the beloved of Jove adorn!

Sprung from no god, and of no goddess born; Yet such his (god) acts, as Greeks unborn shall tell, And curse the battle where their fathers fell.

Now speed thy hasty course along the fleet, There call great Ajax, and the prince of Crete; Ourself to hoary Nestor will repair; To keep the guards on duty be his (Nestor) care, -LRB-For Nestor's influence best that quarter guides, Whose son with Merion

'' , o'er the watch presides.''-RRB- To whom the Spartan:

``These thy orders borne, Say, shall I stay, or with despatch return?'' (the Spartan)

'' There shall thou stay, -LRB-the king of men replied,-RRB- Else may we miss to meet, without a guide, The paths so many, and the camp so wide.

Still, with your voice the slothful soldiers raise, Urge by their fathers' fame their future praise. Forget we now our state and lofty birth; Not titles here, but works, must prove our worth.

To labour is the lot of man below; And when Jove gave us life, he (man) gave us woe. '' This said, each parted to his (man) several cares:

The king to Nestor's sable ship repairs; The sage protector of the Greeks he (Nestor) found Stretch'd in his (Nestor) bed with all his (Nestor) arms around The various-colour'd scarf, the shield he (Nestor) rears, The shining helmet, and the pointed spears; The dreadful weapons of the warrior's rage, That, old in arms, disdain'd the peace of age.

Then, leaning on his (warrior) hand his (warrior) watchful head, The hoary monarch raised his (warrior) eyes and said:

``What art thou, speak, that on designs unknown, While others sleep, thus range the camp alone;

Seek`st thou some friend or nightly sentinel? Stand off, approach not, but thy purpose tell. '' (The monarch)

'' O son of Neleus, -LRB-thus the king rejoin'd,-RRB-

Lo, here the wretched Agamemnon stands, The unhappy general of the Grecian bands, Whom Jove decrees with daily cares to bend, And woes, that only with his (Agamemnon) life shall end!

Pride of the Greeks, and glory of thy kind! Scarce can my knees these trembling limbs sustain, And scarce my heart support its load of pain.

No taste of sleep these heavy eyes have known, Confused, and sad, I wander thus alone, With fears distracted, with no fix'd design; And all my people's miseries are mine.

If aught of use thy waking thoughts suggest, -LRB-Since cares, like mine, deprive thy soul of rest,-RRB- Impart thy counsel, and assist thy friend; Now let us jointly to the trench descend,

Tired with the toils of day and watch of night; Else may the sudden foe our works invade, So near, and favour'd by the gloomy shade.

At every gate the fainting guard excite, '' To him (guard) thus Nestor: ``Trust the powers above, Nor think proud Hector's hopes confirm'd by Jove:

Audacious Hector, if the gods ordain That great Achilles rise and rage again, What toils attend thee, and what woes remain!

How ill agree the views of vain mankind, And the wise counsels of the eternal mind! Lo, faithful Nestor thy command obeys

; The care is next our other chiefs to raise: Ulysses, Diomed, we chiefly need; Meges for strength, Oileus famed for speed.

Some other be despatch'd of nimbler feet, To those tall ships, remotest of the fleet, Where lie great Ajax and the king of Crete.-LRB-216-RRB-

I myself decree; Dear as he (king) is to us, and dear to thee, Yet must I tax his (king) sloth, that claims no share With his (king) great brother in his (king) martial care:
