Him (king) it behoved to every chief to sue, Preventing every part perform'd by you; For strong necessity our toils demands, Claims all our hearts, and urges all our hands.

To whom the king:

``With reverence we allow Thy just rebukes, yet learn to spare them now: My generous brother is of gentle kind, He (brother) seems remiss, but bears a valiant mind; Through too much deference to our sovereign sway, Content to follow when we lead the way: But now, our ills industrious to prevent, Long ere the rest he (Long) rose, and sought my tent.

The chiefs you named, already at his (Long) call, Prepare to meet us near the navy-wall; Assembling there, between the trench and gates,

To rouse the Spartan '' (the king)

Near the night-guards, our chosen council waits. ''
``Then none -LRB-said Nestor-RRB- shall his (Nestor) rule withstand

The shining greaves his (Nestor) manly legs enclose; His (Nestor) purple mantle golden buckles join'd, Warm with the softest wool, and doubly lined.

, For great examples justify command. '' (the warrior)

With that, the venerable warrior rose; Then rushing from his (warrior) tent, he (warrior) snatch'd in haste His (warrior) steely lance, that lighten'd as he (warrior) pass'd.

The camp he (warrior) traversed through the sleeping crowd, Stopp'd at Ulysses' tent, and call'd aloud. Ulysses, sudden as the voice was sent, Awakes, starts up, and issues from his (Ulysses) tent.

'' What new distress, what sudden cause of fright , Thus leads you wandering in the silent night?''

``O prudent chief!

Wise as thou art, be now thy wisdom tried: Whatever means of safety can be sought, Whatever counsels can inspire our thought, Whatever methods, or to fly or fight; All, all depend on this important night!'' (the Pylian sage)

-LRB-the Pylian sage replied-RRB- He (Wise) heard, return'd, and took his (Wise) painted shield; Then join'd the chiefs, and follow'd through the field.

Without his (Wise) tent, bold Diomed they found, All sheathed in arms, his (Wise) brave companions round: Each sunk in sleep, extended on the field, His (Wise) head reclining on his (Wise) bossy shield.

A wood of spears stood by, that, fix'd upright, Shot from their flashing points a quivering light. A bull's black hide composed the hero's bed;

A splendid carpet roll'd beneath his (hero) head. Then, with his (hero) foot, old Nestor gently shakes The slumbering chief, and in these words awakes: ``Rise, son of Tydeus!

to the brave and strong Rest seems inglorious, and the night too long. But sleep`st thou now, when from yon hill the foe Hangs o'er the fleet, and shades our walls below?

At this, soft slumber from his (foe) eyelids fled; The warrior saw the hoary chief, and said:

``Wondrous old man! whose soul no respite knows, Though years and honours bid thee seek repose, Let younger Greeks

My friend, -LRB-he (friend) answered,-RRB- generous is thy care; These toils, my subjects and my sons might bear; Their loyal thoughts and pious love conspire To ease a sovereign and relieve a sire:

But now the last despair surrounds our host; No hour must pass, no moment must be lost; Each single Greek, in this conclusive strife, Stands on the sharpest edge of death or life:

Yet, if my years thy kind regard engage, Employ thy youth as I employ my age; Succeed to these my cares, and rouse the rest; He (sire) serves me most, who serves his (sire) country best.

This said, the hero o'er his (hero) shoulders flung A lion's spoils, that to his (hero) ankles hung; Then seized his (hero) ponderous lance, and strode along.

'' (the chief)

our sleeping warriors wake; Ill fits thy age these toils to undertake.'' '' '' Meges the bold, with Ajax famed for speed, The warrior roused, and to the entrenchments lead.

And now the chiefs approach the nightly guard; A wakeful squadron, each in arms prepared : The unwearied watch their listening leaders keep, And, couching close, repel invading sleep.

With toil protected from the prowling train; When the gaunt lioness, with hunger bold, Springs from the mountains toward the guarded fold: Through breaking woods her (guard) rustling course they hear; Loud, and more loud, the clamours strike their ear Of hounds and men: they start, they gaze around,

Thus watch'd the Grecians, cautious of surprise, Each voice, each motion, drew their ears and eyes: Each step of passing feet increased the affright; And hostile Troy was ever full in sight.

So faithful dogs their fleecy charge maintain, Watch every side, and turn to every sound. Nestor with joy the wakeful band survey'd, And thus accosted through the gloomy shade.

'' ' Tis well, my sons! your nightly cares employ; Else must our host become the scorn of Troy. Watch thus, and Greece shall live.

'' The hero said; Then o'er the trench the following chieftains led. His (hero) son, and godlike Merion, march'd behind -LRB-For these the princes to their council join'd-RRB-.

A place there was, yet undefiled with gore, The spot where Hector stopp'd his (Hector) rage before; When night descending, from his (Hector) vengeful hand Reprieved the relics of the Grecian band:

The trenches pass'd, the assembled kings around In silent state the consistory crown'd. -LRB-The plain beside with mangled corps was spread, And all his (Hector) progress mark'd by heaps of dead:-RRB-

There sat the mournful kings: when Neleus' son, The council opening, in these words begun:

``Is there -LRB-said he (son)-RRB- a chief so greatly brave, His (son) life to hazard, and his (son) country save?

Lives there a man, who singly dares to go To yonder camp, or seize some straggling foe? Or favour'd by the night approach so near, Their speech, their counsels, and designs to hear?

This could he (foe) learn, and to our peers recite, And pass unharm'd the dangers of the night; What fame were his (foe) through all succeeding days, While Phoebus shines, or men have tongues to praise!

If to besiege our navies they prepare, Or Troy once more must be the seat of war? What gifts his (foe) grateful country would bestow!

A sable ewe each leader should provide, With each a sable lambkin by her (leader) side; At every rite his (leader) share should be increased, And his (leader) the foremost honours of the feast.

What must not Greece to her (leader) deliverer owe? '' (Neleus son opening)

Fear held them mute: alone, untaught to fear, Tydides spoke--``The man you seek is here.

Through yon black camps to bend my dangerous way, Some god within commands, and I obey. But let some other chosen warrior join, To raise my hopes, and second my design.

By mutual confidence and mutual aid, Great deeds are done, and great discoveries made; The wise new prudence from the wise acquire, And one brave hero fans another's fire.

Contending leaders at the word arose; Each generous breast with emulation glows; So brave a task each Ajax strove to share, Bold Merion strove, and Nestor's valiant heir; The Spartan wish'd the second place to gain, And great Ulysses wish'd, nor wish'd in vain.

``Thou first of warriors, and thou best of friends, Undaunted Diomed! what chief to join In this great enterprise, is only thine.

'' (the king)

Then thus the king of men the contest ends: Just be thy choice, without affection made; To birth, or office, no respect be paid; Let worth determine here.

'' The monarch spake, And inly trembled for his (monarch) brother's sake. '' Then thus -LRB-the godlike Diomed rejoin'd-RRB- My choice declares the impulse of my mind.

A chief, whose safety is Minerva's care; So famed, so dreadful, in the works of war: Bless'd in his (chief) conduct, I no aid require; Wisdom like his (chief) might pass through flames of fire.''

How can I doubt, while great Ulysses stands To lend his (Ulysses) counsels and assist our hands?

``It fits thee not, before these chiefs of fame,

-LRB-Replied the sage,-RRB- to praise me, or to blame: Praise from a friend, or censure from a foe, Are lost on hearers that our merits know.

, The reddening orient shows the coming day, The stars shine fainter on the ethereal plains, And of night's empire but a third remains.

But let us haste--Night rolls the hours away '' (he)

Thus having spoke, with generous ardour press'd, In arms terrific their huge limbs

Then in a leathern helm he (foe) cased his (foe) head, Short of its crest, and with no plume o'erspread: -LRB-Such as by youths unused to arms are worn:-RRB-

they dress'd. A two-edged falchion Thrasymed the brave, And ample buckler, to Tydides gave: No spoils enrich it, and no studs adorn.

Next him (foe) Ulysses took a shining sword, A bow and quiver, with bright arrows stored: A well-proved casque, with leather braces bound, -LRB-Thy gift, Meriones,-RRB- his (Ulysses) temples crown'd; Soft wool within; without, in order spread,-LRB-217-RRB-

This from Amyntor, rich Ormenus' son, Autolycus by fraudful rapine won, And gave Amphidamas; from him (son) the prize Molus received, the pledge of social ties; The helmet next by Merion was possess'd,

A boar's white teeth grinn'd horrid o'er his (son) head. And now Ulysses' thoughtful temples press'd. Thus sheathed in arms, the council they forsake, And dark through paths oblique their progress take.

Just then, in sign she (son) favour'd their intent, A long-wing'd heron great Minerva sent: This, though surrounding shades obscured their view.

Ulysses pray'd, Hail'd the glad omen, and address'd the maid:

``O daughter of that god whose arm can wield The avenging bolt, and shake the dreadful shield

By the shrill clang and whistling wings they knew. As from the right she (daughter) soar'd, ! O thou! for ever present in my way, Who all my motions, all my toils survey!

Safe may we pass beneath the gloomy shade, Safe by thy succour to our ships convey'd, And let some deed this signal night adorn, To claim the tears of Trojans yet unborn.

'' (the maid)

Then godlike Diomed preferr'd his (god) prayer:
``Daughter of Jove, unconquer'd Pallas! hear. Great queen of arms, whose favour Tydeus won,

When on Ćsopus' banks the banded powers Of Greece he (god) left, and sought the Theban towers, Peace was his (god) charge; received with peaceful show, He (god) went a legate, but return'd a foe:

As thou defend`st the sire, defend the son. Then help'd by thee, and cover'd by thy shield, He (son) fought with numbers, and made numbers yield.

A youthful steer shall fall beneath the stroke, Untamed, unconscious of the galling yoke, With ample forehead, and with spreading horns, Whose taper tops refulgent gold adorns.

So now be present, O celestial maid! So still continue to the race thine aid! '' (The heroes)

The heroes pray'd, and Pallas from the skies

Now, like two lions panting for the prey, With dreadful thoughts they trace the dreary way, Through the black horrors of the ensanguined plain, Through dust, through blood, o'er arms, and hills of slain.

Nor less bold Hector, and the sons of Troy, On high designs the wakeful hours employ; The assembled peers their lofty chief enclosed; Who thus the counsels of his (chief) breast proposed:

``What glorious man, for high attempts prepared, Dares greatly venture for a rich reward?

Accords their vow, succeeds their enterprise. Of yonder fleet a bold discovery make, What watch they keep, and what resolves they take?

His (chief) be the chariot that shall please him (chief) most, Of all the plunder of the vanquish'd host; His (chief) the fair steeds that all the rest excel, And his (chief) the glory to have served so well.

A youth there was among the tribes of Troy, Dolon his (chief) name, Eumedes' only boy, -LRB-Five girls beside the reverend herald told.-RRB-

Rich was the son in brass, and rich in gold; Not bless'd by nature with the charms of face, But swift of foot, and matchless in the race.

If now subdued they meditate their flight, And, spent with toil, neglect the watch of night? '' (chief)

'' Hector! -LRB-he (Hector) said-RRB- my courage bids me meet This high achievement, and explore the fleet:

But first exalt thy sceptre to the skies, And swear to grant me the demanded prize; The immortal coursers, and the glittering car, That bear Pelides through the ranks of war.

Encouraged thus, no idle scout I go, Fulfil thy wish, their whole intention know, Even to the royal tent pursue my way, And all their counsels, all their aims betray.

'' The chief then heaved the golden sceptre high, Attesting thus the monarch of the sky:

``Be witness thou! immortal lord of all!

Whose thunder shakes the dark aerial hall: By none but Dolon shall this prize be borne, And him (lord) alone the immortal steeds adorn.

Across his (lord) back the bended bow he (lord) flung, A wolf's grey hide around his (lord) shoulders hung, A ferret's downy fur his (lord) helmet lined,

'' (the monarch)

Thus Hector swore: the gods were call'd in vain, But the rash youth prepares to scour the plain: And in his (Hector) hand a pointed javelin shined.

Then -LRB-never to return-RRB- he (Hector) sought the shore, And trod the path his (Hector) feet must tread no more. Scarce had he (Hector) pass'd the steeds and Trojan throng, -LRB-Still bending forward as he (Hector) coursed along,-RRB-

I hear some step of hostile feet, Moving this way, or hastening to the fleet; Some spy, perhaps, to lurk beside the main; Or nightly pillager that strips the slain.

When, on the hollow way, the approaching tread Ulysses mark'd, and thus to Diomed;

``O friend! Yet let him (friend) pass, and win a little space; Then rush behind him (friend), and prevent his (friend) pace.

But if too swift of foot he (friend) flies before, Confine his (friend) course along the fleet and shore, Betwixt the camp and him (friend)

With that they stepp'd aside, and stoop'd their head, -LRB-As Dolon pass'd,-RRB- behind a heap of dead: Along the path the spy unwary flew; Soft, at just distance, both the chiefs pursue.

So distant they, and such the space between, As when two teams of mules divide the green, -LRB-To whom the hind like shares of land allows,-RRB-

Now Dolon, listening, heard them as they pass'd; Hector -LRB-he (Hector) thought-RRB- had sent, and check'd his (Hector) haste, Till scarce at distance of a javelin's throw, No voice succeeding, he (Hector) perceived the foe.

As when two skilful hounds the leveret wind; Or chase through woods obscure the trembling hind; Now lost, now seen, they intercept his (Hector) way, And from the herd still turn the flying prey: So fast, and with such fears, the Trojan flew; So close, so constant,

our spears employ, And intercept his (Hector) hoped return to Troy. '' (Diomed)

When now new furrows part the approaching ploughs. the bold Greeks pursue.

Now almost on the fleet the dastard falls, And mingles with the guards that watch the walls; When brave Tydides stopp'd; a gen`rous thought -LRB-Inspired by Pallas-RRB- in his (Hector) bosom wrought,

Lest on the foe some forward Greek advance, And snatch the glory from his (Hector) lifted lance. Then thus aloud:

``Whoe'er thou art, remain; This javelin else shall fix thee to the plain.

'' (He)

He (Hector) said, and high in air the weapon cast, Which wilful err'd, and o'er his (Hector) shoulder pass'd; Then fix'd in earth.

Against the trembling wood The wretch stood propp'd, and quiver'd as he (Hector) stood; A sudden palsy seized his (Hector) turning head; His (Hector) loose teeth

chatter'd, and his (Hector) colour fled; The panting warriors seize him (Hector) as he (Hector) stands, And with unmanly tears his (Hector) life demands. ''

O spare my youth, and for the breath I owe, Large gifts of price my father shall bestow: Vast heaps of brass shall in your ships be told, And steel well-temper'd and refulgent gold.

'' To whom Ulysses made this wise reply:

``Whoe'er thou art, be bold, nor fear to die. What moves thee, say, when sleep has closed the sight, To roam the silent fields in dead of night?

Cam`st thou the secrets of our camp to find, By Hector prompted, or thy daring mind? Or art some wretch by hopes of plunder led, Through heaps of carnage, to despoil the dead?'' (Ulysses/ULYSSES)

Then thus pale Dolon, with a fearful look: -LRB-Still, as he (Hector) spoke, his (Hector) limbs with horror shook:-RRB- '' Hither I came, by Hector's words deceived; Much did he (Hector) promise,

those swift steeds that sweep the ranks of war, Urged me, unwilling, this attempt to make; To learn what counsels, what resolves you take: If now subdued, you fix your hopes on flight,

rashly I believed: No less a bribe than great Achilles' car, And And, tired with toils, neglect the watch of night.

'' '' Bold was thy aim, and glorious was the prize, -LRB- Ulysses, with a scornful smile, replies,-RRB- Far other rulers those proud steeds demand, And scorn the guidance of a vulgar hand

; Even great Achilles scarce their rage can tame, Achilles sprung from an immortal dame. But say, be faithful, and the truth recite!

Where lies encamp'd the Trojan chief to-night? Where stand his (chief) coursers? in what quarter sleep Their other princes? tell what watch they keep:

Say, since this conquest, what their counsels are; Or here to combat, from their city far, Or back to Ilion's walls transfer the war?

'' Ulysses thus, and thus Eumedes' son:

``What Dolon knows, his (Ulysses) faithful tongue shall own. Hector, the peers assembling in his (Hector) tent, A council holds at Ilus' monument.

No certain guards the nightly watch partake; Where'er yon fires ascend, the Trojans wake: Anxious for Troy, the guard the natives keep

; Safe in their cares, the auxiliar forces sleep, Whose wives and infants, from the danger far, Discharge their souls of half the fears of war.'' (Eumedes son)

To whom the spy: ``Their powers they thus dispose The Paeons, dreadful with their bended bows, The Carians, Caucons, the Pelasgian host, And Leleges, encamp along the coast.

``Then sleep those aids among the Trojan train, -LRB-Inquired the chief,-RRB- or scattered o'er the plain?'' (Rhesus)
Not distant far, lie higher on the land

These Troy but lately to her (wives) succour won, Led on by Rhesus, great Eioneus' son: I saw his (son) coursers in proud triumph go, Swift as the wind, and white as winter-snow; Rich silver plates his (Rich) shining car infold; His (Rich) solid arms, refulgent, flame with gold; No mortal shoulders suit the glorious load, Celestial panoply, to grace a god!

The Lycian, Mysian, and Maeonian band, And Phrygia's horse, by Thymbras' ancient wall; The Thracians utmost, and apart from all. Let me, unhappy, to your fleet be borne, Or leave me here, a captive's fate to mourn,

To this Tydides, with a gloomy frown:

``Think not to live, though all the truth be shown: Shall we dismiss thee, in some future strife

In cruel chains, till your return reveal The truth or falsehood of the news I tell. '' (a captive)

To risk more bravely thy now forfeit life?

Sternly he (captive) spoke, and as the wretch prepared With humble blandishment to stroke his (captive) beard, Like lightning swift the wrathful falchion flew, Divides the neck, and cuts the nerves in two;

Or that again our camps thou may`st explore? No--once a traitor, thou betray`st no more. '' One instant snatch'd his (traitor) trembling soul to hell, The head, yet speaking,

mutter'd as it fell. The furry helmet from his (traitor) brow they tear, The wolf's grey hide, the unbended bow and spear;

These great Ulysses lifting to the skies, To favouring Pallas dedicates the prize:

``Great queen of arms, receive this hostile spoil, And let the Thracian steeds reward our toil;

This said, the spoils, with dropping gore defaced, High on a spreading tamarisk he (Great) placed; Then heap'd with reeds and gathered boughs the plain, To guide their footsteps to the place again.

Through the still night they cross the devious fields, Slippery with blood, o'er arms and heaps of shields, Arriving where the Thracian squadrons lay, And eased in sleep the labours of the day.

Thee, first of all the heavenly host, we praise; O speed our labours, and direct our ways! '' (Pallas)

Ranged in three lines they view the prostrate band: The horses yoked beside each warrior stand.

Their arms in order on the ground reclined, Through the brown shade the fulgid weapons shined: Amidst lay Rhesus, stretch'd in sleep profound,

And the white steeds behind his (warrior) chariot bound. The welcome sight Ulysses first descries, And points to Diomed the tempting prize.

now thy courage try, Approach the chariot, and the steeds untie; Or if thy soul aspire to fiercer deeds, Urge thou the slaughter, while I seize the steeds.

'' The man, the coursers, and the car behold! Described by Dolon, with the arms of gold. Now, brave Tydides! ''

Pallas -LRB-this said-RRB- her (Dolon) hero's bosom warms, Breathed in his (hero) heart, and strung his (hero) nervous arms; Where'er he (hero) pass'd, a purple stream pursued His (hero) thirsty falchion, fat with hostile blood, Bathed all his (hero) footsteps, dyed the fields with gore, And a low groan

So the grim lion, from his (hero) nightly den, O'erleaps the fences, and invades the pen, On sheep or goats, resistless in his (hero) way, He (hero) falls, and foaming rends the guardless prey; Nor stopp'd the fury of his (hero) vengeful hand, Till twelve lay breathless of the Thracian band.

Ulysses following, as his (Ulysses) partner slew, Back by the foot each slaughter'd warrior drew; The milk-white coursers studious to convey Safe to the ships, he (warrior) wisely cleared the way:

remurmur'd through the shore. Lest the fierce steeds, not yet to battles bred, Should start, and tremble at the heaps of dead.

Now twelve despatch'd, the monarch last they found; Tydides' falchion fix'd him (monarch) to the ground. Just then a deathful dream Minerva sent, A warlike form appear'd before his (monarch) tent, Whose visionary steel his (monarch) bosom tore:

Ulysses now the snowy steeds detains, And leads them, fasten'd by the silver reins; These, with his (Ulysses) bow unbent, he (Ulysses) lash'd along; -LRB-The scourge forgot, on Rhesus' chariot hung;-RRB- Then gave his (Ulysses) friend the signal to retire;

But him (Ulysses), new dangers, new achievements fire; Doubtful he (Ulysses) stood, or with his (Ulysses) reeking blade To send more heroes to the infernal shade, Drag off the car where Rhesus' armour lay, Or heave with manly force, and lift away.

While unresolved the son of Tydeus stands, Pallas appears, and thus her (Ulysses) chief commands:

``Enough, my son; from further slaughter cease, Regard thy safety, and depart in peace; Haste to the ships, the gotten spoils enjoy, Nor tempt too far the hostile gods of Troy.

So dream'd the monarch, and awaked no more.-LRB-218-RRB- '' (chief)

The voice divine confess'd the martial maid; In haste he (monarch) mounted, and her (maid) word obey'd

Not unobserved they pass'd: the god of light Had watch'd his (god) Troy, and mark'd Minerva's flight, Saw Tydeus' son with heavenly succour

; The coursers fly before Ulysses' bow, Swift as the wind, and white as winter-snow. bless'd, And vengeful anger fill'd his (Swift) sacred breast.

Swift to the Trojan camp descends the power, And wakes Hippocoon in the morning-hour; -LRB-On Rhesus' side accustom'd to attend, A faithful kinsman, and instructive friend;-RRB-

He (friend) rose, and saw the field deform'd with blood, An empty space where late the coursers stood, The yet-warm Thracians panting on the coast; For each he (friend) wept, but for his (friend) Rhesus most: Now while on Rhesus' name he (friend) calls in vain, The gathering tumult spreads o'er all the plain; On heaps the Trojans rush, with wild affright, And wondering view the slaughters of the night.

Meanwhile the chiefs, arriving at the shade Where late the spoils of Hector's spy were laid, Ulysses stopp'd; to him (Ulysses) Tydides bore The trophy, dropping yet with Dolon's gore: Then mounts again; again their nimbler feet

The coursers ply, and thunder towards the fleet. -LSB-Illustration: DIOMED AND ULYSSES RETURNING WITH THE SPOILS OF RHESUS.-RSB- DIOMED AND ULYSSES RETURNING WITH THE SPOILS OF RHESUS.

``Methinks the noise of trampling steeds I hear, Thickening this way, and gathering on my ear; Perhaps some horses of the Trojan breed -LRB-So may, ye gods!

Old Nestor first perceived the approaching sound, Bespeaking thus the Grecian peers around: my pious hopes succeed-RRB- The great Tydides and Ulysses bear, Return'd triumphant with this prize of war.

Yet much I fear -LRB-ah, may that fear be vain!-RRB- The chiefs outnumber'd by the Trojan train; Perhaps, even now pursued, they seek the shore; Or, oh!

the chiefs appear, And spring to earth; the Greeks dismiss their fear: With words of friendship and extended hands They greet the kings; and Nestor first demands:

perhaps those heroes are no more. '' (he)

Scarce had he (Nestor) spoke, when, lo!
``Say thou, whose praises all our host proclaim, Thou living glory of the Grecian name!

Say whence these coursers? by what chance bestow'd , The spoil of foes, or present of a god? Not those fair steeds, so radiant and so gay

, That draw the burning chariot of the day. Old as I am, to age I scorn to yield, And daily mingle in the martial field;

But sure till now no coursers struck my sight Like these, conspicuous through the ranks of fight. Some god, I deem, conferred the glorious prize, Bless'd as ye are, and favourites of the skies;

The care of him (god) who bids the thunder roar, And her (god), whose fury bathes the world with gore.'' (unknown)

``Father! not so, -LRB-sage Ithacus rejoin'd,-RRB-

Of Thracian lineage are the steeds ye view, Whose hostile king the brave Tydides slew; Sleeping he (king) died, with all his (king) guards around, And twelve beside lay gasping on the ground.

These other spoils from conquer'd Dolon came, A wretch, whose swiftness was his (king) only fame; By Hector sent our forces to explore, He (king) now lies headless on the sandy shore.

The gifts of heaven are of a nobler kind. '' (unknown)

Then o'er the trench the bounding coursers flew; The joyful Greeks with loud acclaim pursue.

Straight to Tydides' high pavilion borne, The matchless steeds his (king) ample stalls adorn: The neighing coursers their new fellows greet, And the full racks are heap'd with generous wheat.

But Dolon's armour, to his (king) ships convey'd , High on the painted stern Ulysses laid, A trophy destin'd to the blue-eyed maid.

Then in the polished bath, refresh'd from toil, Their joints they supple with dissolving oil, In due repast indulge the genial hour, And first to Pallas

Now from nocturnal sweat and sanguine stain They cleanse their bodies in the neighb`ring main: the libations pour: They sit, rejoicing in her (maid) aid divine, And the crown'd goblet foams with floods of wine.

Agamemnon, having armed himself, leads the Grecians to battle; Hector prepares the Trojans to receive them, while Jupiter, Juno, and Minerva give the signals of war.

Agamemnon bears all before him (Agamemnon) and Hector is commanded by Jupiter -LRB-who sends Iris for that purpose-RRB- to decline the engagement, till the king shall be wounded and retire from the field.

Ulysses and Diomed put a stop to him (Ulysses) for a time but the latter, being wounded by Paris, is obliged to desert his (Ulysses) companion, who is encompassed by the Trojans, wounded, and in the utmost danger, till Menelaus and Ajax rescue him (Menelaus).

BOOK XI. ARGUMENT THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON. He (Menelaus) then makes a great slaughter of the enemy. Hector comes against Ajax, but that hero alone opposes multitudes, and rallies the Greeks.

In the meantime Machaon, in the other wing of the army, is pierced with an arrow by Paris, and carried from the fight in Nestor's chariot.

Achilles -LRB-who overlooked the action from his (Nestor) ship-RRB- sent Patroclus to inquire which of the Greeks was wounded in that manner; Nestor entertains him (Nestor) in his (Nestor) tent with an account of the accidents of the day, and a long recital of some former wars which he (Nestor) remembered, tending to put Patroclus upon persuading Achilles to fight for his (Nestor) countrymen, or at least to permit him (Nestor) to do it, clad in Achilles' armour.

This book opens with the eight and-twentieth day of the poem, and the same day, with its various actions and adventures is extended through the twelfth, thirteenth, fourteenth, fifteenth, sixteenth, seventeenth, and part of the eighteenth books.

Patroclus, on his (Achilles) return, meets Eurypylus also wounded, and assists him (Achilles) in that distress. The scene lies in the field near the monument of Ilus.

Now rose refulgent from Tithonus' bed; With new-born day to gladden mortal sight, And gild the courts of heaven with sacred light: When baleful Eris, sent by Jove's command, The torch of discord blazing in her (Tithonus) hand, Through the red skies her (Tithonus) bloody sign extends,

The saffron morn, with early blushes spread,-LRB-219-RRB- And, wrapt in tempests, o'er the fleet descends. High on Ulysses' bark her (Tithonus) horrid stand

Even Ajax and Achilles heard the sound, Whose ships, remote, the guarded navy bound, Thence the black fury through the Grecian throng

With horror sounds the loud Orthian song: The navy shakes, and at the dire alarms Each bosom boils, each warrior starts to arms.

She (Tithonus) took, and thunder'd through the seas and land. No more they sigh, inglorious to return, But breathe revenge, and for the combat burn.

-LSB-Illustration: THE DESCENT OF DISCORD.-RSB- THE DESCENT OF DISCORD. The king of men his (king) hardy host inspires With loud command, with great example fires!

And first he (king) cased his (king) manly legs around In shining greaves with silver buckles bound; The beaming cuirass next adorn'd his (king) breast, The same which once king Cinyras

possess'd: -LRB-The fame of Greece and her (Tithonus) assembled host Had reach'd that monarch on the Cyprian coast; 'Twas then, the friendship of the chief to gain, This glorious gift he (chief) sent, nor sent in vain:-RRB-

Ten rows of azure steel the work infold, Twice ten of tin, and twelve of ductile gold; Three glittering dragons to the gorget rise,

Himself first rose, himself before the rest His (chief) mighty limbs in radiant armour dress'd, Whose imitated scales against the skies Reflected various light, and arching bow'd, Like colour'd rainbows o'er a showery cloud

A radiant baldric, o'er his (chief) shoulder tied, Sustain'd the sword that glitter'd at his (chief) side: Gold was the hilt, a silver sheath encased The shining blade, and golden hangers graced.

-LRB-Jove's wondrous bow, of three celestial dies, Placed as a sign to man amidst the skies-RRB-. His (man) buckler's mighty orb was next

That round the warrior cast a dreadful shade; Ten zones of brass its ample brim surround, And twice ten bosses the bright convex crown'd:

Tremendous Gorgon frown'd upon its field, And circling terrors fill'd the expressive shield: Within its concave hung a silver thong, On which a mimic serpent creeps along, His (warrior) azure length in easy waves extends, Till in three heads the embroider'd monster ends.

Last o'er his (warrior) brows his (warrior) fourfold helm he (warrior) placed, With nodding horse-hair formidably graced; And in his (warrior) hands two steely javelins wields, That blaze to heaven, and lighten all the fields.

That instant Juno, and the martial maid, In happy thunders promised Greece their aid; High o'er the chief they clash'd their arms in air, And, leaning from the clouds, expect the war.

Close to the limits of the trench and mound, The fiery coursers to their chariots bound The squires restrain'd: the foot, with those who wield The lighter arms, rush forward to the field.

display'd, To second these, in close array combined, The squadrons spread their sable wings behind. Now shouts and tumults wake the tardy sun, As with the light the warriors' toils begun.

Even Jove, whose thunder spoke his (squires) wrath, distill'd Red drops of blood o'er all the fatal field;-LRB-220-RRB- The woes of men unwilling to survey, And all the slaughters that must stain the day.

Near Ilus' tomb, in order ranged around, The Trojan lines possess'd the rising ground: There wise Polydamas and Hector stood; Ćneas, honour'd as a guardian god; Bold Polybus, Agenor the divine; The brother-warriors of Antenor's line:

With youthful Acamas, whose beauteous face And fair proportion match'd the ethereal race. Great Hector, cover'd with his (Hector) spacious shield, Plies all the troops, and orders all the field.

As the red star now shows his (Hector) sanguine fires Through the dark clouds, and now in night retires, Thus through the ranks

appear'd the godlike man, Plunged in the rear, or blazing in the van; While streamy sparkles, restless as he (man) flies, Flash from his (man) arms, as lightning from the skies.

As sweating reapers in some wealthy field, Ranged in two bands, their crooked weapons wield, Bear down the furrows, till their labours meet; Thick fall the heapy harvests at their feet:

So Greece and Troy the field of war divide, And falling ranks are strow'd on every side. None stoop'd a thought to base inglorious flight;-LRB-221-RRB-

But horse to horse, and man to man they fight, Not rabid wolves more fierce contest their prey; Each wounds, each bleeds, but none resign the day.

Discord alone, of all the immortal train, Swells the red horrors of this direful plain: The gods in peace their golden mansions fill, Ranged in bright order on the Olympian hill:

Discord with joy the scene of death descries, And drinks large slaughter at her (man) sanguine eyes: But general murmurs told their griefs above, And each accused the partial will of Jove.

Meanwhile apart, superior, and alone, The eternal Monarch, on his (Monarch) awful throne, Wrapt in the blaze of boundless glory sate; And fix'd, fulfill'd the just decrees of fate.

On earth he (Monarch) turn'd his (Monarch) all-considering eyes, And mark'd the spot where Ilion's towers arise; The sea with ships, the fields with armies spread, The victor's rage, the dying, and the dead.

Thus while the morning-beams, increasing bright, O'er heaven's pure azure spread the glowing light, Commutual death the fate of war confounds, Each adverse battle gored with equal wounds.

But now -LRB-what time in some sequester'd vale The weary woodman spreads his (woodman) sparing meal, When his (woodman) tired arms refuse the axe to rear, And claim a respite from the sylvan war; But not till half the prostrate forests lay Stretch'd in long ruin, and exposed to day-RRB-

Great Agamemnon then the slaughter led, And slew Bienor at his (Agamemnon) people's head: Whose squire Oileus, with a sudden spring, Leap'd from the chariot to revenge his (Agamemnon) king; But in his (Agamemnon) front he (Agamemnon) felt the fatal wound, Which pierced his (Agamemnon) brain, and stretch'd him (Agamemnon) on the ground.

Then, nor till then, the Greeks' impulsive might Pierced the black phalanx, and let in the light. Atrides spoil'd, and left them on the plain: Vain was their youth,

their glittering armour vain: Now soil'd with dust, and naked to the sky, Their snowy limbs and beauteous bodies lie. Two sons of Priam next to battle move, The product, one of marriage, one of love:-LRB-222-RRB-

In the same car the brother-warriors ride; This took the charge to combat, that to guide: Far other task, than when they wont to keep, On Ida's tops, their father's fleecy sheep.

These on the mountains once Achilles found, And captive led, with pliant osiers bound; Then to their sire for ample sums restored; But now to perish by Atrides' sword: Pierced in the breast the base-born Isus bleeds:

Cleft through the head his (sire) brother's fate succeeds, Swift to the spoil the hasty victor falls, And, stript, their features to his (sire) mind recalls.

The Trojans see the youths untimely die, But helpless tremble for themselves, and fly. So when a lion ranging o'er the lawns.

Finds, on some grassy lair, the couching fawns, Their bones he (sire) cracks, their reeking vitals draws, And grinds the quivering flesh with bloody jaws; The frighted hind beholds, and dares not stay, But swift through rustling thickets bursts her (sire) way; All drown'd in sweat, the panting mother flies, And the big tears roll trickling from her (sire) eyes.

Amidst the tumult of the routed train, The sons of false Antimachus were slain; He (sire) who for bribes his (sire) faithless counsels sold, And voted Helen's stay for Paris' gold.

Atrides mark'd, as these their safety sought, And slew the children for the father's fault; Their headstrong horse unable to restrain, They shook with fear, and dropp'd the silken rein; Then in the chariot on their knees they fall, And thus with lifted hands for mercy call: ``O spare our youth, and for the life we owe, Antimachus shall copious gifts bestow: Soon as he (father) hears, that, not in battle slain, The Grecian ships his (father) captive sons detain, Large heaps of brass in ransom shall be told, And steel well-tempered, and persuasive gold.

These words, attended with the flood of tears, The youths address'd to unrelenting ears: The vengeful monarch gave this stern reply:

``If from Antimachus ye spring, ye die; The daring wretch who once in council stood To shed Ulysses' and my brother's blood, For proffer'd peace! and sues his (Ulysses) seed for grace?

'' (The monarch)

No, die, and pay the forfeit of your race. '' This said, Pisander from the car he (Ulysses) cast, And pierced his (Ulysses) breast: supine he (Ulysses) breathed his (Ulysses) last.

His (Ulysses) brother leap'd to earth; but, as he (Ulysses) lay, The trenchant falchion lopp'd his (Ulysses) hands away; His (Ulysses) sever'd head was toss'd among the throng, And, rolling, drew a bloody train along.

Then, where the thickest fought, the victor flew; The king's example all his (victor) Greeks pursue. Now by the foot the flying foot were slain, Horse trod by horse, lay foaming on the plain.

The brass-hoof'd steeds tumultuous plunge and bound, And the thick thunder beats the labouring ground, Still slaughtering on, the king of men proceeds; The distanced army wonders at his (king) deeds, As when the winds with raging flames conspire, And o'er the forests roll the flood of fire,

In blazing heaps the grove's old honours fall, And one refulgent ruin levels all: Before Atrides' rage so sinks the foe, Whole squadrons vanish, and proud heads lie low.

The steeds fly trembling from his (foe) waving sword, And many a car, now lighted of its lord, Wide o'er the field with guideless fury rolls, Breaking their ranks, and crushing out their souls; While his (foe) keen falchion drinks the warriors' lives; More grateful, now, to vultures than their wives!

From the dry fields thick clouds of dust arise, Shade the black host, and intercept the skies. Perhaps great Hector then had found his (Hector) fate, But Jove and destiny prolong'd his (Hector) date.

Safe from the darts, the care of heaven he (Hector) stood, Amidst alarms, and death, and dust, and blood. Now past the tomb where ancient Ilus lay, Through the mid field the routed urge their way:

Where the wild figs the adjoining summit crown, The path they take, and speed to reach the town. As swift, Atrides with loud shouts pursued, Hot with his (Hector) toil, and bathed in hostile blood.

Now near the beech-tree, and the Scaean gates, The hero halts, and his (hero) associates waits. Meanwhile on every side around the plain, Dispersed, disorder'd, fly the Trojan train.

The lion's roaring through the midnight shade; On heaps they tumble with successless haste; The savage seizes, draws, and rends the last.

So flies a herd of beeves, that hear dismay'd Not with less fury stern Atrides flew, Still press'd the rout, and still the hindmost slew;

Hurl'd from their cars the bravest chiefs are kill'd, And rage, and death, and carnage load the field. Now storms the victor at the Trojan wall; Surveys the towers, and meditates their fall.

But Jove descending shook the Idaean hills, And down their summits pour'd a hundred rills: The unkindled lightning in his (victor) hand he (victor) took, And thus the many-coloured maid bespoke:

``Iris, with haste thy golden wings display, To godlike Hector this our word convey--

Fights in the front, and bathes with blood the ground, Bid him (Hector) give way; but issue forth commands, And trust the war to less important hands:

But when, or wounded by the spear or dart, That chief shall mount his (chief) chariot, and depart, Then Jove shall string his (chief) arm, and fire his (chief) breast, Then to her (Iris) ships shall flying Greece be press'd,

While Agamemnon wastes the ranks around, Till to the main the burning sun descend, And sacred night her (Iris) awful shade extend.

'' (maid)

He (Agamemnon) spoke, and Iris at his (Agamemnon) word obey'd ; On wings of winds descends the various maid. The chief she (Iris) found amidst the ranks of war, Close to the bulwarks, on his (chief) glittering car.

While Agamemnon wastes the ranks around, Fights in the front, and bathes with blood the ground, Abstain from fight; yet issue forth commands, And trust the war to less important hands: But when, or wounded by the spear or dart, The chief shall mount his (chief) chariot, and depart, Then Jove shall string thy arm, and fire thy breast, Then to her (Iris) ships shall flying Greece be press'd,

The goddess then:

``O son of Priam, hear! From Jove I come, and his (son) high mandate bear. Till to the main the burning sun descend, And sacred night her (Iris) awful shade extend.

'' (The goddess)

She (Iris) said, and vanish'd. Hector, with a bound, Springs from his (Hector) chariot on the trembling ground, In clanging arms: he (Hector) grasps in either hand

A pointed lance, and speeds from band to band ; Revives their ardour, turns their steps from flight, And wakes anew the dying flames of fight.

New force, new spirit, to each breast returns; The fight renew'd with fiercer fury burns: The king leads on: all fix on him (king) their eye, And learn from him (king) to conquer, or to die.

They stand to arms: the Greeks their onset dare, Condense their powers, and wait the coming war. Ye sacred nine! celestial Muses!

tell, Who faced him (Muses) first, and by his (Muses) prowess fell? The great Iphidamas, the bold and young, From sage Antenor and Theano sprung;

Scarce did the down his (Muses) rosy cheeks invest, And early honour warm his (Muses) generous breast, When the kind sire consign'd his (Muses) daughter's charms -LRB-Theano's sister-RRB- to his (Muses) youthful arms.

But call'd by glory to the wars of Troy, He (Muses) leaves untasted the first fruits of joy; From his (Muses) loved bride departs with melting eyes, And swift to aid his (Muses) dearer country flies.

Whom from his (Muses) youth his (Muses) grandsire Cisseus bred, And nursed in Thrace where snowy flocks are fed. With twelve black ships

he (Muses) reach'd Percope's strand, Thence took the long laborious march by land. Now fierce for fame, before the ranks he (Muses) springs, Towering in arms, and braves the king of kings.

Atrides first discharged the missive spear; The Trojan stoop'd, the javelin pass'd in air. Then near the corslet, at the monarch's heart, With all his (monarch) strength, the youth directs his (monarch) dart:

But the broad belt, with plates of silver bound, The point rebated, and repell'd the wound. Encumber'd with the dart, Atrides stands, Till, grasp'd with force, he (monarch) wrench'd

it from his (monarch) hands; At once his (monarch) weighty sword discharged a wound Full on his (monarch) neck, that fell'd him (monarch) to the ground.

Stretch'd in the dust the unhappy warrior lies, And sleep eternal seals his (warrior) swimming eyes. Oh worthy better fate! oh early slain!

Thy country's friend; and virtuous, though in vain! No more the youth shall join his (friend) consort's side, At once a virgin, and at once a bride!

No more with presents her (bride) embraces meet, Or lay the spoils of conquest at her (bride) feet, On whom his (friend) passion, lavish of his (friend) store, Bestow'd so much, and vainly promised more!

Unwept, uncover'd, on the plain he (friend) lay, While the proud victor bore his (victor) arms away. Coon, Antenor's eldest hope, was nigh:

Tears, at the sight, came starting from his (Coon) eye, While pierced with grief the much-loved youth he (Coon) view'd, And the pale features now deform'd with blood.

Then, with his (Coon) spear, unseen, his (Coon) time he (Coon) took, Aim'd at the king, and near his (Coon) elbow strook. The thrilling steel transpierced the brawny part, And through his (Coon) arm stood forth the barbed dart.

On Coon rushes with his (Coon) lifted spear: His (Coon) brother's corpse the pious Trojan draws, And calls his (Coon) country to assert his (Coon) cause; Defends him (Coon) breathless on the sanguine field, And o'er the body spreads his (Coon) ample shield.

Atrides, marking an unguarded part, Transfix'd the warrior with his (warrior) brazen dart; Prone on his (warrior) brother's bleeding breast he (warrior) lay, The monarch's falchion lopp'd

Surprised the monarch feels, yet void of fear his (monarch) head away: The social shades the same dark journey go, And join each other in the realms below.

With every weapon art or fury yields: By the long lance, the sword, or ponderous stone, Whole ranks are broken, and whole troops o'erthrown.

This, while yet warm distill'd the purple flood; But when the wound grew stiff with clotted blood, Then grinding tortures his (monarch) strong bosom rend, Less keen those darts

The vengeful victor rages round the fields, the fierce Ilythiae send: -LRB-The powers that cause the teeming matron's throes, Sad mothers of unutterable woes!-RRB-

Stung with the smart, all-panting with the pain, He (victor) mounts the car, and gives his (victor) squire the rein; Then with a voice which fury made more strong, And pain augmented, thus exhorts the throng:

``O friends!

O Greeks! assert your honours won; Proceed, and finish what this arm begun: Lo! angry Jove forbids your chief to stay, And envies half the glories of the day.

Clouds from their nostrils the fierce coursers blow, And from their sides the foam descends in snow; Shot through the battle in a moment's space,

'' (squire rein)

He (chief) said: the driver whirls his (chief) lengthful thong; The horses fly; the chariot smokes along. The wounded monarch at his (monarch) tent they place.

No sooner Hector saw the king retired, But thus his (Hector) Trojans and his (Hector) aids he (Hector) fired:

``Hear, all ye Dardan, all ye Lycian race!

Famed in close fight, and dreadful face to face: Now call to mind your ancient trophies won, Your great forefathers' virtues, and your own.

Behold, the general flies! deserts his (Hector) powers! Lo, Jove himself declares the conquest ours! Now on yon ranks impel your foaming steeds; And, sure of glory, dare immortal deeds.

As the bold hunter cheers his (hunter) hounds to tear The brindled lion, or the tusky bear: With voice and hand provokes their doubting heart, And springs the foremost with his (hunter) lifted dart: So godlike Hector prompts his (Hector) troops to dare; Nor prompts alone, but leads himself the war.

On the black body of the foe he (foe) pours; As from the cloud's deep bosom, swell'd with showers, A sudden storm the purple ocean sweeps, Drives the wild waves, and tosses all the deeps.

'' (he)

With words like these the fiery chief alarms His (chief) fainting host, and every bosom warms. Say, Muse! when Jove the Trojan's glory crown'd, Beneath his (Muse) arm what heroes bit the ground?

Assaeus, Dolops, and Autonous died, Opites next was added to their side; Then brave Hipponous, famed in many a fight, Opheltius, Orus, sunk to endless night; Ćsymnus, Agelaus; all chiefs of name; The rest were vulgar deaths unknown to fame.

As when a western whirlwind, charged with storms, Dispels the gather'd clouds that Notus forms: The gust continued, violent and strong, Rolls sable clouds in heaps on heaps along; Now to the skies the foaming billows rears, Now breaks the surge, and wide the bottom bares:

Now the last ruin the whole host appals; Now Greece had trembled in her (chiefs) wooden walls; But wise Ulysses call'd Tydides forth, His (chiefs) soul rekindled, and awaked his (chiefs) worth.

Thus, raging Hector, with resistless hands, O'erturns, confounds, and scatters all their bands. '' And stand we deedless, O eternal shame!

Till Hector's arm involve the ships in flame? Haste, let us join, and combat side by side. '' The warrior thus, and thus the friend replied:

``No martial toil I shun, no danger fear; Let Hector come; I wait his (Hector) fury here. But Jove with conquest crowns the Trojan train:

; but, sighing, raised his (Hector) vengeful steel, And from his (Hector) car the proud Thymbraeus fell: Molion, the charioteer, pursued his (Hector) lord, His (Hector) death ennobled by Ulysses' sword.

And, Jove our foe, all human force is vain. '' (the friend)

He (Hector) sigh'd There slain, they left them in eternal night, Then plunged amidst the thickest ranks of fight.

So two wild boars outstrip the following hounds, Then swift revert, and wounds return for wounds. Stern Hector's conquests in the middle plain Stood check'd awhile, and Greece respired again.

The sons of Merops shone amidst the war; Towering they rode in one refulgent car: In deep prophetic arts their father skill'd, Had warn'd his (father) children from the Trojan field.

They rush'd to fight, and perish'd on the plain; Their breasts no more the vital spirit warms; The stern Tydides strips their shining arms.

Fate urged them on: the father warn'd in vain; Hypirochus by great Ulysses dies, And rich Hippodamus becomes his (Ulysses) prize. Great Jove from Ide with slaughter fills his (Ulysses) sight, And level hangs the doubtful scale of fight.

Agastrophus was slain, The far-famed hero of Paeonian strain; Wing'd with his (hero) fears, on foot he (hero) strove to fly, His (hero) steeds too distant, and the foe too nigh: Through broken orders, swifter than the wind, He (hero) fled, but flying left his (hero) life behind.

By Tydeus' lance This Hector sees, as his (Hector) experienced eyes Traverse the files, and to the rescue flies; Shouts, as he (Hector) pass'd, the crystal regions rend, And moving armies on his (Hector) march attend.

Great Diomed himself was seized with fear, And thus bespoke his (Great) brother of the war:

``Mark how this way yon bending squadrons yield!

Swift at the word his (Great) ponderous javelin fled; Nor miss'd its aim, but where the plumage danced Razed the smooth cone, and thence obliquely glanced.

The storm rolls on, and Hector rules the field: Here stand his (Hector) utmost force.'' (brother)

--The warrior said; Safe in his (warrior) helm -LRB-the gift of Phoebus' hands-RRB-

His (warrior) arm and knee his (warrior) sinking bulk sustain; O'er his (warrior) dim sight the misty vapours rise, And a short darkness shades his (warrior) swimming eyes.

Tydides followed to regain his (warrior) lance; While Hector rose, recover'd from the trance, Remounts his (Hector) car, and herds amidst the crowd:

The Greek pursues him (Hector), and exults aloud:

``Once more thank Phoebus for thy forfeit breath, Or thank that swiftness which outstrips the death.

Without a wound the Trojan hero stands; But yet so stunn'd, that, staggering on the plain. Well by Apollo are thy prayers repaid, And oft that partial power has lent his (hero) aid.

Thou shall not long the death deserved withstand, If any god assist Tydides' hand. Fly then, inglorious! but thy flight, this day, Whole hecatombs of Trojan ghosts shall pay,'' (him)

Him (god), while he (god) triumph'd, Paris eyed from far,

-LRB-The spouse of Helen, the fair cause of war;-RRB- Around the fields his (god) feather'd shafts he (god) sent, From ancient Ilus' ruin'd monument

: Behind the column placed, he (god) bent his (god) bow, And wing'd an arrow at the unwary foe; Just as he (god) stoop'd, Agastrophus's crest To seize, and drew the corslet from his (god) breast, The bowstring twang'd; nor flew the shaft in vain, But pierced his (god) foot, and nail'd it to the plain.

The laughing Trojan, with a joyful spring. Leaps from his (nail) ambush, and insults the king. '' He (nail) bleeds! -LRB-he (nail) cries-RRB- some god has sped my dart!

So Troy, relieved from that wide-wasting hand, Should breathe from slaughter and in combat stand: Whose sons now tremble at his (nail) darted spear, As scatter'd lambs the rushing lion fear.

Would the same god had fix'd it in his (god) heart! '' He (god) dauntless thus: ``Thou conqueror of the fair, Thou woman-warrior with the curling hair; Vain archer!

trusting to the distant dart, Unskill'd in arms to act a manly part! Thou hast but done what boys or women can; Such hands may wound, but not incense a man.

Nor boast the scratch thy feeble arrow gave, A coward's weapon never hurts the brave. Not so this dart, which thou may`st one day feel

; Fate wings its flight, and death is on the steel: Where this but lights, some noble life expires; Its touch makes orphans, bathes the cheeks of sires, Steeps earth in purple, gluts the birds of air, And leaves such objects as distract the fair.

Ulysses hastens with a trembling heart, Before him (Ulysses) steps, and bending draws the dart: Forth flows the blood; an eager pang succeeds; Tydides mounts, and to the navy speeds.

Now on the field Ulysses stands alone, The Greeks all fled, the Trojans pouring on; But stands collected in himself, and whole, And questions thus his (Ulysses) own unconquer'd soul:

``What further subterfuge, what hopes remain?

'' (the Trojans)

What shame, inglorious if I quit the plain? What danger, singly if I stand the ground, My friends all scatter'd, all the foes around?

Yet wherefore doubtful? let this truth suffice, The brave meets danger, and the coward flies. To die or conquer, proves a hero's heart; And, knowing this, I know a soldier's part.

Such thoughts revolving in his (soldier) careful breast, Near, and more near, the shady cohorts press'd; These, in the warrior, their own fate enclose; And round him (warrior) deep the steely circle grows.

So fares a boar whom all the troop surrounds Of shouting huntsmen and of clamorous hounds; He (warrior) grinds his (warrior) ivory tusks; he (warrior) foams with ire; His (warrior) sanguine eye-balls glare with living fire; By these, by those, on every part is plied; And the red slaughter spreads on every side.

Pierced through the shoulder, first Deiopis fell; Next Ennomus and Thoon sank to hell; Chersidamas, beneath the navel thrust, Falls prone to earth, and grasps the bloody dust.

Charops, the son of Hippasus, was near; Ulysses reach'd him (Ulysses) with the fatal spear; But to his (Ulysses) aid his (Ulysses) brother Socus flies, Socus the brave, the generous, and the wise.

'' Near as he (Ulysses) drew, the warrior thus began:

``O great Ulysses! much-enduring man! Not deeper skill'd in every martial sleight, Than worn to toils, and active in the fight!

This day two brothers shall thy conquest grace, And end at once the great Hippasian race, Or thou beneath this lance must press the field.

He (man) said, and forceful pierced his (man) spacious shield: Through the strong brass the ringing javelin thrown, Plough'd half his (man) side, and bared it to the bone.

'' (the warrior)

By Pallas' care, the spear, though deep infix'd, Stopp'd short of life, nor with his (man) entrails mix'd. The wound not mortal wise Ulysses knew, Then furious thus -LRB-but first some steps withdrew-RRB-:

``Unhappy man! whose death our hands shall grace, Fate calls thee hence and finish'd is thy race. Nor longer check my conquests on the foe;

He (foe) spoke, while Socus, seized with sudden fright, Trembling gave way, and turn'd his (foe) back to flight; Between his (foe) shoulders pierced the following dart, And held its passage through the panting heart: Wide in his (foe) breast

But, pierced by this, to endless darkness go, And add one spectre to the realms below!'' (Ulysses/ULYSSES)

appear'd the grisly wound; He (foe) falls; his (foe) armour rings against the ground.

Then thus Ulysses, gazing on the slain:

``Famed son of Hippasus! there press the plain; There ends thy narrow span assign'd by fate, Heaven owes Ulysses yet a longer date.

no father shall thy corpse compose; Thy dying eyes no tender mother close; But hungry birds shall tear those balls away, And hovering vultures scream around their prey.

Ah, wretch! Me Greece shall honour, when I meet my doom, With solemn funerals and a lasting tomb. '' (Ulysses/ULYSSES)

Then raging with intolerable smart, He (father) writhes his (father) body, and extracts the dart.

The dart a tide of spouting gore pursued, And gladden'd Troy with sight of hostile blood. Now troops on troops the fainting chief invade, Forced he (chief) recedes, and loudly calls for aid.

Thrice to its pitch his (chief) lofty voice he (chief) rears; The well-known voice thrice Menelaus hears: Alarm'd, to Ajax Telamon he (Menelaus) cried,

Ulysses' shouts invade my ear; Distressed he (Ulysses) seems, and no assistance near; Strong as he (Ulysses) is, yet one opposed to all, Oppress'd by multitudes, the best may fall.

Who shares his (Ulysses) labours, and defends his (Ulysses) side:

``O friend! Greece robb'd of him (Ulysses) must bid her (troops) host despair, And feel a loss not ages can repair.

Great Ajax, like the god of war, attends, The prudent chief in sore distress they found, With bands of furious Trojans compass'd round.-LRB-223-RRB-

As when some huntsman, with a flying spear, From the blind thicket wounds a stately deer; Down his (huntsman) cleft side, while fresh the blood distils, He (huntsman) bounds aloft, and scuds from hills to hills, Till life's warm vapour issuing through the wound, Wild mountain-wolves the fainting beast surround: Just as their jaws his (huntsman) prostrate limbs invade, The lion rushes through the woodland shade, The wolves, though hungry, scour dispersed away; The lordly savage vindicates his (huntsman) prey.

'' (he)

Then, where the cry directs, his (huntsman) course he (huntsman) bends; Ulysses thus, unconquer'd by his (Ulysses) pains, A single warrior half a host sustains:

But soon as Ajax leaves his (Ulysses) tower-like shield, The scattered crowds fly frighted o'er the field ; Atrides' arm the sinking hero stays, And, saved from numbers, to his (hero) car conveys.

Victorious Ajax plies the routed crew; And first Doryclus, Priam's son, he (son) slew, On strong Pandocus next inflicts a wound, And lays Lysander bleeding on the ground.

As when a torrent, swell'd with wintry rains, Pours from the mountains o'er the deluged plains, And pines and oaks, from their foundations torn, A country's ruins!

But Hector, from this scene of slaughter far, Raged on the left, and ruled the tide of war: Loud groans proclaim his (Hector) progress through the plain, And deep Scamander swells with heaps of slain.

There Nestor and Idomeneus oppose The warrior's fury; there the battle glows; There fierce on foot, or from the chariot's height, His (Nestor) sword deforms the beauteous ranks of fight.

to the seas are borne: Fierce Ajax thus o'erwhelms the yielding throng; Men, steeds, and chariots, roll in heaps along. The spouse of Helen, dealing darts around, Had pierced Machaon with a distant wound:

In his (Nestor) right shoulder the broad shaft appear'd, And trembling Greece for her (Helen) physician fear'd. To Nestor then Idomeneus begun:

``Glory of Greece, old Neleus' valiant son!

Ascend thy chariot, haste with speed away, And great Machaon to the ships convey; A wise physician skill'd our wounds to heal, Is more than armies to the public weal.

'' (Nestor/Wise Nestor/Wise)

Old Nestor mounts the seat; beside him (Nestor) rode The wounded offspring of the healing god. He (Nestor) lends the lash; the steeds with sounding feet Shake the dry field, and thunder toward the fleet.

But now Cebriones, from Hector's car, Survey'd the various fortune of the war:

``While here -LRB-he (Hector) cried-RRB- the flying Greeks are slain, Trojans on Trojans yonder load the plain.

Before great Ajax see the mingled throng Of men and chariots driven in heaps along! I know him (Hector) well, distinguish'd o'er the field

Thither, O Hector, thither urge thy steeds, There danger calls, and there the combat bleeds; There horse and foot in mingled deaths unite, And groans of slaughter mix with shouts of fight.

Thus having spoke, the driver's lash resounds; Swift through the ranks the rapid chariot bounds; Stung by the stroke, the coursers scour the fields, O'er heaps of carcases, and hills of shields.

The horses' hoofs are bathed in heroes' gore, And, dashing, purple all the car before; The groaning axle sable drops distils, And mangled carnage clogs the rapid wheels.

Here Hector, plunging through the thickest fight, Broke the dark phalanx, and let in the light: -LRB-By the long lance, the sword, or ponderous stone.

By the broad glittering of the sevenfold shield. '' (Hector/HECTOR/Stern)

The ranks he (Hector) scatter'd and the troops o'erthrown:-RRB- Ajax he (Hector) shuns, through all the dire debate, And fears that arm whose force he (Hector) felt so late.

But partial Jove, espousing Hector's part, Shot heaven-bred horror through the Grecian's heart; Confused, unnerved in Hector's presence grown, Amazed he (Hector) stood, with terrors not his (Hector) own.

Thus the grim lion his (Hector) retreat maintains, Beset with watchful dogs, and shouting swains; Repulsed by numbers from the nightly stalls, Though rage impels him (Hector), and though hunger calls, Long stands the showering darts, and missile fires; Then sourly slow the indignant beast retires: So turn'd stern Ajax, by whole hosts repell'd, While his (Long) swoln heart at every step rebell'd.

As the slow beast, with heavy strength endued, In some wide field by troops of boys pursued, Though round his (Long) sides a wooden tempest rain, Crops the tall harvest, and lays waste the plain; Thick on his (Long) hide the hollow blows resound

, The patient animal maintains his (Long) ground, Scarce from the field with all their efforts chased, And stirs but slowly when he (Long) stirs at last: On Ajax thus a weight of Trojans hung, The strokes redoubled on his (Long) buckler rung;

Confiding now in bulky strength he (Long) stands, Now turns, and backward bears the yielding bands; Now stiff recedes, yet hardly seems to fly,

O'er his (Long) broad back his (Long) moony shield he (Long) threw, And, glaring round, by tardy steps withdrew. And threats his (Long) followers with retorted eye.

While hissing darts descend in iron showers: In his (Long) broad buckler many a weapon stood, Its surface bristled with a quivering wood; And many a javelin, guiltless on the plain, Marks the dry dust, and thirsts for blood in vain.

But bold Eurypylus his (Long) aid imparts, And dauntless springs beneath a cloud of darts; Whose eager javelin launch'd against the foe, Great Apisaon felt the fatal blow; From his (Great) torn liver the red current flow'd, And his (Great) slack knees desert their dying load.

The victor rushing to despoil the dead, From Paris' bow a vengeful arrow fled; Fix'd in his (Great) nervous thigh the weapon stood, Fix'd was the point, but broken was the wood.

Back to the lines the wounded Greek retired, Yet thus retreating, his (Great) associates fired:

``What god, O Grecians! has your hearts dismay'd?

Fix'd as the bar between two warring powers, Oh, turn to arms; 'tis Ajax claims your aid. This hour he (Great) stands the mark of hostile rage, And this the last brave battle he (Great) shall wage:

Thus urged the chief: a generous troop appears, Who spread their bucklers, and advance their spears, To guard their wounded friend: while thus they stand With pious care, great Ajax joins the band: Each takes new courage at the hero's sight; The hero rallies, and renews the fight.

Thus raged both armies like conflicting fires, While Nestor's chariot far from fight retires: His (Nestor) coursers steep'd in sweat, and stain'd with gore, The Greeks' preserver, great Machaon, bore.

That hour Achilles, from the topmost height Of his (Achilles) proud fleet, o'erlook'd the fields of fight; His (Achilles) feasted eyes beheld around the plain

Haste, join your forces; from the gloomy grave The warrior rescue, and your country save. '' (associates)

The Grecian rout, the slaying, and the slain.

His (warrior) friend Machaon singled from the rest, A transient pity touch'd his (warrior) vengeful breast. Straight to Menoetius' much-loved son he (warrior) sent: Graceful as Mars, Patroclus quits his (warrior) tent;

In evil hour! Then fate decreed his (warrior) doom, And fix'd the date of all his (warrior) woes to come. '' Why calls my friend?

thy loved injunctions lay; Whate'er thy will, Patroclus shall obey. ''

``O first of friends! -LRB-Pelides thus replied-RRB- Still at my heart, and ever at my side!

The time is come, when yon despairing host Shall learn the value of the man they lost: Now at my knees the Greeks shall pour their moan, And proud Atrides tremble on his (man) throne.

Go now to Nestor, and from him (Nestor) be taught What wounded warrior late his (Nestor) chariot brought: For, seen at distance, and but seen behind, His (Nestor) form recall'd

Machaon to my mind; Nor could I, through yon cloud, discern his (Nestor) face, The coursers pass'd me with so swift a pace.

'' (The hero)

The hero said. His (hero) friend obey'd with haste, Through intermingled ships and tents he (hero) pass'd; The chiefs descending from their car he (hero) found:

The warriors standing on the breezy shore, To dry their sweat, and wash away the gore, Here paused a moment, while the gentle gale Convey'd

that freshness the cool seas exhale; Then to consult on farther methods went, And took their seats beneath the shady tent.

The panting steeds Eurymedon unbound. The draught prescribed, fair Hecamede prepares, Arsinous' daughter, graced with golden hairs: -LRB-Whom to his (hero) aged arms, a royal slave, Greece, as the prize of Nestor's wisdom gave:-RRB-

A table first with azure feet she (daughter) placed; Whose ample orb a brazen charger graced; Honey new-press'd, the sacred flour of wheat, And wholesome garlic, crown'd the savoury treat, Next her (daughter) white hand an antique goblet brings, A goblet sacred to the Pylian kings From eldest times:

emboss'd with studs of gold, Two feet support it, and four handles hold; On each bright handle, bending o'er the brink, In sculptured gold, two turtles seem to drink:

Temper'd in this, the nymph of form divine Pours a large portion of the Pramnian wine; With goat's-milk cheese a flavourous taste bestows, And last with flour the smiling surface strows

: This for the wounded prince the dame prepares: The cordial beverage reverend Nestor shares: Salubrious draughts the warriors' thirst allay, And pleasing conference beguiles the day.

A massy weight, yet heaved with ease by him (Nestor), When the brisk nectar overlook'd the brim. Meantime Patroclus, by Achilles sent, Unheard approached, and stood before the tent.

Old Nestor, rising then, the hero led To his (Nestor) high seat: the chief refused and said: '''Tis now no season for these kind delays; The great Achilles with impatience stays.

To great Achilles this respect I owe; Who asks, what hero, wounded by the foe, Was borne from combat by thy foaming steeds?

With grief I see the great Machaon bleeds. This to report, my hasty course I bend; Thou know`st the fiery temper of my friend.''

``Can then the sons of Greece -LRB-the sage rejoin'd-RRB- Excite compassion in Achilles' mind? Seeks he (Achilles) the sorrows of our host to know?

Tell him (Achilles), not great Machaon bleeds alone, Our bravest heroes in the navy groan, Ulysses, Agamemnon, Diomed, And stern Eurypylus, already bleed.

Achilles heeds not, but derides our pain: Even till the flames consume our fleet he (Achilles) stays, And waits the rising of the fatal blaze.

This is not half the story of our woe. But, ah! what flattering hopes I entertain! Chief after chief the raging foe destroys; Calm he (foe) looks on, and every death enjoys.

Now the slow course of all-impairing time Unstrings my nerves, and ends my manly prime; Oh! had I still that strength my youth

possess'd, When this bold arm the Epeian powers oppress'd, The bulls of Elis in glad triumph led, And stretch'd the great Itymonaeus dead!

Then from my fury fled the trembling swains, And ours was all the plunder of the plains: Fifty white flocks, full fifty herds of swine,

As many goats, as many lowing kine: And thrice the number of unrivall'd steeds, All teeming females, and of generous breeds.

These, as my first essay of arms, I won; Old Neleus gloried in his (females) conquering son. Thus Elis forced, her (I) long arrears restored, And shares were parted to each Pylian lord.

The state of Pyle was sunk to last despair, When the proud Elians first commenced the war: For Neleus' sons Alcides' rage had slain; Of twelve bold brothers, I alone remain!

-LRB-That large reprisal he (Pyle) might justly claim, For prize defrauded, and insulted fame, When Elis' monarch, at the public course, Detain'd his (monarch) chariot, and victorious horse.-RRB-

Oppress'd, we arm'd; and now this conquest gain'd, My sire three hundred chosen sheep obtain'd. The rest the people shared; myself survey'd

Three days were past, when Elis rose to war, With many a courser, and with many a car; The sons of Actor at their army's head -LRB-Young as they were-RRB- the vengeful squadrons led.

High on the rock fair Thryoessa stands, Our utmost frontier on the Pylian lands: Not far the streams of famed Alphaeus flow: The stream they pass'd, and pitch'd their tents below.

The just partition, and due victims paid. Pallas, descending in the shades of night, Alarms the Pylians and commands the fight.

Each burns for fame, and swells with martial pride, Myself the foremost; but my sire denied; Fear'd for my youth, exposed to stern alarms; And stopp'd my chariot, and detain'd my arms.

Along fair Arene's delightful plain Soft Minyas rolls his (sire) waters to the main: There, horse and foot, the Pylian troops unite, And sheathed in arms, expect the dawning light.

My sire denied in vain: on foot I fled Amidst our chariots; for the goddess led. '' (unknown)

Thence, ere the sun advanced his (sire) noon-day flame, To great Alphaeus' sacred source we came.

There first to Jove our solemn rites were paid; An untamed heifer pleased the blue-eyed maid; A bull, Alphaeus; and a bull was slain To the blue monarch of the watery main.

In arms we slept, beside the winding flood, While round the town the fierce Epeians stood. Soon as the sun, with all-revealing ray, Flamed in the front of Heaven, and gave the day.

The first who fell, beneath my javelin bled; King Augias' son, and spouse of Agamede: -LRB-She (maid) that all simples' healing virtues knew, And every herb that drinks the morning dew:-RRB-

Bright scenes of arms, and works of war appear; The nations meet; there Pylos, Elis here. I seized his (King) car, the van of battle led; The Epeians saw, they trembled, and they fled.

The foe dispersed, their bravest warrior kill'd , Fierce as the whirlwind now I swept the field: Full fifty captive chariots graced my train;

Two chiefs from each fell breathless to the plain. Then Actor's sons had died, but Neptune shrouds The youthful heroes in a veil of clouds.

O'er heapy shields, and o'er the prostrate throng, Collecting spoils, and slaughtering all along, Through wide Buprasian fields we forced the foes, Where o'er the vales the Olenian rocks arose; Till Pallas stopp'd us where Alisium flows.

Even there the hindmost of the rear I slay, And the same arm that led concludes the day; Then back to Pyle triumphant take my way.

There to high Jove were public thanks assign'd, As first of gods; to Nestor, of mankind. Such then I was, impell'd by youthful blood; So proved my valour for my country's good.

How shall he (Nestor) grieve, when to the eternal shade Her (us) hosts shall sink, nor his (Nestor) the power to aid! 0 friend!

my memory recalls the day, When, gathering aids along the Grecian sea, I, and Ulysses, touch'd at Phthia's port, And entered Peleus' hospitable court.

'' Achilles with unactive fury glows, And gives to passion what to Greece he (Achilles) owes. A bull to Jove he (Achilles) slew in sacrifice, And pour'd libations on the flaming thighs.

Thyself, Achilles, and thy reverend sire Menoetius, turn'd the fragments on the fire. Achilles sees us, to the feast invites; Social we sit, and share the genial rites.

We then explained the cause on which we came, Urged you to arms, and found you fierce for fame. Your ancient fathers generous precepts gave; Peleus said only this:--`My son! be brave.'

Menoetius thus: `Though great Achilles shine In strength superior, and of race divine, Yet cooler thoughts thy elder years attend; Let thy just counsels aid, and rule thy friend.'

Ah! try the utmost that a friend can say: Such gentle force the fiercest minds obey; Some favouring god Achilles' heart may move; Though deaf to glory, he (Achilles) may yield to love.

Thus spoke your father at Thessalia's court: Words now forgot, though now of vast import. If some dire oracle his (Achilles) breast alarm, If aught from Heaven withhold his (Achilles) saving arm,

If thou but lead the Myrmidonian line; Clad in Achilles' arms, if thou appear, Proud Troy may tremble, and desist from war; Press'd by fresh forces, her (thou) o'er-labour'd train

This touch'd his (Achilles) generous heart, and from the tent Along the shore with hasty strides he (Achilles) went; Soon as he (Achilles) came, where, on the crowded strand, The public mart and courts of justice stand, Where the tall fleet of great Ulysses lies, And altars to the guardian gods arise; There, sad, he (Achilles) met the brave Euaemon's son, Large painful drops from all his (son) members run; An arrow's head yet rooted in his (son) wound,

Some beam of comfort yet on Greece may shine, Shall seek their walls, and Greece respire again. '' The sable blood in circles mark'd the ground.

As faintly reeling he (son) confess'd the smart, Weak was his (son) pace, but dauntless was his (son) heart. Divine compassion touch'd Patroclus' breast,

Who, sighing, thus his (son) bleeding friend address'd:

``Ah, hapless leaders of the Grecian host! Thus must ye perish on a barbarous coast?

Is this your fate, to glut the dogs with gore, Far from your friends, and from your native shore? Say, great Eurypylus!

shall Greece yet stand? Resists she (son) yet the raging Hector's hand? Or are her (son) heroes doom'd to die with shame, And this the period of our wars and fame?'' (friend)

Eurypylus replies:

``No more, my friend; Greece is no more! this day her (son) glories end; Even to the ships victorious Troy pursues, Her (son) force increasing as her (son) toil renews.

Those chiefs, that used her (son) utmost rage to meet, Lie pierced with wounds, and bleeding in the fleet. But, thou, Patroclus! act a friendly part, Lead to my ships, and draw this deadly dart;

With lukewarm water wash the gore away; With healing balms the raging smart allay, Such as sage Chiron, sire of pharmacy,

Of two famed surgeons, Podalirius stands This hour surrounded by the Trojan bands; And great Machaon, wounded in his (sire) tent, Now wants that succour which so oft he (sire) lent.

Once taught Achilles, and Achilles thee. '' (Eurypylus)

To him (Achilles) the chief:
``What then remains to do? The event of things the gods alone can view.

Charged by Achilles' great command I fly, And bear with haste the Pylian king's reply: But thy distress this instant claims relief.

'' (the chief)

He (king) said, and in his (king) arms upheld the chief. The slaves their master's slow approach survey'd, And hides of oxen on the floor display'd:

at length the wounded hero lay; Patroclus cut the forky steel away: Then in his (hero) hands a bitter root he (hero) bruised; The wound he (hero) wash'd, the styptic juice infused.

There stretch'd The closing flesh that instant ceased to glow, The wound to torture, and the blood to flow. -LSB-Illustration: HERCULES.-RSB-

The Greeks having retired into their intrenchments, Hector attempts to force them; but it proving impossible to pass the ditch, Polydamas advises to quit their chariots, and manage the attack on foot.

HERCULES. BOOK XII. ARGUMENT. THE BATTLE AT THE GRECIAN WALL. The Trojans follow his (Hector) counsel; and having divided their army into five bodies of foot, begin the assault.

But upon the signal of an eagle with a serpent in his (Hector) talons, which appeared on the left hand of the Trojans, Polydamas endeavours to withdraw them again.

Hector also, casting a stone of vast size, forces open one of the gates, and enters at the head of his (Hector) troops, who victoriously pursue the Grecians even to their ships.

While thus the hero's pious cares attend The cure and safety of his (hero) wounded friend, Trojans and Greeks with clashing shields engage, And mutual deaths are dealt with mutual rage.

Nor long the trench or lofty walls oppose; With gods averse the ill-fated works arose; Their powers neglected, and no victim slain, The walls were raised, the trenches sunk in vain.

This Hector opposes, and continues the attack; in which, after many actions, Sarpedon makes the first breach in the wall. Without the gods, how short a period stands The proudest monument of mortal hands!

While sacred Troy the warring hosts engaged; But when her (Sarpedon) sons were slain, her (Sarpedon) city burn'd, And what survived of Greece to Greece return'd; Then Neptune and Apollo shook the shore,

Then Ida's summits pour'd their watery store; Rhesus and Rhodius then unite their rills, Caresus roaring down the stony hills, Ćsepus, Granicus, with mingled force, And Xanthus foaming from his (Sarpedon) fruitful source; And gulfy Simois, rolling to the main-LRB-224-RRB-

These, turn'd by Phoebus from their wonted ways, Deluged the rampire nine continual days; The weight of waters saps the yielding wall, And to the sea the floating bulwarks fall.

This stood while Hector and Achilles raged. Helmets, and shields, and godlike heroes slain: Incessant cataracts the Thunderer pours, And half the skies descend in sluicy showers.

The god of ocean, marching stern before, With his (god) huge trident wounds the trembling shore, Vast stones and piles from their foundation heaves, And whelms the smoky ruin in the waves.

Now smooth'd with sand, and levell'd by the flood, No fragment tells where once the wonder stood; In their old bounds the rivers roll again, Shine `twixt the hills, or wander o'er the plain.-LRB-225-RRB-

But this the gods in later times perform; As yet the bulwark stood, and braved the storm; The strokes yet echoed of contending powers; War thunder'd at the gates, and blood distain'd

the towers. Smote by the arm of Jove with dire dismay, Close by their hollow ships the Grecians lay: Hector's approach in every wind they hear, And Hector's fury every moment fear.

So `midst the dogs and hunters' daring bands, Fierce of his (Hector) might, a boar or lion stands; Arm'd foes around a dreadful circle form, And hissing javelins rain an iron storm:

His (Hector) powers untamed, their bold assault defy, And where he (Hector) turns the rout disperse or die: He (Hector) foams, he (Hector) glares, he (Hector) bounds against them all,
