In lines advanced along the shelving strand: Whose bay, the fleet unable to contain At length; beside the margin of the main, Rank above rank, the crowded ships they moor:

Him (Ulysses), in his (Ulysses) march, the wounded princes meet, -LRB-Their ships at distance from the battle stand, Who landed first, lay highest on the shore.-RRB-

Supported on the spears, they took their way, Unfit to fight, but anxious for the day. Nestor's approach alarm'd each Grecian breast, Whom thus the general of the host address'd:

``O grace and glory of the Achaian name; What drives thee, Nestor, from the field of fame? Shall then proud Hector see his (Hector) boast fulfill'd,

Our fleets in ashes, and our heroes kill'd? Such was his (Hector) threat, ah! now too soon made good, On many a Grecian bosom writ in blood.

Is every heart inflamed with equal rage Against your king, nor will one chief engage? And have I lived to see with mournful eyes

In every Greek a new Achilles rise? '' (the general)

Gerenian Nestor then: ``So fate has will'd; And all-confirming time has fate fulfill'd.

The wall, our late inviolable bound, And best defence, lies smoking on the ground: Even to the ships their conquering arms extend, And groans of

Not he (Nestor) that thunders from the aerial bower, Not Jove himself, upon the past has power. slaughter'd Greeks to heaven ascend.

On speedy measures then employ your thought In such distress! if counsel profit aught: Arms cannot much: though Mars our souls incite, These gaping wounds withhold us from the fight.

To him (counsel) the monarch:

``That our army bends, That Troy triumphant our high fleet ascends, And that the rampart, late our surest trust And best defence, lies smoking in the dust; All this from Jove's afflictive hand we bear, Who, far from Argos, wills our ruin here.

Past are the days when happier Greece was blest, And all his (counsel) favour, all his (counsel) aid confess'd; Now heaven averse, our hands from battle ties, And lifts the Trojan glory to the skies.

Cease we at length to waste our blood in vain, And launch what ships lie nearest to the main; Leave these at anchor, till the coming night:

'' (the monarch)

Then, if impetuous Troy forbear the fight, Bring all to sea, and hoist each sail for flight. Better from evils, well foreseen, to run, Than perish in the danger we may shun.

'' Thus he (counsel). The sage Ulysses thus replies, While anger flash'd from his (Ulysses) disdainful eyes:

``What shameful words -LRB-unkingly as thou art-RRB-

Fall from that trembling tongue and timorous heart? Oh were thy sway the curse of meaner powers, And thou the shame of any host but ours!

A host, by Jove endued with martial might, And taught to conquer, or to fall in fight: Adventurous combats and bold wars to wage, Employ'd our youth, and yet employs our age.

And wilt thou thus desert the Trojan plain? And have whole streams of blood been spilt in vain? In such base sentence if thou couch thy fear, Speak it in whispers, lest a Greek should hear.

Lives there a man so dead to fame, who dares To think such meanness, or the thought declares? And comes it even from him (man) whose sovereign sway The banded legions of all Greece obey?

Is this a general's voice that calls to flight, While war hangs doubtful, while his (general) soldiers fight? What more could Troy?

No more the troops -LRB-our hoisted sails in view, Themselves abandon'd-RRB- shall the fight pursue; But thy ships flying, with despair shall see; And owe destruction to a prince like thee.'' (Ulysses/ULYSSES)

What yet their fate denies Thou givest the foe: all Greece becomes their prize. '' Thy just reproofs -LRB-Atrides calm replies-RRB-

Unwilling as I am to lose the host, I force not Greece to quit this hateful coast; Glad I submit, whoe'er, or young, or old, Aught, more conducive to our weal, unfold.

Tydides cut him (foe) short, and thus began:

``Such counsel if you seek, behold the man Who boldly gives it, and what he (man) shall say, Young though he (Young) be, disdain not to obey:

Like arrows pierce me, for thy words are wise. '' (him)

A youth, who from the mighty Tydeus springs, May speak to councils and assembled kings.

Hear then in me the great OEnides' son, Whose honoured dust -LRB-his (son) race of glory run-RRB- Lies whelm'd in ruins of the Theban wall; Brave in his (son) life, and glorious in his (son) fall.

With three bold sons was generous Prothous bless'd, Who Pleuron's walls and Calydon possess'd; Melas and Agrius, but -LRB-who far surpass'd

The rest in courage-RRB- OEneus was the last. From him (son), my sire. From Calydon expell'd, He (son) pass'd to Argos, and in exile dwell'd; The monarch's daughter there -LRB-so Jove ordain'd-RRB-

He (son) won, and flourish'd where Adrastus reign'd; There, rich in fortune's gifts, his (son) acres till'd, Beheld his (son) vines their liquid harvest yield, And numerous flocks that whiten'd all the field.

Such Tydeus was, the foremost once in fame! Nor lives in Greece a stranger to his (stranger) name. Then, what for common good my thoughts inspire, Attend, and in the son respect the sire.

Though sore of battle, though with wounds oppress'd, Let each go forth, and animate the rest, Advance the glory which he (sire) cannot share, Though not partaker, witness of the war.

Beyond the missile javelin's sounding flight, Safe let us stand; and, from the tumult far, Inspire the ranks, and rule the distant war.

But lest new wounds on wounds o'erpower us quite, '' He (sire) added not: the listening kings obey, Slow moving on; Atrides leads the way.

The god of ocean -LRB-to inflame their rage-RRB- Appears a warrior furrowed o'er with age; Press'd in his (warrior) own, the general's hand he (warrior) took, And thus the venerable hero spoke:

``Atrides! lo!

with what disdainful eye Achilles sees his (Achilles) country's forces fly; Blind, impious man! whose anger is his (Achilles) guide, Who glories in unutterable pride.

o'er yonder sands Soon shall thou view the scattered Trojan bands Fly diverse; while proud kings, and chiefs renown'd, Driven heaps on heaps, with clouds involved around Of rolling dust, their winged wheels employ To hide their ignominious heads in Troy.

So may he (Achilles) perish, so may Jove disclaim The wretch relentless, and o'erwhelm with shame! But Heaven forsakes not thee: '' (the hero)

He (Achilles) spoke, then rush'd amid the warrior crew, And sent his (Achilles) voice before him (Achilles) as he (Achilles) flew, Loud, as the shout encountering armies yield When twice ten thousand shake the labouring field; Such was the voice, and such the thundering sound Of him (Achilles) whose trident rends the solid ground.

Meantime Saturnia from Olympus' brow, High-throned in gold, beheld the fields below; With joy the glorious conflict she (Achilles) survey'd, Where her (Achilles) great brother gave the Grecians aid.

Each Argive bosom beats to meet the fight, And grisly war appears a pleasing sight. But placed aloft, on Ida's shady height She (Ida) sees her (Ida) Jove, and trembles at the sight.

At length she (Ida) trusts her (Ida) power; resolved to prove The old, yet still successful, cheat of love; Against his (brother) wisdom to oppose her (Ida) charms, And lull the lord of thunders in her (Ida) arms.

Swift to her (Ida) bright apartment she (Ida) repairs, Sacred to dress and beauty's pleasing cares: With skill divine had Vulcan form'd the bower,

Jove to deceive, what methods shall she (Ida) try, What arts, to blind his (Swift) all-beholding eye? Safe from access of each intruding power.

Here first she (Ida) bathes; and round her (Ida) body pours Soft oils of fragrance, and ambrosial showers: The winds, perfumed, the balmy gale convey Through heaven, through earth, and all the aerial way: Spirit divine!

Touch'd with her (Ida) secret key , the doors unfold: Self-closed, behind her (Ida) shut the valves of gold. whose exhalation greets The sense of gods with more than mortal sweets.

Thus while she (Ida) breathed of heaven, with decent pride Her (Ida) artful hands the radiant tresses tied; Part on her (Ida) head in shining ringlets roll'd, Part o'er her (Ida) shoulders waved like melted gold.

Around her (Ida) next a heavenly mantle flow'd, That rich with Pallas' labour'd colours glow'd: Large clasps of gold the foldings gather'd

round, A golden zone her (Ida) swelling bosom bound. Far-beaming pendants tremble in her (Ida) ear, Each gem illumined with a triple star.

Then o'er her (Ida) head she (Ida) cast a veil more white Than new-fallen snow, and dazzling as the light. Last her (Ida) fair feet celestial sandals grace.

Thus issuing radiant with majestic pace, Forth from the dome the imperial goddess moves, And calls the mother of the smiles and loves.

'' How long -LRB-to Venus thus apart she (Venus) cried-RRB- Shall human strife celestial minds divide? Ah yet, will Venus aid Saturnia's joy, And set aside the cause of Greece and Troy?''

``Then grant me -LRB-said the queen-RRB- those conquering charms, That power, which mortals and immortals warms, That love, which melts mankind in fierce desires, And burns the sons of heaven with sacred fires! '' (unknown)

``Let heaven's dread empress -LRB-Cytheraea said-RRB- Speak her (empress) request, and deem her (empress) will obey'd. '' (unknown)
For lo! I haste to those remote abodes, Where the great parents, -LRB-sacred source of gods!-RRB-

Ocean and Tethys their old empire keep, On the last limits of the land and deep. In their kind arms my tender years were past;

What time old Saturn, from Olympus cast, Of upper heaven to Jove resign'd the reign, Whelm'd under the huge mass of earth and main.

For strife, I hear, has made the union cease, Which held so long that ancient pair in peace. What honour, and what love, shall I obtain,

If I compose those fatal feuds again; Once more their minds in mutual ties engage, And, what my youth has owed, repay their age!''

With awe divine, the queen of love Obey'd the sister and the wife of Jove; And from her (wife) fragrant breast the zone embraced,-LRB-233-RRB-

In this was every art, and every charm, To win the wisest, and the coldest warm: Fond love, the gentle vow, the gay desire, The kind deceit, the still-reviving fire, Persuasive speech, and the more persuasive sighs, Silence that spoke, and eloquence of eyes.

She (wife) said. With various skill and high embroidery graced. This on her (wife) hand the Cyprian Goddess laid:

``Take this, and with it all thy wish;'' (the Cyprian Goddess)
she (Goddess) said.

With smiles she (Goddess) took the charm; and smiling press'd The powerful cestus to her (Goddess) snowy breast. Then Venus to the courts of Jove withdrew; Whilst from Olympus pleased Saturnia flew.

O'er high Pieria thence her (Venus) course she (Venus) bore, O'er fair Emathia's ever-pleasing shore, O'er Hemus' hills with snows eternal crown'd; Nor once her (Venus) flying foot approach'd the ground.

Then taking wing from Athos' lofty steep, She (Venus) speeds to Lemnos o'er the rolling deep, And seeks the cave of Death's half-brother, Sleep.-LRB-234-RRB-

``Sweet pleasing Sleep! -LRB-Saturnia thus began-RRB- Who spread`st thy empire o'er each god and man; If e'er obsequious to thy Juno's will, O power of slumbers!

hear, and favour still. Shed thy soft dews on Jove's immortal eyes, While sunk in love's entrancing joys he (man) lies. A splendid footstool, and a throne, that shine With gold unfading, Somnus, shall be thine;

The work of Vulcan; to indulge thy ease, When wine and feasts thy golden humours please.'' (unknown)

``Imperial dame -LRB-the balmy power replies-RRB-, Great Saturn's heir, and empress of the skies!

O'er other gods I spread my easy chain; The sire of all, old Ocean, owns my reign. And his (sire) hush'd waves lie silent on the main.

But how, unbidden, shall I dare to steep Jove's awful temples in the dew of sleep? Long since, too venturous, at thy bold command, On those eternal lids I laid my hand;

What time, deserting Ilion's wasted plain, His (Long) conquering son, Alcides, plough'd the main. When lo! the deeps arise, the tempests roar, And drive the hero to the Coan shore:

Great Jove, awaking, shook the blest abodes With rising wrath, and tumbled gods on gods; Me chief he (Great) sought, and from the realms on high Had hurl'd indignant to the nether sky, But gentle Night, to whom I fled for aid, -LRB-The friend of earth and heaven,-RRB- her (my) wings display'd; Impower'd the wrath of gods and men to tame,

Even Jove revered the venerable dame.'' (unknown)

``Vain are thy fears -LRB-the queen of heaven replies, And, speaking, rolls her (queen) large majestic eyes-RRB-;

Think`st thou that Troy has Jove's high favour won, Like great Alcides, his (Troy) all-conquering son? Hear, and obey the mistress of the skies,

Nor for the deed expect a vulgar prize; For know, thy loved-one shall be ever thine, The youngest Grace, Pasithae the divine.'' (he)

-LRB-235-RRB-

'' Swear then -LRB-he (Troy) said-RRB- by those tremendous floods That roar through hell, and bind the invoking gods: Let the great parent earth one hand sustain, And stretch the other o'er the sacred main:

Call the black Titans, that with Chronos dwell, To hear and witness from the depths of hell; That she (Grace), my loved-one, shall be ever mine,

The queen assents, and from the infernal bowers Invokes the sable subtartarean powers, And those who rule the inviolable floods, Whom mortals name the dread Titanian gods.

The youngest Grace, Pasithae the divine. '' -LSB-Illustration: SLEEP ESCAPING FROM THE WRATH OF JUPITER.-RSB- SLEEP ESCAPING FROM THE WRATH OF JUPITER.

Then swift as wind, o'er Lemnos' smoky isle They wing their way, and Imbrus' sea-beat soil; Through air, unseen, involved in darkness glide, And light on Lectos, on the point of Ide: -LRB-Mother of savages, whose echoing hills Are heard resounding with a hundred rills:-RRB-

There on a fir, whose spiry branches rise To join its summit to the neighbouring skies; Dark in embowering shade, conceal'd from sight, Sat Sleep, in likeness of the bird of night.

Fair Ida trembles underneath the god; Hush'd are her (Ida) mountains, and her (Ida) forests nod. -LRB-Chalcis his (god) name by those of heavenly birth, But call'd Cymindis by the race of earth.-RRB-

The god, whose lightning sets the heavens on fire, Through all his (god) bosom feels the fierce desire; Fierce as when first by stealth he (god) seized her (Ida) charms, Mix'd with her (Ida) soul, and melted in her (Ida) arms:

To Ida's top successful Juno flies; Great Jove surveys her (Ida) with desiring eyes: Fix'd on her (Ida) eyes he (Great) fed his (Great) eager look,

Then press'd her (Ida) hand, and thus with transport spoke: ``Why comes my goddess from the ethereal sky, And not her (goddess) steeds and flaming chariot nigh?

Then she (goddess)--

``I haste to those remote abodes Where the great parents of the deathless gods, The reverend Ocean and gray Tethys, reign, On the last limits of the land and main.

I visit these, to whose indulgent cares I owe the nursing of my tender years: For strife, I hear, has made that union cease Which held so long that ancient pair in peace.

Wait under Ide: of thy superior power To ask consent, I leave the Olympian bower; Nor seek, unknown to thee, the sacred cells Deep under seas, where hoary Ocean dwells.

'' (she)

The steeds, prepared my chariot to convey O'er earth and seas, and through the aerial way, '' ``For that -LRB-said Jove-RRB- suffice another day!

But eager love denies the least delay. Let softer cares the present hour employ, And be these moments sacred all to joy.

Ne'er did my soul so strong a passion prove, Or for an earthly, or a heavenly love: Not when I press'd Ixion's matchless dame, Whence rose Pirithous like the gods in fame: Not when fair Danae felt the shower of gold Stream into life, whence Perseus brave and bold.

Not thus I burn'd for either Theban dame: -LRB-Bacchus from this, from that Alcides came:-RRB- Nor Phoenix' daughter, beautiful and young, Whence godlike Rhadamanth and Minos sprung.-LRB-236-RRB-

Not thus I burn'd for fair Latona's face, Nor comelier Ceres' more majestic grace. Not thus even for thyself I felt desire,

He (Bacchus) spoke; the goddess with the charming eyes Glows with celestial red, and thus replies:

``Is this a scene for love?

Our joys profaned by each familiar eye; The sport of heaven, and fable of the sky: How shall I e'er review the blest abodes, Or mix among the senate of the gods?

As now my veins receive the pleasing fire. '' (the goddess)

On Ida's height, Exposed to mortal and immortal sight! Shall I not think, that, with disorder'd charms, All heaven beholds me recent from thy arms?

With skill divine has Vulcan form'd thy bower, Sacred to love and to the genial hour; If such thy will, to that recess retire, In secret there indulge thy soft desire.

She (Ida) ceased; and, smiling with superior love, Thus answer'd mild the cloud-compelling Jove:

``Nor god nor mortal shall our joys behold, Shaded with clouds, and circumfused in gold;

'' (the Jove)

Not even the sun, who darts through heaven his (god) rays, And whose broad eye the extended earth surveys. '' Gazing he (god) spoke, and, kindling at the view, His (god) eager arms around the goddess threw.

Glad Earth perceives, and from her (goddess) bosom pours Unbidden herbs and voluntary flowers: Thick new-born violets a soft carpet spread, And clustering lotos swell'd the rising bed, And sudden hyacinths the turf bestrow,-LRB-237-RRB-

And flamy crocus made the mountain glow There golden clouds conceal the heavenly pair, Steep'd in soft joys and circumfused with air; Celestial dews, descending o'er the ground, Perfume the mount, and breathe ambrosia round: At length, with love and sleep's soft power oppress'd, The panting thunderer nods, and sinks to rest.

Now to the navy borne on silent wings, To Neptune's ear soft Sleep his (Celestial) message brings; Beside him (Celestial) sudden, unperceived, he (Celestial) stood, And thus with gentle words address'd the god:

``Now, Neptune! now, the important hour employ, To check a while the haughty hopes of Troy: While Jove yet rests, while yet my vapours shed The golden vision round his (god) sacred head; For Juno's love, and Somnus' pleasing ties, Have closed those awful and eternal eyes.

Neptune, with zeal increased, renews his (god) care, And towering in the foremost ranks of war, Indignant thus--

``Oh once of martial fame!

'' (unknown)

Thus having said, the power of slumber flew, On human lids to drop the balmy dew. O Greeks! if yet ye can deserve the name!

This half-recover'd day shall Troy obtain? Shall Hector thunder at your ships again? Lo! still he (Hector) vaunts, and threats the fleet with fires, While stern Achilles in his (Achilles) wrath retires.

One hero's loss too tamely you deplore, Be still yourselves, and ye shall need no more. Oh yet, if glory any bosom warms, Brace on your firmest helms, and stand to arms:

His (Brace) strongest spear each valiant Grecian wield, Each valiant Grecian seize his (Brace) broadest shield; Let to the weak the lighter arms belong, The ponderous targe be wielded by the strong.

Thus arm'd, not Hector shall our presence stay; Myself, ye Greeks! myself will lead the way.'' -LSB-Illustration: GREEK SHIELD.-RSB- GREEK SHIELD.

The troops assent; their martial arms they change: The busy chiefs their banded legions range. The kings, though wounded, and oppress'd with pain, With helpful hands themselves assist the train.

The strong and cumbrous arms the valiant wield, The weaker warrior takes a lighter shield. Thus sheath'd in shining brass, in bright array The legions march, and Neptune leads the way:

His (warrior) brandish'd falchion flames before their eyes, Like lightning flashing through the frighted skies. Clad in his (warrior) might, the earth-shaking power appears; Pale mortals tremble, and confess their fears.

Troy's great defender stands alone unawed, Arms his (defender) proud host, and dares oppose a god: And lo! the god, and wondrous man, appear: The sea's stern ruler there, and Hector here.

The roaring main, at her (warrior) great master's call, Rose in huge ranks, and form'd a watery wall Around the ships: seas hanging o'er the shores, Both armies join: earth thunders, ocean roars.

the bellowing deeps resound, When stormy winds disclose the dark profound; Less loud the winds that from the Ćolian hall Roar through the woods, and make whole forests fall; Less loud the woods, when flames in torrents pour, Catch the dry mountain, and its shades devour; With such a rage the meeting hosts are driven, And such a clamour shakes the sounding heaven.

The first bold javelin, urged by Hector's force, Direct at Ajax' bosom winged its course; But there no pass the crossing belts afford,

Not half so loud -LRB-One braced his (Hector) shield, and one sustain'd his (Hector) sword.-RRB- Then back the disappointed Trojan drew, And cursed the lance that unavailing flew:

But `scaped not Ajax; his (Hector) tempestuous hand A ponderous stone upheaving from the sand, -LRB-Where heaps laid loose beneath the warrior's feet, Or served to ballast, or to prop the fleet,-RRB- Toss'd round and round, the missive marble flings; On the razed shield the fallen ruin rings, Full on his (warrior) breast and throat with force descends; Nor deaden'd there its giddy fury spends, But whirling on, with many a fiery round, Smokes in the dust, and ploughs into the ground.

As when the bolt, red-hissing from above, Darts on the consecrated plant of Jove, The mountain-oak in flaming ruin lies, Black from the blow, and smokes of sulphur rise; Stiff with amaze the pale beholders stand, And own the terrors of the almighty hand!

So lies great Hector prostrate on the shore; His (Hector) slacken'd hand deserts the lance it bore; His (Hector) following shield the fallen chief o'erspread;

Beneath his (Hector) helmet dropp'd his (Hector) fainting head; His (Hector) load of armour, sinking to the ground, Clanks on the field, a dead and hollow sound.

Loud shouts of triumph fill the crowded plain; Greece sees, in hope, Troy's great defender slain: All spring to seize him (defender); storms of arrows fly, And thicker javelins intercept the sky.

In vain an iron tempest hisses round; He (defender) lies protected, and without a wound.-LRB-238-RRB- Polydamas, Agenor the divine, The pious warrior of Anchises' line, And each bold leader of the Lycian band, With covering shields -LRB-a friendly circle-RRB- stand, His (leader) mournful followers, with assistant care, The groaning hero to his (leader) chariot bear; His (leader) foaming coursers, swifter than the wind, Speed to the town, and leave the war behind.

When now they touch'd the mead's enamell'd side, Where gentle Xanthus rolls his (leader) easy tide, With watery drops the chief they sprinkle round, Placed on the margin of the flowery ground.

Raised on his (leader) knees, he (leader) now ejects the gore; Now faints anew, low-sinking on the shore; By fits he (leader) breathes, half views the fleeting skies, And seals again, by fits, his (leader) swimming eyes.

Soon as the Greeks the chief's retreat beheld, With double fury each invades the field. Oilean Ajax first his (leader) javelin sped, Pierced by whose point the son of Enops bled;

-LRB-Satnius the brave, whom beauteous Neis bore Amidst her (they) flocks on Satnio's silver shore;-RRB- Struck through the belly's rim, the warrior lies Supine, and shades eternal veil his (warrior) eyes.

An arduous battle rose around the dead; By turns the Greeks, by turns the Trojans bled. Fired with revenge, Polydamas drew near,

And at Prothoenor shook the trembling spear; The driving javelin through his (warrior) shoulder thrust, He (warrior) sinks to earth, and grasps the bloody dust.

we rule the field, And thus their arms the race of Panthus wield: From this unerring hand there flies no dart

'' Lo thus -LRB-the victor cries-RRB- But bathes its point within a Grecian heart. Propp'd on that spear to which thou owest thy fall,

Go, guide thy darksome steps to Pluto's dreary hall. '' He (victor) said, and sorrow touch'd each Argive breast: The soul of Ajax burn'd above the rest.

As by his (victor) side the groaning warrior fell, At the fierce foe he (victor) launch'd his (victor) piercing steel ; The foe, reclining, shunn'd the flying death; But fate, Archilochus, demands thy breath:

; Swift to perform heaven's fatal will, it fled Full on the juncture of the neck and head, And took the joint, and cut the nerves in twain: The dropping head first tumbled on the plain.

Thy lofty birth no succour could impart , The wings of death o'ertook thee on the dart So just the stroke, that yet the body stood Erect, then roll'd along the sands in blood.

'' Here, proud Polydamas, here turn thy eyes! -LRB-The towering Ajax loud-insulting cries:-RRB- Say, is this chief extended on the plain A worthy vengeance for Prothoenor slain?

Nor speak him (twain) vulgar, nor of vulgar race; Some lines, methinks, may make his (twain) lineage known, Antenor's brother, or perhaps his (twain) son.

Mark well his (twain) port! his (twain) figure and his (twain) face '' He (twain) spake, and smiled severe, for well he (twain) knew The bleeding youth:

Troy sadden'd at the view. But furious Acamas avenged his (twain) cause ; As Promachus his (twain) slaughtered brother draws, He (twain) pierced his (twain) heart--

``Such fate attends you all, Proud Argives!

destined by our arms to fall. Not Troy alone, but haughty Greece, shall share The toils, the sorrows, and the wounds of war.

Behold your Promachus deprived of breath, A victim owed to my brave brother's death. Not unappeased he (brother) enters Pluto's gate, Who leaves a brother to revenge his (brother) fate.

'' (He)

Heart-piercing anguish struck the Grecian host, But touch'd the breast of bold Peneleus most; At the proud boaster he (brother) directs his (brother) course;

But young Ilioneus received the spear; Ilioneus, his (brother) father's only care: -LRB-Phorbas the rich, of all the Trojan train Whom Hermes loved, and taught the arts of gain:-RRB-

Full in his (brother) eye the weapon chanced to fall, And from the fibres scoop'd the rooted ball, Drove through the neck, and hurl'd him (brother) to the plain; He (brother) lifts his (brother) miserable arms in vain!

The boaster flies, and shuns superior force. Swift his (Swift) broad falchion fierce Peneleus spread, And from the spouting shoulders struck his (Swift) head;

To earth at once the head and helmet fly; The lance, yet sticking through the bleeding eye, The victor seized; and, as aloft he (victor) shook The gory visage, thus insulting spoke:

``Trojans!

Haste, to his (victor) father let the tale be told: Let his (victor) high roofs resound with frantic woe, Such as the house of Promachus must know; Let doleful tidings greet his (victor) mother's ear, Such as to Promachus' sad spouse we bear,

your great Ilioneus behold! When we victorious shall to Greece return, And the pale matron in our triumphs mourn. '' (he)

Dreadful he (victor) spoke, then toss'd the head on high; The Trojans hear, they tremble, and they fly:

Aghast they gaze around the fleet and wall, And dread the ruin that impends on all. Daughters of Jove! that on Olympus shine, Ye all-beholding, all-recording nine!

O say, when Neptune made proud Ilion yield, What chief, what hero first embrued the field? Of all the Grecians what immortal name, And whose bless'd trophies, will ye raise to fame?

Thou first, great Ajax! on the unsanguined plain Laid Hyrtius, leader of the Mysian train. Phalces and Mermer, Nestor's son o'erthrew, Bold Merion, Morys and Hippotion slew.

Strong Periphaetes and Prothoon bled, By Teucer's arrows mingled with the dead, Pierced in the flank by Menelaus' steel, His (Menelaus) people's pastor, Hyperenor fell; Eternal darkness wrapp'd the warrior round, And the fierce soul came rushing through the wound.

But stretch'd in heaps before Oileus' son, Fall mighty numbers, mighty numbers run; Ajax the less, of all the Grecian race Skill'd in pursuit, and swiftest in the chase.

Jupiter, awaking, sees the Trojans repulsed from the trenches, Hector in a swoon, and Neptune at the head of the Greeks: he (Hector) is highly incensed at the artifice of Juno, who appeases him (Hector) by her (warrior) submissions; she (warrior) is then sent to Iris and Apollo.

Juno, repairing to the assembly of the gods, attempts, with extraordinary address, to incense them against Jupiter; in particular she (warrior) touches Mars with a violent resentment; he (Hector) is ready to take arms, but is prevented by Minerva.

Iris and Apollo obey the orders of Jupiter; Iris commands Neptune to leave the battle, to which, after much reluctance and passion, he (Hector) consents.

Apollo reinspires Hector with vigour, brings him (Hector) back to the battle, marches before him (Hector) with his (Hector) aegis, and turns the fortune of the fight.

He (Hector) breaks down great part of the Grecian wall: the Trojans rush in, and attempt to fire the first line of the fleet, but are, as yet, repelled by the greater Ajax with a prodigious slaughter.

-LSB-Illustration: BACCHUS.-RSB- BACCHUS. BOOK XV. ARGUMENT. THE FIFTH BATTLE AT THE SHIPS; AND THE ACTS OF AJAX. Now in swift flight they pass the trench profound, And many a chief lay gasping on the ground:

Then stopp'd and panted, where the chariots lie Fear on their cheek, and horror in their eye. Meanwhile, awaken'd from his (chief) dream of love, On Ida's summit sat imperial Jove:

Round the wide fields he (chief) cast a careful view, There saw the Trojans fly, the Greeks pursue; These proud in arms, those scatter'd o'er the plain

Not far, great Hector on the dust he (Hector) spies, -LRB-His (Hector) sad associates round with weeping eyes,-RRB- Ejecting blood, and panting yet for breath,

And, `midst the war, the monarch of the main. His (monarch) senses wandering to the verge of death. The god beheld him (god) with a pitying look, And thus, incensed, to fraudful Juno

spoke:

``O thou, still adverse to the eternal will, For ever studious in promoting ill! Thy arts have made the godlike Hector yield, And driven his (Hector) conquering squadrons from the field.

Canst thou, unhappy in thy wiles, withstand Our power immense, and brave the almighty hand? Hast thou forgot, when, bound and fix'd on high,

From the vast concave of the spangled sky, I hung thee trembling in a golden chain, And all the raging gods opposed in vain?

Headlong I hurl'd them from the Olympian hall, Stunn'd in the whirl, and breathless with the fall. For godlike Hercules these deeds were done, Nor seem'd the vengeance worthy such a son:

When, by thy wiles induced, fierce Boreas toss'd The shipwreck'd hero on the Coan coast, Him (hero) through a thousand forms of death I bore, And sent to Argos, and his (hero) native shore.

Hear this, remember, and our fury dread, Nor pull the unwilling vengeance on thy head; Lest arts and blandishments successless prove, Thy soft deceits, and well-dissembled love.

By every oath that powers immortal ties, The foodful earth and all-infolding skies; By thy black waves, tremendous Styx! that flow Through the drear realms of gliding ghosts below; By the dread honours of thy sacred head, And that unbroken vow, our virgin bed!

Not by my arts the ruler of the main Steeps Troy in blood, and ranges round the plain: By his (ruler) own ardour, his (ruler) own pity sway'd, To help his (ruler) Greeks, he (ruler) fought and disobey'd:

'' (Juno)

The Thunderer spoke: imperial Juno mourn'd, And, trembling, these submissive words return'd: '' Else had thy Juno better counsels given, And taught submission to the sire of heaven.''

'' Think`st thou with me? fair empress of the skies! -LRB-The immortal father with a smile replies;-RRB- Then soon the haughty sea-god shall obey, Nor dare to act

If truth inspires thy tongue, proclaim our will To yon bright synod on the Olympian hill; Our high decree let various Iris know, And call the god that bears the silver bow.

but when we point the way. Let her (Iris) descend, and from the embattled plain Command the sea-god to his (god) watery reign:

While Phoebus hastes great Hector to prepare To rise afresh, and once more wake the war: His (Hector) labouring bosom re-inspires with breath, And calls his (Hector) senses from the verge of death.

Greece chased by Troy, even to Achilles' fleet, Shall fall by thousands at the hero's feet. He (hero), not untouch'd with pity, to

the plain Shall send Patroclus, but shall send in vain. What youths he (hero) slaughters under Ilion's walls! Even my loved son, divine Sarpedon, falls!

Vanquish'd at last by Hector's lance he (Hector) lies. Then, nor till then, shall great Achilles rise: And lo! that instant, godlike Hector dies.

From that great hour the war's whole fortune turns, Pallas assists, and lofty Ilion burns. Not till that day shall Jove relax his (Hector) rage,

The promise of a god I gave, and seal'd it with the almighty nod, Achilles' glory to the stars to raise; Such was our word, and fate the word obeys.

Nor one of all the heavenly host engage In aid of Greece. '' The trembling queen -LRB-the almighty order given-RRB- Swift from the Idaean summit shot to heaven.

he (Swift) trod before, Sends forth his (Swift) active mind from place to place, Joins hill to dale, and measures space with space:

As some wayfaring man, who wanders o'er In thought a length of lands So swift flew Juno to the bless'd abodes,

If thought of man can match the speed of gods. There sat the powers in awful synod placed; They bow'd, and made obeisance as she (queen) pass'd

Through all the brazen dome: with goblets crown'd-LRB-239-RRB- They hail her (queen) queen; the nectar streams around. Fair Themis first presents the golden bowl, And anxious asks what cares disturb her (queen) soul?

To whom the white-arm'd goddess thus replies:

``Enough thou know`st the tyrant of the skies, Severely bent his (tyrant) purpose to fulfil, Unmoved his (tyrant) mind, and unrestrain'd his (tyrant) will.

Go thou, the feasts of heaven attend thy call; Bid the crown'd nectar circle round the hall: But Jove shall thunder through the ethereal dome Such stern decrees, such threaten'd woes to come,

As soon shall freeze mankind with dire surprise, And damp the eternal banquets of the skies. '' (white-arm goddess)

The goddess said, and sullen took her (goddess) place;

To see the gathering grudge in every breast, Smiles on her (goddess) lips a spleenful joy express'd; While on her (goddess) wrinkled front, and eyebrow bent, Sat stedfast care, and lowering discontent.

Black horror sadden'd each celestial face. Thus she (goddess) proceeds--

``Attend, ye powers above! But know, 'tis madness to contest with Jove: Supreme he (goddess) sits; and sees, in pride of sway.

Your vassal godheads grudgingly obey: Fierce in the majesty of power controls; Shakes all the thrones of heaven, and bends the poles.

Submiss, immortals! all he (goddess) wills, obey: And thou, great Mars, begin and show the way. Behold Ascalaphus! behold him (goddess) die, But dare not murmur, dare not vent a sigh

; Thy own loved boasted offspring lies o'erthrown, If that loved boasted offspring be thy own.'' (she)

Stern Mars, with anguish for his (Stern) slaughter'd son, Smote his (Stern) rebelling breast, and fierce begun: ''

thus shall Mars obey; Forgive me, gods, and yield my vengeance way: Descending first to yon forbidden plain, The god of battles dares avenge the slain;

Thus then, immortals! Dares, though the thunder bursting o'er my head Should hurl me blazing on those heaps of dead. ''

With that he (god) gives command to Fear and Flight To join his (god) rapid coursers for the fight: Then grim in arms, with hasty vengeance flies;

Discharged his (god) wrath on half the host of heaven; But Pallas, springing through the bright abode, Starts from her (my) azure throne to calm the god.

Arms that reflect a radiance through the skies. And now had Jove, by bold rebellion driven, Struck for the immortal race with timely fear, From frantic Mars

the shield and spear; Then the huge helmet lifting from his (Struck) head, Thus to the impetuous homicide she (my) said:

``By what wild passion, furious!

she (my) snatch'd art thou toss'd? Striv`st thou with Jove? thou art already lost. Shall not the Thunderer's dread command restrain, And was imperial Juno heard in vain?

Ilion and Greece no more should Jove engage, The skies would yield an ampler scene of rage; Guilty and guiltless find an equal fate And one vast ruin whelm the Olympian state.

Back to the skies wouldst thou with shame be driven, And in thy guilt involve the host of heaven? Cease then thy offspring's death unjust to call; Heroes as great have died, and yet shall fall.

Why should heaven's law with foolish man comply Exempted from the race ordain'd to die? '' (she)

This menace fix'd the warrior to his (warrior) throne; Sullen he (warrior) sat, and curb'd the rising groan.

Then Juno call'd -LRB-Jove's orders to obey-RRB- The winged Iris, and the god of day. '' Go wait the Thunderer's will -LRB-Saturnia cried-RRB-

On yon tall summit of the fountful Ide : There in the father's awful presence stand, Receive, and execute his (father) dread command.

'' She (Iris) said, and sat; the god that gilds the day, And various Iris, wing their airy way. Swift as the wind, to Ida's hills they came, -LRB-Fair nurse of fountains, and of savage game-RRB-

There sat the eternal; he (Swift) whose nod controls The trembling world, and shakes the steady poles. Veil'd in a mist of fragrance him (Swift)

they found, With clouds of gold and purple circled round. Well-pleased the Thunderer saw their earnest care, And prompt obedience to the queen of air

; Then -LRB-while a smile serenes his (Swift) awful brow-RRB- Commands the goddess of the showery bow:

``Iris! descend, and what we here ordain,

Report to yon mad tyrant of the main. Bid him (tyrant) from fight to his (tyrant) own deeps repair, Or breathe from slaughter in the fields of air.

If he (tyrant) refuse, then let him (tyrant) timely weigh Our elder birthright, and superior sway. How shall his (tyrant) rashness stand the dire alarms, If heaven's omnipotence descend in arms?

Strives he (tyrant) with me, by whom his (tyrant) power was given, And is there equal to the lord of heaven? '' (the goddess)

The all-mighty spoke; the goddess wing'd

Swift as the rattling hail, or fleecy snows, Drive through the skies, when Boreas fiercely blows; So from the clouds descending Iris falls, And to blue Neptune thus the goddess calls:

In me behold the messenger of Jove: He (Swift) bids thee from forbidden wars repair To thine own deeps, or to the fields of air.

her (goddess) flight To sacred Ilion from the Idaean height.

``Attend the mandate of the sire above! This if refused, he (sire) bids thee timely weigh His (sire) elder birthright, and superior sway.

How shall thy rashness stand the dire alarms If heaven's omnipotence descend in arms? Striv`st thou with him (sire) by whom all power is given?

And art thou equal to the lord of heaven?'' (unknown)

'' What means the haughty sovereign of the skies? -LRB-The king of ocean thus, incensed, replies;-RRB-

I. Three brother deities from Saturn came, And ancient Rhea, earth's immortal dame: Assign'd by lot, our triple rule we know; Infernal Pluto sways the shades below;

O'er the wide clouds, and o'er the starry plain, Ethereal Jove extends his (brother) high domain; My court beneath the hoary waves I keep, And hush the roarings of the sacred deep; Olympus, and this earth, in common lie: What claim has here the tyrant of the sky?

Rule as he (tyrant) will his (tyrant) portion'd realms on high; No vassal god, nor of his (tyrant) train, am Far in the distant clouds let him (tyrant) control,

And awe the younger brothers of the pole; There to his (tyrant) children his (tyrant) commands be given, The trembling, servile, second race of heaven.''

'' And must I then -LRB-said she (I)-RRB-, O sire of floods! Bear this fierce answer to the king of gods? Correct it yet, and change thy rash intent; A noble mind disdains not to repent.

To elder brothers guardian fiends are given, To scourge the wretch insulting them and heaven.''

``Great is the profit -LRB-thus the god rejoin'd-RRB-

When ministers are blest with prudent mind: Warn'd by thy words, to powerful Jove I yield, And quit, though angry, the contended field: Not but his (god) threats with justice I disclaim, The same our honours, and our birth the same.

If yet, forgetful of his (god) promise given To Hermes, Pallas, and the queen of heaven, To favour Ilion, that perfidious place, He (god) breaks his (god) faith with half the ethereal race; Give him (god) to know, unless the Grecian train Lay yon proud structures level with the plain, Howe'er the offence by other gods

be pass'd, The wrath of Neptune shall for ever last. '' (he)

Thus speaking, furious from the field he (Lay) strode, And plunged into the bosom of the flood.

The lord of thunders, from his (lord) lofty height Beheld, and thus bespoke the source of light:

``Behold! the god whose liquid arms are hurl'd

Around the globe, whose earthquakes rock the world, Desists at length his (god) rebel-war to wage, Seeks his (god) own seas, and trembles at our rage; Else had my wrath, heaven's thrones all shaking round, Burn'd to the bottom of his (god) seas profound; And all the gods that round old Saturn dwell Had heard the thunders to the deeps of hell.

Well was the crime, and well the vengeance spared; Even power immense had found such battle hard. Go thou, my son!

the trembling Greeks alarm, Shake my broad aegis on thy active arm, Be godlike Hector thy peculiar care, Swell his (Hector) bold heart, and urge his (Hector) strength to war:

Let Ilion conquer, till the Achaian train Fly to their ships and Hellespont again: Then Greece shall breathe from toils. '' (The lord Behold)

Not half so swift the sailing falcon flies, That drives a turtle through the liquid skies, As Phoebus, shooting from the Idaean brow, Glides down the mountain to the plain below.

There Hector seated by the stream he (Hector) sees, His (Hector) sense returning with the coming breeze; Again his (Hector) pulses beat, his (Hector) spirits rise; Again his (Hector) loved companions meet his (Hector) eyes; Jove thinking of his (Hector) pains, they pass'd away, To whom the god who gives the golden day:

``Why sits great Hector from the field so far?

The godhead said; His (Hector) will divine the son of Jove obey'd. What grief, what wound, withholds thee from the war? '' (the god)

The fainting hero, as the vision bright Stood shining o'er him (hero), half unseal'd his (hero) sight:

``What blest immortal, with commanding breath, Thus wakens Hector from the sleep of death?

Has fame not told, how, while my trusty sword Bathed Greece in slaughter, and her (god) battle gored, The mighty Ajax with a deadly blow Had almost sunk me to the shades below?

Even yet, methinks, the gliding ghosts I spy, And hell's black horrors swim before my eye. '' (him)

To him (Hector) Apollo:
``Be no more dismay'd; See, and be strong!

the Thunderer sends thee aid. Behold! thy Phoebus shall his (Hector) arms employ, Phoebus, propitious still to thee and Troy. Inspire thy warriors then with manly force,

And to the ships impel thy rapid horse: Even I will make thy fiery coursers way, And drive the Grecians headlong to the sea.

As when the pamper'd steed, with reins unbound, Breaks from his (Hector) stall, and pours along the ground; With ample strokes he (Hector) rushes to the flood, To bathe his (Hector) sides, and cool his (Hector) fiery blood; His (Hector) head, now freed, he (Hector) tosses to the skies; His (Hector) mane dishevell'd o'er his (Hector) shoulders flies: He (Hector) snuffs the females in the well-known plain, And springs, exulting, to his (Hector) fields again: Urged by the voice divine, thus Hector flew, Full of the god; and all his (Hector) hosts pursue.

As when the force of men and dogs combined Invade the mountain goat, or branching hind; Far from the hunter's rage secure they lie Close in the rock, -LRB-not fated yet to die-RRB-

'' (Apollo)

Thus to bold Hector spoke the son of Jove, And breathed immortal ardour from above. When lo! a lion shoots across the way!

They fly: at once the chasers and the prey. So Greece, that late in conquering troops pursued, And mark'd their progress through the ranks in blood,

Thoas with grief observed his (Hector) dreadful course, Thoas, the bravest of the Ćtolian force; Skill'd to direct the javelin's distant flight, And bold to combat in the standing fight, Not more in councils famed for solid sense, Than winning words and heavenly eloquence.

Soon as they see the furious chief appear, Forget to vanquish, and consent to fear. '' Gods! what portent -LRB-he (chief) cried-RRB- these eyes invades?

We saw him (chief), late, by thundering Ajax kill'd: What god restores him (god) to the frighted field; And not content that half of Greece lie slain, Pours new destruction on her (Gods) sons again?

Lo! Hector rises from the Stygian shades! He (Hector) comes not, Jove! without thy powerful will; Lo! still he (Hector) lives, pursues, and conquers still!

Yet hear my counsel, and his (Hector) worst withstand: The Greeks' main body to the fleet command; But let the few whom brisker spirits warm, Stand the first onset, and provoke the storm.

Thus point your arms; and when such foes appear, Fierce as he (Hector) is, let Hector learn to fear. '' The warrior spoke; the listening Greeks obey, Thickening their ranks, and form a deep array.

Each Ajax, Teucer, Merion gave command, The valiant leader of the Cretan band; And Mars-like Meges: these the chiefs excite, Approach the foe, and meet the coming fight.

Behind, unnumber'd multitudes attend, To flank the navy, and the shores defend. Full on the front the pressing Trojans bear, And Hector first came towering to the war.

Phoebus himself the rushing battle led; A veil of clouds involved his (Hector) radiant head: High held before him (Hector), Jove's enormous shield Portentous shone, and shaded all the field;

Vulcan to Jove the immortal gift consign'd, To scatter hosts and terrify mankind, The Greeks expect the shock, the clamours rise From different parts, and mingle in the skies.

Dire was the hiss of darts, by heroes flung, And arrows leaping from the bow-string sung; These drink the life of generous warriors slain: Those guiltless fall, and thirst for blood in vain.

As long as Phoebus bore unmoved the shield, Sat doubtful conquest hovering o'er the field; But when aloft he (warriors) shakes it in the skies, Shouts in their ears, and lightens in their eyes, Deep horror seizes every Grecian breast, Their force is humbled, and their fear confess'd.

scatter'd wide, No swain to guard them, and no day to guide, When two fell lions from the mountain come, And spread the carnage through the shady gloom.

So flies a herd of oxen, Impending Phoebus pours around them fear, And Troy and Hector thunder in the rear. Heaps fall on heaps: the slaughter Hector leads, First great Arcesilas, then Stichius bleeds;

One to the bold Boeotians ever dear, And one Menestheus' friend and famed compeer. Medon and Iasus, Ćneas sped; This sprang from Phelus, and the Athenians led; But hapless Medon from Oileus came;

A banish'd man, in Phylace he (friend) dwell'd, Press'd by the vengeance of an angry wife; Troy ends at last his (Troy) labours and his (Troy) life.

Him (Troy) Ajax honour'd with a brother's name, Though born of lawless love: from home expell'd, Mecystes next Polydamas o'erthrew; And thee, brave Clonius, great Agenor slew.

By Paris, Deiochus inglorious dies, Pierced through the shoulder as he (Troy) basely flies. Polites' arm laid Echius on the plain; Stretch'd on one heap, the victors spoil the slain.

The Greeks dismay'd, confused, disperse or fall, Some seek the trench, some skulk behind the wall. While these fly trembling, others pant for breath,

On rush'd bold Hector, gloomy as the night; Forbids to plunder, animates the fight, Points to the fleet:

``For, by the gods!

And o'er the slaughter stalks gigantic death. who flies,-LRB-240-RRB- Who dares but linger, by this hand he (Hector) dies; No weeping sister his (Hector) cold eye shall close,

No friendly hand his (Hector) funeral pyre compose. Who stops to plunder at this signal hour, The birds shall tear him (Hector), and the dogs devour.

Furious he (Hector) said; the smarting scourge resounds; The coursers fly; the smoking chariot bounds; The hosts rush on; loud clamours shake the shore; The horses thunder, earth and ocean roar!

Apollo, planted at the trench's bound, Push'd at the bank: down sank the enormous mound: Roll'd in the ditch the heapy ruin lay;

'' (Hector/HECTOR/Stern)

A sudden road! a long and ample way. O'er the dread fosse -LRB-a late impervious space-RRB- Now steeds, and men, and cars tumultuous pass.

The wondering crowds the downward level trod; Before them flamed the shield, and march'd the god. Then with his (god) hand he (god) shook the mighty wall; And lo!

Easy as when ashore an infant stands, And draws imagined houses in the sands; The sportive wanton, pleased with some new play, Sweeps the slight works and fashion'd domes away: Thus vanish'd at thy touch, the towers and walls; The toil of thousands in a moment falls.

The Grecians gaze around with wild despair, Confused, and weary all the powers with prayer: Exhort their men, with praises, threats, commands; And urge the gods, with voices, eyes, and hands.

the turrets nod, the bulwarks fall: Experienced Nestor chief obtests the skies, And weeps his (chief) country with a father's eyes. ''

thy shrine with offer'd gore; If e'er, in hope our country to behold, We paid the fattest firstlings of the fold;

O Jove! if ever, on his (chief) native shore, One Greek enrich'd If e'er thou sign`st our wishes with thy nod: Perform the promise of a gracious god!

This day preserve our navies from the flame, And save the relics of the Grecian name. '' Thus prayed the sage: the eternal gave consent, And peals of thunder shook the firmament.

As, when black tempests mix the seas and skies, The roaring deeps in watery mountains rise, Above the sides of some tall ship ascend, Its womb they deluge, and its ribs they rend: Thus loudly roaring, and o'erpowering all, Mount the thick Trojans up the Grecian wall; Legions on legions from each side arise: Thick sound the keels; the storm of arrows flies.

Presumptuous Troy mistook the accepting sign, And catch'd new fury at the voice divine. Fierce on the ships above, the cars below, These wield the mace, and those the javelin throw.

While thus the thunder of the battle raged, And labouring armies round the works engaged, Still in the tent Patroclus sat to tend The good Eurypylus, his (Patroclus) wounded friend.

But when he (Patroclus) saw, ascending up the fleet, Victorious Troy; then, starting from his (Patroclus) seat, With bitter groans his (Patroclus) sorrows he (Patroclus)

He (Patroclus) sprinkles healing balms, to anguish kind, And adds discourse, the medicine of the mind. express'd, He (Patroclus) wrings his (Patroclus) hands, he (Patroclus) beats his (Patroclus) manly breast.

'' Though yet thy state require redress -LRB-he (Patroclus) cries-RRB- Depart I must: what horrors strike my eyes! Charged with Achilles' high command I go,

A mournful witness of this scene of woe ; I haste to urge him (witness) by his (witness) country's care To rise in arms, and shine again in war.

Perhaps some favouring god his (god) soul may bend; The voice is powerful of a faithful friend. '' He (god) spoke; and, speaking, swifter than the wind Sprung from the tent, and left the war behind.

The embodied Greeks the fierce attack sustain, But strive, though numerous, to repulse in vain: Nor could the Trojans, through that firm array, Force to the fleet and tents the impervious way.

As when a shipwright, with Palladian art, Smooths the rough wood, and levels every part; With equal hand he (god) guides his (god) whole design,

By the just rule, and the directing line: The martial leaders, with like skill and care, Preserved their line, and equal kept the war.

At one proud bark, high-towering o'er the fleet, Ajax the great, and godlike Hector meet; For one bright prize the matchless chiefs contend, Nor this the ships can fire, nor that defend:

Brave deeds of arms through all the ranks were tried, And every ship sustained an equal tide. One kept the shore, and one the vessel trod; That fix'd as fate, this acted by a god.

The son of Clytius in his (son) daring hand, The deck approaching, shakes a flaming brand; But, pierced by Telamon's huge lance, expires: Thundering he (son) falls, and drops the extinguish'd fires.

Great Hector view'd him (Hector) with a sad survey, As stretch'd in dust before the stern he (Hector) lay. '' Oh! all of Trojan, all of Lycian race!

Stand to your arms, maintain this arduous space: Lo! where the son of royal Clytius lies; Ah, save his (son) arms, secure his (son) obsequies!''

This said, his (son) eager javelin sought the foe: But Ajax shunn'd the meditated blow. Not vainly yet the forceful lance was thrown; It stretch'd in dust

An exile long, sustain'd at Ajax' board, A faithful servant to a foreign lord; In peace, and war, for ever at his (lord) side, Near his (lord) loved master, as he (lord) lived, he (lord) died.

unhappy Lycophron: From the high poop he (lord) tumbles on the sand, And lies a lifeless load along the land. With anguish Ajax views the piercing sight, And thus inflames his (lord) brother to the fight:

``Teucer, behold! extended on the shore Our friend, our loved companion! now no more! Dear as a parent, with a parent's care To fight our wars he (companion) left his (companion) native air.

This death deplored, to Hector's rage we owe; Revenge, revenge it on the cruel foe. Where are those darts on which the fates attend?

And where the bow which Phoebus taught to bend?'' (brother)

Impatient Teucer, hastening to his (foe) aid, Before the chief his (foe) ample bow display'd

; The well-stored quiver on his (foe) shoulders hung: Then hiss'd his (foe) arrow, and the bowstring sung. Clytus, Pisenor's son, renown'd in fame, -LRB-To thee, Polydamas!

an honour'd name-RRB- Drove through the thickest of the embattled plains The startling steeds, and shook his (son) eager reins. As all on glory ran his (son) ardent mind, The pointed death arrests him (son) from behind:

Hurl'd from the lofty seat, at distance far, The headlong coursers spurn his (son) empty car; Till sad Polydamas the steeds restrain'd, And gave, Astynous, to thy careful hand; Then, fired to vengeance, rush'd amidst the foe:

Through his (foe) fair neck the thrilling arrow flies; In youth's first bloom reluctantly he (foe) dies. Rage edged his (foe) sword, and strengthen'd every blow.

Once more bold Teucer, in his (foe) country's cause, At Hector's breast a chosen arrow draws: And had the weapon found the destined way, Thy fall, great Trojan! had renown'd that day.

But Hector was not doom'd to perish then: The all-wise disposer of the fates of men -LRB-Imperial Jove-RRB- his (Hector) present death withstands; Nor was such glory due to Teucer's hands.

At its full stretch as the tough string he (Hector) drew, Struck by an arm unseen, it burst in two; Down dropp'd the bow: the shaft with brazen head Fell innocent,

Some god, propitious to the Trojan foe, Has, from my arm unfailing, struck the bow, And broke the nerve my hands had twined with art, Strong to impel the flight of many a dart.''

``Since heaven commands it -LRB-Ajax made reply-RRB- Dismiss the bow, and lay thy arrows by: Thy arms no less suffice the lance to wield, And quit the quiver for the ponderous shield.

and on the dust lay dead. The astonish'd archer to great Ajax cries;

``Some god prevents our destined enterprise: In the first ranks indulge thy thirst of fame, Thy brave example shall the rest inflame.

Fierce as they are, by long successes vain; To force our fleet, or even a ship to gain, Asks toil, and sweat, and blood: their utmost might Shall find its match--No more: 'tis ours to fight.

Then Teucer laid his (god) faithless bow aside; The fourfold buckler o'er his (god) shoulder tied; On his (god) brave head a crested helm he (god) placed, With nodding horse-hair formidably graced; A dart, whose point with brass refulgent shines, The warrior wields; and his (warrior) great brother joins.

'' (Ajax/AJAX/Oilean Ajax)

This Hector saw, and thus express'd his (Hector) joy:
``Ye troops of Lycia, Dardanus, and Troy! Be mindful of yourselves, your ancient fame, And spread your glory with the navy's flame.

Jove is with us; I saw his (Hector) hand, but now, From the proud archer strike his (Hector) vaunted bow: Indulgent Jove! how plain thy favours shine, When happy nations bear the marks divine!

How easy then, to see the sinking state Of realms accursed, deserted, reprobate! Such is the fate of Greece, and such is ours: Behold, ye warriors, and exert your powers.

Death is the worst; a fate which all must try; And for our country, 'tis a bliss to die. The gallant man, though slain in fight he (man) be, Yet leaves his (man) nation safe, his (man) children free

; Entails a debt on all the grateful state; His (man) own brave friends shall glory in his (man) fate; His (man) wife live honour'd, all his (man) race succeed,

And late posterity enjoy the deed!'' (Hector/HECTOR/Stern)

This roused the soul in every Trojan breast: The godlike Ajax next his (man) Greeks address'd:

``How long, ye warriors of the Argive race, -LRB-To generous Argos what a dire disgrace!-RRB- How long on these cursed confines will ye lie, Yet undetermined, or to live or die?

What hopes remain, what methods to retire, If once your vessels catch the Trojan fire? Make how the flames approach, how near they fall, How Hector calls, and Troy obeys his (Troy) call!

Tis now no time for wisdom or debates; To your own hands are trusted all your fates; And better far in one decisive strife, One day should end our labour or our life, Than keep this hard-got inch of barren sands, Still press'd, and press'd by such inglorious hands.

Not to the dance that dreadful voice invites, It calls to death, and all the rage of fights. ' '' (Greeks)

The listening Grecians feel their leader's flame, And every kindling bosom pants for fame.

Then mutual slaughters spread on either side; By Hector here the Phocian Schedius died; There, pierced by Ajax, sunk Laodamas, Chief of the foot, of old Antenor's race.

His (Chief) lance bold Meges at the victor threw; The victor, stooping, from the death withdrew; -LRB-That valued life, O Phoebus! was thy care-RRB-

But Croesmus' bosom took the flying spear: His (victor) corpse fell bleeding on the slippery shore; His (victor) radiant arms triumphant Meges bore.

Dolops, the son of Lampus, rushes on, Sprung from the race of old Laomedon, And famed for prowess in a well-fought field, He (victor) pierced the centre of his (victor) sounding shield: But Meges, Phyleus' ample breastplate wore, -LRB-Well-known in fight on Selle's winding shore

Polydamas laid Otus on the sand, The fierce commander of the Epeian band. ; For king Euphetes gave the golden mail, Compact, and firm with many a jointed scale-RRB-

Full at the Trojan's head he (king) urged his (king) lance, Where the high plumes above the helmet dance, New ting'd with Tyrian dye: in dust below, Shorn from the crest, the purple honours glow.

Which oft, in cities storm'd, and battles won, Had saved the father, and now saves the son. Meantime their fight the Spartan king survey'd, And stood by Meges' side a sudden aid.

Through Dolops' shoulder urged his (king) forceful dart, Which held its passage through the panting heart, And issued at his (king) breast. With thundering sound The warrior falls, extended on the ground.

In rush the conquering Greeks to spoil the slain: But Hector's voice excites his (Hector) kindred train; The hero most, from Hicetaon sprung, Fierce Melanippus, gallant, brave, and young.

He (Hector) -LRB-ere to Troy the Grecians cross'd the main-RRB- Fed his (Hector) large oxen on Percote's plain; But when oppress'd, his (Hector) country

claim'd his (Hector) care, Return'd to Ilion, and excell'd in war; For this, in Priam's court, he (Hector) held his (Hector) place, Beloved no less than Priam's royal race.

Him (Hector) Hector singled, as his (Hector) troops he (Hector) led, And thus inflamed him (Hector), pointing to the dead.

``Lo, Melanippus! lo, where Dolops lies; And is it thus our royal kinsman dies? O'ermatch'd

he (kinsman) falls; to two at once a prey, And lo! they bear the bloody arms away! Come on--a distant war no longer wage, But hand to hand thy country's foes engage:

Till Greece at once, and all her (Hector) glory end; Or Ilion from her (Hector) towery height descend, Heaved from the lowest stone; and bury all In one sad sepulchre, one common fall.

'' (Hector/HECTOR/Stern)

Hector -LRB-this said-RRB- rush'd forward on the foes: With equal ardour Melanippus glows: Then Ajax thus--
``O Greeks! respect your fame,

Let mutual reverence mutual warmth inspire, And catch from breast to breast the noble fire, On valour's side the odds of combat lie; The brave live glorious, or lamented die;

Respect yourselves, and learn an honest shame: The wretch that trembles in the field of fame, Meets death, and worse than death, eternal shame.

His (Hector) generous sense he (Hector) not in vain imparts; It sunk, and rooted in the Grecian hearts: They join, they throng, they thicken at his (Hector) call, And flank the navy with a brazen wall; Shields touching shields, in order blaze above, And stop the Trojans, though impell'd by Jove.

'' (Ajax/AJAX/Oilean Ajax)

The fiery Spartan first, with loud applause. Warms the bold son of Nestor in his (Nestor) cause. '' Is there -LRB-he (Nestor) said-RRB- in arms a youth like you, So strong to fight, so active to pursue?

Why stand you distant, nor attempt a deed? Lift the bold lance, and make some Trojan bleed. '' He (Nestor) said; and backward to the lines retired; Forth rush'd

the youth with martial fury fired, Beyond the foremost ranks; his (Nestor) lance he (Nestor) threw, And round the black battalions cast his (Nestor) view.

Advancing Melanippus met the dart With his (Nestor) bold breast, and felt it in his (Nestor) heart: Thundering he (Nestor) falls; his (Nestor) falling arms resound, And his (Nestor) broad buckler rings against the ground.

The troops of Troy recede with sudden fear, While the swift javelin hiss'd along in air. The victor leaps upon his (victor) prostrate prize:

Thus on a roe the well-breath'd beagle flies, And rends his (victor) side, fresh-bleeding with the dart The distant hunter sent into his (hunter) heart.

Observing Hector to the rescue flew; Bold as he (hunter) was, Antilochus withdrew. So when a savage, ranging o'er the plain, Has torn the shepherd's dog, or shepherd's swain,

While conscious of the deed, he (swain) glares around, And hears the gathering multitude resound, Timely he (swain) flies the yet-untasted food, And gains the friendly shelter of the wood:

So fears the youth; all Troy with shouts pursue, While stones and darts in mingled tempest flew; But enter'd in the Grecian ranks, he (swain) turns His (swain) manly breast, and with new fury burns.

The sire of gods, confirming Thetis' prayer, The Grecian ardour quench'd in deep despair; But lifts to glory Troy's prevailing bands, Swells all their hearts, and strengthens all their hands.

Now on the fleet the tides of Trojans drove, Fierce to fulfil the stern decrees of Jove: On Ida's top he (sire) waits with longing eyes, To view the navy blazing to the skies;

These fates revolved in his (sire) almighty mind, He (sire) raises Hector to the work design'd, Bids him (sire) with more than mortal fury glow, And drives him (sire), like a lightning, on the foe.

Then, nor till then, the scale of war shall turn, The Trojans fly, and conquer'd Ilion burn. So Mars, when human crimes for vengeance call, Shakes his (foe) huge javelin, and whole armies fall.

He (foe) foams with wrath; beneath his (foe) gloomy brow Like fiery meteors his (foe) red eye-balls glow: The radiant helmet on his (foe) temple burns, Waves when he (foe) nods, and lightens as he (foe) turns:

Not with more rage a conflagration rolls, Wraps the vast mountains, and involves the poles. For Jove his (foe) splendour round the chief had thrown, And cast the blaze of both the hosts on one.

Due to stern Pallas, and Pelides' spear: Yet Jove deferr'd the death he (foe) was to pay, And gave what fate allow'd, the honours of a day!

Now all on fire for fame, his (foe) breast, his (foe) eyes Burn at each foe, and single every prize; Still at the closest ranks, the thickest fight, He (foe) points his (foe) ardour, and exerts his (foe) might.

Unhappy glories! for his (foe) fate was near, The Grecian phalanx, moveless as a tower, On all sides batter'd, yet resists his (foe) power:

By winds assail'd, by billows beat in vain, Unmoved it hears, above, the tempest blow, And sees the watery mountains break below.

Girt in surrounding flames, he (foe) seems to fall Like fire from Jove, and bursts upon them all: Bursts as a wave

that from the cloud impends, And, swell'd with tempests, on the ship descends; White are the decks with foam; the winds aloud Howl o'er the masts, and sing through every shroud: Pale, trembling, tired, the sailors freeze with fears; And instant death on every wave appears.

So some tall rock o'erhangs the hoary main,-LRB-241-RRB- So pale the Greeks the eyes of Hector meet, The chief so thunders, and so shakes the fleet.

As when a lion, rushing from his (chief) den, Amidst the plain of some wide-water'd fen, -LRB-Where numerous oxen, as at ease they feed, At large expatiate o'er the ranker mead-RRB-

Leaps on the herds before the herdsman's eyes; The trembling herdsman far to distance flies; Some lordly bull -LRB-the rest dispersed and fled-RRB-

Thus from the rage of Jove-like Hector flew All Greece in heaps; but one he (Hector) seized, and slew: Mycenian Periphes, a mighty name,

In wisdom great, in arms well known to fame; The minister of stern Eurystheus' ire Against Alcides, Copreus was his (minister) sire:

The son redeem'd the honours of the race, A son as generous as the sire was base; O'er all his (son) country's youth conspicuous far In every virtue, or of peace or war:

He (son) singles out; arrests, and lays him (son) dead. But doom'd to Hector's stronger force to yield! Against the margin of his (Hector) ample shield He (Hector) struck his (Hector) hasty foot: his (Hector) heels up-sprung;

Supine he (Hector) fell; his (Hector) brazen helmet rung. On the fallen chief the invading Trojan press'd, And plunged the pointed javelin in his (Hector) breast.

His (Hector) circling friends, who strove to guard too late The unhappy hero, fled, or shared his (Hector) fate. Chased from the foremost line, the Grecian train Now man the next, receding toward the main

: Wedged in one body at the tents they stand, Wall'd round with sterns, a gloomy, desperate band. Now manly shame forbids the inglorious flight; Now fear itself confines them to the fight:

Man courage breathes in man; but Nestor most -LRB-The sage preserver of the Grecian host-RRB- Exhorts, adjures, to guard these utmost shores; And by their parents, by themselves implores.

'' Oh friends! be men: your generous breasts inflame With mutual honour, and with mutual shame! Think of your hopes, your fortunes; all the care Your wives, your infants, and your parents share

: Think of each living father's reverend head; Think of each ancestor with glory dead; Absent, by me they speak, by me

they sue, They ask their safety, and their fame, from you: The gods their fates on this one action lay, And all are lost, if you desert the day.

The mist of darkness Jove around them threw She (you) clear'd, restoring all the war to view; A sudden ray shot beaming o'er the plain, And show'd the shores, the navy, and the main: Hector they saw, and all who fly, or fight, The scene wide-opening to the blaze of light, First of the field great

'' He (Hector) spoke, and round him (Hector) breathed heroic fires; Minerva seconds what the sage inspires. Ajax strikes their eyes, His (Hector) port majestic, and his (Hector) ample size: A ponderous mace with studs of iron crown'd,

Full twenty cubits long, he (Hector) swings around; Nor fights, like others, fix'd to certain stands But looks a moving tower above the bands; High on the decks with vast gigantic stride, The godlike hero stalks from side to side.

So when a horseman from the watery mead -LRB-Skill'd in the manage of the bounding steed-RRB- Drives four fair coursers, practised to obey,

To some great city through the public way; Safe in his (horseman) art, as side by side they run, He (horseman) shifts his (horseman) seat, and vaults from one to one; And now to this, and now to that he (horseman) flies; Admiring numbers follow with their eyes.

As furious, Hector thunder'd threats aloud, And rush'd enraged before the Trojan crowd; Then swift invades the ships, whose beaky prores Lay rank'd contiguous on the bending shores; So the strong eagle from his (Lay) airy height, Who marks the swans' or cranes' embodied flight, Stoops down impetuous, while they light for food, And, stooping, darkens with his (Stoops) wings the flood.

From ship to ship thus Ajax swiftly flew, No less the wonder of the warring crew. Jove leads him (Stoops) on with his (Stoops) almighty hand, And breathes fierce spirits in his (Stoops) following band.

Thou wouldst have thought, so furious was their fire, No force could tame them, and no toil could tire; As if new vigour from new fights they won, And the long battle was but then begun.

The warring nations meet, the battle roars, Thick beats the combat on the sounding prores. Greece, yet unconquer'd, kept alive the war, Secure of death, confiding in despair:

the main Bright with the blaze, and red with heroes slain: Like strength is felt from hope, and from despair, And each contends, as his (them) were all the war.

Troy in proud hopes already view'd '' Twas thou, bold Hector! whose resistless hand First seized a ship on that contested strand;

The first that touch'd the unhappy Trojan shore: For this in arms the warring nations stood, And bathed their generous breasts with mutual blood.

The same which dead Protesilaus bore,-LRB-242-RRB- No room to poise the lance or bend the bow; But hand to hand, and man to man, they grow:

The falchions ring, shields rattle, axes sound, Swords flash in air, or glitter on the ground; With streaming blood the slippery shores are dyed, And slaughter'd heroes swell the dreadful tide.

Wounded, they wound; and seek each other's hearts With falchions, axes, swords, and shorten'd darts. Still raging, Hector with his (Hector) ample hand Grasps the high stern, and gives this loud command:

-LSB-Illustration: AJAX DEFENDING THE GREEK SHIPS.-RSB- AJAX DEFENDING THE GREEK SHIPS. '' Haste, bring the flames! that toil of ten long years Is finished; and the day desired appears!

This happy day with acclamations greet, Bright with destruction of yon hostile fleet. The coward-counsels of a timorous throng Of reverend dotards check'd our glory long: Too long Jove lull'd

us with lethargic charms, But now in peals of thunder calls to arms: In this great day he (reverend) crowns our full desires, Wakes all our force, and seconds all our fires.

'' He (reverend) spoke--the warriors at his (reverend) fierce command Pour a new deluge on the Grecian band. Even Ajax paused, -LRB-so thick the javelins fly,-RRB- Stepp'd back, and doubted or to live or die.

Yet, where the oars are placed, he (Stepp) stands to wait What chief approaching dares attempt his (Stepp) fate: Even to the last his (Stepp) naval charge defends, Now shakes his (Stepp) spear, now lifts, and now protends; Even yet, the Greeks with piercing shouts inspires, Amidst attacks, and deaths, and darts, and fires.

'' O friends! O heroes! names for ever dear, Once sons of Mars, and thunderbolts of war! Ah! yet be mindful of your old renown, Your great forefathers' virtues and your own.

What aids expect you in this utmost strait? What bulwarks rising between you and fate? No aids, no bulwarks your retreat attend, No friends to help, no city to defend.

This spot is all you have, to lose or keep; There stand the Trojans, and here rolls the deep. ' Tis hostile ground you tread; your native lands Far, far from hence

: your fates are in your hands. '' Raging he (forefathers) spoke; nor further wastes his (forefathers) breath, But turns his (forefathers) javelin to the work of death.

Whate'er bold Trojan arm'd his (forefathers) daring hands, Against the sable ships, with flaming brands, So well the chief his (forefathers) naval weapon sped, The luckless warrior at his (forefathers) stern lay dead:

Full twelve, the boldest, in a moment fell, Sent by great Ajax to the shades of hell. -LSB-Illustration: CASTOR AND POLLUX.-RSB-

ARGUMENT THE SIXTH BATTLE, THE ACTS AND DEATH OF PATROCLUS Patroclus -LRB-in pursuance of the request of Nestor in the eleventh book-RRB- entreats Achilles to suffer him (Achilles) to go to the assistance of the Greeks with Achilles' troops and armour.

He (Achilles) agrees to it, but at the same time charges him (Achilles) to content himself with rescuing the fleet, without further pursuit of the enemy.

CASTOR AND POLLUX. BOOK XVI. The armour, horses, soldiers, and officers are described. Achilles offers a libation for the success of his (Achilles) friend, after which Patroclus leads the Myrmidons to battle.

The Trojans, at the sight of Patroclus in Achilles' armour, taking him (Achilles) for that hero, are cast into the uttermost consternation; he (Achilles) beats them off from the vessels, Hector himself flies, Sarpedon is killed, though Jupiter was averse to his (Hector) fate.

Several other particulars of the battle are described; in the heat of which, Patroclus, neglecting the orders of Achilles, pursues the foe to the walls of Troy, where Apollo repulses and disarms him (Achilles), Euphorbus wounds him (Achilles), and Hector kills him (Hector), which concludes the book.

Meantime Patroclus to Achilles flies; The streaming tears fall copious from his (Achilles) eyes Not faster, trickling to the plains below, From the tall rock the sable waters flow.

So warr'd both armies on the ensanguined shore, While the black vessels smoked with human gore. Divine Pelides, with compassion moved.

Thus spoke, indulgent, to his (Achilles) best beloved:-LRB-243-RRB-

``Patroclus, say, what grief thy bosom bears, That flows so fast in these unmanly tears?

No girl, no infant whom the mother keeps From her (mother) loved breast, with fonder passion weeps; Not more the mother's soul, that infant warms, Clung to her (mother) knees, and reaching at her (mother) arms, Than thou hast mine!

Oh tell me, to what end Thy melting sorrows thus pursue thy friend? '' (me)

Griev`st thou for me, or for, my martial band?

Our fathers live -LRB-our first, most tender care-RRB-, Thy good Menoetius breathes the vital air, And hoary Peleus yet extends his (friend) days; Pleased in their age to hear their children's praise.

Perhaps yon relics of the Grecian name, Doom'd in their ships to sink by fire and sword, And pay the forfeit of their haughty lord?

Or come sad tidings from our native land? Or may some meaner cause thy pity claim? Whate'er the cause, reveal thy secret care, And speak those sorrows which a friend would share.

A sigh that instant from his (friend) bosom broke, Another follow'd, and Patroclus spoke:

``Let Greece at length with pity touch thy breast, Thyself a Greek; and, once, of Greeks the best!

every chief that might her (lord) fate prevent, Lies pierced with wounds, and bleeding in his (chief) tent: Eurypylus, Tydides, Atreus' son, And wise Ulysses, at the navy groan, More for their country's wounds than for their own.

'' (Patroclus)

Lo! Their pain soft arts of pharmacy can ease, Thy breast alone no lenitives appease. May never rage like thine my soul enslave, O great in vain! unprofitably brave!

Thy country slighted in her (lord) last distress, What friend, what man, from thee shall hope redress? No--men unborn, and ages yet behind, Shall curse that fierce, that unforgiving mind.

ever amorous hero caused thy birth, Nor ever tender goddess brought thee forth: Some rugged rock's hard entrails gave thee form, And raging seas produced thee in a storm, A soul well suiting that tempestuous kind, So rough thy manners, so untamed thy mind.

If some dire oracle thy breast alarm, If aught from Jove, or Thetis, stop thy arm, Some beam of comfort yet on Greece may shine, If I but lead the Myrmidonian line:

Clad in thy dreadful arms if I appear, Proud Troy shall tremble, and desert the war; Without thy person Greece shall win the day, And thy mere image chase her (person) foes away.

'' O man unpitying! if of man thy race; But sure thou spring`st not from a soft embrace, Nor '' Press'd by fresh forces

, her (person) o'erlabour'd train Shall quit the ships, and Greece respire again. '' Thus, blind to fate! with supplicating breath, Thou begg`st his (man) arms, and in his (man) arms thy death.

Achilles knows no fears; Nor words from Jove nor oracles he (Achilles) hears; Nor aught a mother's caution can suggest; The tyrant's pride lies rooted in my breast.

My wrongs, my wrongs, my constant thought engage, Those, my sole oracles, inspire my rage: I made him (Achilles) tyrant: gave him (Achilles) power to wrong

Unfortunately good! a boding sigh Thy friend return'd; and with it, this reply:

``Patroclus! thy Even my : I felt it; and shall feel it long.

Due to the toils of many a well-fought day; Due to my conquest of her (mother) father's reign; Due to the votes of all the Grecian train.

The maid, my black-eyed maid, he (father) forced away, From me he (father) forced her (maid); me, the bold and brave, Disgraced, dishonour'd, like the meanest slave.

Tis time our fury should relent at last: I fix'd its date; the day I wish'd appears: How Hector to my ships his (Hector) battle bears,

But bear we this--the wrongs I grieve are past; ' The flames my eyes, the shouts invade my ears. Go then, Patroclus!

court fair honour's charms In Troy's famed fields, and in Achilles' arms: Lead forth my martial Myrmidons to fight, Go save the fleets, and conquer in my right.

See the thin relics of their baffled band At the last edge of yon deserted land! Behold all Ilion on their ships descends; How the cloud blackens, how the storm impends!

It was not thus, when, at my sight amazed, Troy saw and trembled, as this helmet blazed: Had not the injurious king our friendship lost, Yon ample trench had buried half her (Myrmidons) host.

No camps, no bulwarks now the Trojans fear, Those are not dreadful, no Achilles there; No longer flames the lance of Tydeus' son; No more your general calls his (son) heroes on: Hector, alone, I hear;

his (Hector) dreadful breath Commands your slaughter, or proclaims your death. Yet now, Patroclus, issue to the plain: Now save the ships, the rising fires restrain, And give the Greeks to visit Greece again.
