Who trusts his (Hector) fame and honours in thy hand, And from thy deeds expects the Achaian host Shall render back the beauteous maid he (Hector) lost: Rage uncontroll'd through all the hostile crew, But touch not Hector, Hector is my due.

But heed my words, and mark a friend's command, Though Jove in thunder should command the war, Be just, consult my glory, and forbear.

The fleet once saved, desist from further chase, Nor lead to Ilion's walls the Grecian race; Some adverse god thy rashness may destroy; Some god, like Phoebus, ever kind to Troy.

Let Greece, redeem'd from this destructive strait, Do her (thy) own work; and leave the rest to fate. O! would to all the immortal powers above, Apollo, Pallas, and almighty Jove!

That not one Trojan might be left alive, And not a Greek of all the race survive: Might only we the vast destruction shun, And only we destroy the accursed town!'' (friend)

the sounding storm sustain'd, So thick the darts an iron tempest rain'd: On his (almighty) tired arm the weighty buckler hung; His (almighty) hollow helm with falling javelins rung; His (almighty) breath, in quick short pantings, comes and goes; And painful sweat from all his (almighty) members flows.

Such conference held the chiefs; while on the strand Great Jove with conquest crown'd the Trojan band. Ajax no more Spent and o'erpower'd, he (almighty) barely breathes at most;

Yet scarce an army stirs him (almighty) from his (almighty) post; Dangers on dangers all around him (almighty) glow, And toil to toil, and woe succeeds to woe.

Stern Hector waved his (Hector) sword, and standing near, Where furious Ajax plied his (Hector) ashen spear, Full on the lance a stroke so justly sped, That the broad falchion lopp'd its brazen head; His (Hector) pointless spear the warrior shakes in vain; The brazen head falls sounding on the plain.

Say, Muses, throned above the starry frame, How first the navy blazed with Trojan flame? Great Ajax saw, and own'd the hand divine; Confessing Jove, and trembling at the sign, Warn'd he (Great) retreats.

Then swift from all sides pour The hissing brands; thick streams the fiery shower; O'er the high stern the curling volumes rise, And sheets of rolling smoke involve the skies.

Divine Achilles view'd the rising flames, And smote his (Achilles) thigh, and thus aloud exclaims:

``Arm, arm, Patroclus! Lo, the blaze aspires!

Arm, ere our vessels catch the spreading flame; Arm, ere the Grecians be no more a name; I haste to bring the troops.'' (Divine Achilles)

--The hero said;

He (hero) cased his (hero) limbs in brass; and first around His (hero) manly legs, with silver buckles bound The clasping greaves; then to his (hero) breast applies The flaming cuirass of a thousand dyes; Emblazed with studs of gold his (hero) falchion shone

In the rich belt, as in a starry zone: Achilles' shield his (hero) ample shoulders spread, Achilles' helmet nodded o'er his (hero) head:

The glowing ocean reddens with the fires. The friend with ardour and with joy obey'd. Adorn'd in all his (hero) terrible array,

, Pelides' javelin stands, Not to be poised but by Pelides' hands: From Pelion's shady brow the plant entire Old Chiron rent, and shaped it for his (hero) sire; Whose son's great arm alone the weapon wields, The death of heroes, and the dread of fields.

He (hero) flash'd around intolerable day. Alone untouch'd -LSB-Illustration: Buckles.-RSB- Buckles. The brave Automedon -LRB-an honour'd name, The second to his (hero) lord in love and fame,

In peace his (hero) friend, and partner of the war-RRB- The winged coursers harness'd to the car; Xanthus and Balius, of immortal breed, Sprung from the wind, and like the wind in speed.

Whom the wing'd harpy, swift Podarge, bore, By Zephyr pregnant on the breezy shore: Swift Pedasus was added to their side, -LRB-Once great Aetion's, now Achilles' pride-RRB-

Who, like in strength, in swiftness, and in grace, A mortal courser match'd the immortal race. Achilles speeds from tent to tent, and warms His (Achilles) hardy Myrmidons to blood and arms.

All breathing death, around the chief they stand, A grim, terrific, formidable band: Grim as voracious wolves, that seek the springs-LRB-244-RRB-

When scalding thirst their burning bowels wrings; When some tall stag, fresh-slaughtered in the wood, Has drench'd their wide insatiate throats with blood, To the black fount they rush, a hideous throng, With paunch distended, and with lolling tongue, Fire fills their eye, their black jaws belch the gore, And gorged with slaughter still they thirst for more.

Like furious, rush'd the Myrmidonian crew, Such their dread strength, and such their deathful view. High in the midst the great Achilles stands, Directs their order, and the war commands.

He (Achilles), loved of Jove, had launch'd for Ilion's shores Full fifty vessels, mann'd with fifty oars: Five chosen leaders the fierce bands obey, Himself supreme in valour, as in sway.

First march'd Menestheus, of celestial birth, Derived from thee, whose waters wash the earth, Divine Sperchius! Jove-descended flood! A mortal mother mixing with a god.

Such was Menestheus, but miscall'd by fame The son of Borus, that espoused the dame. Eudorus next; whom Polymele the gay, Famed in the graceful dance, produced to-day.

Her (mother), sly Cellenius loved: on her (mother) would gaze, As with swift step she (mother) form'd the running maze: To her (mother) high chamber from Diana's quire, The god pursued her (mother), urged, and crown'd his (god) fire.

Strong Echecleus, bless'd in all those charms That pleased a god, succeeded to her (mother) arms; Not conscious of those loves, long hid from fame, With gifts of price he (god) sought and won the dame; Her (mother) secret offspring to her (mother) sire she (mother) bare; Her (mother) sire caress'd him (sire) with a parent's care.

Pisander follow'd; matchless in his (sire) art To wing the spear, or aim the distant dart; No hand so sure of all the Emathian line, Or if a surer, great Patroclus!

The son confess'd his (son) father's heavenly race, And heir'd his (son) mother's swiftness in the chase. thine. The fourth by Phoenix' grave command was graced, Laerces' valiant offspring led the last.

Soon as Achilles with superior care Had call'd the chiefs, and order'd all the war, This stern remembrance to his (Achilles) troops he (Achilles) gave:

``Ye far-famed Myrmidons, ye fierce and brave!

Think with what threats you dared the Trojan throng, Think what reproach these ears endured so long; `Stern son of Peleus, -LRB-thus ye used to say,

Whose rage defrauds us of so famed a field: If that dire fury must for ever burn, What make we here?

While restless, raging, in your ships you lay-RRB- Oh nursed with gall, unknowing how to yield; Return, ye chiefs, return!' Such were your words--

Now, warriors! grieve no more, Lo there the Trojans; bathe your swords in gore! This day shall give you all your soul demands, Glut all your hearts, and weary all your hands!'' (he)

Thus while he (your) roused the fire in every breast, Close and more close the listening cohorts press'd; Ranks wedged in ranks; of arms a steely ring Still grows, and spreads, and thickens round the king.

As when a circling wall the builder forms, Of strength defensive against wind and storms, Compacted stones the thickening work compose, And round him (builder) wide the rising structure grows:

So helm to helm, and crest to crest they throng, Shield urged on shield, and man drove man along; Thick, undistinguish'd plumes, together join'd, Float in one sea, and wave before the wind.

Far o'er the rest in glittering pomp appear, There bold Automedon, Patroclus here; Brothers in arms, with equal fury fired; Two friends, two bodies with one soul inspired.

But mindful of the gods, Achilles went To the rich coffer in his (Achilles) shady tent; There lay on heaps his (Achilles) various garments roll'd, And costly furs, and carpets stiff with gold, -LRB-The presents of the silver-footed dame-RRB-

-LSB-Illustration: DIANA.-RSB- DIANA. From thence he (Achilles) took a bowl, of antique frame, Which never man had stained with ruddy wine, Nor raised in offerings to the power divine,

But Peleus' son; and Peleus' son to none Had raised in offerings, but to Jove alone. This tinged with sulphur, sacred first to flame, He (son) purged; and wash'd it in the running stream.

Then cleansed his (son) hands; and fixing for a space His (son) eyes on heaven, his (son) feet upon the place Of sacrifice, the purple draught he (son) pour'd

Forth in the midst; and thus the god implored:

``O thou supreme! high-throned all height above! O great Pelasgic, Dodonaean Jove!

Their feet unwash'd, their slumbers on the ground; Who hear, from rustling oaks, thy dark decrees; And catch the fates, low-whispered in the breeze;-RRB-

Who `midst surrounding frosts, and vapours chill, Presid`st on bleak Dodona's vocal hill: -LRB-Whose groves the Selli, race austere! surround, Hear, as of old!

Lo, to the dangers of the fighting field The best, the dearest of my friends, I yield, Though still determined, to my ships confined; Patroclus gone, I stay but half behind.

Oh! be his (Dodona) guard thy providential care, Confirm his (Dodona) heart, and string his (Dodona) arm to war: Press'd by his (Dodona) single force let Hector see His (Hector) fame in arms not owing all to me.

But when the fleets are saved from foes and fire, Let him (Hector) with conquest and renown retire; Preserve his (Hector) arms, preserve his (Hector) social train, And safe return him (Hector) to these eyes again!

Great Jove consents to half the chief's request, But heaven's eternal doom denies the rest; To free the fleet was granted to his (Great) prayer; His (Great) safe return, the winds dispersed in air.

Thou gav`st, at Thetis' prayer, Glory to me, and to the Greeks despair. '' (the god)

Back to his (Great) tent the stern Achilles flies, And waits the combat with impatient eyes.

As wasps, provoked by children in their play, Pour from their mansions by the broad highway, In swarms the guiltless traveller engage, Whet all their stings, and call forth all their rage:

Meanwhile the troops beneath Patroclus' care, Invade the Trojans, and commence the war. All rise in arms, and, with a general cry,

Assert their waxen domes, and buzzing progeny. Thus from the tents the fervent legion swarms, So loud their clamours, and so keen their arms:

Be mindful of your deeds in ancient days; Your godlike master let your acts proclaim, And add new glories to his (master) mighty name.

Their rising rage Patroclus' breath inspires, Who thus inflames them with heroic fires:

``O warriors, partners of Achilles' praise! Think your Achilles sees you fight: be brave, And humble the proud monarch whom you save.

'' (Patroclus)

Joyful they heard, and kindling as he (monarch) spoke, Flew to the fleet, involved in fire and smoke. From shore to shore the doubling shouts resound, The hollow ships return a deeper sound.

The war stood still, and all around them gazed, When great Achilles' shining armour blazed: Troy saw, and thought the dread Achilles nigh, At once they see, they tremble, and they fly.

Close to the stern of that famed ship which bore Unbless'd Protesilaus to Ilion's shore, The great Paeonian, bold Pyrechmes stood; -LRB-Who led his (Achilles) bands from Axius' winding flood;-RRB- His (Achilles) shoulder-blade receives the fatal wound; The groaning warrior pants upon the ground.

Then first thy spear, divine Patroclus! flew, Where the war raged, and where the tumult grew. His (Achilles) troops, that see their country's glory slain, Fly diverse, scatter'd o'er the distant plain.

Patroclus' arm forbids the spreading fires, And from the half-burn'd ship proud Troy retires; Clear'd from the smoke the joyful navy lies; In heaps on heaps the foe tumultuous flies; Triumphant Greece her (warrior) rescued decks ascends, And loud acclaim the starry region rends.

So when thick clouds enwrap the mountain's head, O'er heaven's expanse like one black ceiling spread; Sudden the Thunderer, with a flashing ray, Bursts through the darkness, and lets down the day: The hills shine out, the rocks in prospect rise, And streams, and vales, and forests, strike the eyes; The smiling scene wide opens to the sight, And all the unmeasured ether flames with light.

But Troy repulsed, and scatter'd o'er the plains, Forced from the navy, yet the fight maintains. Now every Greek some hostile hero slew, But still the foremost, bold Patroclus flew:

Sharp in his (hero) thigh he (hero) felt the piercing wound; The brazen-pointed spear, with vigour thrown, The thigh transfix'd, and broke the brittle bone: Headlong he (hero) fell.

As Areilycus had turn'd him (hero) round, Next, Thoas was thy chance; Thy breast, unarm'd, received the Spartan lance. Phylides' dart -LRB-as Amphidus drew nigh-RRB-

His (hero) blow prevented, and transpierced his (hero) thigh, Tore all the brawn, and rent the nerves away; In darkness, and in death, the warrior lay.

In equal arms two sons of Nestor stand, And two bold brothers of the Lycian band: By great Antilochus, Atymnius dies, Pierced in the flank, lamented youth!

he (Nestor) lies, Kind Maris, bleeding in his (Maris) brother's wound, Defends the breathless carcase on the ground; Furious he (Maris) flies, his (Maris) murderer to engage:

But godlike Thrasimed prevents his (Maris) rage, Between his (Maris) arm and shoulder aims a blow; His (Maris) arm falls spouting on the dust below: He (Maris) sinks, with endless darkness cover'd o'er: And vents his (Maris) soul, effused with gushing gore.

Slain by two brothers, thus two brothers bleed, Sarpedon's friends, Amisodarus' seed; Amisodarus, who, by Furies led, The bane of men,

abhorr'd Chimaera bred; Skill'd in the dart in vain, his (Maris) sons expire, And pay the forfeit of their guilty sire. Stopp'd

in the tumult Cleobulus lies, Beneath Oileus' arm, a living prize; A living prize not long the Trojan stood; The thirsty falchion drank his (Maris) reeking blood:

Amid the ranks, with mutual thirst of fame, Lycon the brave, and fierce Peneleus came; In vain their javelins at each other flew, Now, met in arms, their eager swords they drew.

Plunged in his (Maris) throat the smoking weapon lies; Black death, and fate unpitying, seal his (Maris) eyes. On the plumed crest of his (Maris) Boeotian foe

The daring Lycon aim'd a noble blow; The sword broke short; but his (Maris), Peneleus sped Full on the juncture of the neck and head:

O'ertaken Neamas by Merion bleeds, Pierced through the shoulder as he (Maris) mounts his (Maris) steeds; Back from the car he (Maris) tumbles to the ground: His (Maris) swimming eyes eternal shades surround.

The head, divided by a stroke so just, Hung by the skin; the body sunk to dust. Next Erymas was doom'd his (Hung) fate to feel, His (Hung) open'd mouth received the Cretan steel:

Beneath the brain the point a passage tore, Crash'd the thin bones, and drown'd the teeth in gore: His (Hung) mouth, his (Hung) eyes, his (Hung) nostrils, pour a flood; He (Hung) sobs his (Hung) soul out in the gush of blood.

As when the flocks neglected by the swain, Or kids, or lambs, lie scatter'd o'er the plain, A troop of wolves the unguarded charge survey, And rend the trembling, unresisting prey:

Thus on the foe the Greeks impetuous came; Troy fled, unmindful of her (Hung) former fame. But still at Hector godlike Ajax aim'd, Still, pointed at his (Hector) breast, his (Hector) javelin flamed.

The Trojan chief, experienced in the field, O'er his (Hector) broad shoulders spread the massy shield, Observed the storm of darts the Grecians pour,

And on his (Hector) buckler caught the ringing shower: He (Hector) sees for Greece the scale of conquest rise, Yet stops, and turns, and saves his (Hector) loved allies.

As when the hand of Jove a tempest forms, And rolls the cloud to blacken heaven with storms, Dark o'er the fields the ascending vapour flies, And shades the sun, and blots the golden skies: So from the ships, along the dusky plain, Dire Flight and Terror drove the Trojan train.

The fiery coursers forced their lord away: While far behind his (lord) Trojans fall confused; Wedged in the trench, in one vast carnage bruised: Chariots on chariots roll: the clashing spokes Shock; while the madding steeds break short their yokes.

Even Hector fled; through heads of disarray In vain they labour up the steepy mound; Their charioteers lie foaming on the ground.

Fierce on the rear, with shouts Patroclus flies; Tumultuous clamour fills the fields and skies; Thick drifts of dust involve their rapid flight; Clouds rise on clouds, and heaven is snatch'd from sight.

Loud o'er the rout was heard the victor's cry, Where the war bleeds, and where the thickest die, Where horse and arms, and chariots he (victor) o'erthrown, And bleeding heroes under axles groan.

The affrighted steeds their dying lords cast down, Scour o'er the fields, and stretch to reach the town. No stop, no check, the steeds of Peleus knew: From bank to bank the immortal coursers flew.

High-bounding o'er the fosse, the whirling car Smokes through the ranks, o'ertakes the flying war, And thunders after Hector; Hector flies, Patroclus shakes his (Hector) lance; but fate denies.

Not with less noise, with less impetuous force, The tide of Trojans urge their desperate course, Than when in autumn Jove his (Hector) fury pours, And earth is loaden with incessant showers; -LRB-When guilty mortals break the eternal laws, Or judges, bribed, betray the righteous cause;-RRB-

From their deep beds he (Hector) bids the rivers rise, And opens all the flood-gates of the skies: The impetuous torrents from their hills obey, Whole fields are drown'd, and mountains swept away; Loud roars the deluge till it meets the main; And trembling man sees all his (man) labours vain!

And now the chief -LRB-the foremost troops repell'd-RRB- Back to the ships his (chief) destined progress held, Bore down half Troy in his (chief) resistless way, And forced the routed ranks to stand the day.

Between the space where silver Simois flows, Where lay the fleets, and where the rampires rose, All grim in dust and blood Patroclus stands, And turns the slaughter on the conquering bands.

Thestor was next, who saw the chief appear, And fell the victim of his (victim) coward fear; Shrunk up he (victim) sat, with wild and haggard eye, Nor stood to combat, nor had force to fly;

First Pronous died beneath his (victim) fiery dart, Which pierced below the shield his (victim) valiant heart. Patroclus mark'd him (victim) as he (victim) shunn'd the war, And with unmanly tremblings shook the car, And dropp'd the flowing reins.

As on a rock that overhangs the main, An angler, studious of the line and cane, Some mighty fish draws panting to the shore: Not with less ease the barbed javelin bore The gaping dastard; as the spear was shook, He (angler) fell, and life his (angler) heartless breast forsook.

Him (angler) `twixt the jaws, The javelin sticks, and from the chariot draws. Next on Eryalus he (angler) flies; a stone, Large as a rock, was by his (angler) fury thrown:

Full on his (angler) crown the ponderous fragment flew, And burst the helm, and cleft the head in two: Prone to the ground the breathless warrior fell, And death involved him (warrior) with the shades of hell.

Then low in dust Epaltes, Echius, lie; Ipheas, Evippus, Polymelus, die; Amphoterus and Erymas succeed; And last Tlepolemus and Pyres bleed.

Where'er he (warrior) moves, the growing slaughters spread In heaps on heaps a monument of dead. When now Sarpedon his (warrior) brave friends beheld Grovelling in dust, and gasping on the field,

With this reproach his (warrior) flying host he (warrior) warms:

``Oh stain to honour! oh disgrace to arms! Forsake, inglorious, the contended plain; This hand unaided shall the war sustain:

The task be mine this hero's strength to try, Who mows whole troops, and makes an army fly. '' (he)

He (hero) spake: and, speaking, leaps from off the car: Patroclus lights, and sternly waits the war.

As when two vultures on the mountain's height Stoop with resounding pinions to the fight; They cuff, they tear, they raise a screaming cry;

The desert echoes, and the rocks reply: The warriors thus opposed in arms, engage With equal clamours, and with equal rage.

Jove view'd the combat: whose event foreseen, He (hero) thus bespoke his (hero) sister and his (hero) queen:

``The hour draws on; the destinies ordain,-LRB-245-RRB-

My godlike son shall press the Phrygian plain: Already on the verge of death he (son) stands, His (son) life is owed to fierce Patroclus' hands,

Say, shall I snatch him (son) from impending fate, And send him (son) safe to Lycia, distant far From all the dangers and the toils of war; Or to his (son) doom my bravest offspring yield, And fatten, with celestial blood, the field?'' (queen)

What passions in a parent's breast debate! Then thus the goddess with the radiant eyes:

``What words are these, O sovereign of the skies!

Short is the date prescribed to mortal man; Shall Jove for one extend the narrow span, Whose bounds were fix'd before his (Short) race began?

How many sons of gods, foredoom'd to death, Before proud Ilion must resign their breath! Were thine exempt, debate would rise above, And murmuring powers condemn their partial Jove.

Give the bold chief a glorious fate in fight; And when the ascending soul has wing'd her (goddess) flight, Let Sleep and Death convey, by thy command,

His (chief) friends and people, to his (chief) future praise, A marble tomb and pyramid shall raise, And lasting honours to his (chief) ashes give; His (chief) fame -LRB-'tis all the dead can have-RRB- shall live.

The breathless body to his (chief) native land. '' (the goddess these)

She (goddess) said: the cloud-compeller, overcome, Assents to fate, and ratifies the doom. Then touch'd with grief, the weeping heavens distill'd

The god, his (god) eyes averting from the plain, Laments his (god) son, predestined to be slain, Far from the Lycian shores, his (god) happy native reign.

Now met in arms, the combatants appear; Each heaved the shield, and poised the lifted spear; From strong Patroclus' hand the javelin fled, And pass'd the groin of valiant Thrasymed; The nerves unbraced no more his (god) bulk sustain, He (god) falls, and falling bites the bloody plain.

The first aloof with erring fury flew, The next transpierced Achilles' mortal steed, The generous Pedasus of Theban breed: Fix'd in the shoulder's joint, he (Achilles) reel'd around, Roll'd in the bloody dust, and paw'd the slippery ground.

His (Achilles) sudden fall the entangled harness broke; Each axle crackled, and the chariot shook: When bold Automedon, to disengage The starting coursers, and restrain their rage, Divides the traces with his (Achilles) sword, and freed The encumbered chariot from the dying steed: The rest move on, obedient to the rein: The car rolls slowly o'er the dusty plain.

The towering chiefs to fiercer fight advance: And first Sarpedon whirl'd his (Achilles) weighty lance, Which o'er the warrior's shoulder took its course, And spent in empty air its dying force.

A shower of blood o'er all the fatal field: Two sounding darts the Lycian leader threw: Not so Patroclus' never-erring dart; Aim'd

at his (leader) breast it pierced a mortal part, Where the strong fibres bind the solid heart. Then as the mountain oak, or poplar tall, Or pine -LRB-fit mast for some great admiral-RRB-

Nods to the axe, till with a groaning sound It sinks, and spreads its honours on the ground, Thus fell the king; and laid on earth supine,

Before his (king) chariot stretch'd his (king) form divine: He (king) grasp'd the dust distain'd with streaming gore, And, pale in death, lay groaning on the shore.

So lies a bull beneath the lion's paws, While the grim savage grinds with foamy jaws The trembling limbs, and sucks the smoking blood; Deep groans, and hollow roars, rebellow through the wood.

The dying chief address'd his (chief) last command;

``Glaucus, be bold; thy task be first to dare The glorious dangers of destructive war, To lead my troops, to combat at their head, Incite the living, and supply the dead.

Then to the leader of the Lycian band Tell them, I charged them with my latest breath Not unrevenged to bear Sarpedon's death.

Then as a friend, and as a warrior fight; Defend my body, conquer in my right: That, taught by great examples, all may try Like thee to vanquish, or like me to die.

What grief, what shame, must Glaucus undergo, If these spoil'd arms adorn a Grecian foe! '' (chief)

He (foe) ceased; the Fates suppress'd

The prostrate prince, and on his (foe) bosom trod; Then drew the weapon from his (foe) panting heart, The reeking fibres clinging to the dart; From the wide wound gush'd out a stream of blood, And the soul issued in the purple flood.

his (foe) labouring breath, And his (foe) eyes darken'd with the shades of death. The insulting victor with disdain bestrode His (victor) flying steeds the Myrmidons detain, Unguided now, their mighty master slain.

His (master) painful arm, yet useless with the smart Inflicted late by Teucer's deadly dart, Supported on his (master) better hand he (master) stay'd:

he (master) pray'd:

``All-seeing monarch! whether Lycia's coast, Or sacred Ilion, thy bright presence boast, Powerful alike to ease the wretch's smart

All-impotent of aid, transfix'd with grief, Unhappy Glaucus heard the dying chief: To Phoebus then -LRB-'twas all he (chief) could-RRB- ; O hear me!

That thrills my arm, and shoots through every vein, I stand unable to sustain the spear, And sigh, at distance from the glorious war.

god of every healing art! Lo! stiff with clotted blood, and pierced with pain, Low in the dust is great Sarpedon laid, Nor Jove vouchsafed his (god) hapless offspring aid;

But thou, O god of health! thy succour lend, To guard the relics of my slaughter'd friend: For thou, though distant, canst restore my might, To head my Lycians, and support the fight.

'' (he)

Apollo heard; and, suppliant as he (friend) stood, His (friend) heavenly hand restrain'd the flux of blood; He (friend) drew the dolours from the wounded part, And breathed a spirit in his (friend) rising heart.

First to the fight his (friend) native troops he (friend) warms, Then loudly calls on Troy's vindictive arms; With ample strides he (Troy) stalks from place to place;

Renew'd by art divine, the hero stands, And owns the assistance of immortal hands. Now fires Agenor, now Polydamas: Ćneas next, and Hector he (Hector) accosts; Inflaming thus the rage of all their hosts.

'' What thoughts, regardless chief! thy breast employ? Oh too forgetful of the friends of Troy! Those generous friends, who, from their country far, Breathe their brave souls out in another's war.

In action valiant, and in council wise, Who guarded right, and kept his (Hector) people free; To all his (Hector) Lycians lost, and lost to thee!

See! where in dust the great Sarpedon lies, Stretch'd by Patroclus' arm on yonder plains, O save from hostile rage his (Hector) loved remains!

Ah let not Greece his (Hector) conquer'd trophies boast, Nor on his (Hector) corse revenge her (their) heroes lost!'' He (Hector) spoke: each leader in his (Hector) grief partook: Troy, at the loss, through all her (their) legions shook.

At once his (Hector) country's pillar, and their own; A chief, who led to Troy's beleaguer'd wall A host of heroes, and outshined them all.

Transfix'd with deep regret, they view o'erthrown Fired, they rush on; first Hector seeks the foes, And with superior vengeance greatly glows.

But o'er the dead the fierce Patroclus stands, And rousing Ajax, roused the listening bands:

``Heroes, be men; be what you were before; Or weigh the great occasion, and be more.

The chief who taught our lofty walls to yield, Lies pale in death, extended on the field. To guard his (chief) body Troy in numbers flies; Tis half the glory to maintain our prize.

The heroes kindle at his (chief) fierce command; The martial squadrons close on either hand: Here Troy and Lycia charge with loud alarms, Thessalia there, and Greece, oppose their arms.

Haste, strip his (chief) arms, the slaughter round him (chief) spread, And send the living Lycians to the dead. '' (the bands)

With horrid shouts they circle round the slain; The clash of armour rings o'er all the plain.

Great Jove, to swell the horrors of the fight, O'er the fierce armies pours pernicious night, And round his (chief) son confounds the warring hosts, His (chief) fate ennobling with a crowd of ghosts.

Now Greece gives way, and great Epigeus falls; Agacleus' son, from Budium's lofty walls; Who chased for murder thence a suppliant came To Peleus, and the silver-footed dame; Now sent to Troy, Achilles' arms to aid, He (Achilles) pays due vengeance to his (Achilles) kinsman's shade.

Soon as his (Achilles) luckless hand had touch'd the dead, A rock's large fragment thunder'd on his (Achilles) head; Hurl'd by Hectorean force it cleft in twain

His (Achilles) shatter'd helm, and stretch'd him (Achilles) o'er the slain. Fierce to the van of fight Patroclus came, And, like an eagle darting at his (Achilles) game,

What grief thy heart, what fury urged thy hand, O generous Greek! when with full vigour thrown, At Sthenelaus flew the weighty stone, Which sunk him (Achilles) to the dead: when Troy, too near That arm, drew back; and Hector learn'd to fear.

Far as an able hand a lance can throw, Or at the lists, or at the fighting foe; So far the Trojans from their lines retired; Till Glaucus, turning, all the rest inspired.

Sprung on the Trojan and the Lycian band. Then Bathyclaeus fell beneath his (foe) rage, The only hope of Chalcon's trembling age; Wide o'er the land was stretch'd

his (foe) large domain, With stately seats, and riches blest in vain: Him (foe), bold with youth, and eager to pursue The flying Lycians, Glaucus met and slew;

The Achaians sorrow for their heroes slain; With conquering shouts the Trojans shake the plain, And crowd to spoil the dead: the Greeks oppose; An iron circle round the carcase grows.

Pierced through the bosom with a sudden wound, He (foe) fell, and falling made the fields resound. Then brave Laogonus resign'd his (foe) breath, Despatch'd by Merion to the shades of death

: On Ida's holy hill he (foe) made abode, The priest of Jove, and honour'd like his (foe) god. Between the jaw and ear the javelin went;

Who stooping forward from the death withdrew; The lance hiss'd harmless o'er his (foe) covering shield, And trembling struck, and rooted in the field; There yet scarce spent, it quivers on the plain, Sent by the great Aeneas' arm in vain.

The soul, exhaling, issued at the vent. His (Aeneas) spear Aeneas at the victor threw, '' Swift as thou art -LRB-the raging hero cries-RRB-

And skill'd in dancing to dispute the prize, My spear, the destined passage had it found, Had fix'd thy active vigour to the ground.''

``O valiant leader of the Dardan host! -LRB-Insulted Merion thus retorts the boast-RRB- Strong as you are, 'tis mortal force you trust, An arm as strong may stretch thee in the dust.

And if to this my lance thy fate be given, Vain are thy vaunts; success is still from heaven: This, instant, sends thee down to Pluto's coast; Mine is the glory, his (leader) thy parting ghost.'' (unknown)

With words to combat, ill befits the brave; Not empty boasts the sons of Troy repel, Your swords must plunge them to the shades of hell.

``O friend -LRB-Menoetius' son this answer gave-RRB- To speak, beseems the council; but to dare In glorious action, is the task of war.

This said, Patroclus to the battle flies; Great Merion follows, and new shouts arise: Shields, helmets rattle, as the warriors close; And thick and heavy sounds the storm of blows.

As through the shrilling vale, or mountain ground, The labours of the woodman's axe resound; Blows following blows are heard re-echoing wide, While crackling forests fall on every side: Thus echoed all the fields with loud alarms, So fell the warriors, and so rung their arms.

Now great Sarpedon on the sandy shore, His (woodman) heavenly form defaced with dust and gore, And stuck with darts by warring heroes shed, Lies undistinguish'd from the vulgar dead.

His (woodman) long-disputed corse the chiefs enclose, On every side the busy combat grows; Thick as beneath some shepherd's thatch'd abode -LRB-The pails high foaming with a milky flood-RRB-

'' (Jove)

The buzzing flies, a persevering train, Incessant swarm, and chased return again. Jove view'd the combat with a stern survey, And eyes that flash'd intolerable day.

, his (shepherd) breast debates The vengeance due, and meditates the fates: Whether to urge their prompt effect, and call The force of Hector to Patroclus' fall, This instant see his (Hector) short-lived trophies won, And stretch him (Hector) breathless on his (Hector) slaughter'd son; Or yet, with many a soul's untimely flight, Augment the fame and horror of the fight.

Fix'd on the field his (Hector) sight To crown Achilles' valiant friend with praise At length he (Hector) dooms; and, that his (Hector) last of days Shall set in glory, bids him (Hector) drive the foe;

Then Hector's mind he (Hector) fills with dire dismay; He (Hector) mounts his (Hector) car, and calls his (Hector) hosts away; Sunk with Troy's heavy fates, he (Hector) sees decline The scales of Jove, and pants with awe divine.

Then, nor before, the hardy Lycians fled, And left their monarch with the common dead: Around, in heaps on heaps, a dreadful wall Of carnage rises, as the heroes fall.

Nor unattended see the shades below. -LRB-So Jove decreed!-RRB- At length the Greeks obtain The prize contested, and despoil the slain.

The radiant arms are by Patroclus borne; Patroclus' ships the glorious spoils adorn. Then thus to Phoebus, in the realms above, Spoke from his (monarch) throne the cloud-compelling Jove:

on the Phrygian plain, And from the fight convey Sarpedon slain; Then bathe his (monarch) body in the crystal flood, With dust dishonour'd, and deform'd with blood; O'er all his (monarch) limbs ambrosial odours shed, And with celestial robes adorn the dead.

They to his (monarch) friends the immortal charge shall bear; His (monarch) friends a tomb and pyramid shall rear: What honour mortals after death receive, Those unavailing honours we may give!''

``Descend, my Phoebus! Those rites discharged, his (monarch) sacred corse bequeath To the soft arms of silent Sleep and Death. -LSB-Illustration: SLEEP AND DEATH CONVEYING THE BODY OF SARPEDON TO LYCIA.-RSB-

Apollo bows, and from mount Ida's height, Swift to the field precipitates his (Swift) flight; Thence from the war the breathless hero bore, Veil'd in a cloud, to silver Simois' shore; There bathed his (hero) honourable wounds, and dress'd His (hero) manly members in the immortal vest; And with perfumes of sweet ambrosial dews Restores his (hero) freshness, and his (hero) form renews.

Then Sleep and Death, two twins of winged race, Of matchless swiftness, but of silent pace, Received Sarpedon, at the god's command,

And in a moment reach'd the Lycian land; The corse amidst his (god) weeping friends they laid, Where endless honours wait the sacred shade.

SLEEP AND DEATH CONVEYING THE BODY OF SARPEDON TO LYCIA. Meanwhile Patroclus pours along the plains, With foaming coursers, and with loosen'd reins.

Fierce on the Trojan and the Lycian crew, Ah blind to fate! thy headlong fury flew Against what fate and powerful Jove ordain

For he (god), the god, whose counsels uncontroll'd Dismay the mighty, and confound the bold; The god who gives, resumes, and orders all, He (god) urged thee on, and urged thee on to fall.

Who last beneath thy vengeance press'd the plain; When heaven itself thy fatal fury led, And call'd to fill the number of the dead?

, Vain was thy friend's command, thy courage vain. Who first, brave hero! by that arm was slain, Adrestus first; Autonous then succeeds; Echeclus follows; next young Megas bleeds, Epistor, Melanippus, bite the ground;

Now Troy had stoop'd beneath his (hero) matchless power, But flaming Phoebus kept the sacred tower Thrice at the battlements Patroclus strook;-LRB-246-RRB-

His (hero) blazing aegis thrice Apollo shook; He (hero) tried the fourth; when, bursting from the cloud, A more than mortal voice was heard aloud.

The slaughter, Elasus and Mulius crown'd: Then sunk Pylartes to eternal night; The rest, dispersing, trust their fates to flight. '' (Patroclus)

Patroclus! cease; this heaven-defended wall Defies thy lance; not fated yet to fall; Thy friend, thy greater far, it shall withstand

, Troy shall not stoop even to Achilles' hand. '' So spoke the god who darts celestial fires; The Greek obeys him (god), and with awe retires.

While Hector, checking at the Scaean gates His (Hector) panting coursers, in his (Hector) breast debates, Or in the field his (Hector) forces to employ, Or draw the troops within the walls of Troy.

Thus while he (Hector) thought, beside him (Hector) Phoebus stood, In Asius' shape, who reigned by Sangar's flood; -LRB-Thy brother, Hecuba! from Dymas sprung, A valiant warrior, haughty, bold, and young;-RRB-

Thus he (warrior) accosts him (warrior). '' What a shameful sight! God! is it Hector that forbears the fight? Were thine my vigour

this successful spear Should soon convince thee of so false a fear. Turn thee, ah turn thee to the field of fame, And in Patroclus' blood efface thy shame.

Perhaps Apollo shall thy arms succeed, And heaven ordains him (God) by thy lance to bleed. '' So spoke the inspiring god; then took his (god) flight, And plunged amidst the tumult of the fight.

He (god) bids Cebrion drive the rapid car; The lash resounds, the coursers rush to war. The god the Grecians' sinking souls depress'd, And pour'd swift spirits through each Trojan breast.

Patroclus lights, impatient for the fight; A spear his (god) left, a stone employs his (god) right: With all his (god) nerves he (god) drives it at the foe.

Pointed above, and rough and gross below: The falling ruin crush'd Cebrion's head, The lawless offspring of king Priam's bed; His (king) front, brows, eyes, one undistinguish'd wound

: The bursting balls drop sightless to the ground. The charioteer, while yet he (king) held the rein, Struck from the car, falls headlong on the plain.

To the dark shades the soul unwilling glides, While the proud victor thus his (victor) fall derides. '' Good heaven! what active feats yon artist shows!

What skilful divers are our Phrygian foes! Mark with what ease they sink into the sand! Pity that all their practice is by land!''

Then rushing sudden on his (Mark) prostrate prize, To spoil the carcase fierce Patroclus flies: Swift as a lion, terrible and bold

, That sweeps the field, depopulates the fold; Pierced through the dauntless heart, then tumbles slain, And from his (Swift) fatal courage finds his (Swift) bane.

Thus for some slaughter'd hind, with equal rage, Two lordly rulers of the wood engage; Stung with fierce hunger, each the prey invades, And echoing roars rebellow through the shades.

Stern Hector fastens on the warrior's head, And by the foot Patroclus drags the dead: While all around, confusion, rage, and fright, Mix the contending hosts in mortal fight.

At once bold Hector leaping from his (Hector) car, Defends the body, and provokes the war. So pent by hills, the wild winds roar aloud

In the deep bosom of some gloomy wood; Leaves, arms, and trees, aloft in air are blown, The broad oaks crackle, and the Sylvans groan; This way and that, the rattling thicket bends, And the whole forest in one crash descends.

on darts, now round the carcase ring; Now flights of arrows bounding from the string: Stones follow stones; some clatter on the fields, Some hard, and heavy, shake the sounding shields.

Not with less noise, with less tumultuous rage, In dreadful shock the mingled hosts engage. Darts shower'd But where the rising whirlwind clouds the plains, Sunk in soft dust the mighty chief remains, And,

Now flaming from the zenith, Sol had driven His (Sol) fervid orb through half the vault of heaven; While on each host with equal tempests fell The showering darts, and numbers sank to hell.

stretch'd in death, forgets the guiding reins! But when his (Sol) evening wheels o'erhung the main, Glad conquest rested on the Grecian train.

Then from amidst the tumult and alarms, They draw the conquer'd corse and radiant arms. Then rash Patroclus with new fury glows, And breathing slaughter, pours amid the foes.

Thrice on the press like Mars himself he (Sol) flew, And thrice three heroes at each onset slew. There ends thy glory!

there the Fates untwine The last, black remnant of so bright a line: Apollo dreadful stops thy middle way; Death calls, and heaven allows no longer day!

For lo! the god in dusky clouds enshrined, Approaching dealt a staggering blow behind. The weighty shock his (god) neck and shoulders feel; His (god) eyes flash sparkles, his (god) stunn'd senses reel

In giddy darkness; far to distance flung, His (god) bounding helmet on the champaign rung. Achilles' plume is stain'd with dust and gore;

That plume which never stoop'd to earth before; Long used, untouch'd, in fighting fields to shine, And shade the temples of the mad divine.

Jove dooms it now on Hector's helm to nod; Not long--for fate pursues him (Hector), and the god. His (god) spear in shivers falls; his (god) ample shield Drops from his (god) arm: his (god) baldric strows the field:

Loose is each joint; each nerve with horror shakes; Stupid he (god) stares, and all-assistless stands: Such is the force of more than mortal hands!

The corslet his (god) astonish'd breast forsakes: A Dardan youth there was, well known to fame, From Panthus sprung, Euphorbus was his (god) name;

Famed for the manage of the foaming horse, Skill'd in the dart, and matchless in the course: Full twenty knights he (god) tumbled from the car,

While yet he (god) learn'd his (god) rudiments of war. His (god) venturous spear first drew the hero's gore; He (god) struck, he (god) wounded, but he (god) durst no more.

Nor, though disarm'd, Patroclus' fury stood: But swift withdrew the long-protended wood. And turn'd him (god) short, and herded in the crowd.

Thus, by an arm divine, and mortal spear, Wounded, at once, Patroclus yields to fear, Retires for succour to his (god) social train, And flies the fate, which heaven decreed, in vain.

Stern Hector, as the bleeding chief he (Hector) views, Breaks through the ranks, and his (Hector) retreat pursues: The lance arrests him (Hector) with a mortal wound; He (Hector) falls, earth thunders, and his (Hector) arms resound.

So, scorch'd with heat, along the desert score, The roaming lion meets a bristly boar, Fast by the spring; they both dispute the flood, With flaming eyes, and jaws besmear'd with blood; At length the sovereign savage wins the strife; And the torn boar resigns his (Hector) thirst and life.

With him (Hector) all Greece was sunk; that moment all Her (Hector) yet-surviving heroes seem'd to fall. Patroclus thus, so many chiefs o'erthrown, So many lives effused, expires his (Hector) own.

As dying now at Hector's feet he (Hector) lies, He (Hector) sternly views him (Hector), and triumphant cries:

``Lie there, Patroclus! and with thee, the joy Thy pride once promised, of subverting Troy; The fancied scenes of Ilion wrapt in flames, And thy soft pleasures served with captive dames.

Unthinking man! I fought those towers to free, And guard that beauteous race from lords like thee: But thou a prey to vultures shalt be made; Thy own Achilles cannot lend thee aid;

Though much at parting that great chief might say, And much enjoin thee, this important day. ' Return not, my brave friend -LRB-perhaps he (friend) said-RRB-, Without the bloody arms of Hector dead.'

He (Hector) spoke, Patroclus march'd, and thus he (Hector) sped. '' (him)

Supine, and wildly gazing on the skies, With faint, expiring breath, the chief replies:
``Vain boaster!

cease, and know the powers divine! Jove's and Apollo's is this deed, not thine; To heaven is owed whate'er your own you call, And

heaven itself disarm'd me ere my fall. Had twenty mortals, each thy match in might, Opposed me fairly, they had sunk in fight:

By fate and Phoebus was I first o'erthrown, Euphorbus next; the third mean part thy own. But thou, imperious! hear my latest breath

Insulting man, thou shalt be soon as I; Black fate o'erhangs thee, and thy hour draws nigh; Even now on life's last verge I see thee stand, I see thee fall, and by Achilles' hand.

; The gods inspire it, and it sounds thy death: '' (He)

He (Achilles) faints: the soul unwilling wings her (thee) way, -LRB-The beauteous body left a load of clay-RRB-

Then Hector pausing, as his (Hector) eyes he (Hector) fed On the pale carcase, thus address'd the dead:

``From whence this boding speech, the stern decree Of death denounced, or why denounced to me?

Flits to the lone, uncomfortable coast; A naked, wandering, melancholy ghost! Why not as well Achilles' fate be given To Hector's lance?

Pensive he (Hector) said; then pressing as he (Hector) lay His (Hector) breathless bosom, tore the lance away; And upwards cast the corse: the reeking spear He (Hector) shakes, and charges the bold charioteer.

But swift Automedon with loosen'd reins Rapt in the chariot o'er the distant plains, Far from his (Hector) rage the immortal coursers drove; The immortal coursers were the gift of Jove.

Who knows the will of heaven? '' (he)

-LSB-Illustration: ĆSCULAPIUS.-RSB- ĆSCULAPIUS. BOOK XVII. ARGUMENT. THE SEVENTH BATTLE, FOR THE BODY OF PATROCLUS.--THE ACTS OF MENELAUS.

Menelaus, upon the death of Patroclus, defends his (Menelaus) body from the enemy: Euphorbus, who attempts it, is slain. Hector advancing, Menelaus retires; but soon returns with Ajax, and drives him (Hector) off.

This, Glaucus objects to Hector as a flight, who thereupon puts on the armour he (Hector) had won from Patroclus, and renews the battle.

The Greeks give way, till Ajax rallies them: Aeneas sustains the Trojans. Aeneas and Hector Attempt the chariot of Achilles, which is borne off by Automedon.

The horses of Achilles deplore the loss of Patroclus: Jupiter covers his (Achilles) body with a thick darkness: the noble prayer of Ajax on that occasion.

Menelaus sends Antilochus to Achilles, with the news of Patroclus' death: then returns to the fight, where, though attacked with the utmost fury, he (Menelaus) and Meriones, assisted by the Ajaces, bear off the body to the ships.

The time is the evening of the eight-and-twentieth day. The scene lies in the fields before Troy. On the cold earth divine Patroclus spread,

Lies pierced with wounds among the vulgar dead. Great Menelaus, touch'd with generous woe, Springs to the front, and guards him (Menelaus) from the foe.

Thus round her (foe) new-fallen young the heifer moves, Fruit of her (foe) throes, and first-born of her (foe) loves; And anxious -LRB-helpless as he (Menelaus) lies, and bare-RRB-

Turns, and re-turns her (foe), with a mother's care, Opposed to each that near the carcase came, His (Menelaus) broad shield glimmers, and his (Menelaus) lances flame.

The son of Panthus, skill'd the dart to send, Eyes the dead hero, and insults the friend. '' This hand, Atrides, laid Patroclus low; Warrior! desist, nor tempt an equal blow:

To me the spoils my prowess won, resign: Depart with life, and leave the glory mine '' The Trojan thus: the Spartan monarch burn'd

With generous anguish, and in scorn return'd: '' Laugh`st thou not, Jove! from thy superior throne, When mortals boast of prowess not their own?

Not thus the lion glories in his (monarch) might, Nor panther braves his (monarch) spotted foe in fight, Nor thus the boar -LRB-those terrors of the plain;-RRB- Man only vaunts his (Man) force, and vaunts in vain.

But far the vainest of the boastful kind, These sons of Panthus vent their haughty mind. Yet 'twas but late, beneath my conquering steel

This boaster's brother, Hyperenor, fell; Against our arm which rashly he (brother) defied, Vain was his (brother) vigour, and as vain his (brother) pride.

These eyes beheld him (brother) on the dust expire, No more to cheer his (brother) spouse, or glad his (brother) sire. Presumptuous youth! like his (brother) shall be thy doom, Go, wait thy brother to the Stygian gloom;

Or, while thou may`st, avoid the threaten'd fate; Fools stay to feel it, and are wise too late. '' Unmoved, Euphorbus thus:

``That action known, Come, for my brother's blood repay thy own.

His (brother) weeping father claims thy destined head, And spouse, a widow in her (widow) bridal bed. On these thy conquer'd spoils I shall bestow,

To soothe a consort's and a parent's woe. No longer then defer the glorious strife, Let heaven decide our fortune, fame, and life.

Swift as the word the missile lance he (Swift) flings; The well-aim'd weapon on the buckler rings, But blunted by the brass, innoxious falls.

great Atrides calls, Nor flies the javelin from his (Swift) arm in vain, It pierced his (Swift) throat, and bent him (Swift) to the plain; Wide through the neck appears the grisly wound, Prone sinks the warrior, and his (warrior) arms resound.

The shining circlets of his (warrior) golden hair, Which even the Graces might be proud to wear, Instarr'd with gems and gold, bestrow the shore, With dust dishonour'd, and deform'd with gore.

As the young olive, in some sylvan scene, Crown'd by fresh fountains with eternal green, Lifts the gay head, in snowy flowerets fair, And plays and dances to the gentle air;

a whirlwind from high heaven invades The tender plant, and withers all its shades; It lies uprooted from its genial bed, A lovely ruin now defaced and dead: Thus young, thus beautiful, Euphorbus lay, While the fierce Spartan tore his (its) arms away.

'' (Euphorbus)

On Jove the father When lo! Proud of his (its) deed, and glorious in the prize, Affrighted Troy the towering victor flies:

Flies, as before some mountain lion's ire The village curs and trembling swains retire, When o'er the slaughter'd bull they hear him (its) roar, And see his (its) jaws distil with smoking gore: All pale with fear, at distance scatter'd round,

And urged great Hector to dispute the prize; -LRB-In Mentes' shape, beneath whose martial care The rough Ciconians learn'd the trade of war;-RRB--LRB-247-RRB-

``Forbear -LRB-he (Hector) cried-RRB- with fruitless speed to chase Achilles' coursers, of ethereal race; They stoop not, these, to mortal man's command, Or stoop to none but great Achilles' hand.

Too long amused with a pursuit so vain, Turn, and behold the brave Euphorbus slain; By Sparta slain! for ever now

They shout incessant, and the vales resound. Meanwhile Apollo view'd with envious eyes, suppress'd The fire which burn'd in that undaunted breast!'' (Hector/HECTOR/Stern)

Thus having spoke, Apollo wing'd his (Achilles) flight, And mix'd with mortals in the toils of fight: His (Achilles) words infix'd unutterable care

Deep in great Hector's soul : through all the war He (Hector) darts his (Hector) anxious eye; and, instant, view'd The breathless hero in his (Hector) blood imbued, -LRB-Forth welling from the wound, as prone he (Hector) lay-RRB-

And in the victor's hands the shining prey. Sheath'd in bright arms, through cleaving ranks he (Hector) flies, And sends his (Hector) voice in thunder to the skies:

Fierce as a flood of flame by Vulcan sent, It flew, and fired the nations as it went. Atrides from the voice the storm divined, And thus explored his (Hector) own unconquer'd mind:

``Then shall I quit Patroclus on the plain, Slain in my cause, and for my honour slain! Desert the arms, the relics, of my friend?

Or singly, Hector and his (Hector) troops attend? Sure where such partial favour heaven bestow'd, To brave the hero were to brave the god

: Forgive me, Greece, if once I quit the field; 'Tis not to Hector, but to heaven I yield. Yet, nor the god, nor heaven, should give me fear,

the voice of Ajax reach my ear: Still would we turn, still battle on the plains, And give Achilles all that yet remains Of his (Achilles) and our Patroclus--

Did but '' (unknown)

This, no more The time allow'd: Troy thicken'd on the shore. A sable scene! The terrors Hector led.

So from the fold the unwilling lion parts, Forced by loud clamours, and a storm of darts; He (Hector) flies indeed, but threatens as he (Hector) flies, With heart indignant and retorted eyes.

Now enter'd in the Spartan ranks, he (Hector) turn'd His (Hector) manly breast, and with new fury burn'd; O'er all the black battalions sent his (Hector) view, And through the cloud the godlike Ajax knew; Where labouring on the left the warrior stood,

All grim in arms, and cover'd o'er with blood; There breathing courage, where the god of day Had sunk each heart with terror and dismay.

Slow he (god) recedes, and sighing quits the dead. To him (god) the king:

``Oh Ajax, oh my friend! Haste, and Patroclus' loved remains defend:

The body to Achilles to restore Demands our care; alas, we can no more! For naked now, despoiled of arms, he (Achilles) lies;

And Hector glories in the dazzling prize. '' (the king friend)

He (Hector) said, and touch'd his (Hector) heart. The raging pair Pierced the thick battle, and provoke the war.

Already had stern Hector seized his (Hector) head, And doom'd to Trojan gods the unhappy dead; But soon as Ajax rear'd his (Hector) tower-like shield, Sprung to his (Hector) car, and measured back the field, His (Hector) train to Troy the radiant armour bear, To stand a trophy of his (Hector) fame in war.

Meanwhile great Ajax -LRB-his (Hector) broad shield display'd-RRB- Guards the dead hero with the dreadful shade; And now before, and now behind he (Hector) stood:

Thus in the centre of some gloomy wood, With many a step, the lioness surrounds Her (Hector) tawny young, beset by men and hounds; Elate her (Hector) heart, and rousing all her (Hector) powers, Dark o'er the fiery balls each hanging eyebrow lours.

But Glaucus, leader of the Lycian aids, On Hector frowning, thus his (Hector) flight upbraids: ``Where now in Hector shall we Hector find?

Fast by his (Hector) side the generous Spartan glows With great revenge, and feeds his (Hector) inward woes. A manly form, without a manly mind.

Since battle is renounced, thy thoughts employ What other methods may preserve thy Troy: 'Tis time to try if Ilion's state can stand By thee alone, nor ask a foreign hand:

Is this, O chief! a hero's boasted fame? How vain, without the merit, is the name! Mean, empty boast! but shall the Lycians stake Their lives for you?

those Lycians you forsake? What from thy thankless arms can we expect? Thy friend Sarpedon proves thy base neglect; Say, shall our slaughter'd bodies guard your walls,

While unreveng'd the great Sarpedon falls? Even where he (friend) died for Troy, you left him (friend) there, A feast for dogs, and all the fowls of air.

Did such a spirit as the gods impart Impel one Trojan hand or Trojan heart, -LRB-Such as should burn in every soul that draws The sword for glory, and his (friend) country's cause-RRB-

On my command if any Lycian wait, Hence let him (friend) march, and give up Troy to fate. Even yet our mutual arms we might employ, And drag yon carcase to the walls of Troy.

Oh! were Patroclus ours, we might obtain Sarpedon's arms and honour'd corse again! Greece with Achilles' friend should be repaid, And thus due honours purchased to his (friend) shade.

But words are vain-- Let Ajax once appear, And Hector trembles and recedes with fear; Thou dar`st not meet the terrors of his (Hector) eye;

The Trojan chief with fix'd resentment eyed The Lycian leader, and sedate replied:

``Say, is it just, my friend, that Hector's ear From such a warrior such a speech should hear?

And lo! already thou prepar`st to fly. '' (The leader)

I deem'd thee once the wisest of thy kind, But ill this insult suits a prudent mind.

I shun great Ajax? I desert my train? ' Tis mine to prove the rash assertion vain ; I joy to mingle where the battle bleeds, And hear the thunder of the sounding steeds.

But Jove's high will is ever uncontroll'd, The strong he (Hector) withers, and confounds the bold; Now crowns with fame the mighty man, and now Strikes the fresh garland from the victor's brow!

Come, through yon squadrons let us hew the way, And thou be witness, if I fear to-day; If yet a Greek the sight of Hector dread, Or yet their hero dare defend the dead.

'' Then turning to the martial hosts, he (Hector) cries:

``Ye Trojans, Dardans, Lycians, and allies! Be men, my friends, in action as in name, And yet be mindful of your ancient fame.

Hector in proud Achilles' arms shall shine, Torn from his (Hector) friend, by right of conquest mine. '' (he)

He (Hector) strode along the field, as thus he (Hector) said: -LRB-The sable plumage nodded o'er his (Hector) head:-RRB-

Swift through the spacious plain he (Hector) sent a look; One instant saw, one instant overtook The distant band, that on the sandy shore The radiant spoils to sacred Ilion bore.

There his (Hector) own mail unbraced the field bestrow'd; His (Hector) train to Troy convey'd the massy load. Now blazing in the immortal arms he (Hector) stands;

The work and present of celestial hands; By aged Peleus to Achilles given, As first to Peleus by the court of heaven: His (Achilles) father's arms not long Achilles wears, Forbid by fate to reach his (Achilles) father's years.

Him (Achilles), proud in triumph, glittering from afar, The god whose thunder rends the troubled air Beheld with pity; as apart he (Achilles) sat,

And, conscious, look'd through all the scene of fate. He (Achilles) shook the sacred honours of his (Achilles) head; Olympus trembled, and the godhead said;

In heavenly panoply divinely bright Thou stand`st, and armies tremble at thy sight, As at Achilles' self! beneath thy dart Lies slain the great Achilles' dearer part.

``Ah, wretched man! unmindful of thy end! A moment's glory; and what fates attend! Thou from the mighty dead those arms hast torn, Which once the greatest of mankind had worn.

no more Andromache shall come With joyful tears to welcome Hector home; No more officious, with endearing charms, From thy tired limbs unbrace Pelides' arms!'' (unknown)

Yet live! I give thee one illustrious day, A blaze of glory ere thou fad`st away. For ah! Then with his (Hector) sable brow he (Hector) gave the nod That seals his (Hector) word; the sanction of the god.

Fill'd with the god, enlarged his (god) members grew, Through all his (god) veins a sudden vigour flew, The blood in brisker tides began to roll, And Mars himself came rushing on his (god) soul.

The stubborn arms -LRB-by Jove's command disposed-RRB- Conform'd spontaneous, and around him (god) closed: Exhorting loud through all the field he (god) strode, And look'd, and moved, Achilles, or a god.

Now Mesthles, Glaucus, Medon, he (Achilles) inspires, Now Phorcys, Chromius, and Hippothous fires; The great Thersilochus like fury found, Asteropaeus kindled at the sound, And Ennomus, in augury renown'd.

``Hear, all ye hosts, and hear, unnumber'd bands Of neighbouring nations, or of distant lands! ' Twas not for state we summon'd you so far,

To boast our numbers, and the pomp of war: Ye came to fight; a valiant foe to chase, To save our present, and our future race.

Tor this, our wealth, our products, you enjoy, And glean the relics of exhausted Troy. Now then, to conquer or to die prepare; To die or conquer are the terms of war.

Whatever hand shall win Patroclus slain, Whoe'er shall drag him (Ye) to the Trojan train, With Hector's self shall equal honours claim; With Hector part the spoil, and share the fame.

'' (the troops)

Fired by his (Hector) words, the troops dismiss their fears, They join, they thicken, they protend their spears; Full on the Greeks they drive in firm array, And each from Ajax hopes the glorious prey:

Vain hope! what numbers shall the field o'erspread, What victims perish round the mighty dead! Great Ajax mark'd the growing storm from far, And thus bespoke his (Hector) brother of the war:

``Our fatal day, alas! is come, my friend; And all our wars and glories at an end! ' Tis not this corse alone

we guard in vain, Condemn'd to vultures on the Trojan plain; We too must yield: the same sad fate must fall On thee, on me, perhaps, my friend, on all.

See what a tempest direful Hector spreads, And lo! it bursts , it thunders on our heads! Call on our Greeks, if any hear the call,

The bravest Greeks: this hour demands them all. '' (brother)

The warrior raised his (warrior) voice, and wide around The field re-echoed the distressful sound.

'' O chiefs! O princes, to whose hand is given The rule of men; whose glory is from heaven! Whom with due honours both Atrides grace:

All, whom this well-known voice shall reach from far, All, whom I see not through this cloud of war; Come all!

Ye guides and guardians of our Argive race! let generous rage your arms employ, And save Patroclus from the dogs of Troy.

'' Oilean Ajax first the voice obey'd , Swift was his (Swift) pace, and ready was his (Swift) aid: Next him (Swift) Idomeneus, more slow with age, And

Merion, burning with a hero's rage. The long-succeeding numbers who can name? But all were Greeks, and eager all for fame.

Fierce to the charge great Hector led the throng; Whole Troy embodied rush'd with shouts along. Thus, when a mountain billow foams and raves, Where some swoln river disembogues his (Hector) waves,

Full in the mouth is stopp'd the rushing tide, The boiling ocean works from side to side, The river trembles to his (Hector) utmost shore, And distant rocks re-bellow to the roar.

Jove, pouring darkness o'er the mingled fight, Conceals the warriors' shining helms in night: To him (Hector), the chief for whom the hosts contend Had lived not hateful, for he (chief) lived a friend:

Nor less resolved, the firm Achaian band With brazen shields in horrid circle stand. Dead he (chief) protects him (chief) with superior care.

Nor dooms his (chief) carcase to the birds of air. -LSB-Illustration: FIGHT FOR THE BODY OF PATROCLUS.-RSB- FIGHT FOR THE BODY OF PATROCLUS.

The first attack the Grecians scarce sustain, Repulsed, they yield; the Trojans seize the slain. Then fierce they rally, to revenge led on By the swift rage of Ajax Telamon.

With headlong force the foremost ranks he (chief) tore; So through the thicket bursts the mountain boar, And rudely scatters, for a distance round, The frighted hunter and the baying hound.

The son of Lethus, brave Pelasgus' heir, Hippothous, dragg'd the carcase through the war; The sinewy ankles bored, the feet he (son) bound With thongs inserted through the double wound: Inevitable fate o'ertakes the deed; Doom'd by great Ajax' vengeful lance to bleed: It cleft the helmet's brazen cheeks in twain; The shatter'd crest and horse-hair strow the plain:

With nerves relax'd he (son) tumbles to the ground: The brain comes gushing through the ghastly wound: He (son) drops Patroclus' foot, and o'er him (son) spread, Now lies a sad companion of the dead: Far from Larissa lies, his (companion) native air, And ill requites his (companion) parents' tender care.

-LRB-Ajax to Peleus' son the second name, In graceful stature next, and next in fame-RRB- Lamented youth! in life's first bloom he (son) fell, Sent by great Ajax to the shades of hell.

Once more at Ajax Hector's javelin flies; The Grecian marking, as it cut the skies, Shunn'd the descending death; which hissing on, Stretch'd in the dust

The boldest warrior and the noblest mind: In little Panope, for strength renown'd, He (warrior) held his (warrior) seat, and ruled the realms around.

Plunged in his (warrior) throat, the weapon drank his (warrior) blood, And deep transpiercing through the shoulder stood; In clanging arms the hero fell and all The fields resounded with his (hero) weighty fall.

The Telamonian lance his (hero) belly rends; The hollow armour burst before the stroke, And through the wound the rushing entrails broke:

the great Iphytus' son, Schedius the brave, of all the Phocian kind Phorcys, as slain Hippothous he (son) defends, In strong convulsions panting on the sands He (son) lies, and grasps the dust with dying hands.

Struck at the sight, recede the Trojan train: The shouting Argives strip the heroes slain. And now had Troy, by Greece compell'd to yield,

Fled to her (hero) ramparts, and resign'd the field; Greece, in her (hero) native fortitude elate, With Jove averse, had turn'd the scale of fate:

But Phoebus urged Ćneas to the fight; He (Struck) seem'd like aged Periphas to sight: -LRB-A herald in Anchises' love grown old, Revered for prudence, and with prudence bold.-RRB-

There have been heroes, who, by virtuous care, By valour, numbers, and by arts of war, Have forced the powers to spare a sinking state, And gain'd at length the glorious odds of fate:

But you, when fortune smiles, when Jove declares His (Struck) partial favour, and assists your wars, Your shameful efforts `gainst yourselves employ, And force the unwilling god to ruin Troy.

Thus he (god)--

``What methods yet, O chief! remain, To save your Troy, though heaven its fall ordain? '' (he)
Ćneas through the form assumed descries The power conceal'd, and thus to Hector cries:
``Oh lasting shame!

to our own fears a prey, We seek our ramparts, and desert the day. A god, nor is he (god) less, my bosom warms, And tells me, Jove asserts the Trojan arms.

'' (Hector/HECTOR/Stern)

He (god) spoke, and foremost to the combat flew: The bold example all his (god) hosts pursue. Then, first, Leocritus beneath him (god) bled,

In vain beloved by valiant Lycomede; Who view'd his (god) fall, and, grieving at the chance, Swift to revenge it sent his (Swift) angry lance; The whirling lance, with vigorous force address'd, Descends, and pants in Apisaon's breast; From rich Paeonia's vales the warrior came,

Asteropeus with grief beheld the slain, And rush'd to combat, but he (warrior) rush'd in vain: Indissolubly firm, around the dead, Rank within rank, on buckler buckler spread, And hemm'd with bristled spears, the Grecians stood,

Next thee, Asteropeus! in place and fame. A brazen bulwark, and an iron wood. Great Ajax eyes them with incessant care,

And stands the centre and the soul of all: Fix'd on the spot they war, and wounded, wound A sanguine torrent steeps the reeking ground: On heaps the Greeks, on heaps the Trojans bled, And, thickening round them, rise the hills of dead.

Greece, in close order, and collected might, Yet suffers least, and sways the wavering fight; Fierce as conflicting fires the combat burns, And now it rises, now it sinks by turns.

In one thick darkness all the fight was lost; The sun, the moon, and all the ethereal host Seem'd as extinct: day ravish'd from their eyes, And all heaven's splendours blotted from the skies.

And in an orb contracts the crowded war, Close in their ranks commands to fight or fall, Such o'er Patroclus' body hung the night,

No vapour rested on the mountain's head, The golden sun pour'd forth a stronger ray, And all the broad expansion flamed with day.

The rest in sunshine fought, and open light; Unclouded there, the aerial azure spread, Dispersed around the plain, by fits they fight,

And here and there their scatter'd arrows light: But death and darkness o'er the carcase spread, There burn'd the war, and there the mighty bled.

Meanwhile the sons of Nestor, in the rear, -LRB-Their fellows routed,-RRB- toss the distant spear, And skirmish wide: so Nestor gave command, When from the ships he (Nestor) sent the Pylian band.

The youthful brothers thus for fame contend, Nor knew the fortune of Achilles' friend; In thought they view'd him (friend) still, with martial joy, Glorious in arms, and dealing death to Troy.

But round the corse the heroes pant for breath, And thick and heavy grows the work of death: O'erlabour'd now, with dust, and sweat, and gore, Their knees, their legs, their feet, are covered o'er; Drops follow drops, the clouds on clouds arise, And carnage clogs their hands, and darkness fills their eyes.

As when a slaughter'd bull's yet reeking hide, Strain'd with full force, and tugg'd from side to side, The brawny curriers stretch; and labour o'er

The extended surface, drunk with fat and gore: So tugging round the corse both armies stood; The mangled body bathed in sweat and blood; While Greeks and Ilians equal strength employ, Now to the ships to force it, now to Troy.

Not Pallas' self, her (it) breast when fury warms, Nor he (Greeks) whose anger sets the world in arms, Could blame this scene; such rage, such horror reign'd; Such, Jove to honour the great dead ordain'd.

Achilles in his (Achilles) ships at distance lay, Nor knew the fatal fortune of the day; He (Achilles), yet unconscious of Patroclus' fall, In dust extended under Ilion's wall, Expects him (Achilles) glorious from the conquered plain, And for his (Achilles) wish'd return prepares in vain; Though well he (Achilles) knew, to make proud Ilion bend Was more than heaven had destined to his (Achilles) friend.

Perhaps to him (Achilles): this Thetis had reveal'd; The rest, in pity to her (Achilles) son, conceal'd. Still raged the conflict round the hero dead, And heaps on heaps by mutual wounds they bled.

'' Cursed be the man -LRB-even private Greeks would say-RRB- Who dares desert this well-disputed day! First may the cleaving earth before our eyes Gape wide, and drink our blood for sacrifice; First perish all, ere

haughty Troy shall boast We lost Patroclus, and our glory lost!'' Thus they: while with one voice the Trojans said,

``Grant this day, Jove! or heap us on the dead!'' (Trojans)

Meantime, at distance from the scene of blood, The pensive steeds of great Achilles stood: Their godlike master slain before their eyes, They wept, and shared in human miseries.-LRB-248-RRB-

In vain Automedon now shakes the rein, Now plies the lash, and soothes and threats in vain; Nor to the fight nor Hellespont they go,

Restive they stood, and obstinate in woe: Still as a tombstone, never to be moved, On some good man or woman unreproved Lays its eternal weight; or fix'd, as stands A marble courser by the sculptor's hands, Placed on the hero's grave.

Then clash their sounding arms; the clangours rise, And shake the brazen concave of the skies. Along their face The big round drops coursed down with silent pace, Conglobing on the dust.

Their manes, that late Circled their arched necks, and waved in state, Trail'd on the dust beneath the yoke were spread, And prone to earth was hung their languid head: Nor Jove disdain'd to cast a pitying look,

While thus relenting to the steeds he (manes) spoke: ``Unhappy coursers of immortal strain, Exempt from age, and deathless, now in vain;

what is there of inferior birth, That breathes or creeps upon the dust of earth; What wretched creature of what wretched kind, Than man more weak, calamitous, and blind?

Did we your race on mortal man bestow, Only, alas! to share in mortal woe? For ah! A miserable race! but cease to mourn:

For not by you shall Priam's son be borne High on the splendid car: one glorious prize He (son) rashly boasts: the rest our will denies.

Ourself will swiftness to your nerves impart, Ourself with rising spirits swell your heart. Automedon your rapid flight shall bear Safe to the navy through the storm of war.

For yet 'tis given to Troy to ravage o'er The field, and spread her (you) slaughters to the shore; The sun shall see her (you) conquer, till his (son) fall With sacred darkness shades the face of all.

He (son) said; and breathing in the immortal horse Excessive spirit, urged them to the course; From their high manes they shake the dust, and bear The kindling chariot through the parted war: So flies a vulture through the clamorous train Of geese, that scream, and scatter round the plain.

From danger now with swiftest speed they flew, And now to conquest with like speed pursue; Sole in the seat the charioteer remains, Now plies the javelin, now directs the reins:

Him (son) brave Alcimedon beheld distress'd, Approach'd the chariot, and the chief address'd:

``What god provokes thee rashly thus to dare, Alone, unaided, in the thickest war?

'' (chief)

Alas! thy friend is slain, and Hector wields Achilles' arms triumphant in the fields.''
``In happy time -LRB-the charioteer replies-RRB-

The bold Alcimedon now greets my eyes; No Greek like him (Hector) the heavenly steeds restrains, Or holds their fury in suspended reins:

Patroclus, while he (Hector) lived, their rage could tame, But now Patroclus is an empty name! To thee I yield the seat, to thee resign

The ruling charge: the task of fight be mine. '' (He)

He (Hector) said. Alcimedon, with active heat, Snatches the reins, and vaults into the seat.

His (Hector) friend descends. The chief of Troy descried, And call'd Ćneas fighting near his (Troy) side. '' Lo, to my sight, beyond our hope restored, Achilles' car, deserted of its lord!

The glorious steeds our ready arms invite, Scarce their weak drivers guide them through the fight. Can such opponents stand when we assail?

The son of Venus to the counsel yields; Then o'er their backs they spread their solid shields: With brass refulgent the broad surface shined, And thick bull-hides the spacious concave lined.

Them Chromius follows, Aretus succeeds; Each hopes the conquest of the lofty steeds: In vain, brave youths, with glorious hopes ye burn, In vain advance!

Unite thy force, my friend, and we prevail. '' not fated to return. Unmov'd, Automedon attends the fight, Implores the Eternal, and collects his (friend) might.

Full on my shoulders let their nostrils blow, For hard the fight, determined is the foe; 'Tis Hector comes: and when he (Hector) seeks the prize, War knows no mean; he (Hector) wins it or he (Hector) dies.

Then turning to his (Hector) friend, with dauntless mind:

``Oh keep the foaming coursers close behind! '' (friend)
Then through the field he (Hector) sends his (Hector) voice aloud, And calls the Ajaces from the warring crowd, With great Atrides.

Turn where distress demands immediate aid; The dead, encircled by his (Hector) friends, forego, And save the living from a fiercer foe.

'' Hither turn, -LRB-he (Hector) said,-RRB- Unhelp'd we stand, unequal to engage The force of Hector, and Ćneas' rage: Yet mighty as they are, my force to prove Is only mine: the event belongs to Jove.

He (Hector) spoke, and high the sounding javelin flung, Which pass'd the shield of Aretus the young: It pierced his (Hector) belt, emboss'd with curious art, Then in the lower belly struck the dart.

As when a ponderous axe, descending full, Cleaves the broad forehead of some brawny bull:-LRB-249-RRB- Struck `twixt the horns, he (Struck) springs with many a bound,

'' Then tumbling rolls enormous on the ground: Thus fell the youth; the air his (Struck) soul received, And the spear trembled as his (Struck) entrails heaved.

Now at Automedon the Trojan foe Discharged his (foe) lance; the meditated blow, Stooping, he (foe) shunn'd; the javelin idly fled, And hiss'd innoxious o'er the hero's head; Deep rooted in the ground, the forceful spear In long vibrations spent its fury there.

With clashing falchions now the chiefs had closed, But each brave Ajax heard, and interposed; Nor longer Hector with his (Hector) Trojans stood, But left their slain companion in his (Hector) blood: His (Hector) arms Automedon divests, and cries,

``Accept, Patroclus, this mean sacrifice: Thus have I soothed my griefs, and thus have paid, Poor as it is, some offering to thy shade.

So looks the lion o'er a mangled boar, All grim with rage, and horrible with gore; High on the chariot at one bound he (Hector) sprung, And o'er his (Hector) seat the bloody trophies hung.

And now Minerva from the realms of air Descends impetuous, and renews the war; For, pleased at length the Grecian arms to aid, The lord of thunders sent the blue-eyed maid.

As when high Jove denouncing future woe, O'er the dark clouds extends his (lord) purple bow, -LRB-In sign of tempests from the troubled air, Or from the rage of man, destructive war,-RRB- The drooping cattle dread the impending skies, And from his (man) half-till'd field the labourer flies: In such a form the goddess round her (goddess) drew A livid cloud, and to the battle flew.

'' (companion)

Assuming Phoenix' shape on earth she (goddess) falls, And in his (man) well-known voice to Sparta calls:
``And lies Achilles' friend, beloved by all, A prey to dogs beneath the Trojan wall?

What shame 'o Greece for future times to tell, To thee the greatest in whose cause he (friend) fell!'' (she)

``O chief, O father!

-LRB-Atreus' son replies-RRB- O full of days! by long experience wise! What more desires my soul, than here unmoved To guard the body of the man I loved?

Ah, would Minerva send me strength to rear This wearied arm, and ward the storm of war! But Hector, like the rage of fire, we dread, And Jove's own glories blaze around his (Hector) head!'' (She)

Pleased to be first of all the powers address'd, She (Minerva) breathes new vigour in her (Minerva) hero's breast, And fills with keen revenge, with fell despite, Desire of blood, and rage, and lust of fight.

So burns the vengeful hornet -LRB-soul all o'er-RRB-, Repulsed in vain, and thirsty still of gore; -LRB-Bold son of air and heat-RRB- on angry wings Untamed, untired, he (son) turns, attacks, and stings.

Fired with like ardour fierce Atrides flew, And sent his (son) soul with every lance he (son) threw. There stood a Trojan, not unknown to fame, Aetion's son, and Podes was his (son) name:

With riches honour'd, and with courage bless'd, By Hector loved, his (Hector) comrade, and his (Hector) guest; Through his (Hector) broad belt the spear a passage found, And, ponderous as he (Hector) falls, his (Hector) arms resound.

Sudden at Hector's side Apollo stood, Like Phaenops, Asius' son, appear'd the god; -LRB-Asius the great, who held his (god) wealthy reign In fair Abydos, by the rolling main.-RRB-

'' Oh prince! -LRB-he (prince) cried-RRB- Oh foremost once in fame! What Grecian now shall tremble at thy name? Dost thou at length to Menelaus yield, A chief once thought no terror of the field?

Yet singly, now, the long-disputed prize He (chief) bears victorious, while our army flies: By the same arm illustrious Podes bled; The friend of Hector, unrevenged, is dead!''

This heard, o'er Hector spreads a cloud of woe, Rage lifts his (Hector) lance, and drives him (Hector) on the foe. But now the Eternal shook his (Hector) sable shield, That shaded Ide and all the subject field Beneath its ample verge.

A rolling cloud Involved the mount; the thunder roar'd aloud; The affrighted hills from their foundations nod, And blaze beneath the lightnings of the god: At one regard of his (god) all-seeing eye

Then trembled Greece: the flight Peneleus led; For as the brave Boeotian turn'd his (god) head To face the foe, Polydamas drew near, And razed his (god) shoulder with a shorten'd spear:

By Hector wounded, Leitus quits the plain, Pierced through the wrist; and raging with the pain, Grasps his (Hector) once formidable lance in vain.

As Hector follow'd, Idomen address'd The flaming javelin to his (Hector) manly breast; The brittle point before his (Hector) corslet yields; Exulting Troy with clamour fills the fields: High on his (Hector) chariots the Cretan stood, The son of Priam whirl'd the massive wood.
