He (son) has a father too; How many valiant sons, in early bloom, Has that cursed hand send headlong to the tomb!

O had thy gentle spirit pass'd in peace, The son expiring in the sire's embrace, While both thy parents wept the fatal hour, And, bending o'er thee, mix'd the tender shower!

Thee, Hector! last: thy loss -LRB-divinely brave-RRB- Sinks my sad soul with sorrow to the grave. Some comfort that had been, some sad relief, To melt in full satiety of grief!'' (he)

Thus wail'd the father, grovelling on the ground, And all the eyes of Ilion stream'd around. Amidst her (Hector) matrons Hecuba appears: -LRB-A mourning princess, and a train in tears;-RRB-

'' Ah why has Heaven prolong'd this hated breath, Patient of horrors, to behold thy death? O Hector! late thy parents' pride and joy, The boast of nations!

the defence of Troy! To whom her (Hector) safety and her (Hector) fame she (Hector) owed; Her (Hector) chief, her (Hector) hero, and almost her (Hector) god!

But not as yet the fatal news had spread To fair Andromache, of Hector dead; As yet no messenger had told his (Hector) fate, Not e`en his (Hector) stay without the Scaean gate.

O fatal change! become in one sad day A senseless corse! inanimated clay! '' Far in the close recesses of the dome, Pensive she (Hector) plied the melancholy loom;

A growing work employ'd her (Hector) secret hours, Confusedly gay with intermingled flowers. Her (Hector) fair-haired handmaids heat the brazen urn, The bath preparing for her (Hector) lord's return In vain; alas!

her (Hector) lord returns no more; Unbathed he (lord) lies, and bleeds along the shore! Now from the walls the clamours reach her (Hector) ear, And all her (Hector) members shake with sudden fear:

Forth from her (Hector) ivory hand the shuttle falls, And thus, astonish'd, to her (Hector) maids she (Hector) calls: -LSB-Illustration: THE BATH.-RSB- THE BATH.

My faltering knees their trembling frame desert, A pulse unusual flutters at my heart; Some strange disaster, some reverse of fate -LRB-Ye gods avert it!-RRB-

'' Ah follow me! -LRB-she (Hector) cried-RRB- what plaintive noise Invades my ear? ' Tis sure my mother's voice. threats the Trojan state.

Far be the omen which my thoughts suggest! But much I fear my Hector's dauntless breast Confronts Achilles; chased along the plain, Shut from our walls!

And sought for glory in the jaws of fate: Perhaps that noble heat has cost his (Hector) breath, Now quench'd for ever in the arms of death.

She (mother) spoke: and furious, with distracted pace, Fears in her (mother) heart, and anguish in her (mother) face, Flies through the dome -LRB-the maids her (mother) steps pursue-RRB-, And mounts the walls, and sends around her (mother) view.

I fear, I fear him (Hector) slain! Safe in the crowd he (Hector) ever scorn'd to wait, '' Too soon her (mother) eyes the killing object found,

The godlike Hector dragg'd along the ground. A sudden darkness shades her (mother) swimming eyes: She (mother) faints, she (mother) falls; her (mother) breath, her (mother) colour flies.

Her (mother) hair's fair ornaments, the braids that bound, The net that held them, and the wreath that crown'd, The veil and diadem flew far away -LRB-The gift of Venus on her (mother) bridal day-RRB-.

Around a train of weeping sisters stands, To raise her (mother) sinking with assistant hands. Scarce from the verge of death recall'd, again She (mother) faints, or but recovers to complain.

-LSB-Illustration: ANDROMACHE FAINTING ON THE WALL.-RSB- ANDROMACHE FAINTING ON THE WALL. '' O wretched husband of a wretched wife! Born with one fate, to one unhappy life!

For sure one star its baneful beam display'd On Priam's roof, and Hippoplacia's shade. From different parents, different climes we came.

At different periods, yet our fate the same! Why was my birth to great Aetion owed, And why was all that tender care

bestow'd? Would I had never been!--O thou, the ghost Of my dead husband! miserably lost! Thou to the dismal realms for ever gone!

And I abandon'd, desolate, alone! An only child, once comfort of my pains, Sad product now of hapless love, remains! No more to smile upon his (husband) sire; no friend To help him (husband) now!

no father to defend! For should he (husband) `scape the sword, the common doom, What wrongs attend him (husband), and what griefs to come!

The day, that to the shades the father sends, Robs the sad orphan of his (father) father's friends: He (father), wretched outcast of mankind! appears For ever sad, for ever bathed in tears; Amongst the happy, unregarded, he (father) Hangs on the robe, or trembles at the knee, While those his (father) father's former bounty fed Nor reach the goblet, nor divide the bread: The kindest but his (father) present wants allay,

Even from his (father) own paternal roof expell'd, Some stranger ploughs his (father) patrimonial field. To leave him (father) wretched the succeeding day. Frugal compassion!

Heedless, they who boast Both parents still, nor feel what he (father) has lost, Shall cry, `Begone! thy father feasts not here:'

The wretch obeys, retiring with a tear. Thus wretched, thus retiring all in tears, To my sad soul Astyanax appears! Forced by repeated insults to return, And to his (father) widow'd mother vainly mourn:

He (father), who, with tender delicacy bred, With princes sported, and on dainties fed, And when still evening gave him (father) up to rest, Sunk soft in down upon the nurse's breast, Must--ah what must he (father) not?

Whom Ilion calls Astyanax, from her (nurse) well-guarded walls,-LRB-279-RRB- Is now that name no more, unhappy boy! Since now no more thy father guards his (father) Troy.

But thou, my Hector, liest exposed in air, Far from thy parents' and thy consort's care; Whose hand in vain, directed by her (nurse) love, The martial scarf and robe of triumph wove.

Now to devouring flames be these a prey, Useless to thee, from this accursed day! Yet let the sacrifice at least be paid, An honour to the living, not the dead!''

So spake the mournful dame: her (nurse) matrons hear, Sigh back her (nurse) sighs, and answer tear with tear. BOOK XXIII. ARGUMENT. FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.-LRB-280-RRB-

After the funeral feast he (nurse) retires to the sea-shore, where, falling asleep, the ghost of his (nurse) friend appears to him (nurse), and demands the rites of burial; the next morning the soldiers are sent with mules and waggons to fetch wood for the pyre.

Achilles and the Myrmidons do honours to the body of Patroclus. The funeral procession, and the offering their hair to the dead.

Achilles sacrifices several animals, and lastly twelve Trojan captives, at the pile; then sets fire to it. He (Achilles) pays libations to the Winds, which -LRB-at the instance of Iris-RRB- rise, and raise the flames.

When the pile has burned all night, they gather the bones, place them in an urn of gold, and raise the tomb.

Achilles institutes the funeral games: the chariot-race, the fight of the caestus, the wrestling, the foot-race, the single combat, the discus, the shooting with arrows, the darting the javelin: the various descriptions of which, and the various success of the several antagonists, make the greatest part of the book.

The night following, the ghost of Patroclus appears to Achilles: the one-and-thirtieth day is employed in felling the timber for the pile: the two-and-thirtieth in burning it; and the three-and-thirtieth in the games.

In this book ends the thirtieth day. The scene is generally on the sea-shore. Thus humbled in the dust, the pensive train Through the sad city

The Grecians seek their ships, and clear the strand, All, but the martial Myrmidonian band: These yet assembled great Achilles holds, And the stern purpose of his (Achilles) mind unfolds:

``Not yet, my brave companions of the war, Release your smoking coursers from the car;

mourn'd her (Achilles) hero slain. The body soil'd with dust, and black with gore, Lies on broad Hellespont's resounding shore. But, with his (hero) chariot each in order led, Perform due honours to Patroclus dead.

Ere yet from rest or food we seek relief, Some rites remain, to glut our rage of grief. '' (These Achilles)

The troops obey'd; and thrice in order led-LRB-281-RRB-

-LRB-Achilles first-RRB- their coursers round the dead; And thrice their sorrows and laments renew; Tears bathe their arms, and tears the sands bedew.

But chief, Pelides: thick-succeeding sighs Burst from his (chief) heart, and torrents from his (chief) eyes: His (chief) slaughtering hands, yet red with blood, he (chief) laid On his (chief) dead friend's cold breast, and thus he (chief) said:

For such a warrior Thetis aids their woe, Melts their strong hearts, and bids their eyes to flow.

``All hail, Patroclus! let thy honour'd ghost Hear, and rejoice on Pluto's dreary coast; Behold!

to the dogs his (chief) carcase I resign; And twelve sad victims, of the Trojan line, Sacred to vengeance, instant shall expire; Their lives effused around thy funeral pyre.

Achilles' promise is complete; The bloody Hector stretch'd before thy feet. Lo! '' (he)

Gloomy he (Hector) said, and -LRB-horrible to view-RRB- Before the bier the bleeding Hector threw, Prone on the dust.

The Myrmidons around Unbraced their armour, and the steeds unbound. All to Achilles' sable ship repair, Frequent and full, the genial feast to share.

Now from the well-fed swine black smokes aspire, The bristly victims hissing o'er the fire: The huge ox bellowing falls; with feebler cries Expires the goat; the sheep in silence dies.

Around the hero's prostrate body flow'd , In one promiscuous stream, the reeking blood. And now a band of Argive monarchs brings The glorious victor to the king of kings.

The attending heralds, as by office bound, With kindled flames the tripod-vase surround: To cleanse his (king) conquering hands from hostile gore, They urged in vain; the chief refused, and swore:-LRB-282-RRB-

From his (chief) dead friend the pensive warrior went, With steps unwilling, to the regal tent. '' No drop shall touch me, by almighty Jove!

The first and greatest of the gods above! Till on the pyre I place thee; till I rear The grassy mound, and clip thy sacred hair.

Howe'er, reluctant as I am, I stay And share your feast; but with the dawn of day, -LRB-O king of men!-RRB-

it claims thy royal care, That Greece the warrior's funeral pile prepare, And bid the forests fall: -LRB-such rites are paid To heroes slumbering in eternal shade:-RRB-

Some ease at least those pious rites may give, And soothe my sorrows, while I bear to live. Then, when his (warrior) earthly part shall mount in fire, Let the leagued squadrons to their posts retire.

He (warrior) spoke: they hear him (warrior), and the word obey; The rage of hunger and of thirst allay, Then ease in sleep the labours of the day.

But great Pelides, stretch'd along the shore, Where, dash'd on rocks, the broken billows roar, Lies inly groaning; while on either hand The martial Myrmidons confusedly stand.

Tired with his (warrior) chase around the Trojan wall; Hush'd by the murmurs of the rolling deep, At length he (warrior) sinks in the soft arms of sleep.

'' Along the grass his (warrior) languid members fall, When lo! the shade, before his (warrior) closing eyes, Of sad Patroclus rose, or seem'd to rise:

In the same robe he (warrior) living wore, he (warrior) came: In stature, voice, and pleasing look, the same. The form familiar hover'd

o'er his (warrior) head,

``And sleeps Achilles? -LRB-thus the phantom said:-RRB- Sleeps my Achilles, his (Achilles) Patroclus dead? Living, I seem'd his (Achilles) dearest, tenderest care,

But now forgot, I wander in the air. Let my pale corse the rites of burial know, And give me entrance in the realms below:

Till then the spirit finds no resting-place, But here and there the unbodied spectres chase The vagrant dead around the dark abode, Forbid to cross the irremeable flood.

Now give thy hand; for to the farther shore When once we pass, the soul returns no more: When once the last funereal flames ascend, No more shall meet Achilles and his (Achilles) friend; No more our thoughts to those we loved make known; Or quit the dearest, to converse alone.

Me fate has sever'd from the sons of earth, The fate fore-doom'd that waited from my birth: Thee too it waits; before the Trojan wall Even great and godlike thou art doom'd to fall.

Together have we lived; together bred, One house received us, and one table fed; That golden urn, thy goddess-mother gave, May mix our ashes in one common grave.'' (unknown)

Hear then; and as in fate and love we join, Ah suffer that my bones may rest with thine! '' And is it thou?

-LRB-he (we) answers-RRB- To my sight-LRB-283-RRB- Once more return`st thou from the realms of night? O more than brother! Think each office paid, Whate'er can rest a discontented shade; But grant one last embrace, unhappy boy!

Afford at least that melancholy joy. '' He (boy) said, and with his (boy) longing arms essay'd In vain to grasp the visionary shade!

Confused he (boy) wakes; amazement breaks the bands Of golden sleep, and starting from the sands, Pensive he (boy) muses with uplifted hands: '''Tis true, 'tis certain; man, though dead, retains Part of himself; the immortal mind remains: The form subsists without the body's aid, Aerial semblance, and an empty shade!

This night my friend, so late in battle lost, Stood at my side, a pensive, plaintive ghost: Even now familiar, as in life, he (friend) came;

Like a thin smoke he (friend) sees the spirit fly,-LRB-284-RRB- And hears a feeble, lamentable cry. Alas! how different! yet how like the same!''

Thus while he (friend) spoke, each eye grew big with tears: And now the rosy-finger'd morn appears, Shows every mournful face with tears o'erspread, And glares on the pale visage of the dead.

But Agamemnon, as the rites demand, With mules and waggons sends a chosen band To load the timber, and the pile to rear; A charge consign'd to Merion's faithful care.

With proper instruments they take the road, Axes to cut, and ropes to sling the load. First march the heavy mules, securely slow, O'er hills, o'er dales, o'er crags, o'er rocks they go:-LRB-285-RRB-

Jumping, high o'er the shrubs of the rough ground, Rattle the clattering cars, and the shock'd axles bound But when arrived at Ida's spreading woods,-LRB-286-RRB-

-LRB-Fair Ida, water'd with descending floods,-RRB- Loud sounds the axe, redoubling strokes on strokes; On all sides round the forest hurls her (Ida) oaks Headlong.

Deep echoing groan the thickets brown; Then rustling, crackling, crashing, thunder down. The wood the Grecians cleave, prepared to burn; And the slow mules the same rough road return

The sturdy woodmen equal burdens bore -LRB-Such charge was given them-RRB- to the sandy shore; There on the spot which great Achilles show'd, They eased their shoulders, and disposed the load; Circling around the place, where times to come

The hero bids his (hero) martial troops appear High on their cars in all the pomp of war; Each in refulgent arms his (hero) limbs attires

Shall view Patroclus' and Achilles' tomb. , All mount their chariots, combatants and squires. The chariots first proceed, a shining train;

Then clouds of foot that smoke along the plain; Next these the melancholy band appear; Amidst, lay dead Patroclus on the bier; O'er all the corse their scattered locks they throw; Achilles next, oppress'd with mighty woe, Supporting with his (Achilles) hands the hero's head, Bends o'er the extended body of the dead.

But great Achilles stands apart in prayer, And from his (Achilles) head divides the yellow hair; Those curling locks which from his (Achilles) youth he (Achilles) vow'd,-LRB-287-RRB-

Patroclus decent on the appointed ground They place, and heap the sylvan pile around. And sacred grew, to Sperchius' honour'd flood:

Then sighing, to the deep his (Achilles) locks he (Achilles) cast, And roll'd his (Achilles) eyes around the watery waste:

``Sperchius! whose waves in mazy errors lost Delightful roll along my native coast!

To whom we vainly vow'd, at our return, These locks to fall, and hecatombs to burn: Full fifty rams to bleed in sacrifice, Where to the day

thy silver fountains rise, And where in shade of consecrated bowers Thy altars stand, perfumed with native flowers! So vow'd my father, but he (father) vow'd in vain;

No more Achilles sees his (Achilles) native plain; In that vain hope these hairs no longer grow, Patroclus bears them to the shades below.

'' (he)

Thus o'er Patroclus while the hero pray'd , On his (hero) cold hand the sacred lock he (hero) laid. Once more afresh the Grecian sorrows flow: And now the sun had set upon their woe;

But to the king of men thus spoke the chief:

``Enough, Atrides! give the troops relief: Permit the mourning legions to retire, And let the chiefs alone attend the pyre; The pious care be ours, the dead to burn--

He (chief) said: the people to their ships return: While those deputed to inter the slain Heap with a rising pyramid the plain.-LRB-288-RRB-

A hundred foot in length, a hundred wide, The growing structure spreads on every side; High on the top the manly corse they lay, And well-fed sheep and sable oxen slay: Achilles covered with their fat the dead,

And the piled victims round the body spread; Then jars of honey, and of fragrant oil, Suspends around, low-bending o'er the pile.

'' (the chief)

Four sprightly coursers, with a deadly groan Pour forth their lives, and on the pyre are thrown. Of nine large dogs, domestic at his (Achilles) board, Fall two, selected to attend their lord,

Then last of all, and horrible to tell, Sad sacrifice! twelve Trojan captives fell.-LRB-289-RRB- On these the rage of fire victorious preys, Involves and joins them in one common blaze.

Smear'd with the bloody rites, he (Achilles) stands on high, And calls the spirit with a dreadful cry:-LRB-290-RRB-

``All hail, Patroclus! let thy vengeful ghost Hear, and exult, on Pluto's dreary coast.

Behold Achilles' promise fully paid, Twelve Trojan heroes offer'd to thy shade; But heavier fates on Hector's corse attend, Saved from the flames, for hungry dogs to rend.

'' (he)

So spake he (Hector), threatening: but the gods made vain His (Hector) threat, and guard inviolate the slain: Celestial Venus hover'd o'er his (Hector) head, And roseate unguents, heavenly fragrance!

shed : She (Celestial) watch'd him (Hector) all the night and all the day, And drove the bloodhounds from their destined prey. Nor sacred Phoebus less

; He (Hector) pour'd around a veil of gather'd air, And kept the nerves undried, the flesh entire, Against the solar beam and Sirian fire.

Nor yet the pile, where dead Patroclus lies, Smokes, nor as yet the sullen flames arise; But, fast beside, Achilles stood in prayer, Invoked the gods whose spirit moves the air, And victims promised, and libations cast, To gentle Zephyr and the Boreal blast:

employ'd his (Achilles) care -LSB-Illustration: THE FUNERAL PILE OF PATROCLUS.-RSB- THE FUNERAL PILE OF PATROCLUS. He (Achilles) call'd the aerial powers, along the skies To breathe, and whisper to the fires to rise.

The winged Iris heard the hero's call, And instant hasten'd to their airy hall, Where in old Zephyr's open courts on high, Sat all the blustering brethren of the sky.

She (Iris) shone amidst them, on her (Iris) painted bow; The rocky pavement glitter'd with the show. All from the banquet rise, and each invites The various goddess to partake the rites.

Not so -LRB-the dame replied-RRB-, I haste to go To sacred Ocean, and the floods below: Even now our solemn hecatombs attend, And heaven is feasting on the world's green end With righteous Ethiops -LRB-uncorrupted train!-RRB-

'' Far on the extremest limits of the main. But Peleus' son entreats, with sacrifice, The western spirit, and the north, to rise!

Swift as the word she (goddess) vanish'd from their view; Swift as the word the winds tumultuous flew; Forth burst the stormy band with thundering roar, And heaps on heaps the clouds are toss'd before.

To the wide main then stooping from the skies, The heaving deeps in watery mountains rise: Troy feels the blast along her (goddess) shaking walls,

Let on Patroclus' pile your blast be driven, And bear the blazing honours high to heaven. '' Till on the pile the gather'd tempest falls.

The structure crackles in the roaring fires, And all the night the plenteous flame aspires. All night Achilles hails Patroclus' soul, With large libations from the golden bowl.

As a poor father, helpless and undone, Mourns o'er the ashes of an only son, Takes a sad pleasure the last bones to burn, And pours in tears, ere

yet they close the urn: So stay'd Achilles, circling round the shore, So watch'd the flames, till now they flame no more. '

The morning planet told the approach of light; And, fast behind, Aurora's warmer ray O'er the broad ocean pour'd the golden day: Then sank the blaze, the pile no longer burn'd, And to their caves the whistling winds return'd: Across the Thracian seas their course they bore;

Then parting from the pile he (Achilles) ceased to weep, And sank to quiet in the embrace of sleep, Exhausted with his (Achilles) grief: meanwhile the crowd Of thronging Grecians round Achilles stood; The tumult waked him (Achilles): from his (Achilles) eyes he (Achilles) shook Unwilling slumber, and the chiefs bespoke:

Twas when, emerging through the shades of night. The ruffled seas beneath their passage roar.

``Ye kings and princes of the Achaian name!

First let us quench the yet remaining flame With sable wine; then, as the rites direct, The hero's bones with careful view select: -LRB-

Amidst the heap, and obvious to the eye: The rest around the margin will be seen Promiscuous, steeds and immolated men:-RRB-

Apart, and easy to be known they lie These wrapp'd in double cauls of fat, prepare; And in the golden vase dispose with care; There let them rest with decent honour laid,

Meantime erect the tomb with pious hands, A common structure on the humble sands: Hereafter Greece some nobler work may raise, And late posterity record our praise!'' (The Greeks)

The Greeks obey; where yet the embers glow, Wide o'er the pile the sable wine they throw, And deep subsides the ashy heap below.

Till I shall follow to the infernal shade. Next the white bones his (posterity) sad companions place, With tears collected, in the golden vase.

That done, they bid the sepulchre aspire, And cast the deep foundations round the pyre; High in the midst they heap the swelling bed Of rising earth, memorial of the dead.

The sacred relics to the tent they bore; The urn a veil of linen covered o'er. The swarming populace the chief detains, And leads amidst a wide extent of plains

; There placed them round: then from the ships proceeds A train of oxen, mules, and stately steeds, Vases and tripods -LRB-for the funeral games-RRB-, Resplendent brass, and more resplendent dames.

First stood the prizes to reward the force Of rapid racers in the dusty course: A woman for the first, in beauty's bloom, Skill'd in the needle, and the labouring loom; And a large vase, where two bright handles rise, Of twenty measures its capacious size.

The second victor claims a mare unbroke, Big with a mule, unknowing of the yoke: The third, a charger yet untouch'd by flame; Four ample measures held the shining frame: Two golden talents for the fourth were placed: An ample double bowl contents the last.

These in fair order ranged upon the plain, The hero, rising, thus address'd the train:

``Behold the prizes, valiant Greeks! decreed To the brave rulers of the racing steed

; Prizes which none beside ourself could gain, Should our immortal coursers take the plain; -LRB-A race unrivall'd, which from ocean's god Peleus received, and on his (god) son bestow'd.-RRB-

But this no time our vigour to display; Nor suit, with them, the games of this sad day: Lost is Patroclus now, that wont to deck Their flowing manes, and sleek their glossy neck.

Sad, as they shared in human grief, they stand, And trail those graceful honours on the sand! Let others for the noble task prepare, Who trust the courser and the flying car.

Fired at his (manes) word the rival racers rise; But far the first Eumelus hopes the prize, Famed though Pieria for the fleetest breed, And skill'd to manage the high-bounding steed.

'' (The hero)

With equal ardour bold Tydides swell'd, The steeds of Tros beneath his (manes) yoke compell'd -LRB- Which late obey'd the Dardan chiefs command,

Then Menelaus his (Menelaus) Podargus brings, And the famed courser of the king of kings: Whom rich Echepolus -LRB-more rich than brave-RRB-, To `scape the wars, to Agamemnon gave, -LRB-Ćthe her (Menelaus) name-RRB- at home to end his (Agamemnon) days; Base wealth preferring to eternal praise.

When scarce a god redeem'd him (god) from his (god) hand-RRB-. Next him (god) Antilochus demands the course With beating heart, and cheers his (god) Pylian horse.

Experienced Nestor gives his (Nestor) son the reins, Directs his (Nestor) judgment, and his (Nestor) heat restrains; Nor idly warns the hoary sire, nor hears The prudent son with unattending ears.

My son! though youthful ardour fire thy breast, The gods have loved thee, and with arts have bless'd; Neptune and Jove on thee conferr'd the skill Swift round the goal to turn the flying wheel.

Fear not thy rivals, though for swiftness known; Compare those rivals' judgment and thy own: It is not strength, but art, obtains the prize, And to be swift is less than to be wise. '

'' To guide thy conduct little precept needs; But slow, and past their vigour, are my steeds. Tis more by art than force of numerous strokes

The dexterous woodman shapes the stubborn oaks; By art the pilot, through the boiling deep And howling tempest, steers the fearless ship; And 'tis the artist wins the glorious course; Not those who trust in chariots and in horse.

In vain, unskilful to the goal they strive, And short, or wide, the ungovern'd courser drive: While with sure skill, though with inferior steeds, The knowing racer to his (racer) end proceeds; Fix'd on the goal his (racer) eye foreruns the course, His (racer) hand unerring steers the steady horse, And now contracts, or now extends the rein, Observing still the foremost on the plain.

Mark then the goal, 'tis easy to be found; Yon aged trunk, a cubit from the ground; Of some once stately oak the last remains, Or hardy fir, unperish'd with the rains:

Inclosed with stones, conspicuous from afar; And round, a circle for the wheeling car. -LRB-Some tomb perhaps of old, the dead to grace; Or then, as now, the limit of a race.-RRB-

Bear close to this, and warily proceed, A little bending to the left-hand steed; But urge the right, and give him (Yon) all the reins; While thy strict hand his (Yon) fellow's head restrains, And turns him (Yon) short; till, doubling as they roll, The wheel's round naves appear to brush the goal.

Clear of the stony heap direct the course; Lest through incaution failing, thou mayst be A joy to others, a reproach to me.

So shalt thou pass the goal, secure of mind, And leave unskilful swiftness far behind: Though thy fierce rival drove the matchless steed Which bore Adrastus, of celestial breed; Or the famed race, through all the regions known, That whirl'd the car of proud Laomedon.

Yet -LRB-not to break the car, or lame the horse-RRB- '' Thus -LRB-nought unsaid-RRB- the much-advising sage Concludes; then sat, stiff with unwieldy age.

Next bold Meriones was seen to rise, The last, but not least ardent for the prize. They mount their seats; the lots their place dispose -LRB-Roll'd in his (their) helmet, these Achilles throws-RRB-.

Young Nestor leads the race: Eumelus then; And next the brother of the king of men: Thy lot, Meriones, the fourth was cast; And, far the bravest, Diomed, was last.

They stand in order, an impatient train: Pelides points the barrier on the plain, And sends before old Phoenix to the place, To mark the racers, and to judge the race.

At once the coursers from the barrier bound; The lifted scourges all at once resound; Their heart, their eyes, their voice, they send before;

And up the champaign thunder from the shore: Thick, where they drive, the dusty clouds arise, And the lost courser in the whirlwind flies; Loose on their shoulders the long manes reclined, Float in their speed, and dance upon the wind:

The smoking chariots, rapid as they bound, Now seem to touch the sky, and now the ground. While hot for fame, and conquest all their care, -LRB-Each o'er his (manes) flying courser hung in air,-RRB-

Erect with ardour, poised upon the rein , They pant, they stretch, they shout along the plain. Now -LRB-the last compass fetch'd around the goal-RRB-

At the near prize each gathers all his (manes) soul, Each burns with double hope, with double pain, Tears up the shore, and thunders toward the main.

First flew Eumelus on Pheretian steeds; With those of Tros bold Diomed succeeds: Close on Eumelus' back they puff the wind, And seem just mounting on his (manes) car behind;

Then had he (manes) lost, or left a doubtful prize; But angry Phoebus to Tydides flies, Strikes from his (manes) hand the scourge, and renders vain His (manes) matchless horses' labour on the plain.

Full on his (manes) neck he (manes) feels the sultry breeze, And, hovering o'er, their stretching shadows sees. Rage fills his (manes) eye with anguish, to survey Snatch'd from his (manes) hope the glories of the day.

The fraud celestial Pallas sees with pain, Springs to her (their) knight, and gives the scourge again, And fills his (knight) steeds with vigour.

At a stroke She (their) breaks his (knight) rival's chariot from the yoke: No more their way the startled horses held; The car reversed came rattling on the field;

Shot headlong from his (knight) seat, beside the wheel, Prone on the dust the unhappy master fell; His (master) batter'd face and elbows strike the ground

; Nose, mouth, and front, one undistinguish'd wound: Grief stops his (master) voice, a torrent drowns his (master) eyes: Before him (master) far the glad Tydides flies; Minerva's spirit drives his (master) matchless pace, And crowns him (master) victor of the labour'd race.

The next, though distant, Menelaus succeeds; While thus young Nestor animates his (Nestor) steeds:

``Now, now, my generous pair, exert your force; Not that we hope to match Tydides' horse, Since great Minerva wings their rapid way, And gives their lord the honours of the day; But reach Atrides!

shall his (lord) mare outgo Your swiftness? vanquish'd by a female foe? Through your neglect, if lagging on the plain The last ignoble gift be all we gain,

No more shall Nestor's hand your food supply, The old man's fury rises, and ye die. Haste then: yon narrow road, before our sight, Presents the occasion, could we use it right.

'' (Nestor/Wise Nestor/Wise)

Thus he (man). The coursers at their master's threat With quicker steps the sounding champaign beat. And now Antilochus with nice survey Observes the compass of the hollow way. '

Twas where, by force of wintry torrents torn, Fast by the road a precipice was worn: Here, where but one could pass, to shun the throng The Spartan hero's chariot smoked along.

Close up the venturous youth resolves to keep, Still edging near, and bears him (hero) toward the steep. Atrides, trembling, casts his (hero) eye below, And wonders at the rashness of his (hero) foe.

'' Hold, stay your steeds-- What madness thus to ride This narrow way! take larger field -LRB-he (hero) cried-RRB-, Or both must fall.''--Atrides cried in vain; He (hero) flies more fast, and throws up all the rein.

Far as an able arm the disk can send, When youthful rivals their full force extend, So far, Antilochus! thy chariot flew Before the king: he (king), cautious, backward drew His (king) horse compell'd; foreboding in his (king) fears The rattling ruin of the clashing cars, The floundering coursers rolling on the plain, And conquest lost through frantic haste to gain.

But thus upbraids his (king) rival as he (king) flies:

``Go, furious youth! ungenerous and unwise! Go, but expect not I'll the prize resign; Add perjury to fraud, and make it thine--

Your rivals, destitute of youthful force, With fainting knees shall labour in the course, And yield the glory yours.'' (he)

--The steeds obey; Already at their heels they wing their way, And seem already to retrieve the day.

'' Then to his (king) steeds with all his (king) force he (king) cries, ``Be swift, be vigorous, and regain the prize! Meantime the Grecians in a ring beheld

them was the Cretan king; High on a rising ground, above the ring, The monarch sat: from whence with sure survey He (monarch) well observed the chief who led the way, And heard from far his (monarch) animating cries, And saw the foremost steed with sharpen'd eyes

The coursers bounding o'er the dusty field. The first who mark'd ; On whose broad front a blaze of shining white, Like the full moon, stood obvious to the sight.

He (monarch) saw; and rising, to the Greeks begun:

``Are yonder horse discern'd by me alone? Or can ye, all, another chief survey, And other steeds than lately led the way?

Those, though the swiftest, by some god withheld, Lie sure disabled in the middle field: For, since the goal they doubled, round the plain I search to find them, but I search in vain.

Perchance the reins forsook the driver's hand, And, turn'd too short, he (driver) tumbled on the strand, Shot from the chariot; while his (driver) coursers stray With frantic fury from the destined way.

Rise then some other, and inform my sight, For these dim eyes, perhaps, discern not right ; Yet sure he (driver) seems, to judge by shape and air, The great Ćtolian chief, renown'd in war.

Thy tongue too hastily confers the prize; Of those who view the course, nor sharpest eyed, Nor youngest, yet the readiest to decide.

Eumelus' steeds, high bounding in the chase, Still, as at first, unrivall'd lead the race: I well discern him (chief), as he (chief) shakes the rein, And hear his (chief) shouts victorious o'er the plain.

'' (the Greeks)

``Old man! -LRB-Oileus rashly thus replies-RRB- '' (he)
Thus he (chief). Idomeneus, incensed, rejoin'd:
``Barbarous of words! and arrogant of mind! Contentious prince, of all the Greeks beside The last in merit, as the first in pride!

To vile reproach what answer can we make? A goblet or a tripod let us stake, And be the king the judge.

The most unwise Will learn their rashness, when they pay the price. '' (He)

He (judge) said: and Ajax, by mad passion borne, Stern had replied; fierce scorn enhancing scorn To fell extremes.

But Thetis' godlike son Awful amidst them rose, and thus begun:

``Forbear, ye chiefs! reproachful to contend; Much would ye blame, should others thus offend: And lo!

the approaching steeds your contest end. '' (Thetis son)

No sooner had he (son) spoke, but thundering near, Drives, through a stream of dust, the charioteer.

His (son) car amidst the dusty whirlwind roll'd, Bright with the mingled blaze of tin and gold, Refulgent through the cloud: no eye could find The track his (son) flying wheels had left behind: And the fierce coursers urged their rapid pace

High o'er his (son) head the circling lash he (son) wields: His (son) bounding horses scarcely touch the fields: So swift, it seem'd a flight, and not a race.

Now victor at the goal Tydides stands, Quits his (victor) bright car, and springs upon the sands; From the hot steeds the sweaty torrents stream; The well-plied whip is hung athwart the beam: With joy brave Sthenelus receives the prize,

The tripod-vase, and dame with radiant eyes: These to the ships his (victor) train triumphant leads, The chief himself unyokes the panting steeds.

Young Nestor follows -LRB-who by art, not force, O'erpass'd Atrides-RRB- second in the course. Behind, Atrides urged the race, more near Than to the courser in his (Nestor) swift career

The following car, just touching with his (Nestor) heel And brushing with his (Nestor) tail the whirling wheel: Such, and so narrow now the space between The rivals, late so distant on the green

; So soon swift Ćthe her (Nestor) lost ground regain'd , One length, one moment, had the race obtain'd. Merion pursued, at greater distance still, With tardier coursers, and inferior skill.

Last came, Admetus! thy unhappy son; Slow dragged the steeds his (son) batter'd chariot on: Achilles saw, and pitying thus begun:

``Behold!

the man whose matchless art surpass'd The sons of Greece! the ablest, yet the last! Fortune denies, but justice bids us pay -LRB-Since great Tydides bears the first away-RRB-

To him (man) the second honours of the day. '' (Achilles)

The Greeks consent with loud-applauding cries, And then Eumelus had received the prize,

But youthful Nestor, jealous of his (Nestor) fame, The award opposes, and asserts his (Nestor) claim. ``Think not -LRB-he (Nestor) cries-RRB- I tamely will resign, O Peleus' son!

the mare so justly mine. What if the gods, the skilful to confound, Have thrown the horse and horseman to the ground?

Perhaps he (horseman) sought not heaven by sacrifice, And vows omitted forfeited the prize. If yet -LRB-distinction to thy friend to show, And please a soul desirous to bestow-RRB-

, view thy store Of beauteous handmaids, steeds, and shining ore; An ample present let him (friend) thence receive, And Greece shall praise thy generous thirst to give.

Some gift must grace Eumelus But this my prize I never shall forego; This, who but touches, warriors! is my foe.

Thus spake the youth; nor did his (foe) words offend; Pleased with the well-turn'd flattery of a friend, Achilles smiled:

``The gift proposed -LRB-he (Achilles) cried-RRB-, Antilochus!

'' (Achilles)

we shall ourself provide. With plates of brass the corslet cover'd o'er, -LRB-The same renown'd Asteropaeus wore,-RRB- Whose glittering margins raised with silver shine, -LRB-No vulgar gift,-RRB- Eumelus! shall be thine.

, his (Achilles) bosom glows With generous joy: then Menelaus rose; The herald placed the sceptre in his (Menelaus) hands, And still'd the clamour of the shouting bands.

Not without cause incensed at Nestor's son, And inly grieving, thus the king begun:

``The praise of wisdom, in thy youth obtain'd, An act so rash, Antilochus! has stain'd.

'' (the king)

He (king) said: Automedon at his (king) command The corslet brought, and gave it to his (king) hand. Distinguish'd by his (king) friend Robb'd of my glory and my just reward, To you, O Grecians!

be my wrong declared: So not a leader shall our conduct blame, Or judge me envious of a rival's fame. But shall not we, ourselves, the truth maintain?

What needs appealing in a fact so plain? What Greek shall blame me, if I bid thee rise, And vindicate by oath th' ill-gotten prize?

Rise if thou darest, before thy chariot stand, The driving scourge high-lifted in thy hand; And touch thy steeds, and swear thy whole intent Was but to conquer, not to circumvent.

The prudent chief with calm attention heard; Then mildly thus:

``Excuse, if youth have err'd; Superior as thou art, forgive the offence,

Swear by that god whose liquid arms surround The globe, and whose dread earthquakes heave the ground! '' (The chief)

Nor I thy equal, or in years, or sense.

Thou know`st the errors of unripen'd age, Weak are its counsels, headlong is its rage. The prize I quit, if thou thy wrath resign; The mare, or aught thou ask`st, be freely thine Ere

I become -LRB-from thy dear friendship torn-RRB- Hateful to thee, and to the gods forsworn. '' So spoke Antilochus; and at the word The mare contested to the king restored.

Joy swells his (king) soul: as when the vernal grain Lifts the green ear above the springing plain, The fields their vegetable life renew, And laugh and glitter with the morning dew; Such joy the Spartan's shining face o'erspread, And lifted his (king) gay heart, while thus he (king) said:

``Still may our souls, O generous youth!

agree 'Tis now Atrides' turn to yield to thee. Rash heat perhaps a moment might control, Not break, the settled temper of thy soul.

Not but -LRB-my friend-RRB- 'tis still the wiser way To waive contention with superior sway; For ah! how few, who should like thee offend, Like thee, have talents to regain the friend!

To plead indulgence, and thy fault atone, Suffice thy father's merit and thy own: Generous alike, for me, the sire and son Have greatly suffer'd, and have greatly done.

He (sire) said; and pleased his (sire) passion to command, Resign'd the courser to Noemon's hand, Friend of the youthful chief: himself content,

I yield; that all may know, my soul can bend, Nor is my pride preferr'd before my friend. '' (he)

The shining charger to his (friend) vessel sent.

The golden talents Merion next obtain'd ; The fifth reward, the double bowl, remain'd. Achilles this to reverend Nestor bears. And thus the purpose of his (Nestor) gift declares:

``Accept thou this, O sacred sire! -LRB-he (Nestor) said-RRB- In dear memorial of Patroclus dead; Dead and for ever lost Patroclus lies, For ever snatch'd from our desiring eyes!

Take thou this token of a grateful heart, Though 'tis not thine to hurl the distant dart, The quoit to toss, the ponderous mace to wield, Or urge the race, or wrestle on the field:

He (Nestor) said, and placed the goblet at his (Nestor) side; With joy the venerable king replied:

``Wisely and well, my son, thy words have proved

Thy pristine vigour age has overthrown, But left the glory of the past thy own. '' (the king)

A senior honour'd, and a friend beloved!

Too true it is, deserted of my strength, These wither'd arms and limbs have fail'd at length. Oh! had I now

that force I felt of yore, Known through Buprasium and the Pylian shore! Victorious then in every solemn game, Ordain'd to Amarynces' mighty name; The brave Epeians gave my glory way

, Ćtolians, Pylians, all resign'd the day. I quell'd Clytomedes in fights of hand, And backward hurl'd Ancaeus on the sand, Surpass'd Iphyclus in the swift career, Phyleus and Polydorus with the spear.

For the famed twins, impatient to survey Prize after prize by Nestor borne away, Sprung to their car; and with united pains

The sons of Actor won the prize of horse, But won by numbers, not by art or force: One lash'd the coursers, while one ruled the reins.

Such once I was! Now to these tasks succeeds A younger race , that emulate our deeds: I yield, alas! -LRB-to age who must not yield?-RRB-

Though once the foremost hero of the field. Go thou, my son! by generous friendship led, With martial honours decorate the dead: While pleased I take the gift thy hands present,

-LRB-Pledge of benevolence, and kind intent,-RRB- Rejoiced, of all the numerous Greeks, to see Not one but honours sacred age and me:

Those due distinctions thou so well canst pay, May the just gods return another day!'' Proud of the gift, thus spake the full of days: Achilles heard him (Achilles), prouder of the praise.

A stately mule, as yet by toils unbroke, Of six years' age, unconscious of the yoke, Is to the circus led, and firmly bound; Next stands a goblet, massy, large, and round.

``Let Greece excite Two heroes equal to this hardy fight; Who dare the foe with lifted arms provoke, And rush beneath the long-descending stroke.

The prizes next are order'd to the field, For the bold champions who the caestus wield. Achilles rising, thus: On whom Apollo shall the palm bestow, And whom the Greeks supreme by conquest know

, This mule his (Achilles) dauntless labours shall repay, The vanquish'd bear the massy bowl away. '' (unknown)

This dreadful combat great Epeus chose;-LRB-291-RRB-

High o'er the crowd, enormous bulk! he (Achilles) rose, And seized the beast, and thus began to say:

``Stand forth some man, to bear the bowl away!

-LRB-Price of his (man) ruin: for who dares deny This mule my right; the undoubted victor I-RRB- Others, 'tis own'd, in fields of battle shine,

Then let my foe Draw near, but first his (foe) certain fortune know; Secure this hand shall his (foe) whole frame confound, Mash all his (foe) bones, and all his (foe) body pound:

But the first honours of this fight are mine; For who excels in all? So let his (foe) friends be nigh, a needful train,

To heave the batter'd carcase off the plain. '' (he)

The giant spoke; and in a stupid gaze The host beheld him (foe), silent with amaze! '

Twas thou, Euryalus! who durst aspire To meet his (foe) might, and emulate thy sire, The great Mecistheus; who in days of yore

Him (foe) great Tydides urges to contend, Warm with the hopes of conquest for his (foe) friend; Officious with the cincture girds him (foe) round; And to his (foe) wrist the gloves of death are bound.

Amid the circle now each champion stands, And poises high in air his (champion) iron hands; With clashing gauntlets now they fiercely close

In Theban games the noblest trophy bore, -LRB-The games ordain'd dead OEdipus to grace,-RRB- And singly vanquish the Cadmean race. , Their crackling jaws re-echo to the blows, And painful sweat from all their members flows.

At length Epeus dealt a weighty blow Full on the cheek of his (champion) unwary foe; Beneath that ponderous arm's resistless sway Down

As a large fish, when winds and waters roar, By some huge billow dash'd against the shore, Lies panting; not less batter'd with his (batter) wound, The bleeding hero pants upon the ground.

To rear his (batter) fallen foe, the victor lends, Scornful, his (batter) hand; and gives him (batter) to his (batter) friends; Whose arms support him (batter), reeling through the throng, And dragging his (batter) disabled legs along; Nodding, his (batter) head hangs down his (batter) shoulder o'er; His (batter) mouth and nostrils pour the clotted gore;-LRB-292-RRB- Wrapp'd round in mists he (batter) lies, and lost to thought; His (batter) friends receive the bowl, too dearly bought.

dropp'd he (batter), nerveless, and extended lay. The third bold game Achilles next demands, And calls the wrestlers to the level sands:

A massy tripod for the victor lies, Of twice six oxen its reputed price; And next, the loser's spirits to restore, A female captive, valued but at four.

Scarce did the chief the vigorous strife prop When tower-like Ajax and Ulysses rose. Amid the ring each nervous rival stands, Embracing rigid with implicit hands.

Below, their planted feet at distance fix'd; Like two strong rafters which the builder forms, Proof to the wintry winds and howling storms, Their tops connected, but at wider space Fix'd on the centre stands their solid base.

Now to the grasp each manly body bends; The humid sweat from every pore descends; Their bones resound with blows: sides, shoulders, thighs Swell to each gripe, and bloody tumours rise.

Nor could Ulysses, for his (Ulysses) art renown'd, O'erturn the strength of Ajax on the ground; Nor could the strength of Ajax overthrow The watchful caution of his (Ulysses) artful foe.

Close lock'd above, their heads and arms are mix'd: While the long strife even tired the lookers on, Thus to Ulysses spoke great Telamon:

``Or let me lift thee, chief, or lift thou me : Prove we our force, and Jove the rest decree. '' (the lookers)

He (chief) said; and, straining, heaved him (chief) off the ground With matchless strength; that time Ulysses found The strength to evade, and where the nerves combine His (chief) ankle struck: the giant fell supine; Ulysses, following, on his (Ulysses) bosom lies; Shouts of applause run rattling through the skies.

Ajax to lift Ulysses next essays; He (Ulysses) barely stirr'd him (Ulysses), but he (Ulysses) could not raise: His (Ulysses) knee lock'd fast, the foe's attempt denied; And grappling close, they tumbled side by side.

Defiled with honourable dust they roll, Still breathing strife, and unsubdued of soul: Again they rage, again to combat rise; When great Achilles thus divides the prize:

``Your noble vigour, O my friends, restrain; Nor weary out your generous strength in vain.

Ye both have won: let others who excel, Now prove that prowess you have proved so well. '' (Achilles)

The hero's words the willing chiefs obey, From their tired bodies

The youths contending in the rapid race: A silver urn that full six measures held, By none in weight or workmanship excell'd: Sidonian artists taught the frame to shine, Elaborate, with artifice divine; Whence Tyrian sailors did the prize transport, And gave to Thoas at the Lemnian port: From him (hero) descended

wipe the dust away, And, clothed anew, the following games survey. And now succeed the gifts ordain'd to grace , good Eunaeus heir'd

The glorious gift; and, for Lycaon spared, To brave Patroclus gave the rich reward: Now, the same hero's funeral rites to grace, It stands the prize of swiftness in the race.

A well-fed ox was for the second placed; And half a talent must content the last. Achilles rising then bespoke the train:

The hero said, and starting from his (hero) place, Oilean Ajax rises to the race; Ulysses next; and he (Ulysses) whose speed surpass'd His (Ulysses) youthful equals, Nestor's son, the last.

Ranged in a line the ready racers stand; Pelides points the barrier with his (Ulysses) hand; All start at once; Oileus led the race; The next Ulysses, measuring pace with pace; Behind him (Ulysses), diligently close, he (Ulysses) sped, As closely following as the running thread

``Who hope the palm of swiftness to obtain, Stand forth, and bear these prizes from the plain. '' (he)
The spindle follows, and displays the charms Of the fair spinster's breast and moving arms:

Graceful in motion thus, his (Ulysses) foe he (Ulysses) plies, And treads each footstep ere the dust can rise; His (Ulysses) glowing breath upon his (Ulysses) shoulders plays

: The admiring Greeks loud acclamations raise: To him (Ulysses) they give their wishes, hearts, and eyes, And send their souls before him (Ulysses) as he (Ulysses) flies.

Now three times turn'd in prospect of the goal, The panting chief to Pallas lifts his (chief) soul:

``Assist, O goddess!'' (Pallas)
thus in thought he (chief) pray'd!

And present at his (chief) thought descends the maid. Buoy'd by her (maid) heavenly force, he (chief) seems to swim, And feels a pinion lifting every limb.

All fierce, and ready now the prize to gain, Unhappy Ajax stumbles on the plain -LRB-O'erturn'd by Pallas-RRB-, where the slippery shore Was clogg'd with slimy dung and mingled gore.

-LRB-The self-same place beside Patroclus' pyre, Where late the slaughter'd victims fed the fire.-RRB- Besmear'd with filth, and blotted o'er with clay,

Obscene to sight, the rueful racer lay; The well-fed bull -LRB-the second prize-RRB- he (racer) shared, And left the urn Ulysses' rich reward.

Then, grasping by the horn the mighty beast, The baffled hero thus the Greeks address'd: ``Accursed fate! the conquest I forego; A mortal I

, a goddess was my foe; She (goddess) urged her (goddess) favourite on the rapid way, And Pallas, not Ulysses, won the day.

Antilochus, more humorous than the rest, Takes the last prize, and takes it with a jest:

``Why with our wiser elders should we strive?

'' (Antilochus)

Thus sourly wail'd he (Ulysses), sputtering dirt and gore; A burst of laughter echoed through the shore. The gods still love them, and they always thrive.

Ye see, to Ajax I must yield the prize: He (Ulysses) to Ulysses, still more aged and wise; -LRB-A green old age unconscious of decays, That proves the hero born in better days!-RRB-

Behold his (hero) vigour in this active race! Achilles only boasts a swifter pace: For who can match Achilles? He (Achilles) who can, Must yet be more than hero, more than man.

'' The effect succeeds the speech. Pelides cries,

``Thy artful praise deserves a better prize. Nor Greece in vain shall hear thy friend extoll'd;

Receive a talent of the purest gold. '' (The youth)

The youth departs content. The host admire The son of Nestor, worthy of his (Nestor) sire.

Next these a buckler, spear, and helm , he (Nestor) brings; Cast on the plain, the brazen burden rings: Arms which of late divine Sarpedon wore, And great Patroclus in short triumph bore.

Whoever dares deserve so rich a prize, Now grace the lists before our army's sight, And sheathed in steel, provoke his (Nestor) foe to fight.

Who first the jointed armour shall explore, And stain his (Nestor) rival's mail with issuing gore, The sword Asteropaeus possess'd of old, -LRB-A Thracian blade, distinct with studs of gold,-RRB-

Shall pay the stroke, and grace the striker's side: These arms in common let the chiefs divide: For each brave champion, when the combat ends, A sumptuous banquet at our tents attends.

'' Stand forth the bravest of our host! -LRB-he (champion) cries-RRB- '' Fierce at the word uprose great Tydeus' son, And the huge bulk of Ajax Telamon.

Clad in refulgent steel, on either hand, The dreadful chiefs amid the circle stand; Louring they meet, tremendous to the sight; Each Argive bosom beats with fierce delight.

Opposed in arms not long they idly stood, But thrice they closed, and thrice the charge renew'd. A furious pass the spear of Ajax made Through the broad shield, but at the corslet stay'd.

Not thus the foe: his (foe) javelin aim'd above The buckler's margin, at the neck he (foe) drove. But Greece, now trembling for her (foe) hero's life, Bade share the honours, and surcease the strife.

Then hurl'd the hero, thundering on the ground, A mass of iron -LRB-an enormous round-RRB-, Whose weight and size the circling Greeks admire, Rude from the furnace, and but shaped by fire.

This mighty quoit Aetion wont to rear, And from his (Rude) whirling arm dismiss in air; The giant by Achilles slain, he (Achilles) stow'd

Yet still the victor's due Tydides gains, With him (Achilles) the sword and studded belt remains. Among his (Achilles) spoils this memorable load.

For this, he (Achilles) bids those nervous artists vie, That teach the disk to sound along the sky.

``Let him (Achilles), whose might can hurl this bowl, arise;

Who farthest hurls it, take it as his (Achilles) prize; If he (Achilles) be one enrich'd with large domain Of downs for flocks, and arable for grain, Small stock of iron needs that man provide; His (man) hinds and swains whole years shall be supplied From hence; nor ask the neighbouring city's aid For ploughshares, wheels, and all the rural trade.

'' (Stern)

Stern Polypoetes stepp'd before the throng, And great Leonteus, more than mortal strong; Whose force with rival forces to oppose,

Uprose great Ajax; up Epeus rose. Each stood in order: first Epeus threw; High o'er the wondering crowds the whirling circle flew.

Leonteus next a little space surpass'd; And third, the strength of godlike Ajax cast. O'er both their marks it flew; till fiercely flung From Polypoetes' arm the discus sung:

Far as a swain his (swain) whirling sheephook throws, That distant falls among the grazing cows, So past them all the rapid circle flies:

Those, who in skilful archery contend, He (swain) next invites the twanging bow to bend; And twice ten axes casts amidst the round, Ten double-edged, and ten that singly wound

The mast, which late a first-rate galley bore, The hero fixes in the sandy shore; To the tall top a milk-white dove they tie, The trembling mark at which their arrows fly.

His (hero) friends, while loud applauses shake the skies, With force conjoin'd heave off the weighty prize. '' Whose weapon strikes yon fluttering bird, shall bear These two-edged axes, terrible in war;

He (hero) said: experienced Merion took the word; And skilful Teucer: in the helm they threw Their lots inscribed, and forth the latter flew.

The single, he (hero) whose shaft divides the cord. '' Swift from the string the sounding arrow flies; But flies unbless'd! No grateful sacrifice, No firstling lambs, unheedful!

turn'd aside, Err'd from the dove, yet cut the cord that tied: Adown the mainmast fell the parted string, And the free bird to heaven displays her (hero) wing:

Sea, shores, and skies, with loud applause resound, And Merion eager meditates the wound: He (Swift) takes the bow, directs the shaft above, And following with his (Swift) eye the soaring dove, Implores the god to speed it through the skies, With vows of firstling lambs, and grateful sacrific

The dove, in airy circles as she (hero) wheels, Amid the clouds the piercing arrow feels; Quite through and through the point its passage found, And at his (Swift) feet fell bloody to the ground.

didst thou vow To Phoebus, patron of the shaft and bow. For this, thy well-aim'd arrow The wounded bird, ere yet

she (hero) breathed her (hero) last, With flagging wings alighted on the mast, A moment hung, and spread her (hero) pinions there, Then sudden dropp'd, and left her (hero) life in air.

From the pleased crowd new peals of thunder rise, And to the ships brave Merion bears the prize. To close the funeral games, Achilles last A massy spear amid the circle placed, And ample charger of unsullied frame,

With flowers high-wrought, not blacken'd yet by flame. For these he (Achilles) bids the heroes prove their art , Whose dexterous skill directs the flying dart.

With joy Pelides saw the honour paid, Rose to the monarch, and respectful said:

``Thee first in virtue, as in power supreme, O king of nations!

Here too great Merion hopes the noble prize; Nor here disdain'd the king of men to rise. all thy Greeks proclaim

; In every martial game thy worth attest, And know thee both their greatest and their best. Take then the prize, but let brave Merion bear This beamy javelin in thy brother's war.

'' (the monarch)

Pleased from the hero's lips his (hero) praise to hear, The king to Merion gives the brazen spear: But, set apart for sacred use, commands The glittering charger to Talthybius' hands.

-LSB-Illustration: CERES.-RSB- CERES. BOOK XXIV. ARGUMENT. THE REDEMPTION OF THE BODY OF HECTOR. The gods deliberate about the redemption of Hector's body.

Jupiter sends Thetis to Achilles, to dispose him (Achilles) for the restoring it, and Iris to Priam, to encourage him (Achilles) to go in person and treat for it.

The old king, notwithstanding the remonstrances of his (king) queen, makes ready for the journey, to which he (king) is encouraged by an omen from Jupiter.

He (king) sets forth in his (king) chariot, with a waggon loaded with presents, under the charge of Idaeus the herald. Mercury descends in the shape of a young man, and conducts him (man) to the pavilion of Achilles.

Priam finds Achilles at his (Achilles) table, casts himself at his (Achilles) feet, and begs for the body of his (Achilles) son: Achilles, moved with compassion, grants his (Achilles) request, detains him (Achilles) one night in his (Achilles) tent, and the next morning sends him (Achilles) home with the body: the Trojans run out to meet him (Achilles).

The time of twelve days is employed in this book, while the body of Hector lies in the tent of Achilles; and as many more are spent in the truce allowed for his (Achilles) interment.

Their conversation on the way. The lamentations of Andromache, Hecuba, and Helen, with the solemnities of the funeral. The scene is partly in Achilles' camp, and partly in Troy.

Now from the finish'd games the Grecian band Seek their black ships, and clear the crowded strand, All stretch'd at ease the genial banquet share, And pleasing slumbers quiet all their care.

he (Achilles), to grief resign'd, His (Achilles) friend's dear image present to his (Achilles) mind, Takes his (Achilles) sad couch, more unobserved to weep; Nor tastes the gifts of all-composing sleep.

The form so pleasing, and the heart so kind, That youthful vigour, and that manly mind, What toils they shared, what martial works they wrought, What seas they measured, and what fields they fought;

Not so Achilles: Restless he (Achilles) roll'd around his (Achilles) weary bed, And all his (Achilles) soul on his (Achilles) Patroclus fed: All pass'd before him (Achilles) in remembrance dear, Thought follows thought, and tear succeeds to tear.

And now supine, now prone, the hero lay, Now shifts his (hero) side, impatient for the day: Then starting up, disconsolate he (hero) goes Wide on the lonely beach to vent his (hero) woes.

There as the solitary mourner raves, The ruddy morning rises o'er the waves: Soon as it rose, his (hero) furious steeds he (hero) join'd!

The chariot flies, and Hector trails behind. And thrice, Patroclus! round thy monument Was Hector dragg'd, then hurried to the tent.

While foul in dust the unhonour'd carcase lies, But not deserted by the pitying skies: For Phoebus watch'd it with superior care, Preserved from gaping wounds and tainting air;

There sleep at last o'ercomes the hero's eyes; And, ignominious as it swept the field, Spread o'er the sacred corse his (hero) golden shield.

But Neptune this, and Pallas this denies, And th' unrelenting empress of the skies, E'er since that day implacable to Troy, What time young Paris, simple shepherd boy, Won by destructive lust -LRB-reward obscene-RRB-

All heaven was moved, and Hermes will'd to go By stealth to snatch him (boy) from the insulting foe: , Their charms rejected for the Cyprian queen.

But when the tenth celestial morning broke, To heaven assembled, thus Apollo spoke: -LSB-Illustration: HECTOR'S BODY AT THE CAR OF ACHILLES.-RSB-

HECTOR'S BODY AT THE CAR OF ACHILLES. '' Unpitying powers! how oft each holy fane Has Hector tinged with blood of victims slain?

And can ye still his (Hector) cold remains pursue? Still grudge his (Hector) body to the Trojans' view? Deny to consort, mother, son, and sire, The last sad honours of a funeral fire?

Is then the dire Achilles all your care? That iron heart, inflexibly severe; A lion, not a man, who slaughters wide,

In strength of rage, and impotence of pride; Who hastes to murder with a savage joy, Invades around, and breathes but to destroy!

Still for one loss he (man) rages unresign'd, Repugnant to the lot of all mankind; To lose a friend, a brother, or a son, Heaven dooms each mortal, and its will is done:

Shame is not of his (son) soul; nor understood, The greatest evil and the greatest good. Awhile they sorrow, then dismiss their care; Fate gives the wound, and man is born to bear.

But this insatiate, the commission given By fate exceeds, and tempts the wrath of heaven: Lo, how his (man) rage dishonest drags along Hector's dead earth, insensible of wrong!

Brave though he (Hector) be, yet by no reason awed, He (Hector) violates the laws of man and god. '' -LSB-Illustration: THE JUDGMENT OF PARIS.-RSB-

THE JUDGMENT OF PARIS. '' If equal honours by the partial skies Are doom'd both heroes, -LRB-Juno thus replies,-RRB- If Thetis' son must no distinction know, Then hear, ye gods!

But Hector only boasts a mortal claim, His (Hector) birth deriving from a mortal dame: Achilles, of your own ethereal race, Springs from a goddess by a man's embrace -LRB-A goddess by ourself to Peleus given, A man divine, and chosen friend of heaven-RRB-

To grace those nuptials, from the bright abode Yourselves were present; where this minstrel-god, Well pleased to share the feast, amid the quire Stood proud to hymn, and tune his (friend) youthful lyre.

the patron of the bow. '' Then thus the Thunderer checks the imperial dame:

``Let not thy wrath the court of heaven inflame; Their merits, nor their honours, are the same.

But mine, and every god's peculiar grace Hector deserves, of all the Trojan race: Still on our shrines his (Hector) grateful offerings lay, -LRB-The only honours men to gods can pay,-RRB-

Nor ever from our smoking altar ceased The pure libation, and the holy feast: Howe'er by stealth to snatch the corse away

But haste, and summon to our courts above The azure queen; let her (queen) persuasion move Her (queen) furious son from Priam to receive The proffer'd ransom, and the corse to leave.

He (son) added not: and Iris from the skies, Swift as a whirlwind, on the message flies, Meteorous the face of ocean sweeps, Refulgent gliding o'er the sable deeps.

, We will not: Thetis guards it night and day. '' (the dame wrath)

Between where Samos wide his (son) forests spreads, And rocky Imbrus lifts its pointed heads,

As bearing death in the fallacious bait, From the bent angle sinks the leaden weight; So pass'd the goddess through the closing wave,

Down plunged the maid; -LRB-the parted waves resound;-RRB- She (goddess) plunged and instant shot the dark profound. Where Thetis sorrow'd in her (goddess) secret cave: There placed amidst her (goddess) melancholy train -LRB-The blue-hair'd sisters of the sacred main-RRB-

Pensive she (goddess) sat, revolving fates to come, And wept her (goddess) godlike son's approaching doom. Then thus the goddess of the painted bow:

``Arise, O Thetis! from thy seats below, 'Tis Jove that calls.'' (the goddess Thetis)
--
``And why -LRB-the dame replies-RRB- Calls Jove his (son) Thetis to the hated skies?

Sad object as I am for heavenly sight! Ah may my sorrows ever shun the light! Howe'er, be heaven's almighty sire

obey'd--'' (She)

She (goddess) spake, and veil'd her (goddess) head in sable shade, Which, flowing long, her (goddess) graceful person clad; And forth she (goddess) paced, majestically sad.

Then through the world of waters they repair -LRB-The way fair Iris led-RRB- to upper air. The deeps dividing, o'er the coast they rise, And touch with momentary flight the skies.

There in the lightning's blaze the sire they found, And all the gods in shining synod round. Thetis approach'd with anguish in her (Iris) face,

Even Juno sought her (Iris) sorrows to console, And offer'd from her (Iris) hand the nectar-bowl: She (Iris) tasted, and resign'd it: then began The sacred sire of gods and mortal man: ``Thou comest, fair Thetis, but with grief o'ercast; Maternal sorrows; long, ah, long to last!

-LRB-Minerva rising, gave the mourner place,-RRB- Suffice, we know and we partake thy cares; But yield to fate, and hear what Jove declares Nine days are past since all the court above

In Hector's cause have moved the ear of Jove; 'Twas voted, Hermes from his (Hector) godlike foe By stealth should bear him (Hector), but we will'd not so

: We will, thy son himself the corse restore, And to his (son) conquest add this glory more. Then hie thee to him (son), and our mandate bear

: Tell him (son) he (son) tempts the wrath of heaven too far; Nor let him (son) more -LRB-our anger if he (son) dread-RRB- Vent his (son) mad vengeance on the sacred dead; But yield to ransom and the father's prayer

; The mournful father, Iris shall prepare With gifts to sue; and offer to his (father) hands Whate'er his (father) honour asks, or heart demands.

Arrived, she (Iris) heard the voice of loud lament, And echoing groans that shook the lofty tent: His (father) friends prepare the victim, and dispose Repast unheeded, while he (father) vents his (father) woes; The goddess seats her (goddess) by her (goddess) pensive son, She (goddess) press'd his (father) hand, and tender thus begun:

``How long, unhappy!

'' (She)

His (father) word the silver-footed queen attends, And from Olympus' snowy tops descends. shall thy sorrows flow, And thy heart waste with life-consuming woe:

Mindless of food, or love, whose pleasing reign Soothes weary life, and softens human pain? O snatch the moments yet within thy power; Not long to live, indulge the amorous hour!

Lo! Jove himself -LRB-for Jove's command I bear-RRB- Forbids to tempt the wrath of heaven too far. No longer then -LRB-his (father) fury if thou dread-RRB-

Detain the relics of great Hector dead; Nor vent on senseless earth thy vengeance vain, But yield to ransom, and restore the slain.

'' To whom Achilles:

``Be the ransom given, And we submit, since such the will of heaven. '' (Achilles)
While thus they communed, from the Olympian bowers Jove orders Iris to the Trojan towers:

Alone the Ilian ramparts let him (Achilles) leave, And bear what stern Achilles may receive: Alone, for so we will; no Trojan near Except, to place the dead with decent care,

``Haste, winged goddess! to the sacred town, And urge her (goddess) monarch to redeem his (monarch) son. Some aged herald, who with gentle hand May the slow mules and funeral car command.

Nor let him (monarch) death, nor let him (monarch) danger dread, Safe through the foe by our protection led: Him (monarch) Hermes to Achilles shall convey, Guard of his (Achilles) life, and partner of his (Achilles) way.

Fierce as he (Achilles) is, Achilles' self shall spare His (Achilles) age, nor touch one venerable hair: Some thought there must be in a soul so brave,

Some sense of duty, some desire to save. '' (Achilles)

-LSB-Illustration: IRIS ADVISES PRIAM TO OBTAIN THE BODY OF HECTOR.-RSB- IRIS ADVISES PRIAM

TO OBTAIN THE BODY OF HECTOR. Then down her (IRIS) bow the winged Iris drives, And swift at Priam's mournful court arrives: Where the sad sons beside their father's throne Sat bathed in tears, and answer'd groan with groan.

And all amidst them lay the hoary sire, -LRB-Sad scene of woe!-RRB- his (sire) face his (sire) wrapp'd attire Conceal'd from sight; with frantic hands he (sire) spread A shower of

From room to room his (sire) pensive daughters roam; Whose shrieks and clamours fill the vaulted dome; Mindful of those, who late their pride and joy, Lie pale and breathless round the fields of Troy!

ashes o'er his (sire) neck and head. Before the king Jove's messenger appears, And thus in whispers greets his (sire) trembling ears:

``Fear not, O father!

; From Jove I come, Jove makes thee still his (sire) care; For Hector's sake these walls he (sire) bids thee leave, And bear what stern Achilles may receive; Alone, for so he (Achilles) wills; no Trojan near, Except, to place the dead with decent care,

no ill news I bear Some aged herald, who with gentle hand May the slow mules and funeral car command. Nor shalt thou death, nor shall thou danger dread:

Safe through the foe by his (foe) protection led: Thee Hermes to Pelides shall convey, Guard of thy life, and partner of thy way.

Fierce as he (foe) is, Achilles' self shall spare Thy age, nor touch one venerable hair; Some thought there must be in a soul so brave, Some sense of duty, some desire to save.

'' (Jove messenger father)

She (foe) spoke, and vanish'd. Priam bids prepare His (foe) gentle mules and harness to the car; There, for the gifts, a polish'd casket lay:

And where the treasures of his (foe) empire lay; Then call'd his (foe) queen, and thus began to say:

``Unhappy consort of a king distress'd!

His (foe) pious sons the king's command obey. Then pass'd the monarch to his (monarch) bridal-room, Where cedar-beams the lofty roofs perfume, Partake the troubles of thy husband's breast

: I saw descend the messenger of Jove, Who bids me try Achilles' mind to move; Forsake these ramparts, and with gifts obtain The corse of Hector, at yon navy slain.

Tell me thy thought: my heart impels to go Through hostile camps, and bears me to the foe. '' (queen consort)

The hoary monarch thus.

Her (husband) piercing cries Sad Hecuba renews, and then replies:

``Ah! whither wanders thy distemper'd mind? And where the prudence now that awed mankind?

Through Phrygia once and foreign regions known; Now all confused, distracted, overthrown! Singly to pass through hosts of foes! to face -LRB-O heart of steel!-RRB-

the murderer of thy race! To view that deathful eye, and wander o'er Those hands yet red with Hector's noble gore!

Alas! my lord! he (Hector) knows not how to spare. And what his (Hector) mercy, thy slain sons declare; So brave! so many fallen!

To claim his (Hector) rage Vain were thy dignity, and vain thy age. No--pent in this sad palace, let us give To grief the wretched days we have to live.

Still, still for Hector let our sorrows flow, Born to his (Hector) own, and to his (Hector) parents' woe! Doom'd from the hour his (Hector) luckless life begun,

To dogs, to vultures, and to Peleus' son! Oh! in his (son) dearest blood might I allay My rage, and these barbarities repay!

For ah! could Hector merit thus, whose breath Expired not meanly, in unactive death? He (Hector) poured his (Hector) latest blood in manly fight, And fell a hero in his (Hector) country's right.'' (unknown)

``Seek not to stay me, nor my soul affright With words of omen, like a bird of night, -LRB-Replied unmoved the venerable man;-RRB- '

Tis heaven commands me, and you urge in vain. Had any mortal voice the injunction laid, Nor augur, priest, nor seer, had been obey'd.

A present goddess brought the high command , I saw, I heard her (goddess), and the word shall stand. I go, ye gods!

obedient to your call: If in yon camp your powers have doom'd my fall, Content-- By the same hand let me expire!

Add to the slaughter'd son the wretched sire! One cold embrace at least may be allow'd, And my last tears flow mingled with his (sire) blood!'' (he)

From forth his (sire) open'd stores, this said, he (sire) drew Twelve costly carpets of refulgent hue, As many vests, as many mantles told, And twelve fair veils, and garments stiff with gold,

With ten pure talents from the richest mine; And last a large well-labour'd bowl had place, -LRB-The pledge of treaties once with friendly Thrace:-RRB- Seem'd all too mean the stores he (sire) could employ, For one last look to buy him (sire) back to Troy!

Two tripods next, and twice two chargers shine, Lo! the sad father, frantic with his (father) pain, Around him (father) furious drives his (father) menial train

: In vain each slave with duteous care attends, Each office hurts him (father), and each face offends. '' What make ye here, officious crowds!

-LRB-he (father) cries-RRB-. Hence! nor obtrude your anguish on my eyes. Have ye no griefs at home, to fix ye there: Am I the only object of despair?

No, you must feel him (father) too; yourselves must fall; The same stern god to ruin gives you all: Nor is great Hector lost by me alone; Your sole defence, your guardian power is gone!

Am I become my people's common show, Set up by Jove your spectacle of woe? I see your blood the fields of Phrygia drown, I see the ruins of your smoking town!

O send me, gods! ere that sad day shall come, A willing ghost to Pluto's dreary dome!'' He (Hector) said, and feebly drives his (Hector) friends away:

Next on his (Hector) sons his (Hector) erring fury falls, Polites, Paris, Agathon, he (Hector) calls; His (Hector) threats Deiphobus and Dius hear, Hippothous, Pammon, Helenes the seer, And generous Antiphon: for yet these nine Survived, sad relics of his (Hector) numerous line.

The sorrowing friends his (Hector) frantic rage obey. '' Inglorious sons of an unhappy sire! Why did not all in Hector's cause expire?

Wretch that I am! my bravest offspring slain. You, the disgrace of Priam's house, remain! Mestor the brave, renown'd in ranks of war, With Troilus, dreadful on his (Hector) rushing car,-LRB-293-RRB-

All those relentless Mars untimely slew, And left me these, a soft and servile crew, Whose days the feast and wanton dance employ, Gluttons and flatterers, the contempt of Troy!

And last great Hector, more than man divine, For sure he (Hector) seem'd not of terrestrial line! Why teach ye not my rapid wheels to run, And speed my journey to redeem my son?''

High on the seat the cabinet they bind: The new-made car with solid beauty shined; Box was the yoke, emboss'd with costly pains, And hung with ringlets to receive the reins; Nine cubits long, the traces swept the ground:

The sons their father's wretched age revere, Forgive his (father) anger, and produce the car. These to the chariot's polish'd pole they bound.

Then fix'd a ring the running reins to guide, And close beneath the gather'd ends were tied. Next with the gifts -LRB-the price of Hector slain-RRB-

The sad attendants load the groaning wain: Last to the yoke the well-matched mules they bring, -LRB-The gift of Mysia to the Trojan king.-RRB-

But the fair horses, long his (king) darling care, Himself received, and harness'd to his (king) car: Grieved as he (king) was, he (king) not this task denied;

The hoary herald help'd him (king), at his (king) side. While careful these the gentle coursers join'd, Sad Hecuba approach'd with anxious mind;

A golden bowl that foam'd with fragrant wine, -LRB-Libation destined to the power divine,-RRB- Held in her (king) right, before the steed she (king) stands, And thus consigns it to the monarch's hands:

Since victor of thy fears, and slighting mine, Heaven, or thy soul, inspires this bold design; Pray to that god, who high on Ida's brow

``Take this, and pour to Jove; that safe from harms His (god) grace restore thee to our roof and arms. Surveys thy desolated realms below

, His (god) winged messenger to send from high, And lead thy way with heavenly augury: Let the strong sovereign of the plumy race Tower on the right of yon ethereal space.

That sign beheld, and strengthen'd from above, Boldly pursue the journey mark'd by Jove: But if the god his (god) augury denies, Suppress thy impulse, nor reject advice.

He (god) spoke, and bade the attendant handmaid bring The purest water of the living spring: -LRB-Her (thy) ready hands the ewer and bason held:-RRB-

Then took the golden cup his (god) queen had fill'd; On the mid pavement pours the rosy wine, Uplifts his (god) eyes, and calls the power divine:

``O first and greatest!

'' (queen)

'''Tis just -LRB-said Priam-RRB- to the sire above To raise our hands; for who so good as Jove? '' heaven's imperial lord!

On lofty Ida's holy hill adored! To stern Achilles now direct my ways, And teach him (Achilles) mercy when a father prays.

Let the strong sovereign of the plumy race Tower on the right of yon ethereal space; So shall thy suppliant, strengthen'd from above, Fearless pursue the journey mark'd by Jove.

If such thy will, despatch from yonder sky Thy sacred bird, celestial augury! '' Jove heard his (Achilles) prayer, and from the throne on high, Despatch'd his (Achilles) bird, celestial augury!

The swift-wing'd chaser of the feather'd game, And known to gods by Percnos' lofty name. Wide as appears some palace-gate display'd.

So broad, his (chaser) pinions stretch'd their ample shade, As stooping dexter with resounding wings The imperial bird descends in airy rings.

A dawn of joy in every face appears: The mourning matron dries her (matron) timorous tears: Swift on his (Swift) car the impatient monarch sprung

; The brazen portal in his (Swift) passage rung; The mules preceding draw the loaded wain, Charged with the gifts: Idaeus holds the rein: The king himself his (king) gentle steeds controls, And through surrounding friends the chariot rolls.

On his (king) slow wheels the following people wait, Mourn at each step, and give him (king) up to fate; With hands uplifted eye him (king) as he (king)

pass'd, And gaze upon him (king) as they gazed their last. Now forward fares the father on his (father) way, Through the lone fields, and back to Ilion they.

Great Jove beheld him (Great) as he (Great) cross'd the plain, And felt the woes of miserable man. Then thus to Hermes: ''

Thou whose constant cares Still succour mortals, and attend their prayers; Behold an object to thy charge consign'd: If ever pity touch'd thee for mankind, Go, guard the sire:

And mounts incumbent on the wings of winds, That high, through fields of air, his (sire) flight sustain, O'er the wide earth, and o'er the boundless main; Then grasps the wand that causes sleep to fly, Or in soft slumbers seals the wakeful eye:
